column2: While there is no question that LED lamps use a fraction of the energy to produce the same amount of light as a standard incandescent bulb, that is only half the story. If the energy used to create and dispose of the LED lamp is more than that for a comparable standard bulb, then all of the proclaimed energy savings to produce light are for naught.

MERINO--Rolando, M.D.,M.Ph., born in Chile on September 28, 1932, beloved husband to his wife of forty eight years, Carmen Montesinos M.D., adored father to Carmen Jr., Rolando Jr. and Gonzalo, and grandfather to seven grandchildren, died peacefully at home on August 8, 2009. As Chairman of Preventive Medicine at the University of Concepcion and Director of the Regional Clinical Hospital of Concepcion in Chile, he championed innovative preventive care for neighboring communities. As Associate Professor of Community Medicine at Mount Sinai School of Medicine from 1973 to 2004, he educated and motivated countless young doctors from around the world to care for under-served communities in their native countries. He was respected and admired as a progressive thinker and loved by people of all walks of life for his dignity, wit and humble spirit. He will be dearly missed forever and ever.

BOXER--Carole. Carole, your love, care, wisdom and integrity towards our family for over 40 years will live with us forever. Our hearts are filled with sadness for Sherman, Maddy, Nelson, Jeff, Lauren and your loving grandchildren. The Altheim Family

ARONSON--Marcia, age 98. Beloved wife of the late Jesse Aronson. Survived by sons Michael, Paul and daughter-in-law Linda, many nieces and nephews including Janice, Leo, Stephen and Sunny; her devoted friend Julia, her wonderful caregiver Leila, and the staff at 480 2nd Ave, all of whom made her last years happy and artistically rewarding. BAUML--Elsa, born Frankfurt a/m, April 3, 1915. Died peacefully in New York City August 8, 2009. Beloved mother, grandmother and great-grandmother.

RABIN--Florence. In celebration of a wonderful life that we were blessed to share. She is fondly remembered by family and friends. Her family includes her best friend and love of a lifetime, Judge Samuel Rabin; her children and their spouses, Jane and Russell Stern and Robert and Barbara Rabin; her grandchildren, Ben and Bill Rabin; and her great-grandchildren, Lexie, Sam, Benjo and Zachary. Dear Florence, you brought joy, laughter and inspiration to us all. We love you. Visiting Tuesday, 6pm-9pm at the Stern's home in Sands Point.

FILLER--Lenny, 74, August 4, 2009, died at home in New Vernon, NJ after a valiant battle with lymphoma. The fight was conducted with innate dignity and courage that defined his life until the very end. By any measure he was a successful man, but never more than in the relationship with his family whose love and respect he valued above all else. He died surrounded by wife Marion, children Joyce and Billy and their spouses, seven grandchildren, and brothers Robert and Wally and their families. He is at peace and safe in our hearts forever. Donations to Morristown Memorial Health Foundation at www.MMHF.org.

POPKIN--Joel. The partners and staff of Joel Popkin & Company, P.C. mourn the passing of our co-founder and dear friend, Joel Popkin. Memorial service, August 9 at 3pm, Gutterman Funeral Home, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury; graveside service, August 10 at 12:30pm, Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus. Donations may be made to: Celiac Disease Center at Columbia University, Harkness Pavilion, 180 Fort Washington Ave., Suite 934, NY, NY 10032. We'll miss you, David.

The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included Monday's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday. According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 0.17 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 0.28 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 0.13 percent.

Louise Caire Clark is making a karmic comeback. Fifteen years after she starred in the infamous Harry and Louise ads -- the televised spots that are generally credited with having turned the tide of public opinion against Clinton-era health reform -- she and Harry are back, angling for a shot at redemption, with a new ad campaign, ''Get the Job Done,'' in support of the Obama plan.

Reposing at Park Chapels, 2175 Jericho Turnpike, Garden City Park, NY. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, 10am, St. Aidan's Church. Entombment Nassau Knolls Cemetery. Visiting hours Tuesday 7-9pm and Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9pm.

A lover of art and literature. A devoted friend. Funeral services, Tuesday August 11, 11:30am at Gutterman's Chapel, 175 N. Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY.

SAYERS--Mark H.,of New York on August 7th after a courageous battle with cancer at age 60. He was a generous, loving, kind and caring soul who will be loved, honored and missed forever. Beloved son of Theodore and Lillian Sayers, brother, uncle, great-uncle, nephew, cousin, godfather to 14 and adored friend to so many. Mark was a graduate of The Hotchkiss School and Washington and Lee University. He was vice president of the highly successful Emes Management Company which primarily invested in real estate in the southern and midwestern United States. He was also the managing general partner of Saymar Partners, a prosperous private hedge fund. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, August 13 at 10am Temple Emanuel, 65th Street and Fifth Avenue in the Beth El Chapel. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to his charitable fund, The Sayers Foundation, Inc. at 130 W. 57th St. Suite 9B, NY, NY 10019.
KIRSCH--Solomon D.,Esq. Sol's memory lives on in the fight for peace, constitutional rights and equality.

Yahoo looks at search differently than Google and Microsoft do. Google and Microsoft want to have stand-alone search franchises that function as helpers for our brains. If you are hunting for something specific, you hit Google or Microsoft's Bing in the hopes of finding an answer. Carol A. Bartz, Yahoo's chief executive, right, places Yahoo's position in a rather different light. ''We have never been a search company,'' she said. ''It is, 'I am on Yahoo. I am going to do a search.' ''
BOXER--Carole. Our dear Aunt Carole, "Mrs. B". Old friends are the best friends. You will stay in our hearts forever. Laurie and Stuart Wilkins Susan and Eddie Tawil

Six weeks after Bernard L. Madoff was sentenced to a 150-year term for running a Ponzi scheme, two books will hit the shelves. ''Too Good to Be True: The Rise and Fall of Bernie Madoff'' by Erin Arvedlund and ''Betrayal: The Life and Lies of Bernie Madoff'' by Andrew Kirtzman, will be released Tuesday. Sensational cases spur action: ''Lethal Lolita,'' the first book about Amy Fisher and the Buttafuocos, was published two months before the trial ended on Dec. 1, 1992. And three TV movies -- one on each network -- were being shown by Jan. 4. SHELLY FREIERMAN

Will your next cellphone be without a microphone, keyboard or screen? It may well, argued Daniel R. Hesse, the chief executive of Sprint Nextel. He said that an increasing number of customers were going to use mobile hot spots -- tiny devices that connect any nearby gadget equipped with Wi-Fi to the Internet using a cellular data network. (In May, David Pogue reviewed one of the first of these hot spots, Novatel's MiFi 2200, above, calling the concept a ''jaw-dropper.'')

LAWRENCE--Joyce, 79, of Delray Beach, Florida passed away on August 7, 2009 after a one year battle with cancer. She was the loving wife of Philip. They shared four children: Robin, Bruce, Jonathan and Elizabeth and their spouses and seven grandchildren. Joyce was the loving "Nana" to them. Joyce is also survived by her sister Judith. Joyce was a kind, gentle, intelligent lady with a zest for life. Joyce loved music, art, theatre and history. She was a legal recruiter for years and then was active with her husband in Lawrence Textiles. Joyce was an enthusiastic sports fan. She was involved with many charities and served on many committees doing good for the community including the Glen Eagles Cancer committee.

Juan Martín del Potro fired 5 of his 19 aces in a deciding tie breaker on Sunday to beat top-seeded Andy Roddick, 3-6, 7-5, 7-6 (6), and win his second consecutive Legg Mason Washington Classic title. Ignoring fatigue and sweltering heat to hit his most powerful serves of the match at the finish, the second-seeded del Potro overcame Roddick on his fourth match-point chance when a replay review upheld a forehand winner.

College students’ debt rose 11 percent between 2003 and 2008, but the percentage of students with bachelor’s degrees who did not take out loans remained constant, at about 34 percent, my colleague, Tamar Lewin, reports today.

Since 1964, New York City Ballet has called Lincoln Center home. In honor of the campus’s 50th anniversary, the ballet company will present a yearlong retrospective of its repertory, beginning with an opening-night benefit in the David H. Koch Theater on Nov. 24. The performance, which will be the company’s first in the theater since it was renovated, will feature a world premiere by Peter Martins to a John Adams score. Another world premiere, by the Russian choreographer Alexey Miroshnichenko, as well as 11 ballets by George Balanchine and Jerome Robbins and five full-length ballets, including “Romeo and Juliet” and “Swan Lake,” are a few of the highlights of the eight-week winter season, beginning Jan. 5. New choreography will be the focus of the spring season, starting May 4, with world premieres by Mr. Martins, Melissa Barak, Mauro Bigonzetti, Wayne McGregor, Benjamin Millepied, Alexei Ratmansky and Christopher Wheeldon. Accompanying the new ballets will be four commissioned scores by Bruno Moretti, Thierry Escaich, Jay Greenberg and Esa-Pekka Salonen. Adding to the mix, the architect Santiago Calatrava will also collaborate in a yet unspecified way with the company during the 2010 season.
The classical music critic James R. Oestreich writes in The Times today about his resistance to Mozart.

At this point, observing that FunnyOrDie.com produces clever videos is like saying that the cell phone is a useful communication device, but sometimes the comedy Web site really knows our sweet spot. If you were put off lately by the relentless trailers for “G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra” and their high-octane Kid Rock soundtrack, but still want to indulge your nostalgia for 1980s action figures, “The Ballad of G.I. Joe” by Daniel Strange and Kevin Umbricht may be more your speed. It’s a low-key guitar jam that imagines what the G.I. Joe team and its Cobra enemies might do in the after hours — and it features a celebrity cast that’s as impressive as the “G.I. Joe” movie. Make sure you stick around to see Destro and the Baroness practicing their clarinets.
What we’re reading on Tuesday morning.

In answer to the Zen koan “What is the shortest amount of footage that a movie studio can release and still call a teaser trailer?,” Summit Entertainment has sent us this: a 16-second sneak preview from “The Twilight Saga: New Moon,” the second entry in its film series adapted from Stephenie Meyer‘s best-selling “Twilight” novels. The trailer will have its debut Friday with the release of “Bandslam,” but if you can’t wait until then (and want to preserve your eardrums), here’s an early look at Kristen Stewart, Robert Pattinson and a shirtless Taylor Lautner.

Our 10-gallon hat is feeling about 5 gallons flat today: the country musicians Kix Brooks and Ronnie Dunn, who since 1990 have performed together as Brooks & Dunn, said that they would go their separate ways after a 2010 concert tour, The Associated Press reported. In a message posted on their official Web site, the musicians wrote that “we have agreed as a duo that” it was time to “call it a day.” The message added: “If you hear rumors, don’t believe them, it’s just time.” Brooks & Dunn said they would release a greatest hits album on Sept. 8 and perform a final set of concerts, to be called the Last Rodeo Tour, next year. After joining up at the suggestion of Tim DuBois, the founder of Arista Nashville Records, Mr. Brooks and Mr. Dunn have released 10 studio albums, including “Waitin’ on Sundown,” “Borderline” and “Red Dirt Road,” and have sold more than 30 million records.

Looking at a planned cover design for “Liar,” a coming young adult novel by Justine Larbalestier, the blogger Cory Doctorow summarized the feelings of many perplexed readers — including the author herself — when he wrote, “Why is there a white girl on the cover of this book about a black girl?” Now, following weeks of online discussion, Bloomsbury Children’s Books said that it would change the novel’s cover to feature a black girl when it releases “Liar” in October, Publishers Weekly reported.

The Knitting Factory, which ceased regular programming in TriBeCa at the end of last year after two decades in Manhattan, will reopen in a smaller space in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, on Sept. 9, the club’s parent company, Knitting Factory Entertainment, announced. Located in the former space of the Luna Lounge — itself a Manhattan transplant — at 361 Metropolitan Avenue, the new club will present the Brooklyn band Les Savy Fav on its opening night, and future shows are to include Boss Hog, Rasputina, the No Neck Blues Band and Titus Andronicus, among others. The renovated space will include a restored 1930s bar from West Virginia and windows salvaged from the Brooklyn Navy Yard, the announcement said.

After weeks of searching for the filmmaker John Hughes and then trying to sell a documentary about that search, the documentary’s director finally found a distributor for his movie — one day after his elusive subject died, Variety reported. The documentary, called “Don’t You Forget About Me,” was made by Matt Austin Sadowski, a Canadian director and actor, and three filmmaking colleagues, Michael Facciolo, Kari Hollend and Lenny Panzer. It combines footage from road trips spent seeking Mr. Hughes, the writer and director of 1980s teen comedies like “The Breakfast Club,” “Ferris Bueller’s Day Off” and “Sixteen Candles,” with interviews of stars from these films, including Judd Nelson, Ally Sheedy and Mia Sara. After Mr. Hughes died on Thursday of a heart attack, Mr. Austin Sadowski said, he started receiving interview requests from the news media the next day. And by noon on Friday, Variety said, Mr. Austin Sadowski had sold worldwide rights to Alliance Films, a Montreal-based distributor. An American release date for the film was not announced.

Even if you enjoy Martin McDonagh‘s newest play, you may wish to resist the urge to give it a big hand. “A Behanding in Spokane,” the latest work from Mr. McDonagh, the Irish writer and filmmaker, will have its Broadway opening on March 4, publicists for the play said Tuesday in a news release. No cast or theater has yet been announced, but the play will be directed by John Crowley, who directed Mr. McDonagh’s drama “The Pillowman” in its National Theater and Broadway productions, and who is directing Hugh Jackman and Daniel Craig in the coming Broadway staging of “A Steady Rain.” “A Behanding in Spokane” is described as a black comedy involving two con artists, a hotel clerk and a man searching for his missing hand; “the rest,” says the punning news release, “is up for grabs.” The play is the first by Mr. McDonagh (“The Lieutenant of Inishmore,” “The Beauty Queen of Leenane”) to be set in the United States as well as his first to originate on Broadway.

Having created dance narratives from the songbooks of Billy Joel (the pride of Long Island) and Bob Dylan (the pride of Minnesota), Twyla Tharp has found her latest inspiration in New Jersey. If you’re thinking of the Boss, try aiming one notch higher, as in the Chairman of the Board. Ms. Tharp’s new musical, “Come Fly With Me,” is built around the music and vocals of Frank Sinatra (the pride of Hoboken, not to mention Las Vegas), and will have its opening at the Alliance Theater in Atlanta, publicists for the production said Tuesday. “Come Fly With Me,” for which Ms. Tharp will serve as director and choreographer, will feature several songs made popular by Sinatra, including “Witchcraft,” “Summer Wind” and — of course — “My Way,” as well as Sinatra’s vocals on some songs, with music performed by a live 17-piece big band. A news release said that the show would follow “four couples over the course of one night falling in and out of love.” Previews are scheduled to begin Sept. 15 with an official opening slated for Sept. 23, followed by a national tour next summer. Ms. Tharp won a Tony Award for the choreography of her Billy Joel musical, “Movin’ Out.”

PARIS — An angry Russian woman pulled a teacup out of her purse and threw it at the Mona Lisa on Aug. 2, the Louvre said on Tuesday. The Da Vinci masterpiece, which is protected by bulletproof glass, was undamaged. “The work is intact, and viewing was only disturbed the time it took to pick up the pieces,” said David Madec, a Louvre spokesman. The woman was taken to the police psychiatric infirmary. “She was clearly deranged,” a police spokesman said.

The latest offerings from the directors Alain Resnais and Pedro Almodóvar will bookend the 2009 New York Film Festival, the Film Society of Lincoln Center said Tuesday. The festival, which returns to Alice Tully Hall this year, will open Sept. 25 with the American premiere of “Wild Grass,” a new film by Mr. Resnais (“Hiroshima Mon Amour”). The film is adapted from Christian Gailly’s novel “The Incident,” and tells the story of seemingly disparate characters brought together by a purse-snatching. On Oct. 11, the festival will conclude with Mr. Almodóvar’s new film, “Broken Embraces,” about a blind and brokenhearted screenwriter. The festival’s lineup also includes Lee Daniels’s film “Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire,” as well as Michael Haneke’s “The White Ribbon,” Todd Solondz’s “Life During Wartime” and Lars von Trier’s “Antichrist.” A spotlight retrospective will feature a high-definition restoration of Victor Fleming’s “Wizard of Oz” (hopefully not on the same bill as “Antichrist”).
How ‘Here Comes the Sun’ and other scenes from the Beatles video game went from concept to screen.

An article in Skeletal Radiology, a well-respected journal, created something of a sensation in Europe last year. It reported that researchers from Danube Hospital in Austria examined the knees of marathon runners using M.R.I. imaging, before and after the 1997 Vienna marathon. Ten years later, they scanned the same runners' knees again. The results were striking. "No major new internal damage in the knee joints of marathon runners was found after a 10-year interval," the researchers reported. Only one of the participants had a knee that was truly a mess, and he'd quit running before the 1997 marathon (but had been included in that study anyway). His 1997 knee M.R.I. revealed cartilage lesions, swelling and other abnormalities. In the years that followed, the knee became worse, showing augmented tissue damage and more serious lesions. His exam prompted the researchers to wonder whether he would have been better off persisting as a runner, because, as they speculate, "continuous exercise is protective, rather than destructive," to knees.

I couldn't help chuckling at myself the other morning as I typed "Humpty Dumpty" into the search box of one of the big science databases. Humpty Dumpty, as anyone who remembers their nursery rhymes will recall, is an egg-shaped fellow who takes a bad fall. At which point, "All the King's horses / and all the King's men / Couldn't put Humpty together again".

Meteor alert! Wednesday is the peak of the annual Perseid meteor shower. The best view of the shooting stars will be in the pre-dawn hours of Wednesday, but non-early-birds can also get a good look after sunset on Wednesday.

Ross Douthat: Gail, this week I've been thinking back to the aftermath of last November's election, when quite a few conservatives comforted themselves with the notion that the United States was still a "center-right" nation, Barack Obama's victory notwithstanding. I wasn't one of them: I thought that you could find a steady leftward movement in polling data, running back to the late 1990s and driven by both economic and demographic trends, that might have made Obama's election possible even without the various disasters of the Bush era. Which is to say that I agreed with many of Obama's more left-wing supporters, who thought that he had a lot more room to govern like a liberal than many conservatives and centrists supposed.

One of my stops on my recent trip to Spain was Rioja, where I was able to spend quite a bit of time at the venerable winery López de Heredia, which is the focus of my column this week.
Wineries like López de Heredia and Marqués de Murrieta in the Rioja region of Spain provide a model for young winemakers who want to return to traditional methods.

It might seem strange for a chef to abandon the restaurant that earned him a Michelin star, but Paul Kitching is nothing if not eccentric. The chef recently cut ties with Juniper, in the English town of Altincham, to open a restaurant and hotel in a Georgian townhouse on a residential block of Edinburgh's New Town. The new 21212, which debuted in May, has already become one of the city's hot spots.

I was sitting with Josie Bonnie on the hood of the Bonnie family clunker on Main Street in Nantucket. It was August 1969, and the older kids, we kept hearing for a week, were leaving the island for a music festival in a place called Woodstock. Josie and I were waiting for her older brother to come along and drive us back to Sconset. We were 13. The Bonnie station wagon was parked in front of the Bosun's Locker, a mysterious place to me then, the last bar on Main Street, and a young woman announced (with some hysteria, I thought at the time) that she and her boyfriend were going to get married. Then and there. The woman kept flitting in and out of the bar, looking, I guess, for her groom. It all seemed perfectly normal, even to a 13-year-old, but for some reason I have chosen, as E.B. White would say, to put it away in lavender. Somewhere in a shoebox at home there is a picture of me on Alter Rock, in a cut-off jean skirt and faded blue flannel shirt. That is my chief sartorial memory of that period, but what else would be contained in a memory from then?

Two and a half months after TD1 formed off the northeast US coast, TD2 forms near the Cape Verde Islands off the west coast of Africa. This is peculiar in two ways: it's rather late in the season to have the second Depression form, and it's rather early to have the "Cape Verde season" kick in. The easterly wave that became TD2 was over Chad on August 4, and exited the African coast on August 8, so it has been a feature of interest for some time. There's actually another potent easterly wave now located over Guinea, but that'll be a topic for a future discussion.

Much has been made lately of the bloodless rise of vampire chic. "Rarely have monsters looked so sultry - or so camera-ready," writes Ruth La Ferla, picking up on the generally attractive and well-clad undead of "Twilight," "True Blood" and "Vampire Diaries." To wit, a fair number of male models seen in Paris and Milan this season mimicked a pale epicene vampire. But vampires aren't the only supernatural beings who contend with an eternity of sartorial choices. Witness "Being Human," a new BBC America series about a vampire, a ghost and a werewolf sharing a flat in Bristol, England. What of the other creatures in this monster mash - what do ghosts and werewolves choose to wear forever? The style conundrums of the undead may be a new field of study, but let's sinks our teeth into it, shall we?

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the Berkshire Fringe theater festival in Massachusetts referred incorrectly to the academic structure of Bard College at Simon’s Rock, the alma mater of two of the festival’s founders. The university enrolls students who have completed at least 10th grade, then offers them college-level courses to earn a bachelor’s degree. The program does not incorporate the last two years of high school and the first two years of college. (It did when Simon’s Rock was founded, in 1966, but that structure was phased out in the early ’70s.).

An article on Monday about Rafael Nadal’s return to tennis from injury referred incorrectly to the record set when his chief rival, Roger Federer, won Wimbledon for his 15th Grand Slam title. The victory gave Federer the most men’s singles Grand Slam championships, not the most “in tennis history.” (Five women have claimed more singles Grand Slam titles in their careers: Margaret Smith Court, Steffi Graf, Helen Willis Moody, Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert.).

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about quarterly earnings for several retailers misstated the corporate standing of one retailer, Ross Stores. An off-price retailer, Ross Stores is a public company based in California; it has no connection with TJX, which is the parent company of another off-price retailer, T.J. Maxx.

Hours after a judge in Los Angeles approved a deal for a movie using footage of Michael Jackson’s concert rehearsals, Sony announced that the film, “This Is It,” would be released on Oct. 30 in theaters around the world. Named after Mr. Jackson’s planned 50-date engagement in London, the film is to include scenes of him rehearsing at the Staples Center in Los Angeles, along with a career retrospective and interviews with friends and collaborators, and parts of it will be in 3-D, the announcement said. Sony paid $60 million to make the film, part of a deal involving the studio, the Jackson estate and AEG Live, the concert promoter that shot the rehearsals. Until permanent executors are confirmed, Judge Mitchell Beckloff of Los Angeles County Superior Court must approve deals made by the interim administrators, John G. Branca and John McClain. The two were named as executors in Mr. Jackson’s will. ... The Associated Press reported that Mr. Jackson will be honored in Vienna with an all-star concert at the Schönbrunn Palace. The event was announced Monday by the promoter World Awards Media G.m.b.H. A date was not set, but tickets for the concert, which will take place at an outdoor stage shaped like a crown, are to go on sale Aug. 20. The promoters said Jermaine Jackson would appear at the concert “to celebrate the life of his brother and perform some of Michael’s unforgettable songs,” along with other members of the Jackson family.

Is there anything Twitter can’t do (when it isn’t shut down by the cyberattacks of malicious hackers)? The popular online network connects you to your friends, feeds you the latest news — and now it’s about to help create a new opera. The Independent reported that the Royal Opera House of London is planning to produce a work called “The Twitter Opera,” in which the libretto will be composed of short messages sent by the public to the opera house’s @youropera Twitter feed. The music will be a mixture of familiar opera music and original compositions by Helen Porter, and the finished work will be performed Sept. 4 through 6. A cast has not yet been announced, but if you’re a soprano who can handle a lyric like “I can’t stand you — no, stronger./You are a horse. And now escape is what I long for,” the Royal Opera may have need for you. ... In other crazy classical music news (a phrase we don’t often get to type), The Associated Press reported that Glenn Donnellan, above, a violinist for the National Symphony Orchestra, performed the national anthem at a Major League Baseball game on Saturday night using an electric violin that he made from a regulation bat. Mr. Donnellan, who performed before a game between the Washington Nationals and Arizona Diamondbacks in Washington, said he used a Derek Jeter-model bat purchased at a sporting goods store. “I went to the Sports Authority with my fiddle one day after work, held it up to the bat and it looked about right,” Mr. Donnellan said, according to The A.P.

The bookseller Barnes & Noble said Monday it would acquire Barnes & Noble College Booksellers, a privately held company owned by the chairman of Barnes & Noble, in a deal valued at $596 million. To avoid a conflict of interest between the company and its chairman, Leonard Riggio, Barnes & Noble said it set up an independent committee of directors to evaluate the transaction. The company said the college bookseller had a leading market position in the growing college book business, with contracts with 405 institutions. About 35 percent of college bookstores are run by Barnes & Noble College Booksellers and other third parties, with the remainder operated by the colleges themselves. For the college bookseller’s recently completed fiscal year, it generated about $1.8 billion in revenue. Its same store sales rose 1 percent, while in the first quarter Barnes & Noble saw its same store sales decline by 5.7 percent.

Glenn D. Lowry, below, the director of the Museum of Modern Art, earned $1.32 million in pay and benefits for the fiscal year that ended in June, Bloomberg News reported. A spokeswoman for the Modern told Bloomberg that Mr. Lowry’s pay package was reduced after he took a voluntary pay cut as the museum cut spending by 10 percent across departments and implemented a hiring freeze to weather the recession. The previous year Mr. Lowry earned $1.95 million in salary, bonus and benefits, Bloomberg said, citing tax returns filed by the museum. That figure represented a raise of 13 percent from the year before and made him the highest-paid director among the six United States museums with the largest budgets that have filed returns for 2008, according to Bloomberg. In comparison, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Philippe de Montebello, its outgoing director, was paid $818,935 for the year ending in June 2008, up 7 percent from the year earlier.

A Jewish group in Germany has called for that country to lift its longstanding ban on Hitler’s book “Mein Kampf” and allow it to be published there, The Independent reported. Stephan J. Kramer, the general secretary of the Central Council of Jews in Germany, said the group favored the publication of a new edition of “Mein Kampf” with scholarly commentaries that would educate future generations on the evils of Nazism. Hitler wrote the manifesto, whose title translates as “My Struggle” and which articulates his anti-Semitic views, while serving a four-year term for treason at Landsberg prison in Bavaria. The book, first published in two volumes in 1925 and 1926, has been banned in Germany since 1945, and the Bavarian government holds the copyright on it until 2015. A spokesman for the Bavarian government told The Independent, “We won’t lift the ban, as it may play straight into the hands of the far right. Prohibition is highly regarded by Jewish groups, and we mean to keep it that way.”.

In a recent interview Kathryn Bigelow, below, was asked by Stephen Colbert, the button-pushing late-night host, “When are you going to settle down and make a movie about Diane Lane finding love the second time around?” The answer: Not anytime soon. Variety reported that Ms. Bigelow, the director of action films like “The Hurt Locker” and “Point Break,” had struck a deal with Paramount Pictures to direct a new adventure movie called “Triple Frontier” for the studio. Few plot details about the new movie were given, except that it is set at a border zone shared by Paraguay, Argentina and Brazil, where organized crime is rampant. The film will reunite Ms. Bigelow with the screenwriter Mark Boal, who wrote “The Hurt Locker,” about a United States Army bomb squad in the Iraq war. Production on “Triple Frontier” is expected to start next year; a cast and a release date were not announced.

Brian d’Arcy James will have to endure those 90-minute makeup treatments for only a few more months: next year he’ll depart the swamps of “Shrek the Musical” to join the cast of the Manhattan Theater Club production of “Time Stands Still,” the Donald Margulies play, publicists for the theater company said on Monday. Mr. James was nominated for a Tony Award for his performance as the titular belching green ogre in “Shrek.” In “Time Stands Still” Mr. James, below, will play the journalist husband of a photographer, played by Laura Linney, who is recovering from an injury in the Iraq war. The cast also includes Alicia Silverstone, and the play will be directed by Daniel Sullivan. It is scheduled to begin previews at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater on Jan. 5 and open on Jan. 28. Mr. James is the first member to announce his departure from the principal cast of “Shrek,” which also includes Sutton Foster, Daniel Breaker and Christopher Sieber. A date for his final “Shrek” performance was not given.

Shortly after 5:30 p.m. Monday, the grandstands at Stade Uniprix in Montreal emptied in the middle of a first-round match at the Rogers Cup. Fans left en masse, scampering toward the adjacent court, filling empty seats and huddling at railings with unhindered views. This was no ordinary doubles match they were going to see. This was Rafael Nadal's first match of any sort since he lost in the fourth round of the French Open on May 31. This was the beginning of his comeback.

When the story of this season is told, however it ends, people will point to the Yankees' weekend sweep of the Boston Red Sox as a turning point. But look at what happened right before that series: The Yankees had lost three in a row in Chicago through Aug. 1; they faced, in order, Mark Buehrle of the White Sox and Roy Halladay of Toronto; and the Yankees started Sergio Mitre on Aug. 5 in Toronto before the four games at home with Boston.

GUNTHER--Edgar. Died peacefully at home in New York on August 8. Born in 1921 in Germany, his family left for New York to escape Nazi persecution. Educated at CCNY and the Sorbonne (Ph.D., economics). Served in the U.S. Army during WWII. He was market research director at Fortune magazine and co-founder of NORAM, an investment firm. He is survived by his sons, Marc, Noel and Andrew, and six grandchildren.

Children who spend a lot of time watching television have higher blood pressure than those who watch less, even if the children are thin and get enough exercise, according to new research. Earlier studies associated TV viewing and obesity, which is linked to higher blood pressure. But the new report suggests a more direct link between extensive TV watching and increases in blood pressure, the authors said.

DALVA--David L.,II. Dalva Brothers, Inc., deeply mourns the loss of our beloved senior partner, father, brother, cousin, and uncle. We valued and will miss his encyclopedic knowledge of 18th century French decorative arts and his passion for restoring and preserving the works of art in our collection. Well known as an expert in his field, his opinions were respected by all. In recent years, he was involved in every aspect of the design and decoration of our new gallery. The move from our building on 57th Street was a challenge that David tackled with the expertise, attention to detail, and enthusiasm he brought to every project. Gifted at both leadership and friendship, he enjoyed long ties to the military, where he rose to the rank of full colonel in the United States Army Reserves, as well as many civic and social organizations. He was a past president of the Art and Antiques Dealers' League of America, served on the board of the International Foundation for Art Research (IFAR), was a member of the Mayor's Council for the Arts, and a fellow in perpetuity of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. He was an Associate Publisher of El Diario-La Prensa in the 1980s. Friends are invited to join his family for a celebration of his life at the Down Town Association, 60 Pine Street, from 11am to 1pm on Friday, August 14th. Donations may be sent to: Weill-Cornell Medical Center Prostate Cancer Research Center, 520 East 70th Street, Box 403, New York, NY 10021 or The Wounded Warrior Project, 370 Seventh Avenue, Room 320, New York, NY 10001.

9 P.M. (Discovery) SWORDS: LIFE ON THE LINE This newest entry in the deadliest-catch oeuvre explores the risks inherent in long-line swordfish hunting, above. The boats include two out of Fairhaven, Mass.: the 100-foot-long, steel-hulled Eagle Eye II, captained by Scott Drabinowicz, and the 70-foot-long Sea Hawk, overseen by Linda Greenlaw, who survived the infamous ''perfect storm'' in the Hannah Boden, the sister ship to the Andrea Gail. There's also the dilapidated, 58-foot-long fiberglass Big Eye run by Chris Hanson of Wanchese, N.C., and owned by his fiancée, as well as the Frances Anne, a 72-foot-long, forward-housed boat run by Chris Kleme and several New Jersey surfer dudes. In this premiere episode the crews take a voyage to hell on the Grand Banks off the coast of Newfoundland. 7 A.M. (CBS) THE EARLY SHOWNeil Diamond croons some of his hits. Topics include raising children to avoid drug abuse and cooking with corn.

Hispanics who move to the United States are 40 percent more likely to develop certain cancers than those who remain in their native countries, according to a study from the University of Miami Miller School of Medicine that was conducted in Florida, a state with a diverse Hispanic population. Researchers speculate that one reason for the possible increase in cancer risk is that immigrants quickly adopt new, less healthy dietary and lifestyle habits, like increased alcohol consumption, after moving to the United States.

On Monday, at 2:04 p.m., it was 90 degrees in Central Park. Not an unusual occurrence in a typical New York summer, but worth noting this year; the last time the temperature in the park reached that milestone was April 28. Around the city, people enjoyed the heat or endured it, according to their inclinations. Above, showering before entry to the Hamilton Fish Park pool on the Lower East Side; left and right, both in Battery Park: on a boat to Liberty and Ellis Islands, and taking a rest. The weather is expected to remain warm, but not get warmer, with highs of 88 degrees on Tuesday and 84 on Wednesday.

It comes as little surprise to learn that the lush portraits of the living world here and on the cover, which dazzle with their jewel-like colors and exquisite detail, were executed by one of the 19th century's most lauded natural history artists. It might be a bit more surprising to discover that the painter was also one of the most influential scientists of his day. The artist was Ernst Haeckel, the German zoologist best known today for his infamous and mistaken declaration that ''ontogeny recapitulates phylogeny,'' meaning that the developmental stages an organism passes through are a kind of instant replay of its species' evolutionary history.

Adults who had slightly elevated cholesterol in their early 40s were at greater risk of developing dementia decades later, a new study has found. While earlier studies had shown a link between high cholesterol in midlife and an elevated risk of Alzheimer's disease, ''we were surprised to see the association with borderline levels,'' said Rachel A. Whitmer, an epidemiologist with the Kaiser Permanente Division of Research and the paper's senior author. It was published online in Dementia & Geriatric Cognitive Disorders.

In the introduction to his essay collection “The Wicked Son: Anti-Semitism, Self-Hatred and the Jews,” David Mamet offered the book, in part, to readers “whose favorite Jew is Anne Frank and whose second-favorite does not exist.” We presume he won’t be quite as provocative with his next project, a new film version of “The Diary of Anne Frank,” which Mr. Mamet is writing and directing for Disney.

If a certain presidential election distracted you last November from the New York Comedy Festival, you have no excuse for missing out this year, especially now that all the nation’s political disputes have been completely resolved. On Wednesday, the festival’s organizers announced the lineup for this year’s festival, which will run from Nov. 4 through 8, and it’s a formidable crop: Andy Samberg, the “Saturday Night Live” star; the sometime film actor Dane Cook; the “Howard Stern Show” regular (and “Joe Buck Live” hijacker) Artie Lange; as well as Patton Oswalt, Mike Birbiglia, Bill Burr and Mike Epps have been added to the bill. They join the previously announced headliners Ricky Gervais (who performs on Nov. 5 at Carnegie Hall), Tracy Morgan (Nov. 6 at Carnegie Hall) and Bill Maher (Nov. 8 at Avery Fisher Hall). More than 150 comedians are expected to perform over the course of the festival; panel discussions at the Paley Center for Media are also planned, with those lineups still to be announced.

The filmmaker John Hughes was buried Tuesday in a private ceremony at a funeral home in Lake Forest, Ill., north of Chicago, The Chicago Tribune reported. Mr. Hughes, a longtime North Shore resident who paid tribute to the area in films like “Ferris Bueller’s Day Off,” died in Manhattan on Thursday of a heart attack. He was 59. The funeral service was attended by the actors Vince Vaughn and Matthew Broderick, the star of “Ferris Bueller,” as well as Ben Stein, the actor and commentator who played a droning high school teacher in that film, and was a longtime friend of Mr. Hughes’s. Speaking of Mr. Hughes, Mr. Stein told The Tribune, “We’ll never see his like again. He was the Wordsworth of the suburban America post-war generation. He was a great, great, great genius and as much of a friend and a great family man as he was a poet.”

LOS ANGELES – The Autry National Center of the American West in Los Angeles has withdrawn its $175 million plan to expand its museum complex in Griffith Park, blaming “virtually endless official delays” and threatened litigation. The expansion would have created new exhibition space for the extensive collection of Native American artifacts that the Autry gained when it merged its Museum of the American West, endowed by the cowboy-singer Gene Autry, with the Southwest Museum of the American Indian in 2003. The Southwest Museum was formerly housed in a landmark white adobe building northeast of downtown that was damaged in the 1994 Northridge earthquake. The Southwest Museum’s collections were later found to be suffering from severe neglect. Neighborhood groups wanted a commitment to keep the building as a functioning museum. But John L. Gray, the Autry president, said in a letter to museum supporters Tuesday that the cost of and delays in the approval process for its multi-campus plan were no longer supportable. The museum said it will continue to use its existing facilities, both in Griffith Park and at Mount Washington, for exhibitions.

The Writers Guild of America said that it would not discipline Jay Leno for continuing to deliver his “Tonight Show” monologues while the guild was on strike, Variety reported. In a message sent to its membership on Tuesday, the WGA West said that it would take no further action against Mr. Leno, the former “Tonight Show” host and a guild member, who was accused of violating the guild’s rules. The writers’ strike began on Nov. 5, 2007, and concluded on Feb. 12, 2008; “Tonight” was in reruns until Jan. 2, 2008, at which point Mr. Leno, who supported the strike, resumed performing monologues that he composed without his writers. Mr. Leno met with a guild panel in February to answer questions about the matter, and could have been punished with a fine, suspension or expulsion.

Every opera company has to grapple now and then with withdrawals by important singers. But in recent months the Metropolitan Opera has experienced a daunting spate of cancellations and substitutions. And it continues.

Stephen Rea and Sean McGinley, who originated the two roles in Sam Shepard‘s play “Ages of the Moon” when it had its premiere at the Abbey Theater in Dublin, will reprise those characters for the Atlantic Theater Company‘s production of the play. On Wednesday, publicists for the Atlantic Theater Company said that Mr. Rea (of the film “The Crying Game” and “Someone Who’ll Watch Over Me” on Broadway) and Mr. McGinley would return to the characters of Byron and Ames, two longtime friends who are reunited in middle age. The play, which is Mr. Shepard’s first for Atlantic, will begin previews at the Linda Gross Theater on Jan. 12 and open on Jan. 27. Its limited engagement runs through March 7.

Seven weeks since his death, Michael Jackson continues to dominate record sales, although his competition lately has not been very strong. Once again, Mr. Jackson’s “Number Ones” (Epic) was the best-selling album in the United States last week, with 98,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan. His other titles, particularly “Thriller” and “The Essential Michael Jackson,” also continue to rack up significant sales; in total, about 3.7 million Jackson albums have been sold since his death on June 25.

We don’t know a lot of things about Thomas Pynchon, the hermetic novelist, but we know he likes music. Apparently, he recently provided Amazon.com with a play list to accompany his new novel, “Inherent Vice.” And in 1988, writing in The New York Times Book Review, he began a review of Gabriel Garcia Marquez’s novel “Love in the Time of Cholera” this way: “Love, as Mickey and Sylvia, in their 1956 hit single, remind us, love is strange.”

LOS ANGELES — The Academy of Television Arts & Sciences reversed course on Wednesday and said it would present all 28 awards during its live broadcast on CBS on Sept. 20, eliminating a plan to pre-tape some of the awards that drew stiff opposition from television writers and cable networks. The Academy had planned to prerecord and edit the presentation of eight awards to allow for more time to celebrate shows that are popular with the public but which might not have been nominated. The plan was to try to boost ratings after viewers told the Academy last year that the awards focus too much on shows that are unfamiliar to the public. Members of at least two unions — the Writers Guild of America, West, and the Directors Guild of America – opposed the plan, as did HBO, which usually dominates the movie and miniseries categories that were scheduled for pre-taping. The academy also faced the prospect that the unions would force it to pay substantial fees for the clips of television shows it uses during the broadcast. In a statement, an academy official said it reversed the plan “to mend relationships within the television community.”

Along with "tubular," "gnarly" and other eighties era argot, "rad" has pretty much faded from East Coast vocabularies. In the Dude State (a k a California), however, it's standard English. Hence the name Warriors of Radness, a surf-inspired men's clothing line that takes its cues from the Jeff Spicoli years. "'Rad' never seems to escape our left coast lingo," says Rick Klotz, the line's founder and designer. "And combining it with 'warriors' made sense because the guys I surf with and I felt like we were warriors in search of anything rad, whether it be a party, waves, girls or beer. I always tell people we're conducting a W.O.R. on mundane surf wear." Weapons in the W.O.R. arsenal include pastel T-shirts (Klotz is partial to the Gidget one above), seersucker shorts and, for fall, wool muscle pants, a sort of trouser-length version of board shorts. "I was wearing them last night with dress shoes," Klotz says. "And you know, for the West Coast, they looked pretty fancy."

For beer fans, this is like Elton and Billy on the Dueling Pianos Tours. In May two master brewers - Garret Oliver of New York's Brooklyn Brewery and Hans-Peter Drexler of the G. Schneider & Sohn in Kelheim, Germany - teamed up to create a reserve beer, the wonderfully satisfying to pronounce Brooklyner-Schneider Hopfen-Weisse. The beer mixes the best aspects of German pilsner wheat malt and Bavarian yeast with the floral, fruity esters of American Willamette, Cascade, Palisade and Amarillo hops. The welding of these ingredients produced 2,900 cases of pale-hopped, robustly bitter beer that has found its way onto restaurant menus in Brooklyn and Manhattan, including Blue Smoke and DBGB. (I had it at Building on Bond, in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn.) The current reserve is low, so get your fill of the brew now; finding the beer through October will be difficult. But if you miss out, there will be a second run at the Brooklyn Brewery this summer, yielding around 35,000 bottles that will be available after November.

Maplewood Township's engineer, Rich Calbi, will be leaving his post for a municipal job in Livingston, Maplewood officials said today. Mr. Calbi, who has been in his current job for about five years, did not immediately respond to a message seeking comment, but Township Committeeman Jerry Ryan explained why he was leaving in an e-mail message: "The Livingston job is, from what I can see, more pay and more responsibility, and so for Rich I think it is an excellent career opportunity. I liked working with Rich very much and have an enormous amount of respect for the quality (and quantity!) of his work." Mayor Vic DeLuca said the township will be advertising the vacancy and possibly using a pool of retired professional engineers in the interim, for projects like the refurbishing of DeHart Park, and repairs to the library and Township Hall. -- Tina Kelley

Bruce Pask, T Magazine's men's fashion director, writes on style every week.Scott Schuman has long been trailing the fashion-show caravan from Florence to Milan, Paris and New York City, photographing selected stylish folk and plenty of fashion world regulars for his blog, The Sartorialist.com, and becoming a sort of de facto cultural anthropologist along the way. His eye is discerning but it doesn't discriminate: the quirky, the refined, the interesting, the elegant, the chic and the sometimes outrageous, all shot very simply on the street, come together in a visual history of the fashion business, marking our place in the timeline of style."The Sartorialist," a hefty 512-page paperback hot off of the press from Penguin, is a clever nod to the democratic nature of his photography, more high school yearbook than highbrow coffee-table tome. It's chock-full of photographs you will want to pore over with friends, searching for those you know - and maybe even yourself. Schuman gives a well-deserved nod to Bill Cunningham, the New York Times journalist and granddaddy of the street photography style, and has included a photo of him hard at work. He has also captured a few T Magazine editors and contributors in the pages, including countless great photos of our fearless style leader Stefano Tonchi. A brief chapter is devoted to our stylish Milan-based contributing fashion editor, Robert Rabensteiner, and there's even a shot in there of yours truly. Make some room on your bookshelf, I'm feeling for "The Sartorialist."

The Peninsula Shanghai, an Art-Deco inspired hotel on Shanghai's historic Bund, is scheduled to open Oct. 15. The 235 rooms are large - a Superior Room ranges from 581 to 721 square feet - and many offer views of the Pudong, the Huangpu River or the gardens of the former British Consulate. The hotel also has a luxurious spa, rooftop restaurant and ballroom - all with a handsome décor reminiscent of Shanghai's Golden Age.

Masha Hamilton's latest novel, 31 Hours, explores what it means to be the parent of a young adult. As I prepare to take my oldest son off to college (more about that next week), the question she raises - in the book and in a guest essay today - is one that has been looping through my brain for months now: after years of protecting our kids, what should we do - and what are we allowed to do - to keep them safe once they are grown?

I worked on this fried squid piece a month or so ago, while spending a few days on Cape Cod, so I fried not only squid but clams, oysters, and scallops. The technique is precisely the same. In fact little bits of seafood are among the easiest things to deep-fry because they don't usually need to spend more than 5 minutes in hot oil, and frequently less - when their exteriors look the way you want them to, their interiors are done.

A little over a year ago, I met a Frenchman coming off the ferry from Dover, England, to Calais, France. He was in his 60s, with a distinguished but relaxed air, and he switched effortlessly and seamlessly between English and French as we spoke. He carried no luggage. He wore a light, finely woven cashmere sweater and spotless khaki pants, and his shoes - well, he didn't have any. His feet were entirely bare.

Love letters, scrapbooks, pressed flowers, vials of blood: these relationship mementos finally have a place to call home. "The Museum of Broken Relationships" is a roving exhibition of donated objects organized by Olinka Vistica and Drazen Grubisic in Croatia as a cathartic response to the emotional turmoil of love lost. Along with an anonymous short story detailing the emotional resonance of each donation, these artifacts of failed romances provide a much-needed alternative to the usual heartbreak-recovery methods like Charlie Kaufman's memory erasure and/or binge drinking.

The Knitting Factory, which ceased regular programming in TriBeCa at the end of last year after two decades in Manhattan, will reopen in a smaller space in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, on Sept. 9, the club’s parent company, Knitting Factory Entertainment, announced. Located in the former space of the Luna Lounge — itself a Manhattan transplant — at 361 Metropolitan Avenue, the new club will present the Brooklyn band Les Savy Fav on its opening night, and future shows are to include Boss Hog, Rasputina, the No Neck Blues Band and Titus Andronicus, among others. The club’s lease on space on Leonard Street in TriBeCa expired in July.

After weeks of searching for the filmmaker John Hughes and then trying to sell a documentary about that search, the documentary’s director finally found a distributor, Variety reported. The film, “Don’t You Forget About Me,” was made by Matt Austin Sadowski, a Canadian director and actor, and three filmmaking colleagues, Michael Facciolo, Kari Hollend and Lenny Panzer. Mr. Hughes died on Thursday of a heart attack, and on Friday, Variety said, Mr. Austin Sadowski sold worldwide rights for his documentary to Alliance Films, a distributor in Montreal. An American release date for the film has not been announced.

The latest offerings from the directors Alain Resnais and Pedro Almodóvar will bookend the 2009 New York Film Festival, the Film Society of Lincoln Center said Tuesday. The festival, which returns to Alice Tully Hall this year, will open on Sept. 25 with the American premiere of “Wild Grass,” a new film by Mr. Resnais (“Hiroshima Mon Amour”). “Wild Grass” is adapted from Christian Gailly’s novel “The Incident,” and tells the story of seemingly disparate characters brought together by a purse-snatching. On Oct. 11 the festival will conclude with Mr. Almodóvar’s new film, “Broken Embraces,” about a blind and brokenhearted screenwriter. The festival’s lineup also includes Lee Daniels’s film “Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire,” as well as Michael Haneke’s “White Ribbon,” Todd Solondz’s “Life During Wartime” and Lars von Trier’s “Antichrist.”.
Night two of ABC’s special two-week revival of “Who Wants to Be a Millionaire” inched up in the ratings on Monday.
Developers in New Jersey are finding desirable retail tenants for their residential projects. And given the economic slump, retailers are able to drive a harder bargain.

Having created dance narratives from the songbooks of Billy Joel (the pride of Long Island) and Bob Dylan (the pride of Minnesota), the choreographer and director Twyla Tharp, below, has found her latest inspiration in New Jersey. Ms. Tharp’s new musical, “Come Fly With Me,” is built around the music and vocals of Frank Sinatra (the pride of Hoboken, not to mention Las Vegas), and will have its opening at the Alliance Theater in Atlanta, publicists for the production said Tuesday. Previews are to begin Sept. 15, with an official opening slated for Sept. 23; a national tour will follow next summer.

The country musicians Kix Brooks, near left, and Ronnie Dunn, far left, who since 1990 have performed as Brooks & Dunn, said they would go their separate ways after a 2010 tour, The Associated Press reported. In a message posted on their official Web site (brooks-dunn.com), the musicians wrote that “we have agreed as a duo that” it was time to “call it a day.” The message added: “If you hear rumors, don’t believe them, it’s just time.” Brooks & Dunn said they would release a greatest hits album on Sept. 8 and perform a final set of concerts, the Last Rodeo Tour, next year. After joining up at the suggestion of Tim DuBois, the founder of Arista Nashville Records, Mr. Brooks and Mr. Dunn have released 10 studio albums, including “Waitin’ on Sundown,” “Borderline” and “Red Dirt Road,” and have sold more than 30 million records.

Even if you enjoy Martin McDonagh’s newest play, you may wish to resist the urge to give it a big hand. “A Behanding in Spokane,” the latest work from Mr. McDonagh, below, the Irish writer and filmmaker, will have its Broadway opening on March 4, publicists for the play said Tuesday in a news release. No cast or theater has yet been announced, but the play will be directed by John Crowley, who directed Mr. McDonagh’s drama “The Pillowman” in its National Theater and Broadway productions. “A Behanding in Spokane” is described as a black comedy involving two con artists, a hotel clerk and a man searching for his missing hand.

Looking at a planned cover design, top right, for “Liar,” a coming young-adult novel by Justine Larbalestier, the blogger Cory Doctorow summarized the feelings of many perplexed readers — including the author herself — when he wrote at boingboing.net, “Why is there a white girl on the cover of this book about a black girl?” Now, after weeks of online discussion, Bloomsbury Children’s Books said it would change the novel’s cover to feature a black girl, below right, when it releases “Liar” in October, Publishers Weekly reported. After readers who had received advance copies of “Liar” called attention to the discrepancy, Ms. Larbalestier wrote on her blog (justinelarbalestier.com/blog/) that the heroine of “Liar” “is black with nappy hair, which she wears natural and short. As you can see that description does not match the U.S. cover.” Bloomsbury said in a statement that it was changing the cover design, adding that it regretted that the original cover “ has been interpreted by some as a calculated decision to mask the character’s ethnicity,” according to Publishers Weekly.

Since 1964, New York City Ballet has called Lincoln Center home. In honor of the campus’s 50th anniversary, the ballet company will present a yearlong retrospective of its repertory, beginning with an opening-night benefit in the David H. Koch Theater on Nov. 24. The performance, which will be the company’s first in the theater since it was renovated, will feature a world premiere by Peter Martins, the company’s balletmaster in chief, to a John Adams score. Another world premiere, by the Russian choreographer Alexey Miroshnichenko, as well as 11 ballets by George Balanchine and Jerome Robbins are a few of the highlights of the eight-week winter season, beginning Jan. 5. New choreography will be the focus of the spring season, starting May 4, with world premieres by Benjamin Millepied, Alexei Ratmansky and Christopher Wheeldon, among others.

McTIERNAN--Patricia A. After enjoying a beautiful day with her grandchildren and friends, Patricia A. McTiernan passed away at her home on August 9, 2009 with her husband, Roger P. McTiernan, Sr. by her side. The daughter of Dave and Ann Sullivan, she was born in Greenwich Village. Her love of the ocean brought her to Rockaway, a community she cherished. She is survived by her husband Roger; brother Edward Sullivan; children Roger, Brian, Barry and Patricia; sister and brother-in-law, Bridgett and Philip McManus; 15 grandchildren, one nephew and two nieces. She attended Cathedral High School in New York City and graduated from the Hospital for Special Surgery in Nursing. Best known as Mimi, she will be remembered for living life to the fullest. Viewing will be at the Denis S. O'Connor Funeral Home, Rockaway Beach, NY, on Tuesday, 25pm and 7-10pm. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, St. Francis De Sales R.C. Church at 11am. Donations may be made to the Gladney Center for Adoption 817-922-6000; www.adoptionsbygladney.com

THOMAS--Yvonne, noted abstract expressionist painter, died on August 7 at age 95. She is survived by daughters Viviane Thomas Trimble and Gwenn Thomas Avillez, and grandchildren Christopher Trimble, Nicholas Trimble and Joana Avillez. Memorial service to be held in the fall.

PROPP--Eugenie. Westchester Day School is profoundly saddened by the passing of Eugenie Propp, who, along with her late husband, Mortimer J. Propp, was a founder and life-time supporter of our school. Sincere condolences to her children, Morris (Marni) and Helen (Melvin) Heller, and grandchildren, Adrienne and Jack. Enia will be sorely missed by the Westchester Day School community. Rabbi Joshua Einzig, Head of School Amy Eagle, President Russell Mannis, Chairman of the Board Alisa Mannis, Vice Chair

PROPP--Eugenie. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of the wife of the late Mortimer Propp and sister-in-law of his brothers Ephraim(and Gail) and the late Seymour, and his wife Gabrielle Propp, whose family jointly established the Propp Brothers Scholarship Fund in memory of their parents Morris and Anna Propp at the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary and supported many other projects at YU. The Propp family are Guardians of YU. Eugenie Propp was a member of the Executive Council of Yeshiva University Women's Organization, along with her sisters-in-law, Gabrielle Propp and Gail Propp. Heartfelt condolences are extended to her children Helen Heller and Morris Propp and to her brother-in-law, Ephraim Propp, and sisters-in-law Gabrielle and Gail Propp and grandchildren; Jack and Adrienne, and all the members of the Propp family. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry J. Weiss, Chair, YU Board of Trustees Dinah Pinczower, National Chairman of the Board, YUWO

GOULD--Jane. HistoryinAction (HIA) an intergenerational email list of feminist activists mourns the death but the celebrates the life of one of our most beloved members. Feminist, writer, environmental activist, philanthropist, first director of the Barnard Center for Research on Women, we promise to carry on your legacy.

SCHWARTZ--William, on August 11, 2009, three days short of his 92nd birthday. Dear husband of Charlotte, devoted and beloved father of Andrew, Linda and Barbara, adored grandfather of David, Adam and Marissa. A respected leader his entire life in the metropolitan milk industry as President of Meadowbrook Farms. A kind and generous person of spirit and integrity. A truly wonderful man. Services 10am Thursday, August 13th at Temple Sinai, 425 Roslyn Road, Roslyn, New York.

SULLIVAN--Toby, 90, predeceased by husband Jim; mother of Peter; daughter-in-law of Allison; sister of Nettie, Mannie, Bernie and Judy; died peacefully on Tuesday, August 4, 2009. She enjoyed a life long career as an artist and art teacher. Her art work was first recognized in 1940 and in successive years she accumulated many awards and participated in many exhibits. She lived most of her life in Glen Cove and Sea Cliff, Long Island.

RABIN--Florence B. North Shore Country Club records with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed honorary member, Florence Rabin. We extend our deepest condolences to her family. Robert D. Malkin, President Lawrence Gottlieb, Secretary

The bronze statuary groups on the Soldiers' and Sailors' Memorial Arch at Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn are being cleaned and recoated with lacquer as part of the Citywide Monuments Conservation Program. The arch, with its statues by Frederick W. MacMonnies, commemorates the Union forces of the Civil War. John C. Saunders, a conservator with the Department of Parks and Recreation, worked on one of the statues in late July. Earlier Sight/Site installments: nytimes.com/lens.

FERRERO CONTINUES CLIMB Juan Carlos Ferrero found himself in an unusual position at the Rogers Cup. The slots for ATP tournament fields are determined six weeks in advance, so Ferrero, a former world No. 1, was not ranked high enough to earn automatic entry. Now 29th in the world, Ferrero still had to win a qualifying match just to advance to the main draw here. ''Of course, it's very tough to play quallies when you've been blah, blah, blah,'' Ferrero said.

RABIN--Florence. The North Shore - LIJ Health System mourns the passing of Florence Rabin, the widow of Samuel Rabin, a judge who served at all three levels of the New York State court system. Judge and Mrs. Rabin both had a significant impact on the development of Long Island Jewish (LIJ) Medical Center -- Judge Rabin was one of the hospital's founders and Mrs. Rabin was a foun- der of the LIJ Service Guild. We deeply appreciate their long-time commitment and dedication, and extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Rabin family. Saul Katz, Chairman Michael Dowling, President & CEO

SHORT--Frank J.,of East Hampton, New York, died Friday, August 7, 2009, at the Meadow Green Nursing Home in Waltham, MA after a lengthy illness. He was 82. Frank worked for the New York Times as a pressman for nearly fifty years. Mr. Short was the beloved husband of forty years of the late Marie (Grimes) Short. He is survived by his daughter Margaret Short of Waltham, MA and grandchildren Jonathan and Raymond Roselli. A Memorial Service will take place at a later date in East Hampton, New York.

DALVA--David L.,II, 73, Col. USAR (Ret.) Beloved husband of Mimi, devoted father of Jean, David and Peter; Father in law to Michelle, Dirk and Jenny. Loving Grandfather of Leila, Curran, Eric, Grace, Laurel and Helen. He was President of Dalva Brothers Incorporated, past publisher of El Diario La Prensa and President and CEO of Dalva Aviation. He is dearly missed.

MAY--William Henry, 79, of Brooklyn Heights, New York. Died Monday, August 10th 2009. Beloved husband of Diane. Loving father of John, Margaret and Billy. Adoring grandpa of Christopher, Katie, Molly, and Liam. Predeceased by brothers James and John. Caring brother-in-law to Annette and Carol. Fond father-in-law to Ewa and Emily. Dear uncle of David, Edward John, Nancy, Linda, Matthew, Michelle, Danielle, Jonathan, Mona and Marilyn. Life-long Brooklynite. Long-time mathematics teacher, New Utrecht HS. Retired Director, Office of School Financial Aid, NYC Board of Education. Trustee, St. Charles Borromeo Church, Brooklyn Heights. Retired member, Board of Directors, Angel Guardian Children and Family Services. U.S. Marine Corps 1947 1952. Graduate St. John's Prep (Brooklyn), Brooklyn College (BS), Fordham University (MS). Graduate student, well into in his 70s, GIS program, Hunter College. Elected to International Geographical Honor Society, 2007. Proud of his Irish heritage, devoted to the Roman Catholic faith, and utterly immersed in scholarly pursuits. Viewing Thursday, August 13th 2009, 24pm and 79pm, Heights and Hill Funeral Directors, 115 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn Heights. Mass of the Resurrection, Friday, August 14th 2009, 10am, St. Charles Borromeo Church, 21 Sidney Place, Brooklyn Heights.

LANDES--Leo J.,on August 8, 2009. Son of the late Rabbi Henry Azer and Bessie Landes. Beloved husband of Nehama, nee Rosenberg, for 61 years. Father of Diana, Susan, and Todd Cohen; and grandfather of Lindsey, Alexa, and Jaimie. Brother of Marilyn Landes, Rabbi Aaron Landes, and the late Rabbi Morris Landes. As executive head of the Joint Retirement Board for Conservative Judaism, Leo pioneered and established group insurance, pension, and retirement plans for rabbis, cantors, Jewish educators and musicians. He was a founder and the first Jewish president of the Church Alliance now known as the Church Benefits Association. He will be sorely missed by his family and the hundreds of beneficiaries of the programs he established.

DALVA--David L.,II, 73. Among his many interests in life his time spent involved in military pursuits was amongst his favorite. He joined the 101st Cavalry in 1959. He later applied and was selected for New York State's OCS Program. Two years later he received his commission as a Second Lieutenant. He stayed with the 101st until 1970 when he joined the 77th Infantry Division (RTU) where he served in a number of positions and eventually became the Assistant Chief of Staff for Operations and Training and later the Commander. When he retired, he had attained the rank of Colonel. He is a Graduate of the US Army Command & General Staff College, The Industrial College of the Armed Forces, and the Air War College. Among his many decorations are the Legion of Merit, The Army Meritorious Service Medal with one Oak Leaf Cluster, The Army Air Assault Badge, and the Expert Infantry Badge. He was also a member of the 77th USARCOM Rifle and Pistol Team, Squadron A, and New York's oldest military unit, the Veteran Corps of Artillery. Donations may be sent to: Weill-Cornell Medical Center, Prostate Cancer Research Center, 520 East 70th Street, Box 403, New York, NY 10021 or The Wounded Warrior Project, 370 Seventh Avenue, Room 320, New York, NY 10001.

KENNEDY SHRIVER--Eunice. The Board of Trustees, staff and consumers of the YAI/National Institute for People with Disabilities Network mourn the passing of Eunice Kennedy Shriver. She was a pivotal partner in our quest to build brighter futures for people with disabilities and their families. She will be greatly missed. Eliot P. Green, Chair Dr. Philip H. Levy, CEO and President The YAI/NIPD Network

In this sprawling metropolis in southeastern China stand the Longgang trash incinerators, two hulking brown buildings erected by a private company. They can be smelled a mile away and pour out so much dark smoke and hazardous chemicals that hundreds of local residents recently staged an all-day sit-in, demanding that the incinerators be cleaner and that a planned third incinerator not be built nearby. After surpassing the United States as the world's largest producer of household garbage, China has embarked on a vast program to build incinerators as landfills run out of space. But the incinerators have become a growing source of toxic emissions that can damage the body's nervous system.

GOULD--Jane S. Barnard College remembers the contributions of Jane S. Gould, class of 1940, who served as Director of Career Planning and Placement beginning in 1965, and then as the first permanent Director of the Barnard Center for Research on Women, founded in 1971, and known locally as the Women's Center. Jane guided the Center to become an established leader in the field, particularly with its world-renowned annual conference, "The Scholar and The Feminist," which is now in its 35th year. Jane's work was an invaluable contribution to the project of creating a world in which all women could, in the words of the Center's mission, live in "dignity, autonomy and equality." Condolences are offered to her extended family, friends, and colleagues. Debora L. Spar, President, and Janet R. Jakobsen, Director, Barnard Center for Research on Women.

PICKING UP WHERE SHE LEFT OFF Marion Bartoli had no idea what to expect from Kim Clijsters. Now the tennis world knows. ''The level of play, yes, it's inside the top 10 already,'' Bartoli said after Clijsters returned from a 27-month layoff with a 6-4, 6-3 victory Monday in the first round at the Western and Southern Financial Group Women's Open.

SHRIVER--Eunice Kennedy. The faculty, staff and volunteers of the Rose F. Kennedy University Center for Excellence in Developmental Disabilities (UCEDD) and its Children's Evaluation and Rehabilitation Center (CERC) at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University are deeply saddened by the loss of Eunice Kennedy Shriver. Mrs. Shriver was a driving force in advocating for the rights of the disabled and for research to ameliorate the causes and effects of intellectual disabilities. She played a central role in founding Einsteins Rose F. Kennedy Center for Research in Mental Retardation and Human Development, named after her mother, Rose. Mrs. Shiver's life-long dedication to those with developmental disabilities will continue to inspire us. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire Kennedy and Shriver families. Donald S. Faber, Ph.D. Chair, Dominick P. Purpura Department of Neuroscience Robert Marion, M.D. Director, Children's Evaluation and Rehabilitation Center (CERC) Allen M. Spiegel, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University

KENNEDY--John P.,67, of Waldwick, NJ, passed away on Sunday, August 9, 2009. Past president of Local 2 of the New York Printing Pressman's Union, he spent over 40 years as a Pressman/Journeyman at the Daily Mirror, ALCO-Gravure, The New York Post and The New York Times. A man of great abilities and great modesty, a man of his word, he was an exceptional negotiator of contracts, a shrewd steward of pension funds, and a fierce advocate for his members. He led the union in the 1990 strike of the New York Daily News. He is survived by his beloved wife Georgina, his son John, daughter-in-law Janine, daughter Elizabeth, his sister Patricia and brothers James and Joseph and seven nieces and nephews who loved and admired him. Jack loved his family, his jazz, his books and his second career as docent at The Hermitage in Ho-Ho-Kus, and as a volunteer at WBGO JAZZ 88.3 FM in Newark. He will be deeply missed. Funeral services today at Our Lady Queen of Peace in Maywood, NJ at 10:30am. Donations in his name may be made to The American Cancer Society-Bergen County Unit or WBGO JAZZ 88.3 FM in Newark.

(21) WOODSTOCK REMEMBERED This three-hour 40th-anniversary presentation looks back at the ''three days of peace and music,'' above, through performances by Jimi Hendrix, Janis Joplin, Joan Baez, Creedence Clearwater Revival, Sly and the Family Stone, the Grateful Dead, the Who, Jefferson Airplane, Santana, Levon Helm, Arlo Guthrie, Ravi Shankar, Richie Havens, John Sebastian, and Crosby, Stills, Nash and Young. It also features interviews with Henry Diltz, the official festival photographer; Susan Reynolds, the author of ''Woodstock Revisited''; Colleen Plimpton, whose mud-covered body, photographed by Newsweek, became an emblem of the festival; and Louis Salvatore Denaro, who was only 7 when he and his parents, on the way to a Catskills retreat, found themselves surrounded by hippies. 7 A.M.
