You’re traveling through another dimension: a dimension where, for 44 cents, small items of correspondence can be dropped into blue boxes that will transport them around the country in a matter of days (or sometimes not at all). Your next stop: the post office. The United States Postal Service started selling its new “Early TV Memories” stamps this week, commemorating television shows from the 1950s and ’60s. Among the performers and programs preserved on the new postage designs are Groucho Marx of “You Bet Your Life”; Jackie Gleason and Art Carney of “The Honeymooners”; Lucille Ball and Vivian Vance of “I Love Lucy”; and Rod Serling of “The Twilight Zone.” The series was introduced Tuesday at a ceremony in Los Angeles whose attendees included June Lockhart, a star of “Lassie,” whose titular collie was given its own stamp. “In all my years of working with them,” Ms. Lockhart told The Associated Press, “not one has bitten me.”

In her review of the third season of “Mad Men,” which begins on Sunday on AMC, Alessandra Stanley writes that characters “struggle in shame and secrecy with the very things that today are openly, incessantly boasted and blogged about: humble roots, broken homes, homosexuality, unwed motherhood, caring for senile parents.”

As is often the case in hip-hop, what looked like the end for Vibe magazine won’t really be the end. In June, the rap and R&B publication founded by Quincy Jones, which published its first test issue back in 1992, said that it would be shutting down immediately, having been unable to find a new buyer or restructure its debt. The Associated Press reported that Vibe and its Web site, Vibe.com, have been purchased by a group led by InterMedia Partners, a private equity fund. With the assistance of Uptown Media Group, which publishes Uptown Magazine, and Blackrock Digital, an interactive media company, the group plans to relaunch Vibe magazine in November or December and publish it on a quarterly basis. Vibe.com was expected to relaunch soon; terms of the sale were not announced.

At the end of June, the Cleveland Museum of Art was celebrating the opening of the first of three new wings designed by the architect Rafael Viñoly, marking the halfway point of the museum’s planned $350 million expansion. But on Tuesday, The Cleveland Plain Dealer reported, the museum let go 14 employees and said that it would leave another eight positions vacant as it attempts balance its budgets in the current and coming fiscal years. The Plain Dealer said that the 14 employees worked in the museum’s information technology, finance and clerical support departments, representing about 5 percent of the museum staff, and that the cuts would save the museum $1.2 million. The museum’s endowment declined to $510 million at the end of March from $821 million two years ago, and trustees said they will decide in December whether to proceed with the next major phase in its expansion. In September, the museum’s director, Timothy Rub, will leave to become director and chief executive of the Philadelphia Museum of Art.

It’s time once again for that theatrical roulette known as the New York International Fringe Festival, which runs Friday through Aug. 30: spin the wheel and if you’re lucky you’ll hit a winner, though you may well come away feeling as if you’ve just spent $15 to see someone’s bad idea. That’s what I felt after my initial Fringe exposure, and therein lies a story.

Yale University Press decided to pull 12 controversial caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad from a forthcoming book after a number of experts on Islam and counterterrorism warned that reprinting them could cause violence. When the cartoons were published in 2005 and 2006, riots erupted around the world and more than 200 people were killed. The press withdrew the drawings as well all other images of the prophet from the book, “The Cartoons That Shook the World,” which details the entire controversy. Some argue that Yale University Press’s decision is a defeat for free expression and a victory for extremists. Others maintain the removal of the images is prudent given the risk of violence. Read the full article here.

Jim Leach, the former Republican congressman from Iowa who is now a professor at Princeton University’s Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs, was sworn in on Wednesday as the ninth chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities.

The seemingly indefatigable David Cromer has taken on yet another project. In addition to directing and playing the Stage Manager in the Barrow Street Theater’s current production of Thornton Wilder’s “Our Town,” and directing “The Neil Simon Plays,” the coming repertory productions of “Brighton Beach Memoirs” and “Broadway Bound,” he will direct the American premiere of “When the Rain Stops Falling,” a new work by the Australian playwright Andrew Bovell, Lincoln Center announced on Thursday. The play by Mr. Bovell (who was also a screenwriter of Baz Luhrmann’s “Strictly Ballroom”) is a drama that spans 80 years of a family’s history in England and Australia. It is scheduled to begin previews at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater on Feb. 11 and open on March 8; a cast was not announced. “The Neil Simon Plays” begin previews of “Brighton Beach Memoirs” on Oct. 2 and “Our Town” is scheduled to run at the Barrow Street Theater through Jan. 31.
Rashied Ali, whose expressionistic, free-jazz drumming helped define the experimental style of John Coltrane’s final years, died Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 76.

For fans of Michael Jackson who feel that their appreciation can be best expressed through buying things, merchants are all too happy to supply them with Jackson-related products. Universal Motown Records said Thursday that it would release a new album called “Michael Jackson: The Remix Suite,” containing more than 20 new remixes of songs that Mr. Jackson and the Jackson 5 recorded for the label. In a news release, Motown Universal said that the album would feature reworked versions of songs including “ABC” and “Dancing Machine” (as well as a remix of “Never Can Say Goodbye” by the Neptunes), and that it would begin releasing songs for digital download on Aug. 25, followed by the complete album on Oct. 27.

Living on the Waterpod, the 3,000-square foot barge that’s been docked around New York harbor this summer, was a little like camping and a little like staying at a really far-out (in both senses) country house. I was surprised at how easy it was to adapt to the Pod’s eco-conscious systems (reuse everything, don’t mind the ever-present flies, and compost, compost, compost) and how quickly the rhythms and routines of urban life melted away. Even though the Pod was docked only blocks away, a brief visit to the farmer’s market in Dumbo one Sunday felt like a trip into “town” – and into civilization. Ooh, look! A flushing toilet!

I wonder what the folks who work on the molecular (as opposed to digital) version of The New York Times think about 1 Across. Newspapers used to make money on classified ads and now that entire revenue stream is gone. The problem with trying to sell information in the Internet age is that no matter how little you want to charge for it, someone else is willing to undercut your price or even provide a free alternative for their own broader business reasons. Try selling crossword answers for $1.49 a minute when bloggers reveal all for the price of a mouse click. How this will all shake out is anyone's guess. We live in interesting times.

In the Superior Court hearing on Thursday in Newark regarding the contested estate of the Short Hills billionaire Yung-Ching Wang, a date of Sept. 11 was set for a case management conference. Attendees included lawyers representing one of the plaintiffs -- his oldest son, Winston Wen-Young Wong, 58 -- as well as the company Mr. Wang founded, Formosa Plastics Group, along with two sets of his children from two longtime companions. Mr. Wang died at 91 in Short Hills without a will, and his estate -- which his son argues includes $7.5 billion in various trusts in Bermuda, the British Virgin Islands and the Cayman Islands, another $1 billion in a Swiss bank account, and his Short Hills mansion -- may be subject to significant estate taxes. A message left Thursday afternoon with the deputy attorney general who handles the Treasury Department's Estate and Inheritance Tax Division, to find out about the state's possible interest in the case, was not immediately answered. -- Janet Armuth Wolkoff

Even if you are a habitué of Long Beach - the beautiful white-sand strand that lies a bridge-length off Long Island between Atlantic Beach and Jones Beach State Park - the chances are good that you know only the Boardwalk, the beach and the 10-minute walk to the water from the old restored train station. You cannot go to Long Beach without enjoying the ocean, but there are other things in town to round out your excursion, according to Roslyn Bernstein, a native of the island and the author of "Boardwalk Stories," a recent collection of linked tales that use her sunburned memories of childhood as their narrative core.

ROME | Who would have thought that the Vatican could provide the ultimate Friday night out on the town? Every Friday from September 4 through October 30, the museums at the famed city-within-a-city will stay open late, so bring a date (or go solo) to enjoy its extraordinary treasures and romantic views of the papal gardens by moonlight.

I lived in Britain for three years as a student; Jackie is British; we travel to England several times a year. So I'm more or less bilingual: In a restaurant, I never ask for the check rather than the bill, and I never say bathroom when I mean toilet. But there are some things I just cannot bring myself to say. One of them is "cheese" where "and cheese" is meant, as in "macaroni cheese" instead of "macaroni and cheese" -- to my ear, the former is utterly meaningless.

Construction workers have begun to install the first of 24 giant steel columns at the site of One World Trade Center, formerly known as the Freedom Tower. The perimeter columns -- each about 60 feet long and weighing about 70 tons -- will allow the initial floors of the tower to be built out.

At Joseph Leonard, most of the food is eaten at the zinc bar, but it's far from bar food. Now going on its seventh day, the 31-seat West Village restaurant and bar has transformed a sad empanada place into a pleasantly buzzy, antiques-filled spot. There are no pulled-pork sliders or Pat La Frieda burgers here. While there is a raw bar - lobster tail and claws ($10!), oysters ($1.50 each!) and seared sardines on toast - most of the chef Jim McDuffee's offerings require a knife and fork (or spoon). A Flintstonian lamb T-bone ($17) is paired with cauliflower gratin and fried onions. A bowl of corn soup ($7) gets crispness from house-made potato chips and depth from crème fraîche. Jars of duck rillettes ($11) and brandade ($8) are about as bar-foody as it gets.

Since yesterday, TD2 has seemingly ingested quite a bit of that stable dry air I mentioned, and is now nothing more than a low-level swirl of clouds. The small circulation is also especially prone to even moderate vertical wind shear, which it's experiencing. These conditions combine to give a small likelihood that TD2 will reach TS intensity in the foreseeable future.As of 15Z today, the intensity was estimated at 25kts and 1008mb and it was located about 1400 miles east of the Leeward Islands.

The New Island Festival, the arts celebration that will take place at Governors Island next month, has released the first details of its events, and it's a little wacky. (For starters, you might end up with performers on your dinner table.) Among the highlights that have been announced for the festival (which runs from Sept. 10 through 13 and Sept. 17 through 20) are "Land," an outdoor concert that combines music made from natural sounds, musical instruments, and human voices with footage of Dutch landscapes; "Salto Vitale," in which the Dutch theater group Tuig performs acrobatic feats from a 45-foot-tall wooden structure that they assemble; and "Wind Nomads," an installation of 400 butterfly-like paintings that flap in the wind. There's also the aforementioned "Boulevard of Broken Dreams," at which short performances are presented on a football-field-long table while you eat. (In answer to your next question, yes, there are also bars.) A full roster of events can be found at newislandfestival.com.

Well, that's one Dan Brown mystery that's been tidily solved: the Knopf Doubleday Publishing Group, which previously released Mr. Brown's blockbuster novel "The Da Vinci Code," said on Thursday that it would release an electronic version of the book's follow-up, "The Lost Symbol," simultaneously with the book's hardcover incarnation. Earlier this summer, the publisher said that it was weighing plans for the release of a "Lost Symbol" e-book, as the publishing industry studies how sales of electronic books affect sales of their dead-tree counterparts. (A hardcover book usually sells for $25 to $35, while an e-book sells for less than $10; Knopf Doubleday is planning a first printing of five million copies of "The Lost Symbol.") In an email message this morning, Suzanne Herz, a spokeswoman for Knopf Doubleday, said, "Now that all of our security and logistical issues surrounding the e-book of 'The Lost Symbol' have been resolved, the e-book will be released simultaneously with the hardcover on September 15."

Researchers have debated for years whether men or women are likelier to engage in "mate poaching." Some surveys indicated that men had a stronger tendency to go after other people's partners, but was that just because men were more likely to admit engaging in this behavior? Now there's experimental evidence that single women are particularly drawn to other people's partners, according to a report in the Journal of Experimental Social Psychology by two social psychologists, Melissa Burkley and Jessica Parker of Oklahoma State University.

The San Diego Union-Tribune has announced another round of layoffs. The paper's owners, Platinum Equity, a Beverly Hills-based investment firm, declined to say how many people had been let go, or who they might be, but the names began to dribble out almost as soon as the announcement was made on Wednesday. Particularly startling was that those laid off include Robert A. Kittle, the well-known architect of the paper's conservative editorial page.

But something funny happened on the way to the junkyard. As the LedeObserver blog reports, a group of Birmingham residents, led by David Bloom, a Ford employee and local activist, and Linda Solomon, a nationally recognized photojournalist, pushed back on the demise of the print paper and may end up hearing that plop on the doorstep for many weeks to come.

School starts three weeks from today (ack!) and at least one South Orange resident has already started preparing. Michael Maier has put a fresh coat of paint on the South Orange Middle School weather vane, which he created. "I have to do that every few years, because the elements really beat it up," he said. The United States Chamber of Commerce has taken to the airwaves, already cluttered with health care ads, with the goal of defeating the idea of a government-run health insurance option. Chamber officials would not discuss the amount they are spending but said it was "multimillions of dollars," making this ad buy one of the biggest by a single group so far in the health care debate. The ads began running on Wednesday on network television in 20 states; while dozens of other groups have released ads, most of them are running on cable and the Internet, which are much cheaper than the networks.

Things are coming to a head in the saga to sell Opel. General Motors' European unit said on Thursday on its Web site that Magna International and its partner Sberbank had "clarified" their offer for the European automaker, and that the bid would be duly considered by G.M.'s board.

Remember when the cast of "Dawson's Creek" modeled in the J. Crew catalog and suddenly everyone was wearing those rollneck sweaters? J. Crew has come a long way from the East Coast prep look it once embodied. Now it's a (relatively) affordable style resource for many types of guys, offering versatile suiting for the office man, some broken-in chinos for the outdoorsy guy to wear with a Barbour jacket and, for the arty hipster, a secret-wash shirt paired with vintage jeans. Speaking of jeans, Frank Muytjens, the company's vice president of men's design, tells us about the debut of the Levi's Vintage collection at the men's stores (available for sale as of today) and gives us a little insight into life at J. Crew H.Q.

Though her work lovingly depicts a world and time anchored deeply in the past, Marcey Jacobson was rooted in the present. As recently as two months ago, at the age of 97, she was helping to prepare an exhibition of more than 100 images that she had taken from the 1960s to the 1980s in her adopted home of San Cristóbal de las Casas, in the Chiapas highlands of southern Mexico. She died July 26, leaving behind "an incredible historical and ethnographic document of a time long gone by in this blessed corner of the earth," said Janet Schwartz, her friend and executor. That legacy - some 14,000 negatives - is to be housed at the Na Bolom Cultural Association in San Cristóbal. Ms. Schwartz shared what few photos have been scanned with the Lens blog.

The hedge fund run by John Paulson, who foresaw the distress in subprime mortgages and reaped billions by betting against the related securities, has bought about 168 million shares of Bank of America, according to a regulatory filing Wednesday.

Legg Mason on Wednesday announced the final results of its offer to exchange its outstanding debt in the firm for common stock and cash. Debt holders agreed to swap 20.9 million, or 91 percent, of the 21.8 million debt units.

When is the right time to quit the hedge fund rat race? For Tim Barakett at Atticus Capital, it's at 44 with $1 billion in the bank, but near the bottom of his game. That's not ideal, but at least it's honest to hand back money when your heart's not in the job. Others make the mistake of hanging on too long and being forced to give up, Breakingviews.com writes.

The California Public Employees' Retirement System, or Calpers, has injected $60 million into a seed-stage fund at Khosla Ventures that has thus far raised $250 million, The San Francisco Business Times reported.

Investment banks say it's all different now. Familiar refrain. They realized too late that profiting from cheap short-term borrowing wouldn't last. Now they're hawking the benefits of a risk-light business model rooted in trading for clients, Breakingviews.com writes.

An article on Aug. 4 about a judge’s ruling granting permanent custody of Michael Jackson’s three children to his mother, Katherine Jackson, and an editors’ note last Thursday, said that lawyers for Mrs. Jackson were considering challenging the two executors of Mr. Jackson’s will on the grounds that they allegedly took advantage of addictions that incapacitated him and impaired his judgment. That allegation was attributed to “people close to the Jackson family who asked not to be named,” and in later copies of the newspaper the original article reported that a spokesman for the executors denied it. Times editors should not have published the anonymously made accusation, unsupported in the article by any evidence or publicly available corroboration — with or without a denial.

DEVOTEES of tanning aren’t the only ones who might be distressed over the recent reclassification by the International Agency for Research on Cancer of tanning beds as “carcinogenic.” Eczema sufferers who lack access to physician-administered light treatments have long used commercially available ultraviolet tanning beds to control their outbreaks.

A recent report on cancer risk may make tanning options without UV rays more attractive.

The filmmaker John Hughes was buried Tuesday after a private ceremony at a funeral home in Lake Forest, Ill., north of Chicago, The Chicago Tribune reported. Mr. Hughes, a longtime North Shore resident who paid tribute to the area in films like “Ferris Bueller’s Day Off,” died of a heart attack in Manhattan on Thursday. He was 59. The funeral service was attended by the actors Vince Vaughn and Matthew Broderick, the star of “Ferris Bueller,” as well as Ben Stein, the actor and commentator who played a droning high school teacher in that film and was a longtime friend of Mr. Hughes. Speaking of Mr. Hughes, Mr. Stein told The Tribune: “We’ll never see his like again. He was the Wordsworth of the suburban America postwar generation. He was a great, great, great genius and as much of a friend and a great family man as he was a poet.”.

The Academy of Television Arts & Sciences reversed course on Wednesday and said it would present all 28 awards during its live broadcast on CBS on Sept. 20, eliminating a plan to pretape some of the awards, which drew stiff opposition from television writers and cable networks. The academy had planned to record and edit the presentation of eight awards to allow for more time to celebrate shows that are popular with the public but that might not have been nominated. The plan was to try to increase ratings after viewers told the academy last year that the awards focus too much on shows that are unfamiliar to the public. Members of at least two unions — the Writers Guild of America, West and the Directors Guild of America — opposed the plan, as did HBO, which usually dominates the movie and mini-series categories that were scheduled for taping. The academy also faced the prospect that the unions would force it to pay substantial fees for the clips of television shows it uses during the broadcast. In a statement an academy official said it reversed the plan “to mend relationships within the television community.”.

A two-hour installment of “America’s Got Talent” attracted an average of 12.5 million viewers on Tuesday, lifting NBC to No. 1 for the night, according to Nielsen’s estimates. CBS earned a second-place finish over all with a lineup that included “Big Brother” (6.9 million). Fox was third with “Hell’s Kitchen” at 8 (6.7 million) and “More to Love” at 9 (3.9 million). ABC ranked fourth as “Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?” (5.9 million) slipped in the ratings. The two-part finale of ABC’s “Better Off Ted” drew just 2.6 million viewers.

An angry Russian woman pulled a teacup out of her purse and threw it at the Mona Lisa, above, on Aug. 2, the Louvre said on Tuesday. The Leonardo masterpiece, which is protected by bulletproof glass, was undamaged. “The work is intact, and viewing was only disturbed the time it took to pick up the pieces,” said David Madec, a Louvre spokesman. The woman was taken to the police psychiatric infirmary. “She was clearly deranged,” a police spokesman said. This is the latest in a long history of attacks on the portrait, which was stolen in 1911 by an Italian nationalist before being returned in 1913. In 1956 it was doused with acid. Later that same year a man damaged the painting by throwing a rock at it.

In the introduction to his essay collection “The Wicked Son: Anti-Semitism, Self-Hatred and the Jews,” David Mamet offered the book, in part, to readers “whose favorite Jew is Anne Frank and whose second-favorite does not exist.” We presume he won’t be quite as provocative with his next project, a new film version of “The Diary of Anne Frank,” which Mr. Mamet is writing and directing for Disney. Variety reported that Mr. Mamet’s script would combine the original diary, written by Anne Frank while she and her family hid from Nazis in Amsterdam, with the stage play written by Albert Hackett and Frances Goodrich and new material from Mr. Mamet. A 1959 film version of “The Diary of Anne Frank,” directed by George Stevens, won three Academy Awards and was nominated for best picture; it has also been adapted for television several times and was revived on Broadway in 1997, featuring Natalie Portman. A cast and release date for Mr. Mamet’s version were not announced.

The Autry National Center of the American West in Los Angeles has withdrawn its $175 million plan to expand its museum complex in Griffith Park, blaming “virtually endless official delays” and threatened litigation. The expansion would have created new exhibition space for the extensive collection of American Indian artifacts that the Autry gained when it merged its Museum of the American West, endowed by the cowboy singer and actor Gene Autry, with the Southwest Southwest the American Indian in 2003. The Southwest Museum was formerly housed in a landmark white adobe building that was damaged in the 1994 Northridge earthquake, and its collections were later found to be suffering from severe neglect. Neighborhood groups wanted a commitment to keep the building as a functioning museum. But John L. Gray, the Autry president, said in a letter to museum supporters Tuesday that the cost of and delays in the approval process for its plan were no longer supportable. The museum said it would continue to use its existing facilities, both in Griffith Park and at Mount Washington, for exhibitions.

So, what’s in the news today? Have you heard about this? The Writers Guild of America said it would not discipline Jay Leno for continuing to deliver his “Tonight Show” monologues while the guild was on strike, Variety reported. In a message sent to its membership on Tuesday, the Writers Guild of America, West said it would take no further action against Mr. Leno, the former “Tonight Show” host and a guild member, who was accused of violating the guild’s rules. The writers’ strike began on Nov. 5, 2007, and concluded on Feb. 12, 2008; “Tonight” was in reruns until Jan. 2, 2008, when Mr. Leno, who supported the strike, resumed performing monologues that he composed without his writers. Mr. Leno met with a guild panel in February to answer questions about the matter, and could have been punished with a fine, suspension or expulsion.

If a certain presidential election distracted you from the New York Comedy Festival last November, you have no excuse for missing out this year, especially now that all the nation’s political disputes have been completely resolved. On Wednesday the festival’s organizers announced the lineup for this year’s event, which will run from Nov. 4 through 8, and it’s a formidable crop: Andy Samberg, top left, the “Saturday Night Live” star; the sometime film actor Dane Cook, bottom right; the “Howard Stern Show” regular (and “Joe Buck Live” hijacker) Artie Lange; as well as Patton Oswalt, Mike Birbiglia, top right, Bill Burr and Mike Epps, bottom left. They join the previously announced headliners Ricky Gervais (who performs on Nov. 5 at Carnegie Hall), Tracy Morgan (Nov. 6 at Carnegie) and Bill Maher (Nov. 8 at Avery Fisher Hall). More than 150 comedians are expected to perform over the course of the festival; panel discussions at the Paley Center for Media are also planned, with those lineups still to be announced.

Stephen Rea and Sean McGinley, who originated the two roles in Sam Shepard’s “Ages of the Moon” when it had its premiere at the Abbey Theater in Dublin, will reprise those characters for the Atlantic Theater Company’s production of the play. On Wednesday publicists for the Atlantic Theater Company said Mr. Rea (of the film “The Crying Game” and “Someone Who’ll Watch Over Me” on Broadway) and Mr. McGinley would return to the characters of Byron and Ames, two longtime friends who are reunited in middle age. The play, which is Mr. Shepard’s first for the Atlantic, will begin previews at the Linda Gross Theater on Jan. 12 and open on Jan. 27. Its limited engagement runs through March 7. The Atlantic Theater Company also said that the final main stage production of its 2009-10 season would be “Gabriel” by the British playwright Moira Buffini. Set during World War II, it tells the story of a man who washes up on the island of Guernsey, able to speak German and English but unsure of who he is. The play is expected to begin previews in April and open in May; casting has not yet been announced.

Seven weeks since his death Michael Jackson continues to dominate record sales, though his competition lately has not been very strong. Once again Mr. Jackson’s “Number Ones” (Epic) was the best-selling album in the United States last week, with 98,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan. His other titles, particularly “Thriller” and “The Essential Michael Jackson,” also continue to rack up significant sales; in total, about 3.7 million Jackson albums have been sold since his death on June 25. The best-selling new album last week was “Live on the Inside” by the country duo Sugarland, which was released by Mercury Nashville through an exclusive retail deal with Wal-Mart. It sold 76,000 copies, enough to reach No. 1 on Billboard’s standard album chart, the Billboard 200. (Most Jackson titles are too old to qualify for it.) The next five spots on the chart are a photo finish, with each title scoring between 44,000 and 45,000 sales. Vol. 31 of the pop compilation series “Now That’s What I Call Music!” is No. 2, and another country group, Gloriana, is No. 3 with its new, self-titled debut album, on Warner Brothers. The Black Eyed Peas are No. 4 with “The E.N.D.” (Interscope), the Kings of Leon’s “Only by the Night” (RCA) is No. 5, and Daughtry’s “Leave This Town” (RCA) is No. 6.

India is struggling to cope with the spread of swine flu, with at least 17 deaths confirmed from the virus and nearly 1,200 diagnosed cases. The outbreak has caused panic in much of the country, with schools, theaters and shopping malls closing in many places. The government is grappling with competing and sometimes conflicting goals: preventing widespread panic, but preparing for the worst. It has made available tens of thousands of test kits and has built up a stock of 20 million doses of a generic version of the antiflu drug Tamiflu.

MILLER--Irving. 86, of Plainview, NY and Boynton Beach, FL. Beloved and devoted father, grandfather, husband, brother, uncle and cousin on August 10, 2009. Survived by his children Marcie (Lars), Nancy, Wayne (Lisa), Rhonda (Scott), and grandchildren Cara, Laura, Samantha, Sandra, Sarah and Ethan, predeceased by his wife Sadie, their mother and grandmother. Survived by his wife Lorraine and sister Harriet. He will be deeply missed.

The European Ryder Cup captain Colin Montgomerie is in the P.G.A. Championship field on an exemption given to him and to the United States captain Corey Pavin. He said he hoped to use the opportunity to play well and possibly contend in the tournament, and to connect with the potential team members among the 31 other Europeans in the field. Like any team captain, he began by fretting about an injured player.

WOLK--Brad Lawrence, age 50. Father of Adam, husband of Jana Ertrachter, son of Dale and Dick, brother of Jeffrey. Loved by all, passed away August 11th. Services at Gutterman's, Sunrise Highway, Rockville Centre, NY, 10am, Thursday, August 13. Brad you are missed by all. Your Family and Friends

Phil Mickelson arrived here Tuesday night after spending a couple of days at home in California with his wife and mother, who are undergoing treatment for breast cancer. Mickelson said both were doing well and that he was confident he would play well in the final major of the season, the P.G.A. Championship. ''I felt I had a really good week last week, even though I didn't play well or score the way I wanted to,'' Mickelson said Wednesday, referring to the W.G.C.-Bridgestone Invitational, where he tied for 58th at seven over par in his first event since his stirring runner-up finish at the United States Open.

Sony claims to have solved a problem we all grapple with: getting good photos in low light without resorting to an ambience-killing flash. The company announced two Cyber-shot point-and-shoot cameras with low-light sensors that it said would deliver sharp images -- bright lighting not necessary. The two new Cyber-shots, the $380 DSC-TX1 and the $350 DSC-WX1, deliver better light sensitivity because of Sony's Exmor R back-illuminated sensor, first available on the DSC-HX1.

PULLMAN--Clifford. The Fresh Air Fund and its Board of Directors are saddened by the passing of Clifford Pullman, cherished Fresh Air friend and husband of The Fund's Development Director Lori Seader. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Lori's entire family, long-standing supporters of The Fund. He leaves behind his beloved wife Lori and daughter Elizabeth, mother Shirley Pullman, his sister and brother-in-law Marjorie and Steve Pollock, nieces Lauren and Meredith Pollock, mother-in-law Sissy Seader, and sisters and brothers-in-law Andrea Seader, Sam Harrison, Michael Seader and Laurie Loweecey, along with his truly special aunts, uncles and cousins of the Gallant family. Clifford was the owner of hardware store B & S Supply Co. in Hackensack, New Jersey. He will be deeply missed by all. The funeral will be held Friday, August 14th at 11:45am at Riverside Chapel in New York City. Mrs. Donald Newhouse, Chairman of The Fresh Air Fund Jenny Morgenthau, Executive Director of The Fresh Air Fund The Fresh Air Fund staff members

SAMUEL--Fred A. 89, passed away on Friday, August 7, 2009 of cardiac arrest in Aventura, Florida. Fred was born in Rodalben, Germany November 8, 1919. As part of a youth aliyah movement in the 1930's he became a member of Kibbutz Gan Shmuel and Kibbutz Sarid, before coming to America as a young man with a young family. He built one of the most respected cabinetmaking firms in New York. Beloved father and father-in-law of Reuben and Janet Bartucci Samuel. Devoted grandfather of Alexandra and David Samuel and Blake and Betsy Tannen. Fred was pre-deceased by his adored wife, Eleanor Tannen Samuel, as well as his first wife, Esther Samuel. Fred was a true friend to many. His warmth, elegance and friendship will be sorely missed by all who knew him. He was truly a man of the twentieth century. A Memorial Service will be held at 10am Monday, August 17th at Scarsdale Synagogue Temples Tremont and Emanu-El. 2 Ogden Road, Scarsdale. For directions www.sstt.org. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Fred's honor to ARZA or the Anti-Defamation League. The family will receive visitors Monday at their home in Scarsdale.

The most interesting thing about T-Mobile's new myTouch smartphone isn't the phone itself. It's a nice phone with much better battery life than the first Android phone, the G1. But more interesting are two apps that T-Mobile has been promoting heavily. One is a smart example of what an app should be, and the other is a missed opportunity. The smart example is Sherpa, an app that learns your likes and dislikes, then makes recommendations of nearby restaurants, shopping and such, wherever you go.

ZEISEL--Henry I.,89, beloved Husband of Gloria for 67 years, Father of Dr. Cheryl (Abe) Kramer, Dr. Elliot (Mary) Zeisel, Howard Zeisel, LCSW, and Debbie (Sam) Moed. Grandfather of eight, and Great-Grandfather of ten. Brother of Murray Zeisel. President of Accura - Zeisel Machinery Corp. and an industry leader. A founder of the Community Synagogue of Monsey and HIRC/ASHAR, a graduate and generous benefactor of Yeshiva University. Master of many languages who used his skills to welcome one and all, and was always available to those in need. An intellect whose interests ranged from Judaica to geography Henry was a colorful man who had a beautiful voice. Funeral, August 12th, Shiva observed at the Zeisel residence.

SHRIVER--Eunice Kennedy. The world all over has lost a Giant of a Woman - Eunice Kennedy Shriver, and she was a very special Gift from God! We have been deeply blessed all of these years by this valiant and dedicated woman who founded the Special Olympics, who gave hope and love to hundreds of millions of people with intellectual disabilities. We also shared a great love for our beloved Blessed Mother Teresa and tried to live by her words. To quote Mother: "Intense loved does not measure, it just gives." "The world today is hungry not only for bread but hungry for love, hungry to be wanted, and to be loved." "If we pray we will believe; if we believe, we will love, if we love we will serve." These quotes all epitomize the life of Eunice Kennedy Shriver. Once again, we thank Almighty God for putting Eunice in this world. Eunice will long be remembered and ever loved by the people she touched and will truly be missed! The D'Urso family feels privileged to have known Eunice, as a special close friend, we will treasure our friendship forever. We love Eunice dearly. I thank Almighty God for putting Eunice in my life. When Eunice met Our Lord and His Blessed Mother Our Lord said, "Well done, thy good and most Faithful Servant!" As one of His apostles who walked on this earth helping those with special needs, I know Our Lord welcomed Eunice to heaven with open loving arms, and as her reward He will make her a new saint. With a heavy heart Florence D'Urso and her family send their profound sympathy and dearest love to her devoted and loving husband Sarge and their children all the Shriver and Kennedy families.

The Starter Garden traces the progress of the writer's first vegetable garden, in Minneapolis. An excerpt: HOW many days remain in summer? President Óscar Arias of Costa Rica, who is trying to negotiate an end to the political standoff in Honduras, said in a statement late Tuesday he had contracted swine flu. ''Apart from the fever and a sore throat, I feel well and in good shape to carry out my work by telecommuting,'' he said. Mr. Arias is one of 865 in Costa Rica who have contracted the H1N1 flu virus, officials said. There have been 28 reported deaths there.

WEEKENDS at the Surf Lodge in Montauk, N.Y., are one part Summer of Love, two parts California Dreamin', its hippie deluxe aura preserved in details like the whitewashed walls and porch swings -- and the laid-back crowd it sedulously cultivates. On a recent weekend, this boutique motel, on Fort Pond, drew a mix of pro surfers, haute Bohemians and summer Hamptonites chasing the scene. A handful of regulars provided the color. Chris Pfund (center, second from bottom), a Montauk native, showed off a weathered tan and corkscrew ponytail. Tracy Feith (bottom, far left), who designs airy frocks for his in-house boutique, played out the surfside fantasy, with his sun-parched hair, frayed shorts and flip-flops. The picture of surfer style, he cheerfully billboards what he has identified as ''the authenticity that everyone is trying to find in the marketplace.''

Google Sky Map, a free app available only on Android phones, merges a phone's GPS and compass with date and time to show you a map of the sky from where you are standing. It charts stars, constellations, planets and Messier objects (that's basically everything else in the sky), oriented with or without a grid and horizon line. Rotate the phone and celestial bodies pan by. Manual mode lets you move the map without waving the handset.

WHEN it comes to summertime relaxation, the idea of an outdoor picnic -- complete with a nice bottle of wine -- is hard to beat. One of the hardest tricks to pull off, however, is keeping the wine chilled along the way, particularly if the trip involves a car ride. ''You can always pack white or red wine in an ice bath in a cooler; you won't harm wine by chilling it that way,'' said Elliott Mackey, publisher of the Wine Appreciation Guild, a supplier of wine books and accessories.

NACHTRAB--Frank Charles, Sr. 91, of Raleigh, formerly of Ridgewood, NY, died Monday, August 10, 2009 at his home in Raleigh. (CNN) GENERATION ISLAM Christiane Amanpour, above, travels to Afghanistan, Pakistan and Gaza to report on the battle for the hearts and minds of Muslim youth, who are especially vulnerable to recruitment by extremist groups. Her subjects include 12-year-old Nassim, who was cast out of his home after his father took a new wife, and his 15-year-old brother, Alahdad, who was taken in by a fundamentalist madrasa in Taliban country; Dr. Izzeldin Abuelaish, a Palestinian obstetrician in Gaza and Nobel Peace Prize nominee whose three daughters were killed by Israeli shells during the war this year between Israel and Hamas; and 35 children at a Gaza preschool, many of whom lost their homes or a parent in that same battle -- and one-third of whom say they want to become martyrs. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Khloe and Kourtney Kardashian are the guests; also ambush makeovers and affordable cruises.

The $150 Sound Blaster Wireless for iTunes, from Creative, streams music on a laptop to your stereo's amplifier and speakers anywhere -- well, almost anywhere -- in your house. The starter kit, for $150, includes a U.S.B. dongle for a Mac or PC, and a single receiver with 35 millimeter and RCA stereo output jacks. Additional receivers for stereo equipment in other rooms are sold for $70 each. Creative's device employs old tech -- streaming along the ancient 2.4-gigahertz frequency -- but the results, for the most part, are seamless.

British inflation may well remain below the central bank's 2 percent target in coming years, the Bank of England said Wednesday, forecasting that an economic recovery would take time because the recession ''appeared deeper than previously estimated.'' ''Inflation is more likely to be below target in the medium term than above,'' the bank said in its quarterly Inflation Report.

The British financial regulator issued rules on Wednesday governing bonus payments by banks, but it backpedaled on recommendations to defer payment because of concerns the restrictions would hurt the country's competitiveness as a financial center. After a five-month consultation period, the Financial Services Authoritypublished its final code, effective in January, that aims to keep banks from paying bonuses that are guaranteed for more than one year or that are several times a banker's salary.

A lawyer for J. D. Salinger has asked an appeals court to uphold an injunction on a novel that was ruled to be an illegal sequel to Mr. Salinger’s “The Catcher in the Rye.”

After an injury-plagued road trip that culminated with its lead singer, Steven Tyler, falling from a stage, the rock band Aerosmith said that it had canceled the remaining dates of its summer tour. In a news release sent late Thursday night, the band said that it was “in a state of shock” and, with “great regret,” it would not be able to complete its AeroForceOne tour, scheduled to end on Sept. 16 in Detroit.

One of the most famous novels about book burning, “Fahrenheit 451” by Ray Bradbury, is the subject of a graphic novel adaptation by Tim Hamilton. The illustrated edition, which has been released in both hardcover and softcover, is No. 6 on our softcover list this week. The new version comes with the cooperation of Mr. Bradbury, a fact proudly touted by the word “authorized” on the cover. In a video interview at the Web site of Macmillan, the graphic novel’s publisher, Mr. Bradbury discusses his book and its transformation into a graphic novel.

The Cleveland Museum of Art said that Deborah Gribbon, the former director of the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles, would serve as its interim director while the Cleveland Museum searches for someone to fill the position permanently. In a news release on Thursday, the Cleveland Museum said that Ms. Gribbon, who served as the Getty’s director from 2000 to 2004, would officially take the position of interim director on Sept. 21. She succeeds Timothy Rub, who is leaving to become director and chief executive of the Philadelphia Museum of Art. Ms. Gribbon previously held several positions at the Getty, including Associate Director and Chief Curator, but resigned there after clashing with Barry Munitz, who was then the president and chief executive of the J. Paul Getty Trust. On Tuesday, the Cleveland Museum said that it was laying off 14 employees and leaving another eight positions vacant as it attempts to balance its budget.

The church council of the Sicilian city of Caltagirone has canceled a planned performance of the Mascagni opera “Cavalleria Rusticana,” saying that the work was ”immoral” and inappropriate during a three-day long feast for the city’s patron saint, the Italian news agency ANSA reported. The Caltagirone Curia said that portions of the opera, which was to be presented during the feast of Maria Santissima Del Ponte, “contrasted with the religious festivity and the sacredness of the family” and could not be performed, ANSA said. The opera, often performed on a double bill with “Pagliacci,” tells of a soldier who returns to his Sicilian village to find that his lover has married another man; more affairs and a deadly duel follow. Gianfranco Piluso, who was to direct the opera for the festival, said that the council’s decision was an act of “cultural obscurantism,” according to ANSA.

With three different gigs on David Cromer‘s plate, you knew that one of them would have to go: on Friday, publicists for the Barrow Street Theater production of “Our Town” said that Mr. Cromer would depart the role of the Stage Manager, and would be succeeded by Jason Butler Harner in the play (which Mr. Cromer also directed). Mr. Harner, who made his Broadway debut as Ivan Turgenev in Tom Stoppard’s trilogy “The Coast of Utopia,” and appeared earlier this year in “The Gingerbread House” at Rattlestick Playwrights Theater, will take over the “Our Town” role on Aug. 25. Mr. Cromer is leaving to direct “The Neil Simon Plays,” in which “Brighton Beach Memoirs” and “Broadway Bound” will be performed in repertory on Broadway; he will also direct Andrew Bovell’s play “When the Rain Stops Falling” for Lincoln Center Theater.

“Saving Grace,” a TNT series that explores the criminal world through adetective’s eyes, and “Reno 911!,” a Comedy Central show that has mined that world forlaughs, are ending their respective runs on cable TV.

“Battlestar Galactica,” the thinking person’s science-fiction saga, is about to be remade yet again, this time as a big-budget Hollywood feature to be directed by Bryan Singer, Variety reported. The original “Battlestar Galactica,” about a star ship carrying the last human survivors from a distant group of planets, made its debut as a television series in 1978, amid the fanfare over “Star Wars” (and just ahead of the first batch of “Star Trek” movies). That first series ran for only one season, and a revival, “Galactica 1980,” was even shorter-lived. But the franchise recently found new acclaim with a reimagined “Battlestar Galactica” series on that ended its run on the Sci Fi channel in March. Mr. Singer, the director of “X-Men,” “Superman Returns” and “Valkyrie,” will be directing his film for Universal and producing with Glen A. Larson, the “Battlestar Galactica” creator. No release date or casting was announced, and it was unclear if any talent from previous incarnations of the show would be involved with the movie.

A jazz musician takes musical matter and, without much detailed planning or many written notes, spins out lines into uncharted space. The great ones surprise us as their solos unwind, but their sound is always identifiable. Jimmy Katz, the photographer who generally works with his wife Dena Katz, compares their picture-taking to that kind of music-making. They struggle, he says, to capture spontaneity and maintain a consistent look.

As an impresario tells Jimmy and Dena Katz in their eye-popping book "World of Wonders": "In its heyday, around 1950, there were 104 traveling sideshows touring America. "Summer reading? Good. Assigned reading? Bad." That's how Lisa Von Drasek, a children's librarian at the Bank Street College of Education in Manhattan, sums up her criticism of many summer reading lists: they're simply too short and too weighed down by good-for-you classics. Bank Street's own lists don't make that mistake. They're imaginative, wide-ranging and (helpfully) organized by age. Also extensive (and organized by subject) are the lists at the Cooperative Children's Book Center at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. (Just for the record, we know some 11 year olds who, forced to read "The Hobbit" in between educational reruns of "Star Trek," are by now thoroughly enjoying it. Hey, it's a great book.)

The publication of the women's fall fashion issue this weekend marks T Magazine's fifth anniversary. To celebrate we invited five visionaries -- the architect Frank Gehry and the artists Jenny Holzer, Francesco Vezzoli, Jeff Koons and the Starn brothers -- to have their way with the T logo for five different covers. The bonus candle on the cake comes from Karl Lagerfeld, whose glitzy interpretation of the T opens the fashion well. And speaking of fashion, T's cover star, Carey Mulligan, also gets an extreme makeover -- by no less than Marc Jacobs, Stefano Pilati, Alber Elbaz, Miuccia Prada and Nicolas Ghesquière, all of whom reimagined the young actress in fall's leading fashion roles. (See Mulligan's screen test with Lynn Hirschberg here.) And those are just some of the highlights. The magazine itself got a bit of a face-lift in the form of a redesign. Think of it as our birthday present to ourselves -- and also to you.

Pedro E. Guerrero, born in 1917 in Casa Grande, Ariz., is a photographer of architecture and artists. His subjects have included Frank Lloyd Wright, Alexander Calder, Louise Nevelson ... and Julia Child. He worked for many years as a freelancer for magazines such as House & Garden, taking on assignments ranging from then-new modernist houses in Connecticut to John Huston's stately Georgian manor in Ireland. A capable cook, he insists on authentic albondigas (no rice!) and chile con carne (no beans!). He says the two most interesting kitchens he ever shot were Julia Child's and Louisa Calder's -- but that's another story.

An obituary on Aug. 5 about the Modernist architect Charles Gwathmey was erroneously corrected in this space on Tuesday. As the obituary correctly noted, Mr. Gwathmey began college at the University of Pennsylvania and then transferred as an undergraduate to Yale, from which he graduated with a master’s degree in architecture in 1962. He did not, as the correction said, earn a bachelor’s degree from the University of Pennsylvania in 1961.

The High and Low Finance column on Aug. 7, about General Electric’s accounting, referred incorrectly to an allegation by the Securities and Exchange Commission regarding G.E.’s accounting for a railroad locomotive transaction. An article last Friday about the collision on the Taconic Parkway that killed eight people misstated the purpose of tests on the eyeball fluid of Diane Schuler, the driver who caused the wreck. The seemingly indefatigable David Cromer, below, has taken on yet another project. In addition to directing and playing the Stage Manager in the Barrow Street Theater’s current production of “Our Town” and directing “The Neil Simon Plays,” the coming repertory productions of “Brighton Beach Memoirs” and “Broadway Bound,” he will direct the American premiere of “When the Rain Stops Falling,” a new work by the Australian playwright Andrew Bovell, Lincoln Center Theater announced on Thursday. The play by Mr. Bovell (who was also a screenwriter of Baz Luhrmann’s “Strictly Ballroom”) is a drama that spans 80 years of a family’s history in England and Australia. It is scheduled to begin previews at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater on Feb. 11 and open on March 8; a cast was not announced. “The Neil Simon Plays” begin previews of “Brighton Beach Memoirs” on Oct. 2, and “Our Town” is scheduled to run through Jan. 31.

At the end of June the Cleveland Museum of Art was celebrating the opening of the east wing gallery, above, the first of three new wings designed by the architect Rafael Viñoly, signifying the halfway point of the museum’s planned $350 million expansion. But on Tuesday, The Cleveland Plain Dealer reported, the museum laid off 14 employees and said it would leave another 8 positions vacant as it tried to balance its budgets for the current and coming fiscal years. The Plain Dealer said that the 14 employees worked in the museum’s information technology, finance and clerical support departments, representing about 5 percent of the museum staff, and that the cuts would save $1.2 million. The museum’s endowment declined to $510 million at the end of March, from $821 million two years ago, and trustees said they would decide in December whether to proceed with the next major phase in its expansion. In September the museum’s director, Timothy Rub, will leave to become director and chief executive of the Philadelphia Museum of Art.

Jim Leach, above left, the former Republican congressman from Iowa who is now a professor at Princeton University in the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs, was sworn in on Wednesday as the ninth chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities. Mr. Leach was confirmed by the Senate on Aug. 7, along with Rocco Landesman, above right, the new chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts. Also on Wednesday, Mr. Landesman, 62, was sworn in by Romy Scott, assistant to the director of human resources at the arts endowment; a ceremonial swearing-in is expected at a later date. Mr. Leach, 66, was sworn in by Michael McDonald, the acting deputy chairman and general counsel of the humanities endowment. Mr. Leach, who represented southeastern Iowa in the House for 30 years, founded and served as co-chairman of the Congressional Humanities Caucus. He was also chairman of the Banking and Financial Services Committee and the Subcommittee on Asian and Pacific Affairs. Mr. Leach joined Princeton after leaving Congress in 2007. ... Eva J. Pell, the senior vice president for research and the dean of the graduate school at Pennsylvania State University, has been named under secretary for science at the Smithsonian Institution. Among other duties she will oversee the operations of the National Museum of Natural History, the National Air and Space Museum and the National Zoo.

Two explosions in southern Afghanistan killed 14 people, including 3 children at play, Afghan officials said Thursday, as mounting violence before next week's elections exacts an increasing toll on civilians caught up in the broadening war with the Taliban. Dawoud Ahmadi, a spokesman for the Helmand provincial authorities, said a roadside bomb exploded next to a van carrying civilians, killing 11, including 2 women, in the province's Gereshk district. ''The Taliban have planted mines everywhere,'' Mr. Ahmadi said. ''That's why most of the time, civilians are the targets.''

An obituary on Aug. 5 about the Modernist architect Charles Gwathmey was erroneously corrected in this space on Tuesday. As the obituary correctly noted, Mr. Gwathmey began college at the University of Pennsylvania and then transferred as an undergraduate to Yale, from which he graduated with a master's degree in architecture in 1962. He did not, as the correction said, earn a bachelor's degree from the University of Pennsylvania in 1961. An e-mail message to The Times on Aug. 6 from a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania said that Mr. Gwathmey received his bachelor's degree there. The correction was based on an online alumni directory.

France has a long tradition of drawing on colonial troops to help fight in its wars. As long ago as the end of the 18th century, Napoleon used troops from the French colonies in his Egypt campaign. More recently, soldiers from countries like Senegal, Morocco, Mali, Algeria and Cambodia have fought under the tricolor, either during the two world wars or in subsequent campaigns in places like Indochina and Algeria.

DEALY--Francis X.,Jr. (Bud), 71, of Greenwich, CT, passed away on August 10, 2009 after a lengthy illness. Beloved husband of Ellen, nee Fairbanks, for 25 years. Father of Patrick of Rhinebeck, NY, Brendan of Auburndale, MA, Christopher of New York, NY (sons of his first marriage to Jane, nee Sim), Maximilian, Samson, and John (Beau), all of Greenwich. Survived also by his sisters, Mary Pohlschroeder of Wilton, CT and Dona Dealy of San Francisco, CA, seven grandchildren and numerous nieces and nephews. Mr. Dealy was an advertising executive (Wells, Rich, Green), a magazine publisher (Dow Jones, New York Times and CBS), an award winning author (Win at Any Cost: The SellOut of College Athletics and The Power and the Money: Inside the Wall Street Journal). More recently he worked in real estate and wrote a popular weekly column for a local newspaper in Greenwich, CT. His abilities and passions were legendary: he was a tennis player, a marathoner, a cyclist, an orator and a skier. He loved his family, friends, the written word, Italy, the NYAC, Lake Kezar, London, and especially, in recent years, watching his younger sons play the sports he loved. He will be deeply missed. Calling hours are from 5-8pm on August 16th, at Leo P. Gallagher Funeral Home, 31 Arch Street, Greenwich, and a service will take place at 11am on August 17th at Christ Church, 254 East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Boys and Girls Club of Greenwich would be appreciated.

'ADAM' (PG-13, 1:38) He (Hugh Dancy) has Asperger's syndrome; she (Rose Byrne) has daddy issues; together they learn to cope. Considering the story's twee details -- his passion is the heavens, hers is teaching tiny children -- Max Mayer's charming romantic comedy is more involving than you might expect. The humor is delicate, the performances sweet and sure and the Manhattan locations (lovingly photographed by Seamus Tierney) have a starry-eyed glaze. (Jeannette Catsoulis) 'ALIENS IN THE ATTIC' (PG, 1:29) Little green critters invade Earth with the help of a mind-control device that works only on adults; five youngsters must save the world while keeping their parents in the dark. The real challenge: staying interested in what's basically an overblown cable movie. (Mike Hale)

FAGAN--Robert A.,writer, poet, and independent scholar in literature and art history, died July 25, 2009, in New York City at age 74. He is survived by his wife Lenore Parker of New York City, stepson Donald Parker, his wife Amy, and step-grandchildren Jim and Rachel Parker of Brookline, Massachusetts; sisters Joan Rohn of Hampton Bays, New York, and Constance Dealy of Portsmith, Rhode Island; and brothers Larry Fagan of Portsmith, Rhode Island, and Peter Fagan of Newport, Rhode Island. He received his Ph.D. from Columbia University in English Literature. He has published fiction, poetry and critical essays in numerous literary journals. A volume of poetry, "Stepping Out," and two volumes of short fiction -- "Lost Cities Found Objects" and "Peaceable Kingdoms and Other Fictions" -- have been published by Red Moon Press. A fourth volume, a collection of critical essays, poetry and fiction, is forthcoming. His intelligence was encyclopedic, and his interests covered all eras and mediums of human art-making from paleolithic cave paintings to the latest poetry magazines. Conversation with him was an unending delight, a voyage of discovery with a continual frisson of ideas and insights. The world will be a duller place without Robert to observe, comment, and make deeper sense of it for us.

BRENNER--Paul R.,a man who was respected by everyone who knew him died on August 10, 2009 following a short illness. He was 66. Paul was graduated with honors from Fordham Preparatory School (1960), Fordham College of Arts and Science (1964), Fordham University School of Law (1968-L.L.M. in Taxation ). He was counsel at the Law Firm of Salans from July 1996 and prior thereto was a senior tax partner at the Law Firm of Kelley, Drye & Warren which he joined in 1968. He was a prolific author of tax articles and a lecturer at various graduate tax institutions. Paul was a former Trustee of the Buffalo Bill Historical Center in Cody, Wyoming, a former Trustee of the Planting Fields Arboretum in Oyster Bay, NY. He also was a Director of the Highstead Arboretum located in Redding, CT. In addition, Paul was a Trustee of The Louis Calder Foundation formally located in New York, NY and then in New Caanan, CT. He was also Corporate Secretary, Counsel, and a Director of The Swiss Helvetia Fund, Inc., a New York Stock Exchange listed closed-end investment fund investing exclusively in Swiss equity securities. He served in various capacities with the Archdiocese of New York under the tutelage of John Cardinal O'Connor. In addition, Paul served in various leadership capacities at the Church of Saint Joseph, Lawrence Hospital, and the Bronxville School Foundation, all located in Bronxville, New York. Paul was a member of the Metropolitan Club in New York City, Siwanoy Country Club in Bronxville, NY, The Misquamicut Club in Watch Hill Rhode Island, and the Watch Hill Yacht Club. He is the brother of George and the late Kevin. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Joseph's Church in Bronxville on Monday, August 17 at 10am. In Lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory, to the Fordham University School of Law, National Scholars Fund, 140 West 62nd Street, New York, NY 10023.

SINGH IN GROUP TIED FOR THIRD Vijay Singh's 69 matched David Toms for the lowest score among those who teed off in the afternoon Thursday, putting them in a six-way tie for third. At three under through 11 holes, Singh could get no closer to the leader, Tiger Woods. He bogeyed No. 12, leaving a 15-footer to save par on the lip. But he got back to three under by nearly holing his second shot on the par-4 No. 16. COULD IT COME DOWN TO TOP 8? The third round of the Rogers Cup and men's tennis history unfolded simultaneously Thursday in Montreal. The ATP World Tour started ranking players in 1973, and over 36 years and thousands of tournaments, the top eight ranked players in the world had never advanced to the quarterfinals of the same championship. The top eight seeds had done so, but never the top eight players.

If drinking fountains were as ubiquitous as fire hydrants, there would be no need for steel thermoses, plastic bottles or backpack canteens. Thirsty folks could just amble over to the next corner for a sip of free-of-charge, ecofriendly, delicious water. But there are only about 2,700 public fountains in all of New York -- and those are mostly confined to our parks and playgrounds -- so we're still forced, in the dehydrating August heat, to carry our water around with us, like camels. The Op-Ed editors asked eight illustrators from around the country to spend an hour one summer afternoon surveying the scene at their local fountains. BALTIMORE

There was not an empty seat in the Pantages Theater in Minneapolis on Wednesday night when Bill Powell, 92, accepted the P.G.A. of America's Distinguished Service Award -- except when the more than the 600 people in attendance rose as one to give Powell four standing ovations during his acceptance speech. Powell, a World War II veteran, built his own golf course in 1946 after he was denied access to the golf courses in and around his hometown of Minerva, Ohio, because he was African-American. To accept the highest honor bestowed by an organization that at one time had rules barring people of color from membership, Powell said, ''is something I never thought could happened and something I'll never forget.''

Ask most Americans what they know about military women and their performance in Iraq and Afghanistan and they often draw a blank. Or they mention two headline-grabbing names, Pvt. Jessica Lynch, who was held captive in Iraq, and Lynndie England, who got tangled up in the Abu Ghraib scandal.

Today, we introduce you to a new blog about America at war. This generation's conflict, which began on 9/11, is nearly eight years old. Yet there are no signs that it will end anytime soon, with the Obama administration sending thousands more troops into Afghanistan and Iraq facing enormous military and political challenges as American troops withdraw. So "At War" - an expansion of our Baghdad Bureau blog - is a recognition that war is now, and will be, a defining experience for Americans. One of our contributors, Dexter Filkins, captured that in the title of his book about 9/11, Afghanistan and Iraq: "The Forever War."

An article on Wednesday about two former military psychologists who designed the Central Intelligence Agency’s interrogation program in 2002 misstated the credentials of an Air Force officer who criticized the interrogation methods but suggested that the two psychologists had acted out of patriotic motives. The officer, Steven M. Kleinman, is a career intelligence officer and former interrogator; he is not a psychologist and is not “Dr. Kleinman.” (He has master’s degrees in strategic intelligence and forensic sciences, but does not have a doctorate.).

A lawyer for J. D. Salinger has asked an appeals court to uphold an injunction on a novel that was ruled to be an illegal sequel to Mr. Salinger’s “Catcher in the Rye.” In a brief filed on Thursday with the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in Manhattan, the lawyer, Marcia B. Paul, said a lower court ruled correctly on July 1 when it indefinitely banned publication in the United States of “60 Years Later: Coming Through the Rye,” a novel written by Fredrik Colting under the pen name J. D. California. In her brief, Ms. Paul wrote that despite the coverage the case had received in the news media, “this is a straightforward case of copyright infringement arising from the upcoming U.S. publication of a book promoted, labeled and sold in England as an unabashed sequel to Salinger’s iconic work ‘The Catcher In The Rye.’ ” Last month lawyers for Mr. Colting appealed the ruling of Judge Deborah A. Batts, of Federal District Court in Manhattan, who prohibited the release of “60 Years Later.” In their appeal the lawyers said the book was a legally protected work of commentary on the novel, its author and its teenage protagonist, Holden Caulfield.

The Cleveland Museum of Art has announced that Deborah Gribbon, the former director of the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles, would serve as its interim director while it searches for someone to fill the position permanently. In a news release on Thursday, the Cleveland Museum said Ms. Gribbon, the Getty’s director from 2000 to 2004, would officially take the position of interim director on Sept. 21. She succeeds Timothy Rub, who is leaving to become director and chief executive of the Philadelphia Museum of Art. Ms. Gribbon previously held several positions at the Getty, including associate director and chief curator. She resigned after clashing with Barry Munitz, who was then the president and chief executive of the J. Paul Getty Trust.

Rashied Ali, whose expressionistic free-jazz drumming helped define the experimental style of John Coltrane's final years, died Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 76. The cause was a heart attack, said his wife, Patricia Ali.

It is a post-Olympic year, not usually ideal timing for a compelling world track and field championship. But the nine-day meet that will begin in Berlin on Saturday is generating an unusually strong amount of anticipation and nostalgia. The anticipation is tightly focused on two disparate sprinters: Usain Bolt of Jamaica and Tyson Gay of the United States.

MENAGH--Claire, died peacefully at her home in Manhattan on Thursday. She was 87 years old. Wife of Donald F. Menagh, the New York City labor lawyer, who predeceased her in 2001, Mrs. Menagh, longtime resident of East 52nd St., was an esteemed member of the community, known for her kindness to neighbors and friends. Her charitable work included service to the Ladies of Charity, for which she served on the board, the Catholic Center of NYU, and The College of Mount St. Vincent, her alma mater. Mrs. Menagh is survived by her daughter Diane Menagh and her son Douglas Menagh, both of New York. The wake will be at Frank E. Campbell on Sunday August 16, 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial at St. John the Evangelist Church, 348 East 55th St., Monday August 17, 10:30am.

The half-marathon distance gives elite marathoners a chance to turn up their pace a notch, sometimes creating the type of footrace down the stretch more commonly seen in track meets. In last year's New York City Half-Marathon, Tadese Tola, right, of Ethiopia outsprinted Patrick Makau of Kenya by one second, finishing in 1:00:58. Tola is comfortable mixing it up. He was disqualified from the Peachtree 10K in Atlanta last month for elbowing another runner in a battle for fourth place about 100 feet from the finish.

SCHMIDT--Elizabeth "Betty" R.,91, of Scarsdale, NY and Salisbury, CT died peacefully on August 13, 2009. She was predeceased by her husband Carl. Betty is survived by her three children. A memorial will be held at 3pm on Monday, August 17th at Geer Village, 77 South Canaan Road, Canaan, CT.

(Starz) NICK & NORAH'S INFINITE PLAYLIST (2008) Nick (Michael Cera, above with Kat Dennings) and Norah (Ms. Dennings), a couple of music-loving New Jersey high school students who while away their evenings in New York rock clubs, go in search of their favorite band -- and try to decide what they want from each other in the process. Peter Sollett directed the ''idiomatically spot-on screenplay by Lorene Scafaria,'' adapted from the novel by Rachel Cohn and David Levithan, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''The movie is so friendly that you may wish for a little more conflict: higher emotional stakes, riskier jokes, a touch of danger in the night air,'' he wrote, adding, ''Why begrudge them their fun, or wish premature heartache upon them? There will be plenty of time for the blues later on.'' 6 A.M. (TCM) SUMMER UNDER THE STARS: DEBORAH KERR Turner Classic Movies devotes the day to the Scottish-born Kerr, who gained prominence on the British stage and screen before earning six Academy Award nominations as Hollywood's ''great lady'' during the 1950s and '60s. The salute begins with ''The End of the Affair'' (1955), Edward Dmytryk's adaptation of the Graham Greene novel, and ends on Sunday at 4:30 a.m. with ''Please Believe Me'' (1950), about an Englishwoman who learns that a soldier she befriended during World War II has left her his Texas ranch. Other Saturday highlights include ''Julius Caesar'' (1953) at 8 a.m.; ''The Avengers'' (1942) at 10:30; ''Tea and Sympathy'' (1956) at 5:30 p.m.; ''An Affair to Remember'' (1957), with Ms. Kerr and Cary Grant, above, at 8; ''From Here to Eternity'' (1953) at 10:15; and ''The Hucksters'' (1947), starring Kerr in her American film debut, at 12:30 a.m.

GILBERT--Deborah S.,84, died Friday in Hanover, NH. She is survived by her son Michael Gilbert, her daughter Sarah Gilbert, and her two grandchildren Emily and Daniel. A private graveside service will be held at the Longridge Union Cemetery in Stamford, CT.

The Spanish economy contracted sharply in the second quarter, official data showed on Friday, confirming that a nascent recovery in Germany and France had yet to spread throughout the euro area. Gross domestic product fell 4.1 percent in the second quarter from a year earlier, and declined 1 percent from the previous quarter, when it shrank 1.9 percent, the Madrid-based National Statistics Institute said in a preliminary estimate.

Fans in this sports-obsessed city seemed divided over the Eagles' signing of Michael Vick, but they were united in at least one response: shock. ''The whole city was full of people running outside to communicate with other people,'' said Tim Quigley, 26, who was at a bar for a bachelor party when he received the news via text message.
One way to get to a city’s heart is to immerse yourself in its music.
The city is experiencing a cultural revival.
This old-world city offers both decadence and bargains.

Quick: Think fashion stylist/costume designer and what image comes to mind? Someone impossibly skinny, prone to hissy fits, outfitted in the designer du jour and a cunning accessory or two (earrings from, say, Tom Binns)? A diva of sorts consumed by clothes, attuned to surface signifiers and radiating indifference to anyone outside her spheres of influence, right?.

Few designers have withstood the test of time and fashion like James Galanos. He started his career in Los Angeles in 1951 with $200 in backing from Jean Louis, who had hired him as a sketch artist at Columbia Pictures, and a big break from the actress Rosalind Russell. In the 1980s, he ranked among Nancy Reagan’s favorite designers (she wore Galanos to all her husband’s inaugurations). And while he officially retired in 1998, he shows no signs of falling out of fashion anytime soon: the model Amber Valletta wore a canary-yellow vintage Galanos gown to this year’s Costume Institute gala. Now well into his own 80s, he has taken to making constructivist paper collages — still cutting quite the figure himself. [?][?][?]ALIX BROWNE.
Meet Carey Mulligan, whose bravura turn in “An Education” has landed her center stage.

Designers have sewn up a new motto for fall: when the going gets tough, the tough get shoulder padding. After years of flirty dresses, fashionistas are now shouldering a style that is part workingwoman, part power diva.
Kristin Scott Thomas is the real deal.

She gets more mileage out of compressed emotion than other actresses get out of nervous breakdowns. In “Four Weddings and a Funeral,” she confessed her love to a clueless Hugh Grant, delivering the news with such an affecting blend of misery and composure that she walked off with the movie. As the adulteress Katharine Clifton in “The English Patient,” she smoldered opposite Ralph Fiennes, igniting one of the great screen romances of our time.

“Once seen,” Oscar Wilde viciously quipped of the architecture of the English face, “never remembered.” Men traditionally possessed stiff upper lips (fortitude in adversity) but were also chinless wonders (weakness in matters moral). Women? They had complexions like an English rose: the horticultural imagery is significant since lush gardens and creamy-pink women are among the few consolations of a wretched climate. Or were . . . because now there is Lily Cole.

Arianne Phillips is Hollywood’s wardrobe mistress, Madonna’s style confidante and a global trendsetter. Just don’t call her a celebrity stylist.

Paula Patton did not land her first major acting job until she was 28, an age at which many actresses are faced with diminishing opportunities. But Patton, who spent her 20s working on documentaries and studying at U.S.C.’s film school, brings an intelligence and depth of experience to her performances that can only be had by living life. In “Precious,” which opens in New York on Nov. 6, Patton plays Blu Rain, a teacher who takes a special interest in Clareece Jones, a horribly abused African-American teenage girl known as Precious. Ms. Rain is at once strict, inspiring and determined — her stubborn sense of possibility grants the film a jolt of hopefulness.

JUICY FRUITS: What started as a line of maternity jeans has morphed into a multimillion-dollar fashion business for Gela Nash-Taylor and Pamela Skaist-Levy. Juicy Couture, which the two best friends started in 1996 with $200, was the tracksuit heard round the world. Today the clothing line includes accessories, fragrances, canine fashions, even a Maclaren stroller — all made in a spirit of fun. “Juicy is definitely autobiographical,” said Pamela, a former costume designer. “We have infused the brand with us: with love, happiness, color.” With about 100 stores from L.A. to Dubai, the Juicy girls wanted to create something more personal. The result is their new collection of tailored, vintage-inspired outerwear and clever knits called Bird by Juicy Couture — “Juicy’s older sister,” explained Gela, a former actress. They say Bird is for them, not the mainstream, but why fight it? “It blows our mind that Juicy is part of popular culture,” Pamela said. “When we started, we were wacky thrift-shop girls.”.

A few weeks ago, sitting with Miuccia Prada and talking about the last golden years of fashion and the present financial crisis, I asked her if she thought people would change their attitude and not spend on fashion. Her answer was short and precise: we will always buy clothes because they let us live our dreams. Ah yes, dreams. The stuff of Hollywood and fashion. While actors rely on costumes, sometimes even prosthetics, to become another person, the rest of us depend on a great-looking pair of shoes and a hot new haircut. As the editor of T magazine, I am a firm believer in the transformative powers of fashion. Every season for the past five years we have tried to share our dreams and to inspire yours. On our covers, and in our pages, we have asked actors and actresses to role-play. They’ve been directed by some great photographers: Jean-Baptiste Mondino, Raymond Meier, Paolo Roversi, Mark Segal, Solve Sundsbo and many others we admire. Designers, stylists, makeup artists and hairdressers have been our accomplices. We want to thank them all for inspiring us and for making this special anniversary issue on Hollywood their celebration, too. Almost from the start, Hollywood was called the dream factory. Unknowns would land in Los Angeles and get a new identity with the help of costume designers like Adrian and Irene. An actress would have little to say in the way she looked, which is ironic, since how she looked often dictated fashion for the rest of us. (Later on, designers like Giorgio Armani, with “American Gigolo,” and Ralph Lauren, with “The Great Gatsby,” would create a fashion frenzy.) But with the rise of celebrity culture, costume designers largely have gone from being creative types to personal shoppers. That puts the pressure on fashion, which has the capacity to take us out of ourselves and let us live in our own private movies. We hope that T will be your dream factory — we are ready for your close-up. [?][?][

I got this because I wanted to add some razzle and dazzle to my glamorous evening gowns — something new and sexy. Several of my friends were actresses who adored Bob Mackie and always looked fabulous, so I felt I had nothing to lose. I remember wearing it for one of my birthday parties. Yes, it’s very heavy, but nothing ever stops me from having a great time. In fact, that’s my slimming tip of the day: wear a heavy beaded dress and go dancing every night. You’ll have a fabulous time and lose a ton of weight. [?][?][?] IVANA TRUMP, AS TOLD TO BEN WIDDICOMBE.
For those who run with wolves, Bob Basset, an artist from Kharkov, Ukraine, has created a tantalizing prototype.
