It seems that in Britain, if you’re unconventional, rebellious or crazy for long enough, eventually you become an institution. That, at least, is the strategy that seems to have worked for Pam Hogg. In June she was inducted into the Scottish Fashion Awards Hall of Fame, shortly after returning to the London catwalks for the first time in years with a fall collection of sci-fi bodysuits and multicolored patchwork fur.

Back in the 1980s, Christian Lacroix wasn’t the only one pumping up the volume of his silhouettes. The industrial designer and architect Ron Arad, who founded his One Off Ltd. studio in London in 1981, was developing a look that eventually became his signature: curvaceous, relatively unfurniture-like forms. “Ron Arad: No Discipline,” the first major United States retrospective of the designer’s work, is now on view at the Museum of Modern Art, where it runs through Oct. 19. The title refers to Arad’s joyful promiscuity with materials but also winks at a stubborn refusal to play by the rules. (He famously designed a stereo made of rough concrete and a chair made of two seats from a Rover P6 2000, a metal frame and a few Kee Klamps.) Keeping with the theory that no trend ever comes back the same way twice, Arad’s Big Easy armchair, with its linebacker shoulders, has enjoyed more than one revival but never in exactly the same fashion. The painted fiberglass New Orleans chair (left) came out in 1999; the latest incarnation, a stainless-steel duo called Even the Odd Balls?, is also in the show. [?][?][?] ALIX BROWNE.
1. Rei Kawakubo succinctly summed up the spirit of her Comme des Garçons collection: “Nothing is as it seems.”.

1. For his sophomore collection, the Paris-born, New York-based Joseph Altuzarra pays homage to the legends of the silver screen with goddess draping and exaggerated shoulders. Looks like his stints at Marc Jacobs and Givenchy paid off. Dresses start at $1,000 at Barneys New York.

Perusing the pages of Maripol’s book of Polaroids, “Maripolarama,” taken between 1976 and 1992, you might think you have stumbled onto a time warp. Is that really a decades-old picture of Edwige and Bianca Jagger, and not an outtake from the latest Marc Jacobs show? Those big jackets that Klaus Nomi is wearing sure look a lot like the new Margiela. And isn’t that the same punkish hair and makeup featured in Steven Meisel’s recent story for Italian Vogue?.

Madeleine Albright was the first woman to be named secretary of state, and it’s a safe bet that she was the first American cabinet member to use jewelry as diplomatic sign language. “Read My Pins: The Madeleine Albright Collection,” an exhibition that opens Sept. 30 at the Museum of Arts and Design in New York, and “Read My Pins: Stories From a Diplomat’s Jewel Box,” to be published around the same time by HarperCollins, chronicle Albright’s use of pins, from costume jewelry to family heirlooms. When a member of Saddam Hussein’s regime referred to her (while she was the United States ambassador to the United Nations) as a serpent, Albright donned a snake pin to a meeting with an Iraqi official. For Nelson Mandela, she wore a zebra pin. If Albright displayed a sun or ladybug, you could breathe easy; a crab or a wasp meant “watch out.” Who needs brass knuckles when you can walk softly and carry a big brooch? [?][?][?] PILAR VILADAS.

5x5x5 To celebrate our fifth anniversary, T asked five artists to reimagine our logo and five fashion designers to create five personas for the Hollywood newcomer Carey Mulligan. (Karl Lagerfeld, a No. 5 expert, created our signature T on Page 181.) To get all the artist-designed T covers, call (800) 671-4332) or go to nytstore.com.

“None of it feels vintage,” says Betsey Johnson, surveying the 40-odd pieces that make up the Betsey Johnson Archive Curated by Opening Ceremony. The joyous reissue of her greatest hits from the 1970s and ’80s — corset lacings! giant zippers! — explains how she became the darling of Mudd Club-carousing downtown dollies. Johnson and Opening Ceremony were sticklers for historical verisimilitude — they had the original fabrics replicated, so the rib knit skirts are superbly stretchy; the rosebud prints, a Betsey signature, look like they blossomed this morning. Of course, we know that all of these are her precious babies, but if she had to pick a favorite, which would it be? Johnson is unable to decide between a peplum frock — “It represents my career, my life, it’s what I’ve stood for” — and the shaggy faux fur jacket over satin spandex pants, because “that’s really what I always want to look like.” Don’t we all? [?][?][?] LYNN YAEGER.
1. Alexis Morrell Carrington.

She may be Tinseltown royalty, but Kimberly Ovitz — yes, daughter of that Ovitz — doesn’t do tinsel. With her daring collection, Ovitz, 26, reworks the cliché of “Hollywood glamour” by substituting chain mail for chinchilla and leather for lace. Deployed on a mostly black-and-white palette (an hommage to a Jasper Johns minimalist “White Flag” painting that hangs in her father Michael’s collection), these touches lend modernity and just a hint of menace to pieces that are otherwise classic to the core — from sleek, skinny jodhpurs to slouchy cashmere tunics. Small wonder that her logo should feature two crossed riding crops, suggesting the improbable intersection of bondage-inflected high jinks and horsy good breeding. This pairing, Ovitz explains, undoes the idea of feminine allure as necessarily “overdressed and frilly.” So is the Ovitz girl the femme fatale for these harder, darker times? Perhaps. But the designer warns that her goal for spring 2010 is to “use more color, because people need to feel hopeful.” Spoken like a true daughter of Hollywood. [?][?][?] CAROLINE WEBER.

The photographer Norman Parkinson is finally getting his due. With a 56-year career that spanned prewar London and 1980s French Vogue, he captured fashion with a distinctly British eye. His early images for Harper’s Bazaar have a reportage quality that goes beyond clothes; even mid-’70s photos of Jerry Hall in the Soviet Union tell a larger story. “He makes our lovely American ladies look like duchesses and indeed, on occasion, he has been known to make a duchess appear a lady,” wrote the editor in chief of Town Country in 1987. With “Norman Parkinson: A Very British Glamour,” by Louise Baring (Rizzoli), Americans can rediscover his gifts. [?][?][?] CHRISTINE MUHLKE.

Even though she is as voluble as she is modelesque, Maria Sharapova prefers to let her tennis racket do the talking. But when a career-threatening injury forced the 22-year-old off the courts, she hit the sketchbooks. The result is a surprisingly cool accessories collection for Cole Haan, which is owned by her apparel sponsor, Nike. The three-time Grand Slam winner says she drew upon her own peripatetic lifestyle for the shoes ($138 to $328) and handbags ($248 to $428). And while Sharapova’s aware that not all women her age travel as much as she does, they still “juggle a lot of concerns, so comfort and adaptability are key.” Spoken like a true garmento. [?][?][?] HORACIO SILVA.
Tell all the Truth,” wrote Emily Dickinson, “but tell it slant.” Really?

Nowhere is the transformative power of fashion more visible than on the backs of celebrities. Thanks to the proliferation of tabloid TV, magazines, Web sites and blogs whose modus operandi is to track every star-torial step and misstep, not to mention the discriminate propagation of celebrities themselves (um, who is Melissa Rycroft, anyway, and why do we care what she’s wearing to the deli?), what may have started out as a symbiotic creative relationship between designers and actresses has exploded into a fashion-industrial complex. But even in the days before Rachel Zoe and her ilk, the exchange of gown for publicity was not necessarily a smooth one. Hubert de Givenchy was famously deflated when a dark-haired gamine first waltzed through his doors. He was expecting the great Katharine Hepburn, not Audrey, then unknown. Fortunately, he got over himself — and we all know how that story turned out. In fact, there are fewer thrills greater for a fledgling designer than to see someone famous wear his or her clothes by choice (and possibly even pay for them). For Roberto Cavalli, it was spying Brigitte Bardot in his silk chiffon caftan in St.-Tropez back in 1979. “That was the beginning of my brand philosophy,” Cavalli says. For Giorgio Armani, it was Lauren Hutton, who according to the designer still hangs on to her vintage Armani from the ’70s. John Galliano’s first brush with fame was Diana Ross. “She was not only the first celebrity,” he says, “but also one of my first clients when she bought about eight pieces from my 1984 St. Martins graduate collection. It was one of the most exciting yet insane moments of my life.” For Isaac Mizrahi, it was the day he got a call from Bergdorf’s informing him that Liza Minnelli had just bought an outfit. “She came to my studio and said, ‘Darling’ — I didn’t even know her and she called me darling — ‘I saw this from t

STYLE MAP LONDON: The Mayfair district used to be the exclusive territory of old money and galleries dealing in old masters, but now Balenciaga, Marc Jacobs, Christian Louboutin and Lanvin sit shoulder to shoulder with the ornate Victorian facades. The neat Mount Street Gardens and the absence of heavy traffic gives the area a peaceful air; add to that quirky stores and a handful of great restaurants like Scott’s and the Audley pub (which Michelle Obama visited), and it’s easy to see why Mayfair suddenly has all the fizz of a classic Champagne cocktail. SUSIE RUSHTON.

Scarlett Johansson always reminds me of the so-called Venus of Willendorf. Like the famous figurine’s, her looks suggest an idealization of womanhood rather than an actual woman. Of course, the particular idealization in question here — one of sexuality in the service of fertility and motherhood — tends to run counter to the current era, with its fetishization of the looks that cheat the camera into believing a woman has yet to experience childbed, let alone putting a child to bed.

THE LOOK PRETTY ’80S “EIGHTIES GLAMOUR” was Pat McGrath and Luigi Murenu’s edict before the Gucci show. Murenu added volume to the front of the hair and kept the sides and back tight and straight. McGrath channeled Tina Chow as well as the photography of Helmut Newton and Guy Bourdin with strong but pretty eyes and cheeks and perfect crimson lips.
François Nars may have many faces — makeup artist, cosmetics entrepreneur, photographer, author — but his stock in trade has always been glamour.

The emptiness began for me, as I think it does for most of us, with the visual. Where I live, in Murray Hill, stores on Third Avenue became bare windows overnight. You walked below 34th and . . . wait, wasn’t there a store over here? The owner had just shut it down and was standing on the sidewalk looking at it. He saw me staring, processing the void. “Wanna see?” he asked. Stripped walls, wiring hanging like the Gorgon’s hair from the ceiling. That’s when the smell of the recession kicked in: old plaster dust first, then concrete (Gaultier’s Puissance Deux without the vanilla). Then emptiness: the absence of people, of circulated air, of the layers of plastic, fiberboard and carpeting with which we surround ourselves.

Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana have never been lacking in the muse department. For their new DG fragrance anthology, they’ve amassed an eclectic cast of glamazons and gods to serve as the faces of the campaign. As Dolce explains, “We thought that just one perfume could not convey it all.” Gabbana adds, “We liked the idea of linking the fragrances to different personalities.” They’ve also found inspiration in the tarot, naming all five fragrances for archetypes from the cards. Naomi Campbell is the muse behind 3 L’Impératrice (the Empress), while Claudia Schiffer embodies the more subtle 18 La Lune (the Moon). Eva Herzigova and the Brazilian pugilist-turned-pinup Fernando Fernandes pair up for 10 La Roue de la Fortune. For 1 Le Bateleur (the Magician), the designers picked Tyson Ballou, while the musky 6 L’Amoureux is based on Noah Mills. [?][?][?] MAURA EGAN.

In the quest to create more effective (or merely more expensive) skin-care lines, the list of esoteric ingredients grows ever more rarefied. White lotus, grapeseed oil, rice, copper and algae are just a few of the substances that have been touted as beneficial to the luminosity and firmness of one’s skin. Although it is hard to be fazed by the cosmeceutical wonders of any one new thing, every once in a while something stops the leery but eternally hopeful beauty-product consumer in her tracks.

There’s nothing the style set loves more than a secret, and while the Rome-based jeweler Luigi Scialanga is something of an insider (he’s the partner of Giambattista Valli), his sculptural, one-of-a-kind designs have remained mostly under the radar. Which suits his clientele — fashion and social types like Alba Clemente, Mirella Petteni, Princess Alessandra Borghese and Sasha Pivovarova — just fine. An exhibition of his work, scheduled for next month at David Gill Galleries in London, might garner him a few more fans, but commerce isn’t his endgame. “I only make jewels when a material inspires me,” he says. The fashion historian Bronwyn Cosgrave, who curated the exhibit, is intrigued by the surreal quality of many of Scialanga’s designs. “Luigi’s jewels are similar in attitude to the ones Jean Cocteau produced for Schiaparelli,” she says. “The craftsmanship is impeccable, but there’s a free-form spirit that makes his work highly original and highly covetable.” [?][?][?] SANDRA BALLENTINE.

But it wasn’t until he got on the trail of Grace Coddington, the magazine’s legendary creative director, that he struck gold. Flashing a knowing smile and flaunting her witchy mane of frizzy red hair, Coddington steals the lead right from under Wintour’s nose and does it so adroitly that you could imagine her teaching screenwriting. Tucked behind a nondescript metal gate on Manhattan’s gritty but hip Freeman Alley, Dana Lorenz’s new Fenton-Fallon jewelry store (opening this month) is definitely a hidden gem. A front courtyard containing life-size flamingo topiaries, gigantic moss-covered spikes, classical sculptures and two aqua Lebello loungers serves as the shopping equivalent of foreplay. Pink neon “pawnshop” lighting around the front windows lures clients down to the basement-level boutique, with its Nagel lithograph, Biedermeier desk and bespoke bronze display cases as well as stools upholstered in a custom silk jacquard print that was designed by Lorenz’s friend Thakoon Panichgul. Here, Lorenz’s Fenton and Fallon costume collections and her new fine jewelry line share space with an outpost of Sully Fair, the online vintage dealer that offers exquisite pieces from Balenciaga, Chanel, YSL, Dior and Stephen Sprouse. “We were going for Sigourney Weaver’s town house in ‘Working Girl,’ ” Lorenz says of the mishmash of merchandise and décor. “But it’s more like an ‘80s teenager inherited her grandparents’ Park Avenue apartment and turned it on its ear.” Go to danalorenz.com. Pursimonious/ (prs mone\ s) /adj. / A recession-era neologism for the (often reluctant) recent tendency to be uncharacteristically frugal or stingy when it comes to snapping up status-conscious handbags, as in,“Bless her. Her definition of pursimonious is to buy only one ‘It’ bag this season — the YSL Roady in stingray!” or, “Uxorious, schmuxorious. An article on Aug. 2 about older alumni who have been helped by university career counselors referred imprecisely to comments by a 1990 graduate of Lehigh University who lost his job in February when his company was downsized, and a correction in this space last Sunday misspelled his surname. Michael Pollan argues that sensationalized, sportslike food shows discourage spectators from actually cooking themselves, but I, a 20-year-old college student, beg to differ. “Top Chef” not only inspired me to start to cook two years ago, but also to imitate haute cuisine — experimenting with ingredient combinations and presentations way beyond what I could imagine without food TV and attempting to figure out what constitutes a good “flavor profile.” I have to say that without that show, I wouldn’t be half the cook I am today. New York.

Peter Singer writes (July 19) that if being quadriplegic makes life half as good for a person as being nondisabled, then it is as good to cure two people of quadriplegia as to save another person’s life. This type of reasoning implies that if having a weak ankle makes a life 95 percent as good as being nondisabled, it is permissible to cure a weak ankle in each of 21 people rather than save another person’s life.

THE ART RESTORER Teresa Zakow, 65, worked alongside her husband, Joel, for 32 years in a studio on Greene Street in SoHo. After he died in 2006, she continued the business they had run together, repairing great works of art.

Two second-half substitutes -- Natasha Kai and Francielle -- scored Saturday for Sky Blue F.C. in a 2-1 victory over the Washington Freedom and put the team one victory from playing in the championship game of Women's Professional Soccer. Kai entered the match in the 54th minute and scored a minute later. Francielle, a 29-year-old striker from Brazil, entered the match in the 61st minute and scored the winner in the 84th. The victory sent Sky Blue to what the league is calling a Super Semifinal, against St. Louis Athletica on Wednesday in Fenton, Mo. The winner of that game will advance to next Saturday's title match against the Los Angeles Sol. The Sol won the right to host the championship game as the league's top team with 41 points during the 20-game regular season.

It was no iPhone line, but 40 or so fans of the Madden video game franchise lined the sidewalk outside Game Stop in Manhattan's Herald Square on Thursday, awaiting the release of the latest Madden game at midnight. HONEYSTEIN--Karl I. Born in 1932 in Long Island, NY, a graduate of Yale and Columbia Law School, Karl served as an officer in the Navy. He began his career in 1959 as an attorney with Greenbaum, Wolff & Ernst in New York and left in 1962 to join Ashley/Steiner, Inc., a talent and packaging agency. After the agency was sold and renamed Ashley-Famous, Karl stayed for two years as head of the TV department. While there, he was instrumental in the packaging of TV series such as "Get Smart" and "Hootenanny" and bringing The New Christy Minstrels to prominence. After Ashley-Famous was dissolved, Karl went to work for Marvin Josephson as a consultant. He later left to become a partner in the Sy Fischer Co. which represented companies like Hanna Barbera as well as writer-producer-director talent like Garry Marshall. The company opened a west coast office to allow its talent to expand and Karl moved to LA. In the early 80's, that company was acquired by Taft Broadcasting, where Karl became EVP and COO of its division the Taft Entertainment Co. Most recently he was President of KH Strategy Corp., a management company for film and television. He represented companies such as Weintraub/Kuhn Prods. and properties such as The Addams Family. He was on the Board of Directors at Rhythm & Hues, an Academy Award winning visual effects studio, a Fellow of the International Academy of Television Arts and Sciences for many years, and a longtime member of the Friars Club. Karl is survived by wife Shauna Trabert, daughter Gail Honeystein, sister Floren Harper, step-children Brooke Trabert Dabkowski, Mike Trabert and six grandchildren.

Will a Visitor to New Orleans Be Disappointed? I remember my trip to New Orleans a few years before Katrina, and in three days I knew it was my favorite city in America. I wonder if post-Katrina, even if life may have returned to near normalcy, the city has lost some of its character, with all the rebuilding. Is there a big disappointment in store for a post-Katrina visitor? -- Lalit Bhatia, Bangalore, India

COUPER--Mary Frances Bowles, loving daughter, wife, and friend died peacefully at her estate, Piney Point, on Friday morning, the 14th of August 2009. She was born in Beaumont, Texas, the only child of Edna Henderson Bowles and William Victor Bowles, President of W.V. Bowles Oil Production Company. A more detailed and specific obituary is published in the August 16th edition of the Houston Chronicle and is also accessible electronically at www.geohlewis.com. Services in Houston are entrusted to Geo. H. Lewis & Sons The Funeral Directors Since 1936, 713-789-3005. In accordance with Mrs. Couper's specific wishes, a private interment and memorial service are to be conducted at a later date. For those desiring, contributions in memory of Mary Frances Bowles Couper may be directed to a charity of one's choice.
LESSER--Sylvia. The Lesser family announces the passing, on August 14. Beloved wife of Bernard, loving mother of Lauren, treasured sister and friend.

HORTON-COHEN--Stephanie, died in New York City on August 14 at age 74, after a long illness. She leaves her husband Lawrence, son Jonathan, daughter-in-law Traci, grandchildren Alexander and Natalie, and step-son Eric. A 1952 graduate of The Birch Wathen School and of Barnard College, class of 1956. She long worked as a fashion publicist for RH Macy, Henri Bendel and Celenese Corp. Subsequently, she became president of Union Tours the preeminent specialist for travel to the Baltic States. Our memories of her warmth, kindness, generosity, wit and elegance will long survive her passing.

STRAWBERRY HILL By Mary Ann Hoberman. Illustrated by Wendy Anderson Halperin.231 pp. Little, Brown. $15.99.(Ages 8 to 12) Even if you didn't know that Mary Ann Hoberman is the current national children's poet laureate, with a shelf of distinguished picture books to her credit, you could tell from ''Strawberry Hill,'' her first novel, that you were in the hands of a seasoned writer. The restraint of her style is a tip-off that here is someone who knows how to bring detail and language into just the right balance to catch you up and pull you into the story.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended Saturday, August 1st 2009, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount and department stores; and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Among those categories not actively tracked are: perennial sellers; required classroom reading; text, reference and test preparation guides; journals and workbooks; calorie counters; shopping guides; comics; and crossword puzzles. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

EXPLORING BYBLOS, A UNESCOWORLD HERITAGE SITE NEAR BEIRUT, LEBANON, MARCH 26, 2009 Angela Hartwick, a 31-year-old Canadian online art gallery director based in Dubai, walks among the ancient ruins. ''Byblos is this crazy historical site, and yet it's a stone's throw away from this whole suburban sprawl, some of which suffered so much damage and destruction in 2006. So Lebanon has both modern ruins and ancient ruins. And its culture blends rough-edged Arabic ways with refined French ways. Walking through Beirut, in a span of 20 minutes, you can go from a Shiite Muslim stronghold to a really affluent French neighborhood. This kind of contrast spreads across the people as well. There are strict traditional Muslims, and then there are women in miniskirts and enhanced breasts. As I walked through Byblos, I kept thinking how humanity keeps reinventing itself. You're standing there in thousands of years of history, but then you see different eras cropping up. You see a 12th-century castle, and then you see a building blown out from the 2006 war. It's all sort of there in the same picture.''

MENAGH--Claire, died peacefully at her home in Manhattan on Thursday. She was 87 years old. Wife of Donald F. Mosquito levels in Westchester County remained normal for May and much of June, but then started spiking in tandem with the rain. The county has 20 trapping sites, with each trap capturing about 40 mosquitoes a night, at least twice the usual amount, according to Frank Guido, assistant commissioner for public health protection in the county's Department of Health. The county's 70,000 catch basins have been treated with larvicide, Mr. Guido said. So far, no mosquito batches have tested positive for the West Nile virus. ''But that's likely to change in short order,'' Mr. Guido said, ''based on past history. Through late August, more mosquitoes with West Nile virus are likely to appear.''

ESPN will carry 48 live matches from the English Premier League on Saturdays and Mondays in the United States, the cable network announced Friday night, hours before the start of the 2009-10 Premier League season. The network began its coverage with the Chelsea-Hull City match Saturday morning. Chelsea played its first game under its new manager, Carlo Ancelotti, and American viewers had hoped to see the debut of Jozy Altidore, who has just joined Hull City on a season-long loan from Villarreal in Spain. But late Friday, in a posting on Twitter, Altidore said that work still needed to be done on his British work visa and that he was still in the United States.

BARTOL--Mary Farr, a resident of Sonoita, Arizona, died on August 13, 2009 at her Morristown, New Jersey home. Since 1989 when her husband of 45 years, George E. Bartol, III died, she was the matriarch of a far-flung and growing family. She is survived by four daughters: Blair B. MacInnes of Morristown; Maisie Wolszon of St. Paul, Minnesota; Victoria Vallely of Boston; and, Katherine Stenson-Lunt of Falmouth, MA, nine grandchildren, and eight great-grandchildren. Mary Farr was born in New York City on February 18, 1923, and attended the Brearly and St. Timothy schools. During World War II, she was employed as a censor of international mail. She and Mr. Bartol raised their four daughters in Paoli, PA until 1982 when they moved to Sonoita, Arizona. There Mrs. Bartol was active in the community, including, much to the surprise of her children, being the Road Commissioner for the Tunnel Springs Association. Other involvements included the establishment of the Arizona Young Artists Award granted annually by the Arizona Community Foundation. To reflect her life long love of books, she volunteered at the Patagonia Public Library where she had a connoisseurs eye for fine detective stories. She was a fine writer in her own right and published two delightful works of nonfiction: "A Legend in my Own Mind" and "Sweet and Sour". In her memory, contributions may be sent to: Atlantic Home Care and Hospice, 33 Bleeker Street, Millburn, NJ 07041.

As of early this month, Connecticut's 90 trapping sites had caught 184,801 mosquitoes this year, about 66,000 more than during the same period last year. After counting their catch, workers separate the insects by species (Connecticut has 50), pop them into vials, grind them up, centrifuge them down and screen them for eight types of viruses, including West Nile. ''We've been working with very few breaks,'' said Theodore G. Andreadis, chief medical entomologist for the state. Lately, the state's trappers have been capturing 4,500 to 8,000 of the insects a day.

BRENNER--Paul R.,a man who was respected by everyone who knew him died on August 10, 2009 following a short illness. He was 66. Paul was graduated with honors from Fordham Preparatory School (1960), Fordham College of Arts and Science (1964), Fordham University School of Law (1968-L.L.M. in Taxation ). He was counsel at the Law Firm of Salans from July 1996 and prior thereto was a senior tax partner at the Law Firm of Kelley, Drye & Warren which he joined in 1968. He was a prolific author of tax articles and a lecturer at various graduate tax institutions. Paul was a former Trustee of the Buffalo Bill Historical Center in Cody, Wyoming, a former Trustee of the Planting Fields Arboretum in Oyster Bay, NY. He also was a Director of the Highstead Arboretum located in Redding, CT. In addition, Paul was a Trustee of The Louis Calder Foundation formally located in New York, NY and then in New Caanan, CT. He was also Corporate Secretary, Counsel, and a Director of The Swiss Helvetia Fund, Inc., a New York Stock Exchange listed closed-end investment fund investing exclusively in Swiss equity securities. He served in various capacities with the Archdiocese of New York under the tutelage of John Cardinal O'Connor. In addition, Paul served in various leadership capacities at the Church of Saint Joseph, Lawrence Hospital, and the Bronxville School Foundation, all located in Bronxville, New York. Paul was a member of the Metropolitan Club in New York City, Siwanoy Country Club in Bronxville, NY, The Misquamicut Club in Watch Hill Rhode Island, and the Watch Hill Yacht Club. He is the brother of George and the late Kevin. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Joseph's Church in Bronxville on Monday, August 17 at 10am. In Lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory, to the Fordham University School of Law, National Scholars Fund, 140 West 62nd Street, New York, NY 10023.

THE NEWS The Federal Reserve said the recession was ending. BEHIND THE NEWS The central bank stopped well short of declaring victory. But it said that the downturn appears to have hit bottom and that consumer spending, financial markets and inventory building by businesses were stabilizing. Still, the Fed cautioned that the recovery would be slow and would pick up speed only gradually in 2010. Unemployment is also likely to continue to climb and remain high through the next year. The Fed's assessment comes two years after it began the first of its emergency lending programs to banks when credit markets seized up in response to the crisis in the subprime credit market.

WARNER--Patricia. Her friends and family mourn her passing July 29th in London after a short illness. Born in 1936, she was evacuated to Wales during the World War II blitz. Pat attended St. Martin's School of Art in London, then worked at Apple Records. Starting in 1964 Pat was the assistant to Mario Amaya the founding editor of "Art and Artists" in London and moved to Toronto in 1969 as his assistant at the Royal Ontario Museum. In 1971 she became Associate Editor in the Publications Department of the Museum of Modern Art and edited "The Meanings of Modern Art" (1976) by John Russell, and "The Architecture of Luis Barragan" (1976) by Emilio Ambasz. She wrote articles for The New York Times Sunday advertising supplement and was a features writer for Andy Warhol's "Interview". From 1980-1985 Pat was Director of Advertising and Marketing of Tiffany's. She also wrote the introduction to "The Tiffany Wedding" by John Loring (Doubleday, NY, 1988/edited by Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis). In 1989 she edited Stephen Harvey's "Directed by Vincente Minnelli". She was a contributing writer for Architectural Digest and Gourmet. In 1990 Pat moved to London, then Norfolk and back to London, where she wrote entries for the "Macmillan Dictionary of Art" (1996). She designed enamel boxes for Halcyon Days and painted portraits of cats and dogs. Her marriage to George White ended in divorce. She married Bradford Warner, Jr. in 1976 and became the stepmother to his daughters, Elizabeth and Claire. They were divorced in 1989. She is missed by all whose lives were enriched by her friendship, her high spirits, her good heart, her intelligence and her imagination.

SHERLOCK HOLMES is the men's style icon for fall, but pulling off his signature mutton chops is a mystery to most men. For a clue on how to do it, contact Yves Durif, the master hairstylist at the Carlyle Hotel. He has made a name for himself advising men on how to maintain their facial hair. (Nicolas Sarkozy recently stopped by for a consultation.) His rule of thumb for non-Holmesian sideburns: figure out where your sideburn hairline ends, and your stubble begins, and never, ever shave above that. ''Men look really stupid if they do,'' he says. Case solved. For appointments, (212) 744-1600 or thecarlyle.com. ARMAND LIMNANDER

In its battle against the West Nile virus, New York City has taken aim at the dead. Well, not exactly the dead; more specifically, their mourners. During mosquito season, generally April 1 to Oct. 15, water-filled vases are banned at city cemeteries, lest they serve as mosquito breeding grounds. The ban took effect five years ago.

THE debate over General Motors' claim that the Chevrolet Volt will get the equivalent of 230 miles a gallon in the city has probably been good for calculator sales, as analysts pore over the numbers and offer their own predictions about the likely performance of this hybrid-electric car, which makes its debut in late 2010. To arrive at its controversial number, Tony Posawatz, vehicle line director for the Volt, said G.M. used the Environmental Protection Agency's proposed methodology for measuring plug-in hybrid vehicles in city driving and the company's data on real-world driving.

Colombia's luxury quotient continues to bubble with the openings of two boutique hotels. The fashion designer Silvia Tcherassi will open the Tcherassi Hotel + Spa (www.tcherassihotels.com) in Cartagena this fall. Housed in a 250-year-old mansion that was meticulously renovated by Ms. Tcherassi, the hotel will embrace a colonial-era style (high ceilings and private balconies) and offer modern amenities (custom toiletries and robes created by Ms. Tcherassi). The hotel has seven rooms and suites with open bathrooms, four pools, a full-service spa, private lounge with an outdoor bar and an Italian restaurant. Rates will start at $275.

IT'S August and the heat is finally catching up with us. With temperatures hitting 90 for the first time since April -- yes, April -- we're thinking of baseball, packing for trips to the Cape (both Cod and May), or fishing out a sweater for cool nights in the Adirondacks. The last thing on anyone's mind is gardening. And yet our towns are still blooming.

First it was Tom Glavine. Then Randy Johnson and John Smoltz. And now, JaMIe Moyer. It has been a rough year for 40-something pitchers. Normally, future Hall of Famers and World Series heroes go out with one last glorious tip of the cap. But this season, the goodbyes have been more unceremonious. Glavine, 43, was bitter after being released by his longtime employer, the Braves. Smoltz, 42, was cut by the Red Sox after a pounding at Yankee Stadium.

It's not exactly a great time to start a travel magazine, but that hasn't stopped two entrepreneurs with no publishing experience from launching Afar, which landed in mailboxes this month. The magazine, based in San Francisco, emphasizes ''experiential travel.'' ''People used to just want stuff,'' writes Greg Sullivan in the premier issue. Mr. Sullivan, who sold coin-operated basketball games, founded Afar with Joe Diaz, a former real estate investor. ''Many of us took the same approach in our travels. We went to the most glamorous places, stayed in the trendiest spots.'' Instead, he says, ''we now search for meaning wherever we can find it.''

IN an age when the French are pushing for a burqa ban and the president is chiding boys to pull up their jeans (while everyone else is roasting Mr. Obama about his own), the show ''Dress Codes: Clothing as Metaphor'' at the Katonah Museum of Art in Katonah, N.Y. (through Oct. 4) is extremely apt. Thirty-six artists illustrate how fashion is not just an expression of personal identity but also a way to convey global ideas, from war to religion. Maureen Connor's ''Thinner Than You'' points to the media-imposed ideals of beauty with a wispy dress, above left, that features -- are you ready? -- a 10-inch waist. Yael Mer's ''2 Evacuation Dresses,'' top, has a more relaxed fit and inflates into an emergency kayak, making it fashionable enough for the next natural disaster. There is also Derick Melander's sculpture made from folded secondhand clothes, left, which reminds the viewer that style comes in all shapes and sizes. MAURA EGAN
Film A. O. Scott

ALONG with the flip-flops, short-short skirts and steaming subway platforms, this year I've noticed a new sign of summer: legions of petition-waving college students have flooded the streets, accosting any and all who cross their paths. While there is no reason to doubt their commitment to save the world or advance a cause, their numbers and intensity seem to be on the increase. In the past month I have been approached to sign my name in favor of gay rights, environmental rights, pet rights, saving third world countries -- and by the way, am I a registered Democrat? The causes are endless.

He will live in our hearts forever. Services 11:30am Monday at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I.

Survived by wife of 63 years, Bella, sons, Howard (Sonna), Paul (Rhona) and Martin (Elaine), grandchildren, Matthew (Jennifer), Benjamin (Kelley), Sarah, Jeffrey, Michael, Lisa and Elyse, great-grandchildren, Jacob, Rachel, Sammy and Lucy, brother Irving and numerous nieces and nephews. WWII Veteran, Purple Heart and Bronze Star recipient, former vice president Blue Bell Lumber Company. Nat loved his family, worked hard and enjoyed a good card game. Services today at the Weinstein Memorial Chapel, Yonkers, at 11:30am.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Taking Vows in a League Blindsided by Divorce,'' Aug. 9: The article states that unnamed polls and studies -- combined with anecdotal evidence -- suggests that the divorce rate for N.F.L. players is from 60 to 80 percent. If the N.F.L. office had been asked, we would have offered a much different view based on a University of Michigan phone survey in 2008 of 1,040 retired N.F.L. players. That poll found 64.5 percent of retired players ages 30-49 are still married to their first wife while 52.7 percent of retirees 50 years or older are married to their first spouse. These numbers are better than the national average. Joe Browne

FAYE can't remember what first attracted her to Charlie Yonker. It might have been his soft-spoken manner. Or his Ford Model A roadster. Then again, it could have been the way Charlie and his pals sang Kingston Trio songs in three-part harmony while sitting atop that roadster on Woodward Avenue in the Detroit area. Charlie Yonker was a year ahead of Faye McAlister at Lincoln High School in Ferndale, Mich., a suburb just north of Detroit and the starting point of the annual Woodward Dream Cruise, which was to take place on Saturday. Charlie was a big man on campus with his customized Model A, and it made him the apple of many a young lady's eye. Faye was not among them.

In Long Island, mosquito levels have been only slightly higher this year despite all the rain. In Nassau County at the end of July, officials had caught 11,699 mosquitoes in their traps, up about 10 percent from the same time last year. Late last week, one batch of mosquitoes did test positive for the virus, but the area has had no human or animal case of the West Nile virus so far this year. Last year, two infected birds had been detected by the end of July.

HAPPY DAYS I've been skateboarding seriously for more than 20 years, and while I never met Andy Kessler, I know his life story. Most skaters over the age of 25 do. Raised on West 71st Street, Kessler started skateboarding when he was 11. This was in the 1970s, a time when skateboarding was so alien to New York City that he had to mail-order his gear from California. Significance-wise, think: Prometheus and fire. When other kids saw Kessler carving around the Upper West Side on his board -- which would've been three inches wide with metal wheels -- they followed, and just like that, the East Coast skate scene was born. It was gritty, dirty and beautiful, the shadow-version of the breezy West Coast surf-style. It still is. The current state of skateboarding -- the ubiquitous television presence, the department-store displays of designer skater apparel -- is roughly to Kessler's brand of skating what a country club swimming pool is to the ocean. His was a raw, aggressive way of skating, fast and slashing and explosive. He fell a lot, bled and got hurt a lot. But there was also a grace to it, a power and soulfulness that often gets lost in the flashy spectacle of televised competitions.

BERKHEIMER--Margaret Polk Yates, writer and journalist, died August 13, 2009 in New York City at age 93. She is the widow of the late Dr. George A. Berkheimer, and the sister of late Eugene A. Yates, Jr and Betty Yates Shepard Ensign. She is survived by the children of her brother and sister and their children and grandchildren. She was born December 9, 1915 in New Jersey, spent her early childhood years in Birmingham, Alabama, came out as a debutante in NYC in 1933, and resided in Manhattan her whole adult life. A graduate of Sarah Lawrence and the Columbia School of Journalism, she served in the OSS during WWII and wrote two mysteries published by EP Dutton including "The Widows Walk," published in 1945, one of the first mysteries with Nantucket, MA as the setting. Mrs. Berkheimer was a devotee of Nantucket, residing there in the summers for over 60 years, and contributing to numerous Nantucket causes. A funeral service will be held at St. Paul's Episcopal Church on Nantucket at 4pm, on Saturday August 29. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Nantucket Conservation Foundation would be appreciated.

ZEISEL--Henry I.,89, beloved Husband of Gloria for 67 years, Father of Dr. Cheryl (Abe) Kramer, Dr. Elliot (Mary) Zeisel, Howard Zeisel, LCSW, and Debbie (Sam) Moed. Grandfather of eight, and Great-Grandfather of ten. Brother of Murray Zeisel. President of Accura - Zeisel Machinery Corp. and an industry leader. A founder of the Community Synagogue of Monsey and HIRC/ASHAR, a graduate and generous benefactor of Yeshiva University. Master of many languages who used his skills to welcome one and all, and was always available to those in need. An intellect whose interests ranged from Judaica to geography Henry was a colorful man who had a beautiful voice. Funeral, August 12th, Shiva observed at the Zeisel residence.

In the nearly two and a half months since the major league baseball draft, 16 of the 32 first-round picks have signed contracts with their teams. By 11:59 p.m. Monday, the other 16, a group that includes the much-heralded pitching prospect Stephen Strasburg, who went first over all to the Nationals, will have to sign or they will re-enter the draft next season. Strasburg, a star at San Diego State, has been talked about as a once-in-a-lifetime prospect who could compete immediately at the major league level, but his agent, Scott Boras, has held firm in contract demands.

An article in Skeletal Radiology, a well-respected journal, created something of a sensation in Europe last year. It reported that researchers from Danube Hospital in Austria examined the knees of marathon runners using M.R.I. imaging, before and after the 1997 Vienna marathon. Ten years later, they scanned the same runners' knees again. The results were striking. ''No major new internal damage in the knee joints of marathon runners was found after a 10-year interval,'' the researchers reported. Only one of the participants had a knee that was truly a mess, and he'd quit running before the 1997 marathon (but had been included in that study anyway). His 1997 knee M.R.I. revealed cartilage lesions, swelling and other abnormalities. In the years that followed, the knee became worse, showing augmented tissue damage and more serious lesions. His exam prompted the researchers to wonder whether he would have been better off persisting as a runner, because, as they speculate, ''continuous exercise is protective, rather than destructive,'' to knees. You can't be a runner past the age of 40, as I am, without hearing that running will ruin your knees, by which doomsayers usually mean that we'll develop ''degeneration of the cartilage in the kneecap, which reduces its shock-absorbing capacity,'' says Ross Tucker, a physiologist in South Africa and co-author of the new book ''The Runner's Body: How the Latest Exercise Science Can Help You Run Stronger, Longer and Faster.'' In other words, we'll be afflicted with arthritis.
A Florida doctor was forced out of his job running a local health department after posting signs critical of junk food and doughnuts.

Updated | 4:25 p.m. Neeme Jarvi, who in May stepped down from his position as the music director of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, will take charge of the Estonian National Symphony Orchestra, where he began his career in 1963 before fleeing that former Soviet republic, Agence France-Presse reported. After arriving in the United States in 1980, Mr. Jarvi eventually appeared with the New York Philharmonic, Philadelphia Orchestra, San Francisco Symphony, and Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra. He has also been the principal conductor of the Gothenburg Symphony and the music director of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra, and is the chief conductor of The Hague’s Residentie Orkest. “I am really moved to return in front of the orchestra where my career started,” Mr. Jarvi said, according to Agence-France Presse. He is to take over at the Estonian orchestra from the conductor Nikolai Alexeyev in 2010.

An eclectic mix of dance groups, from the hip-hop troupe Groovaloo, winners of NBC’s “Superstars of Dance,” to the acclaimed Pacific Northwest Ballet, will be among the companies making their Joyce Theater debuts this coming season. Some 16 individual performers and companies from across the country and the globe will appear during the season, which begins on Sept. 15 and runs through February. Along with the above groups, Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet will also come to the Joyce for the first time as well as Rasta Thomas’s “Rock the Ballet,” and Balletto Teatro di Torino from Italy, which will also be performing for the first time in the United States beginning on Oct. 13. Other highlights include the New York premiere of Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company’s “Serenade/The Proposition,” and works by Lucinda Childs, Richard Alston, and the Dutch company Emio Greco | PC. Joyce regulars, including Garth Fagan, Complexions Contemporary Ballet, Rioult and Parsons Dance, will round out the season.

Andy Ward, the executive editor of GQ Magazine, will become vice president and executive editor at the Random House publishing imprint in mid-September, reporting to Susan Kamil, who is editor in chief at the imprint as well as editorial director of The Dial Press. “Andy’s editorial acumen, experience, and passion for great writing—particularly narrative nonfiction, both literary and reportorial—make him an ideal addition to our accomplished Random House editorial team,” Ms. Kamil said in a prepared statement. He is not the only top magazine editor to make the shift to book publishing. In May, the former editor in chief of Ladies’ Home Journal, Diane Salvatore, was named publisher of Broadway Books, another Random House imprint. And last year, Priscilla Painton, formerly deputy managing editor at Time magazine, became editor in chief at Simon & Schuster’s flagship imprint.

Do you ever get the feeling you’re being watched? This week,A. O. Scott peers into the world of Francis Ford Coppola’s “The Conversation.” Mr. Scott calls it “one of the masterpieces of paranoid cinema from the 1970s.”

After nearly three-quarters of a century Robert Capa’s “Falling Soldier” picture from the Spanish Civil War remains one of the most famous images of combat ever. It is also one of the most debated, with a long string of critics claiming that the photo, of a soldier seemingly at the moment of death, was faked. Now, a new book by a Spanish researcher asserts that the picture could not have been made where, when or how Capa’s admirers and heirs have claimed.
What we’re reading on Monday morning.

Right before the lights went down at “Powerhouse,” a portrait of the visionary career and blinkered personal life of musical pioneer Raymond Scott, I leaned forward to the row in front of me to ask the longtime publicist of the Fringe Festival, Ron Lasko, if he had seen anything great that I should know about. “No!” he said in a refreshing break from tradition of the usual press agent puffery (Ron, God bless him, had also warned me to avoid the opening ceremonies at all costs, which is the kind of thing that can give a flack a reputation for honesty).

For the second time this summer, it has been reported that the Prince of Wales sought to have an architect replaced on a major British construction project. The Guardian reported that Prince Charles lobbied for the removal of Jean Nouvel, the French architect and the winner of the 2008 Pritzker Prize, as the designer of an $815 million office and shopping complex planned for a site near St Paul’s Cathedral, the 17th century structure designed by Christopher Wren. In a letter sent in 2005 to the commercial developer Land Securities, The Guardian said, Prince Charles wrote that the complex should feature a design that would “allow St Paul’s to shine bright,” and suggested that his own architectural advisers, who prefer traditional designs, should help. The office of the royal family at Clarence House confirmed to The Guardian that the prince had sent the letter after Mr. Nouvel, a modernist architect, was named the winner of an international competition to design the complex. In June, the architect Richard Rogers accused the prince of abusing his power after he had him removed as the designer of a housing project to be built in London’s Chelsea district, near the Royal Hospital designed by Christopher Wren.

In his bestselling novel “Lord of the Flies,” William Golding vividly reminded readers of the primal side of man that lurks beneath his civilized demeanor. The Nobel Prize-winning author was apparently no stranger to barbaric behavior: in an unpublished memoir composed for his wife, Mr. Golding wrote that he tried to rape a 15-year-old girl when he was a young man, The Times of London reported. The account of the incident written by Mr. Golding, who died in 1993, was discovered by John Carey, the chief book reviewer of The Sunday Times of London and an emeritus professor of English literature at Oxford University, who is the author of a coming biography, “William Golding: The Man Who Wrote ‘Lord of the Flies,'” and who had access to Mr. Golding’s archives. In the unpublished memoir, called “Men, Women & Now,” Mr. Golding wrote that he had tried to rape a friend, whom he calls Dora, after he returned home at age 18 from his first year at Oxford. Mr. Golding also wrote that as a schoolteacher, he would pit his pupils against each other in “Lord of the Flies”-like experiments, to see what happened when he gave them more freedom. The novel, about a group of schoolboys who revert to savagery while stranded on a deserted island, was published in 1954.

The first time I attended the New York International Fringe Festival, ten years ago, it was on a date. What a horrible idea! For one thing, a solo adaptation of Dostoyevsky’s existentialist rant “Notes from Underground” does not exactly make for a romantic night out. It’s also hard to think of an easier way to scare away a young woman you recently met than to bring her to a grim, sweltering basement in the scrappy, early days of the festival when air-conditioning and elbow-room were scarce. And yet the over-packed theater, bathed in blackness, forced me and my game companion into close quarters, our knees briefly (and memorably) touching during one of the Underground Man’s splenetic screeds.
The Fringe Festival is utilizing 18 different performance spaces this year, and with 201 productions involved, these locations are bustling with one show after another throughout the 17-day festival.
One of my favorite parts of any show at the Fringe Festival is that inevitable moment when something goes terribly, terribly wrong.

Spider-Man’s Broadway debut next year may have hit a bump, with work on the planned musical suspended because of money problems, but the web-slinging hero is still looking strong in other areas. The Marvel Comics champion will make his return to the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade on Thursday, Nov. 26, with a brand new balloon. The previous inflatable Spider-Man made has first appearance in the parade in 1987 and retired from the procession in 1998. Like the first balloon, this one captures the hero in a wall-crawling position but updates his costume to its more modern look. There’s also good news for fans of the Spider-Man movie franchise starring Tobey Maguire and Kirsten Dunst. Variety reported that Sony Pictures Entertainment had hired the screenwriter James Vanderbilt (whose credits include the David Fincher film “Zodiac”) to work on the fifth and sixth installments of “Spider-Man.” The report said the two films will have a connected storyline. “Spider-Man 4,” directed by Sam Raimi, is expected to be released in May 2011.

Shah Rukh Khan, the Indian film star who was detained by American immigration officials at a New Jersey airport on Friday, criticized the United States in an interview on Monday, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Khan, who is promoting the film “My Name Is Khan,” which addresses the racial profiling of Muslims after Sept. 11, 2001, told the Indian television channel CNN-IBN that the United States does not lead “an isolated, parallel universe existence,” and that “there is a whole world which makes all the good and bad that is happening,” according to Agence France-Presse. Mr. Khan added: “So if we are scared of violence and terrorism, all of us are responsible for it. It’s not that the world is and America is not.” Mr. Khan was at Newark Liberty International Airport after immigration officials said that his name had come up on a routine alert list. The officials said that Mr. Khan was not “formally held,” and that his examination, which lasted about an hour, would have gone faster if his luggage had not been lost. The actor’s detention has been widely discussed within the Indian community and condemned by Indian film stars and politicians.

This turns out to be an unfortunate attraction, since such dichotomous couples report more marital conflict.

The first image, from Afghanistan, is familiar to anyone who has witnessed 11th-hour presidential campaigning. But Slide 2 tells a more interesting story about the main opposition candidate, Abdullah Abdullah. The photographer Tyler Hicks was in the scrum and described it: "Following his appearance, supporters became overwhelmed with excitement to greet him, making it nearly impossible for him to move." A member of Mr. Abdullah's security detail finally placed his hand on the candidate's head to physically guide him through the human gridlock to his motorcade. Elsewhere in the country, as David Goldman recorded (Slide 3), American soldiers removed threatening Taliban notices warning citizens not to vote.

The initiative aims to raise $200,000, which the organization says is enough to feed 4,000 children for a year.

Updated, 5:34 p.m. | A mass of warm and humid air descended over New York City on Monday, driving temperatures into the 90s nearly two months in to what has so far been one of the mildest summers on record. The National Weather Service issued a heat advisory, and for the first time this year, the city opened cooling centers across the five boroughs.

The six-foot wreath the artist Agathe Snow unveiled at the Fireplace Project in East Hampton, N.Y., this weekend looks like an overgrown charm bracelet. Adorned with crisply wrapped presents, party favors and Christmas tree ornaments, the piece is indeed a celebration of sorts, "but only if you know what to do with the gifts New York City has to offer," Snow explains. It was recycled from an installation Snow showed last year at the Sculpture Center in Long Island City, Queens, which was intended at the time to start a conversation with "the boys of my generation," in particular Terence Koh, Banks Violette and her ex-husband, the late Dash Snow.

The Broadway cast of "Shrek the Musical" has found the performer who will fill the colossal shoes of the flatulent ogre at its center: Ben Crawford will succeed Brian d'Arcy James in the role of Shrek on Nov. 10, the show's publicists said in a news release. Mr. James, who was nominated for a Tony Award for his performance in "Shrek," will depart after Nov. 8 to join the cast of Manhattan Theater Club's production of "Time Stands Still," the Donald Margulies play. Mr. Crawford, who is currently the stand-by for the Shrek role, made his Broadway debut in the "Les Misérables" revival, in which he understudied the roles of Javert and Jean Valjean.

So much of how you parent is shaped by how you were parented. There are things you do in the same way, because you see them as correct, or wise, or because they're the only way you know. And there are things that you deliberately do differently - because your own mom and dad messed those up, or times have changed, or your children have different needs. But either way, your own parents are the parents you know best and the departure point from which all your parenting journeys begin.

Brad Stone from our sister site Bits reports that EveryBlock.com, the two year-old experiment in hyperlocal news, is being bought by MSNBC.com, a joint venture between NBC and Microsoft. The artists Mike and Doug Starn went to great lengths -- and widths and heights -- to realize the T they created for one of the five artist-designed covers of our fifth-anniversary issue. The 35-foot-tall bamboo structure was an outcropping of their continuing installation "Big Bambú," which they have been working on at the former Tallix Foundry in Beacon, N.Y., throughout much of this past year. Like "Big Bambú," the T came together more or less organically, and was assembled by a team of rock climbers under the direction of the artists. Watch its progress in the Starns's time-lapse video here.

As a painter, I was excited to sign up for ArtPrize, a contest open to any artist who can connect with a venue in downtown Grand Rapids, Mich., and win a popular vote. The prizes are among the largest in art-world history: $250,000 to the grand winner and a whopping $450,000 total.

Spider-Man's Broadway debut next year may have hit a bump, with work on the planned musical suspended because of money problems, but the web-slinging hero is still looking strong in other areas. The Marvel Comics champion will make his return to the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade on Thursday, Nov. 26, with a brand-new balloon. The previous inflatable Spider-Man made has first appearance in the parade in 1987 and retired from the procession in 1998. Like the first balloon, this one captures the hero in a wall-crawling position but updates his costume to its more modern look. There's also good news for fans of the Spider-Man movie franchise starring Tobey Maguire and Kirsten Dunst. Variety reported that Sony Pictures Entertainment had hired the screenwriter James Vanderbilt (whose credits include the David Fincher film "Zodiac") to work on the fifth and sixth installments of "Spider-Man." The report said the two films will have a connected storyline. "Spider-Man 4," directed by Sam Raimi, is expected to be released in May 2011.

Back in January, when I was still blogging at U.S. News and World Report, I wrote a post that showed that, even though the number of self-employed people initially rose at the beginning of the recession, by the end of 2008, the rate of job loss was more severe among the self-employed than among those in the private sector who work for others. By December 2008, the number of self-employed people was only 96.2 percent of what it was before the recession began, while the number of private sector wage employed people was 97.2 percent of the December 2007 level.

On Saturday, under an unrelenting sun, a wild array of old and new machinery rumbled up and down Woodward Avenue from 9 Mile Road in Ferndale, Mich., to the avenue's northern terminus in Pontiac. In many locations, spectators lined the street a dozen or so deep, eating, drinking and generally making merry. If the Woodward Dream Cruise is a party, it's the kind where someone ends up wearing the lampshade. It's a party complete with costumes, bizarre machinery and loud music. The Detroit area's problems are many and deep, but Saturday was a day to put serious concerns aside.

Today's idea: "The emerging clean-energy sector could someday be for Democrats what the gas and oil industry is for Republicans," an article says. Perhaps, but another article says liberals will have to lose their urban NIMBY-ism to be truly green. Environment | A historic blue-green union of interests between Democrats and clean energy "is already emerging, albeit in miniature form," writes Ronald Brownstein in the National Journal. In the 2008 campaign, three-fourths of the alternative-energy industry's contributions went to Democrats. True, that was just $1.9 million -- chump change in Exxon terms -- but Brownstein sees a long-term dynamic gathering momentum: "employment in the industry is trending toward blue (Democratic) states, partly because they are more likely to adopt the policies (renewable power requirements for utilities, for example) that nurture the industry."

Touch Revolution, a start-up specializing in touch-screen technology for a wide range of computing devices, calls the 42nd floor of a 48-story San Francisco financial district high-rise home. A hedge fund used to occupy the space but bailed out as Wall Street's collapse affected its business model. Now, a line of trading desks packed with power to run monitors and computers has been turned into a workbench covered in motherboards, testing equipment and touch displays. (Apparently, the hedge fund left a few mementos behind, including one whiteboard outlining the condition of foreign markets and another detailing where the company went right and where it went wrong. The ''where it went wrong'' list was much longer.)

9 P.M. (HBO) FIXER: THE TAKING OF AJMAL NAQSHBANDI (2009) Only 24, Mr. Naqshbandi, above, had already become one of Afghanistan's top fixers, an aide who helped foreign journalists gain access to government officials, average citizens and armed rebels. And then he was hired in 2007 by Daniele Mastrogiacomo, an Italian reporter, to arrange an interview with a Taliban commander. The job, which resulted in the kidnapping of Mr. Naqshbandi and Mr. Mastrogiacomo, and the beheading of their Afghan driver, Sayed Agha, would be his last. Directed by Ian Olds, who won the award for new documentary filmmaker at the Tribeca Film Festival this year, and produced by Christian Parenti, one of Mr. Naqshbandi's clients, this film juxtaposes the bungling of this highly publicized case against the violence raging in Afghanistan as the Taliban strengthen their hold on the country. 7 A.M. Andrew Mann had been trying to start a Web service that would help people prevent skin cancer by uploading photos of moles and tracking them over time, but he could not raise the money to get it off the ground. One day, discouraged, he sat on the steps of his house and forlornly stared at the dent in his car. Suddenly he realized he could apply his idea to fixing cars instead of cancer. He started DentBetty, a Web site that gets body shops to vie for repair business.

EDLIN--Charles, legendary food broker, passed away on August 16th. He was 94. He began his 50 year career in the food business by selling jams and jellies from the trunk of his car in 1945 and through, charm and perseverance became the toast of a nascent industry. He told a great joke and his Yiddish accent rivaled Myron Cohen's. He is survived by his son, Jay and wife Claudia, his son Andrew and companion Valerie Rousseau, his beloved companion Lilian Bernstein, grandchildren Ruby, Daniel, Dillon, Raquel and Marlon. A lifelong Yankee fan, he left us on the same day as Babe Ruth did. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, August, 18th at 12:45pm at Riverside Chapel, 331 Amsterdam Ave. New York, NY.

RUBIN--Robert Michael, at the age of seventy-five passed away peacefully at New York University Hospital on Sunday August 16th in the presence of his family. He lived a life full of rich experiences with family and friends. His home in Weston, CT serves as a gathering place, weekend retreat, and spa. A graduate of the Birch Wathen School in New York City in 1952 and of Brown University in 1956, Mr. Rubin had a successful career as the President of Whitney Stores, Incorporated. Upon his retirement from retailing, Mr. Rubin pursued his interest in African art through a long association with the Museum for African Art in New York, holding the position of Honorary Life Trustee at the time of his death. In addition, his love of African art resulted in numerous trips toe different areas of the continent as well as pursuing a private collection. His generosity in loaning a variety of pieces to museums around the world has allowed others to share in his love of African art., He was also a founding board member of the Prison University Project in California of which his stepdaughter Jody Lewen is Executive Director. His contributions were pivotal to the expansion of that organization. Son of the late Doris and Harry and brother to Richard and the late Stephen, he was devoted to his family. Robert is survived by his brother Richard, wife Lynne, two sons David and Joseph, and three stepdaughters, Merrill, Jody, and Donna Lewen. His beloved grandchildren, Lauren and Eric, Rachel and Jalen, Hannah and Eden and Carina will miss him terribly,. In August 2008, Robert received the tremendous gift of a kidney transplant from Claire Theroux Oliver, which provided him the precious opportunity to enjoy numerous events over the remaining portion of his life. Robert's family wishes to recognize and thank the Oliver family for the freedom and opportunities that they gave Robert. Family will received friends on Tuesday 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Services Wednesday, August 19th, 10am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave, at 65th St.

Economic concerns are becoming even more important to cellphone owners, according to a report by Nielsen. Every month, the company surveys 25,000 wireless customers, asking why they chose their current carrier. Price has long been the top factor cited. In the third quarter of 2006, however, before the economy started to sour, the second factor was network quality, followed by the reputation of the carrier. By the first quarter of this year, people had pushed aside quality in favor of saving money. The second factor was the availability of a family plan -- one way to save money. The third factor was what Nielsen calls ''payment options,'' meaning the availability of prepaid service, which is used by people who want to save money and those with bad credit. No. 5 was free in-network calling. Network quality dropped to the sixth spot.

What part of “Monty Python reunion” did you not understand? All six — yes, six — members of that influential British comedy troupe, which supplied us with those classic routines and catch phrases that we could totally recite from memory but won’t bore you with, will come together in New York in the fall for an event to mark the group’s 40th anniversary and to promote a documentary. The anniversary event, to be held on Oct. 15 at the Ziegfeld Theater in Manhattan, was announced Tuesday by the Independent Film Channel and the British Academy of Film and Television Arts, which are jointly organizing the event. In a news release, the groups said that the Monty Python founders John Cleese, Terry Gilliam, Eric Idle, Terry Jones, Michael Palin and, somehow, Graham Chapman (who died in 1989) would be present for a screening of the documentary “Monty Python: Almost the Truth (The Lawyer’s Cut),” after which the surviving comedians would take part in a Q&A session and receive an award from the British Academy. The group has variously reunited several times over the years, from a 1998 appearance at the U.S. Comedy Arts Festival in Aspen to the 2005 opening of the Broadway musical “Monty Python’s Spamalot.” A six-hour version of the documentary will have its premiere on IFC on Oct. 18.

Upon returning to his native India on Tuesday, the Bollywood star Shah Rukh Khan said that an incident Friday, when he was detained by American immigration officials at a New Jersey airport, had been blown out of proportion, but that he would limit his future visits to the United States, The Associated Press reported. Speaking to reporters, Mr. Khan said, “Of course I will visit the U.S. if I have to go for my work, but I will go less often,” according to The A.P. He also asked his fans to cease their protests. “Let’s put this behind us,” Mr. Khan said, “think positively and move ahead.” The actor was detained Friday for about an hour at Newark Liberty International Airport after immigration officials said that his name had come up on a routine alert list. He was promoting a film called “My Name Is Khan,” which addresses the racial profiling of Muslims after Sept. 11, 2001.

The South Orange-Maplewood school district recorded 91 incidents of vandalism, violence or substance abuse last year, according to a state report. The report, which was presented to the Board of Education at last night's meeting, said the incidents included 10 instances of vandalism, 59 instances of violence, 8 instances of weapon possession, and 16 instances of substance abuse. Of reported instances of vandalism, there was no cost involved, officials said. The figures were lower than during the 2007-2008 school year in all categories except substance abuse, when there were only nine incidents reported. "The incidences are going down, this is the second year we have seen declines," said Paul Roth, the district's chief information officer. However, what is, and what is not, reported to the state also changed this year: "If an incident occurs after the school day, it is no longer reported," Mr. Roth said. It is unclear how much the change in state law affected the figures. The 2007-2008 reports for every school district in the state can be found here. -- Heather Hodder

One of the great joys of strolling London - definitely one of the world's greatest cities for aimless wanders - is spotting the city's "blue plaques," signs posted on the facades of buildings that commemorate the lives of those who lived and worked inside. The plaques, which in fact aren't always blue, are themselves objects of beauty, attractively lettered in highly legible fashion and often featuring intricate border designs. Most important, though, they remind the passerby of the incredibly rich historical fabric of this city, viewed through the lens of individuals, some household names, others not, who have called it home. This week, Yale University Press releases "Lived in London: Blue Plaques and the Stories Behind Them," a comprehensive guide to 800 of the plaques arranged by geographic area.The book, which is arranged by geographic area, includes contemporary and archival images as well as lovely illustrated maps detailing where you can find the plaques. Equally enjoyable is the text, which is full of interesting tidbits, like the fact that the critic and biographer Lytton Strachey's lost dissertation was discovered in the basement of his house at 51 Gordon Square more than 30 years after his death, or that the writer H.G. Wells wrote in his own obituary that he occupied "an old tumble-down house" on Hanover Terrace when in fact the house was practically luxurious, then and now. There are plenty of entries about fascinating figures you may never have heard of - such as the calligrapher Edward Johnston, whose sans serif font is used for the London Underground's signage - and one of the compelling things about reading an entire section is learning the historical character (bohemian, prosperous, workaday) of individual London neighborhoods, as evidenced by the kind of people who lived there.

They won't win you popularity points like a Prius will -- unless you have some kind of exhibitionist streak -- but PACT underwear does follow a similar principle: If it's something you have to buy anyway, why not choose the option that makes you feel virtuous? The new brand of men's and women's organic cotton skivvies, founded by two social entrepreneurs in partnership with the design celeb Yves Behar, donates 10 percent of each sale to the nonprofits Oceana, ForestEthics and 826 Valencia, the writing workshop for kids started by Dave Eggers. Each cause has its own pattern, as interpreted by Behar - abstract waves, spindly trees, crisscrossing sentences - though PACT will soon expand the roster of beneficiaries and of artists enlisted to translate them into undergarments. The goal is to get you to stop splashing Bjorn Borg's name across your heinie and start using that space to advertise your good deeds instead. PACT's cheeky motto? "Change starts with your underwear." Indeed.

As fashionistas everywhere know, Saks Fifth Avenue and Barneys are two of the best places in New York to update your closet, but now they are also two of the best places to load your iPod. Thanks to the Music Tee, a high-quality T-shirt that doubles as an album-length digital download, these and other stores are doing their part to help resurrect a moribund music retail industry. The Music Tee is the result of a collaboration between Invisible DJ, an in-store music programming company that's worked with Ron Herman and Juicy Couture, and LnA fashions, whose high-end tees are available at Henri Bendel and Bloomingdales (and are worn by Brad Pitt, Robert Pattinson, Madonna and many others). The fitted T-shirts have the album artwork or graphic design on the front and the track listings on the back. Each one comes with a tag that has its own unique URL, allowing wearers to download the album. At the suggested retail price of $39, no one's going to lose his shirt over a Music Tee.

Needless to say, returning to Seoul as an adult - especially as a jewelry market editor - allowed me to appreciate the city in a new light.One of my favorite finds was Ah-Won Crafts in In Sa Dong, an area of many interesting alleyways filled with antique shops, handmade arts and crafts, and a slew of charming cafes and restaurants. Ah-Won is the Zen-like boutique of an amazing artisan who works mostly with metal. She creates one-of-a-kind pieces, including simple brushed-silver pendants and rings, intricate floral brooches topped with coral and amber, and a collection of dinnerware and flatware.

The initial public offering planned by Dole Foods is a good early test for leveraged buyouts, Breakingviews.com writes. The Broadway cast of “Shrek the Musical” has found a performer to fill the colossal shoes of the flatulent ogre at its center: Ben Crawford, who will succeed Brian d’Arcy James as Shrek on Nov. 10, the show’s publicists said in a news release. Mr. James will depart to join the cast of Manhattan Theater Club’s production of Donald Margulies’s play “Time Stands Still.” Mr. Crawford, currently the stand-by for Shrek, made his Broadway debut in the revival of “Les Misérables,” in which he understudied the roles of Javert and Jean Valjean. ...
