In his novel “Lord of the Flies,” William Golding vividly reminded readers of the primal nature of man lurking beneath his civilized exterior. Golding, who won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1983, was apparently no stranger to the dark side. In an unpublished memoir composed for his wife, Golding, below, who died in 1993, wrote that he tried to rape a 15-year-old girl when he was a young man, The Times of London reported. Golding’s account of the incident was discovered by John Carey, chief book reviewer of The Sunday Times of London and an emeritus professor of English literature at Oxford University, who has written a forthcoming biography, “William Golding: The Man Who Wrote ‘Lord of the Flies,’ ” and had access to Golding’s archives. In the unpublished memoir, called “Men, Women & Now,” Golding wrote that he had tried to rape a friend after returning home at 18 from his first year at Oxford. Golding also wrote that as a schoolteacher he pitted his pupils against one another in “Lord of the Flies”-like experiments to see what happened when he gave them more freedom. “Lord of the Flies,” about a group of schoolboys who revert to savagery when stranded on a deserted island, was published in 1954.

Shah Rukh Khan, below, the Indian film star detained by American immigration officials at a New Jersey airport on Friday, criticized the United States in an interview on Monday, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Khan, who is promoting the film “My Name Is Khan,” which addresses the racial profiling of Muslims in America after Sept. 11, 2001, told the Indian television channel CNN-IBN that the United States did not lead “an isolated, parallel-universe existence,” and that “there is a whole world which makes all the good and bad that is happening,” according to Agence France-Presse. Mr. Khan added: “So if we are scared of violence and terrorism, all of us are responsible for it. It’s not that the world is and America is not.” Mr. Khan was detained at Newark Liberty International Airport after immigration officials said his name had come up on an alert list.

For the second time this summer it has been reported that Prince Charles, below left, sought to have an architect replaced on a major British construction project. The Guardian reported that the prince lobbied for the removal of Jean Nouvel, below right, the French architect and the winner of the 2008 Pritzker Prize, as the designer of an $815 million office and shopping complex planned for a site near St. Paul’s Cathedral, above, the 17th-century structure designed by Christopher Wren. In a 2005 letter sent to the commercial developer Land Securities, The Guardian said, Prince Charles wrote that the complex should feature a design that would “allow St Paul’s to shine bright,” and suggested that his own architectural advisers, who prefer traditional designs, should help. The office of the royal family at Clarence House confirmed to The Guardian that the prince had sent the letter after Mr. Nouvel was named the winner of an international competition to design the complex. In June the architect Richard Rogers accused the prince of abusing his power after he was removed as the designer of a housing project to be built in the Chelsea district of London, near the Royal Hospital designed by Wren.

An eclectic mix of dance groups — from the hip-hop troupe the Groovaloos, above, winners of NBC’s “Superstars of Dance,” to the acclaimed Pacific Northwest Ballet — will be among the companies making their Joyce Theater debuts in the coming season. Some 16 individual performers and companies from across the country and the globe will appear during the season, which begins on Sept. 15 and runs through February. Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet will also come to the Joyce for the first time, as will Balletto Teatro di Torino from Italy, making its first appearance in the United States. Other highlights include the New York premiere of Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company’s “Serenade/The Proposition,” and works by Lucinda Childs, Richard Alston and the Dutch company Emio Greco | PC.

He is to take over at the Estonian orchestra from the conductor Nikolai Alexeev in 2010.

MOLLICA--Mary Jean, beloved wife, mother and grandmother died Saturday, August 15, surrounded by her family at her home in Pennington, NJ. She fought a courageous battle with breast cancer for over 20 years. She was 68. Mrs. Mollica was born in Milwaukee, WI, to the late Vincent and Yolanda Otis. She graduated from University of Wisconsin at Madison in 1964, majoring in Political Science. She married Joseph Mollica in 1964 and moved to the East Coast residing in New York, Delaware and New Jersey for 45 years. They lived in the Princeton area the past 15 years. She never started the day without a New York Times crossword. Her favorite times were spent designing and building numerous homes followed with decorating work inside and hours tending her gardens and ponds outside. She enjoyed golf, tennis and her book club. Her love of her dogs was immense. Besides her husband, Mrs. Mollica is survived by her daughter Christine of Pennington; her son Michael of Pennington; her daughter and son-in-law, Linda and Andrew Lippman of Pennington, and their three children, Caroline, Sarah and Joseph. She is also survived by her sister, Patricia Otis-Abel of New York City. Friends may call Tuesday from 7-9pm at the Blackwell Memorial Home, 21 North Main St., Pennington. A Funeral Mass will be held Wednesday, 10am at St. James Church, 115 East Delaware Ave., Pennington. Burial will be in the Pennington Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations would be appreciated to The D&R Greenway Land Trust, One Preservation Place, Princeton, NJ, 08540 (609)924-4646 www.drgreenway.org

In lieu of flowers donations to New York Public Library or Maryknoll Sisters.
RUBIN--Robert. Beloved cousin, lifelong friend. I will miss you always. Barbara

RUBIN--Robert Michael, at the age of seventy-five passed away peacefully at New York University Hospital on Sunday August 16th in the presence of his family. He lived a life full of rich experiences with family and friends. His home in Weston, CT serves as a gathering place, weekend retreat, and spa. A graduate of the Birch Wathen School in New York City in 1952 and of Brown University in 1956, Mr. Rubin had a successful career as the President of Whitney Stores, Incorporated. Upon his retirement from retailing, Mr. Rubin pursued his interest in African art through a long association with the Museum for African Art in New York, holding the position of Honorary Life Trustee at the time of his death. In addition, his love of African art resulted in numerous trips to different areas of the continent as well as pursuing a private collection. His generosity in loaning a variety of pieces to museums around the world has allowed others to share in his love of African art. He was also a founding board member of the Prison University Project in California of which his stepdaughter Jody Lewen is Executive Director. His contributions were pivotal to the expansion of that organization. Son of the late Doris and Harry and brother to Richard and the late Stephen, he was devoted to his family. Robert is survived by his brother Richard, wife Lynne, two sons David and Joseph, and three stepdaughters, Merrill, Jody, and Donna Lewen. ROSHKOW--Sylvia E.,died August 10 after a courageous fight with multiple myeloma, surrounded and supported by the family she nurtured and adored and that, in turn, adored her. Born in Brooklyn in 1929, she was the youngest of four siblings who helped raise her after her parents both died within a tragically short period when she was still a child. Nicknamed Tippi, she remained the baby of the family her entire life, a role that she embraced and that helped mould her unique blend of self-deprecating humor and eternal optimism. Together with Howard, her husband of fifty-six years, she served as the emotional center of a vital and supportive circle of friends first in Inwood, then New Rochelle and, finally back to Manhattan. Sylvia gratefully assumed the responsibilities of confidante, surrogate parent and mentor to an endless collection of colleagues and friends, as well as friends of her children who constantly sought out her company and advice. Beyond her actual family, she was also honored and appreciated by the many students who passed through her classroom during her almost thirty years as an English professor at Hunter College. She possessed the teacher's ideal skill set: an almost superhuman tolerance, a love of learning, a touch of the theatrical, and finally, a ferocious erudition that she never wore on her sleeve and that informed her successful career as an author of respected textbooks, the last of which she was editing during her final days. She was a loving grandmother to her three grandchildren, all of whom reveled in her playful imagination. She was predeceased by her husband, Howard, sister, Doris Krasnow; and brother, Philip Pearson. She is survived by her daughter, Julia, her son, Matthew, sister, Evelyn Rokaw, her grandchildren Rachel, Jacob and Luke, her son-in-law Steve Salzman, her daughter-in-law Helaine Olen, numerous nieces and nephews, as well as all those touched by her generosity and light. Services are private. Contributions in her memory can be made to the Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation at: www.multiplemyeloma.org

A S Afghanistan prepares for presidential elections this week, Kabul is covered in colorful campaign posters. One is struck by the sheer number of candidates (more than three dozen), but also by the sheer range of attire: pinstriped suits, turbans, hats, capes, vests. Why? In ethnically divided Afghanistan, what a candidate wears sends as powerful a message as what he says. As sketched below, the three top candidates (President Hamid Karzai, Abdullah Abdullah and Ashraf Ghani) have all used dress in their election strategy -- be it for ethnic unity or exclusion. Abdullah Abdullah

Rex Ryan has injected a badly needed dose of energy and humor into the Jets, but his players are not giving him much help getting his defense off the ground. On Monday, the N.F.L. announced that defensive end Shaun Ellis would be suspended for the season opener and fined $100,000 because of his arrest last November for marijuana possession, speeding and driving without insurance. For a team that hopes to play Ravens-style football -- low-scoring games with a great defense and a tough running game limiting the need for a rookie quarterback to win the game with his arm (assuming Mark Sanchez gets the starting job) -- the suspension was not good news. Especially because linebacker Calvin Pace will miss the first four games for violating the league's policy on performance-enhancing drugs.

Retreating from a government-run insurance plan may help the Obama administration gain bipartisan support for a health care overhaul. But can it bridge the generation gap? Older Americans were not really on board with overhauling the system in the first place and have been the age group most resistant to change, according to various surveys. Among them was a Gallup poll in July that indicated fewer than half of Medicare-age people favored changing the system, fearing their own medical care would worsen. Similarly, a CNN/Opinion Research Corporation survey showed the contrast with younger voters, who strongly favor a change.

When a 26-year-old Aboriginal man became the first Australian to die of swine flu in June and dozens of indigenous people fell ill soon after, health officials were saddened but not surprised. For most Australians, swine flu has turned out to be a highly infectious but not particularly life-threatening virus. But the disease is taking a disproportionately heavy toll on indigenous people, highlighting the deep inequalities between them and the white majority here.

The Italian conductor Riccardo Muti will lead the Teatro dell’Opera di Roma, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Muti, who last year agreed to become the music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra starting with its 2010-2011 season, would hold both positions simultaneously after joining the Roman opera house in December 2010. Citing a news release from the city hall of Rome, The A.P. said that Mayor Gianni Alemanno had met with Mr. Muti in Austria to discuss the arrangement. Mr. Muti has previously served as the principal conductor of the New Philharmonia (now Philharmonia) Orchestra in London and the music director of the Philadelphia Orchestra. He turned down the music directorship of the New York Philharmonic in 2000, and in 2005 resigned from La Scala in Milan amid a heated dispute with its musicians and house workers.

“Stop by FringeCentral,” implores an advertisement in all of the programs I have seen so far for productions in the New York International Fringe Festival. While theatergoers who frequent Fringe productions are likely to visit more than one of the many performance spaces during the 17-day event, they may be less likely to pay a visit to FringeCentral. Sure, there is a box office there, but you can also buy tickets on line, so what’s the deal with this place that is hyped in programs and pamphlets as a hub of Fringe activity?

Updated | 1:16 p.m. Having waited nearly a year for the new season of “Mad Men” to have its premiere last Sunday, some fans of that AMC drama discovered on Tuesday that they were briefly able to download the third episode of the new season from the Apple iTunes store, nearly two weeks before the episode is scheduled to be broadcast on television.

Already known for his opinionated — some would say imaginative — takes on notable American events and figures, the filmmaker Oliver Stone will be hitting the history books again in a new television series for Showtime, Reuters reported. In a new series, “Oliver Stone’s Secret History of America,” the director and screenwriter (whose resume includes “Platoon,” “Wall Street” and “The Doors”) will create 10 documentary films that will focus on different episodes in United States history — episodes so secret that perhaps only Mr. Stone knows the truth about them. Reuters said that topics would include the Cold War, Harry S. Truman‘s decision to drop atomic bombs on Japan and the global role of the United States since the fall of Communism. Over the years, Mr. Stone has been criticized for his depictions of John F. Kennedy’s assassination and George W. Bush’s presidency in the films “JFK” and “W.” In a statement, he said he hoped the series would be “the deepest contribution I could ever make in film to my children and the next generation,” according to Reuters.

A British film board took a rare step on Wednesday by banning a Japanese horror film that it said was unrelentingly brutal, even compared to movies like “Saw” and “Hostel,” BBC News reported. The British Board of Film Classification rejected the movie “Grotesque,” a straight-to-DVD release in which a man and a woman are sexually assaulted and tortured. The DVD cannot be cannot be sold legally in Britain under penalty of fine or imprisonment. David Cooke, the director of the classification board, said, “Unlike other recent torture-themed horror works, such as the ‘Saw’ and ‘Hostel’ series, ‘Grotesque’ features minimal narrative or character development and presents the audience with little more than an unrelenting and escalating scenario of humiliation, brutality and sadism.” According to BBC News, the film board has turned down only five films in the last four years (their titles included “Murder Set Pieces” and “Terrorists, Killers and Other Wackos”), and gave its approval to Lars von Trier‘s violent horror film “Antichrist.” The distributors of “Grotesque” can appeal the decision.

Don Hewitt, who changed the course of broadcast news by creating the television magazine “60 Minutes,” fusing journalism and show business as never before, and who then presided over the much-copied program for nearly four decades died Wednesday at his home in Bridgehampton, N.Y. He was 86 and also had a home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

After making us wait a few extra months for the premiere of the new Douglas Carter Beane comedy “Mr. & Mrs. Fitch,” Second Stage Theater has announced the cast for the play. John Lithgow (lately of “All My Sons”) and Jennifer Ehle (“The Coast of Utopia”) will star as a husband-and-wife team of gossip columnists who discover, according to a news release, that “great celebrity can appear out of thin air” when “the social circuit no longer provides any scandalous news.” The play is Mr. Beane’s first for Second Stage since the 2005 debut of his comedy “The Little Dog Laughed,” and the production will reunite him with its director, Scott Ellis, whose recent stint on the Showtime series “Weeds” prompted Second Stage to delay “Mr. & Mrs. Fitch” until its 2009-10 season. The new play is to begin previews on Jan. 26 and open on Feb. 22.

For only the second time in two months, someone has sold more records than Michael Jackson. The first to do so, a month ago, was Daughtry, and this week the country hero George Strait has the best-selling album in the country with “Twang” (MCA Nashville), which opens at No. 1 on the Billboard chart with 155,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan. No. 2 is Neil Diamond‘s new CD/DVD package “Hot August Night/NYC” (Sony), recorded live at Madison Square Garden last year. Available only at Wal-Mart and Sam’s Club stores, it sold 57,000 copies. The Black Eyed Peas are No. 3 with “The E.N.D.” (Interscope), selling 45,000 copies, and the rock band Cobra Starship opens at No. 4 with 42,000 sales of its new “Hot Mess” (Fueled by Ramen/Decaydance). Kings of Leon‘s “Only by the Night” (RCA) is fifth with just under 42,000, which brings that album’s 47-week total to more than 1.3 million.

Covering Afghanistan is an extremely dangerous assignment for any photojournalist -- avoiding ambushes, snipers, roadside bombs and kidnappings take priority over taking photographs. Now there is another concern. Afghan police are threatening photojournalists by pointing guns at them.
From Jenna Wortham at Bits:

Canon announced a lineup of six new PowerShot point-and-shooters today, and while they were all pretty nice, I liked three in particular: a 20X ultrazoom, a slim model with a fast lens, and Canon's first touch-screen snapper.

Braves Manager Bobby Cox decided to make Wednesday a personal doubleheader. Cox made his first trip to the new Yankee Stadium during the day before trekking to Citi Field to manage the Braves against the Mets at night. Cox, who played 220 games for the Yankees in 1968 and 1969, was given a tour of the Yankees' new stadium by Lou Cucuzza, the visiting clubhouse manager.
What's in a name? Hedge funds often have unique and catchy names to differentiate themselves from the hundreds of other funds vying for investors' money. But a new fund may have crossed the line.

Earlier today we posted some interactive maps showing state-by-state health care spending per capita, life expectancy and healthy behaviors. A reader wisely suggested I create a scatterplot with the data to provide a better view of their big-picture relationships. In response, I've whipped up a few graphs that examine these variables, as well as how they're affected by the competitiveness of a given state's health insurance market.

Beverley Eggleston, a Virginia farmer who raises pigs for some New Yorkers' favorite restaurants including Blue Hill, Gramercy Tavern, Five Points and the Momofuku chain, had his delivery rounds disrupted recently by a short stay in Manhattan's noted lockup, the Tombs.
The design competition, which has moved from Bravo to Lifetime, brings back former competitors for the premiere of its long-delayed sixth season.
After 26 years acting in films, Donnie Yen's star is finally rising.

After more than 30 years as a Times foreign correspondent, I've grown used to looking out of the aircraft or jeep or train on arrival in unfamiliar and often inhibiting terrain, and wondering with a mixture of anticipation and anxiety how quickly, and capably, I'll get my professional bearings - and justify the editors' faith in assigning me. The boundary I'll be crossing with this new venture for "At War," our new and expanded blog on the conflicts of the post-9/11 era, is a different kind of challenge - but just as daunting, in its way, as those old forays into unknown lands.
A top Senate Democrat is not optimistic that major changes to the health care system will be enacted this year.
Jay Leno apparently sees himself as the Brett Favre of NBC.

Of all the hedge fund managers on Wall Street, Paul E. Singer is one the most revered. In his latest confidential letter to clients, Mr. Singer, the founder of Elliott Management, a $14 billion hedge fund firm, shares his views on a wide range of topics, including the auto industry bailouts and the new financial regulation.
The clash over health-care reform now centers on the public option: Should it stay or should it go?
The garment district is shrinking, and the city, concerned about its image as a fashion center, wants to help.
A look at Thursday's elections, with voices from the streets of Kabul.

In October 2008, C.Y. Wang, a billionaire who lived in Short Hills, died without a will. Mr. Wang's heirs now are fighting over the fortune he accumulated, as the founder of the Formosa Plastics Group, in Superior Court in Newark.

As September approaches, we here at the T photo department are looking forward to all the blockbuster photography books coming out this fall. But while we wait for William Klein's "Rome," and Robert Frank's "Seven Stories," we've been checking out some more D.I.Y.-style books from other talented lensmen like John Clang, who has recently created two self-published books - one created old-school scrapbook style, with actual images inserted into the clear corner tabs. For these books, Clang has "abducted" people and things from the busy streets of New York and transported them into alternative locations and realities. (Kind of sounds like my day today.) These limited editions are hard to come by, so we've published a few of the images here.
Location: Atlanta

Confirming rumors circulating around the Web this week, MySpace said today that it would acquire iLike, a popular music application for social networks that lets users share playlists and make song recommendations.
Long-term urban homesteaders along with newer arrivals have renovated dozens of Victorian-era houses in a once dilapidated neighborhood in Flint, Mich.
A Queens supermarket group was charged with sex discrimination in a lawsuit filed on Wednesday by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission in Brooklyn Federal Court.

Americans are living nearly two-and-a-half months longer, according to new life expectancy statistics released today. In 2007, life expectancy in the United States reached a high of nearly 78 years, up from 77.7 a year earlier.

Bombings in Iraq and insurgent attacks in Afghanistan aimed at disrupting the presidential election add more scars to two already fragile nations (Slides 1, 2, 3 and 4). Wednesday's show depicts the unrelenting violence of the two wars. Elsewhere, water remains the preferred solution for dealing with the summer heat (Slides 7, 8, 9 and 10).
"Solo show."

Following is the first set of answers from Emily Rosenbaum, professor of sociology at Fordham University and co-author of "The Housing Divide: How Generations of Immigrants Fare in New York's Housing Market." Ms. Rosenbaum is responding to readers' questions about how race influences immigrants' housing options, and what this may mean for the future prospects of some immigrant groups.
Video | President's upbeat upswing becomes matter of great gravity:

Update | 5:54 p.m. Clarified that all the charges brought against Albert Gonzalez have been by federal prosecutors, although through different United States attorney's offices in Massachusetts, New York and New Jersey.

The New York Times Magazine this week is an exploration of the needs of women and girls around the world. It is filled with tales of change in some of the least egalitarian corners of the globe, and in it I write about the money that is nudging that change.

There are some signs that the economy is starting to turn around. If you have been running lean on people, you might be considering hiring someone soon. Happily, there are some very good people out there looking for jobs -- but there are many more less-than-good people. The question is, how do you know which is which? You can get lucky only so often. I can tell you that most of the business problems I've had over the years have been because of bad hiring.
Seen chatting at the N.F.L. owners' meeting in Chicago today: Jets owner Woody Johnson and Vikings owner Zygi Wilf.
Bruce Pask, T Magazine's men's fashion director, writes on style every week.

That other sports have unfortunate elements - equestrian events come in for a particular thrashing (from, for example, comments No. 6, 37, 105) - does not exempt golf from criticism, particularly when the I.O.C. is currently taking golf under consideration. As comment No. 3 on yesterday's post astutely notes: "The standards for getting in [to the Olympics] and staying are legitimately different." Similarly, a job interview is generally a more rigorous trial than hanging onto a job you already have: that's why interviewees dress so well. It takes more for a would-be student to gain admittance to college than it does for one already enrolled not to get tossed out: that's why some of the latter are able to drink or nap or throw the Frisbee - none of which are Olympic sports - so enthusiastically.
Saved by the watermark?
The former head of the regulator that oversaw Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac has joined W.L. Ross & Company as a vice chairman, the distressed investment firm run by Wilbur L. Ross said on Wednesday.
You packed the night before, booked a taxi and even called the airline before arriving at the airport 60 minutes early - only to be delayed for four hours. What else could you have done?

With the offensive star power of Troy Aikman, Emmitt Smith and Michael Irvin powering those dominant Dallas Cowboys teams of the early 1990s, it's easy to forget just how good the Cowboys' defense was.

Perhaps President Obama has "lost control of the argument" over health care and doesn't have the "political muscle" to get his proposals enacted, it was suggested on Wednesday to Robert Gibbs, the president's chief spokesman.
A boy basks in water fountains and sunshine near the South Bank Centre in London.

The first thing I am going to eat when I land in Rome this time (we leave in a couple of weeks) is a scoop of gelato. It doesn't matter what flavor it is, as long as it has a dollop of fresh cream on top. Mmm -- just the thought of that makes my mouth water.

Updated, 3:50 p.m. | Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's re-election campaign issued its most scathing critique to date of its Democratic rival, William C. Thompson Jr., on Wednesday afternoon, saying that he had a "record of failure" as comptroller.
Earlier today I posted about how, despite Seattle voters' rejection of a 20-cent tax on plastic and paper bags, the bag wars are likely to continue.

Since yesterday's update, Bill went from 90kts to 115kts and from a central pressure of 963mb to 950mb. Those figures are as of 15Z today. As I type this update, a reconnaissance aircraft is heading into the core of the storm to determine the latest winds and pressure. Hurricane Bill is located about 1000 miles SSE of Bermuda and heading WNW at 16kts. This motion is expected to turn more NW then N in the coming days, avoiding the US coast, but perhaps threatening Bermuda, Nova Scotia, Newfoundland. Environmental conditions are favorable for additional strengthening, and Bill is forecast to reach 125kts before encountering higher shear and cooler water in 5-6 days.
From our colleagues over at The Frugal Traveler ...

Remember the planned Buick crossover vehicle that was going to get the plug-in hybrid technology that had been earmarked for the Saturn Vue (before General Motors sold Saturn)? You should: G.M. announced the news only two weeks ago.
One more potential (totally unscientific) sign of recovery, or at least a possible sign of the thawing of credit markets: the return of the happy lender dance ads.

The tomatoes are blighted and losing their leaves. The blue Jarrahdale pumpkins are almost done flowering. And the pickling cucumbers are spreading as if they have a mind to creep in the nursery window and make off with the baby. The story of my starter garden seems to have as many plotlines as "Lost"-and as many dark portents. One week, the American rapa makes a tasty dinner salad; the next, it's tougher than a comedy club audience on open-mic night.

LONDON | Life in Shoreditch, an area known for its high concentration of bars and victims of alternative fashion trends, can feel like a grown-up, slightly demented Disneyland. So it seems appropriate that the exhibit "Neurodisney," by the young Swedish artist Martin Wollerstam, is being held at the Old Shoreditch Station, a local train station that has been converted into a coffee shop, through the end of the month.
With the one-year anniversary of Lehman Brothers's collapse fast approaching, prepare to soon see a version of the seminal event on the small screen.
Insurgents struck at the heart of Iraq’s government, killing at least 95 people in the worst attacks since U.S. forces handed over security responsibilities in June.
Christine Muhlke, T Magazine's food editor and de facto concierge, is at your service. Have a dining or imbibing quandary for her? Leave your question in the comments section below.

Updated, 5:27 p.m. | Ringed with Jersey barriers, One Police Plaza, the headquarters of the New York Police Department, is an imposing, fortress-like cube where top law enforcement commanders, and the occasional criminal, go in and out each day. Less well-known is the fact that the building is also a home to 3- and 4-year-old children cavorting around with their toys.

In my column on vermentino in today's newspaper, I make the point that really good white wine can be found from all over Italy. Yet many people still assume the only good wine from Italy must be red. Not true at all, whether you're tasting wine from Alto Adige, Friuli Venezia-Giulia, Umbria, Tuscany, Campania or even Sicily. And for those regions I'm forgetting - I heard you, Valle d'Aoste - please forgive me.
The Big Call is set for tomorrow night.

Our colleagues at Room for Debate have just posted an interesting roundtable discussion on whether President Obama made a mistake in letting Congress take the lead on drafting a health care overhaul. Read it here.

The Securities and Exchange Commission still appears to be picking over the filings for the Bankrate deal. On Tuesday, Apax Partners filed the second amendment to its Schedule TO for its tender offer for all of Bankrate's outstanding shares. And once again, important new information has been disclosed, probably in response to the commission's comments.
House Democrats sent letters to the nation's top insurance companies this week, asking the firms to detail the compensation paid to their executives, as well as company revenue and profits.
Le Fooding, the group that organizes culinary be-ins in France, takes a playful approach to food. For its first event in New York next month, they're playing hide-and-seek with their tickets.
Update | 3:32 p.m. John Smoltz has agreed to a deal with the Cardinals for the major league minimum of $400,000. The Red Sox are on the hook for the remainder of his $5.5 million contract.
Nothing planned for tonight or tomorrow night? Children and families can head outdoors for free and breezy performances, courtesy of the South Orange Performing Arts Center (SOPAC).

Time Warner and YouTube said they had signed an agreement that would make short clips of various Time Warner shows available on the popular video-sharing Web site. The deal is the latest to bring professional content to YouTube.

Updated, 5:34 p.m. | Imagine, after leaving a job at Goldman Sachs, turning down a teaching job in Philadelphia and securing a spot in New York City's vaunted Teaching Fellows program, you are eager to teach children the wonders of geometry and algebra. You send your résumé to dozens of schools, go out to give a sample lesson in the Bronx, and impress the principal enough that she wants to hire you.
House Democrats sent letters to the nation's top insurance companies (PDF) this week, asking the firms to detail the compensation paid to their executives, as well as company revenue and profits.

A number of economists have started proclaiming that the recession is over, or at least that a recovery is just around the corner. Others disagree. Robert Hall, the chairman of the National Bureau of Economic Research's Business Cycle Dating Committee, reportedly indicated recently that the group is still waiting for "activity to surpass its previous peak."
A 1,300-square-foot home built on a grassy sliver of land on Long Island's South Fork is an exercise in seclusion.
Don Hewitt changed the course of broadcast news by creating the television magazine program, “60 Minutes,” for CBS.

Gail Collins: Ross, since this is our last week of conversing I wanted to show my appreciation by not making you talk about health care again. So - how about Michael Vick, the dog-abusing football player who was just signed by the Philadelphia Eagles?

Oliver Perez tripped as he was scampering to cover first base against the Atlanta Braves on Tuesday night, which aggravated his left knee. Perez described his knee as being inflamed and the Mets' left-hander would not guarantee that he would make his next start against Pedro Martinez and Phillies on Sunday.

During these rough economic times, nearly everyone has had to sacrifice. Everyday decisions like buying or packing lunch or indulging in the smallest luxuries -- say, a newspaper or a bagel -- have joined the list of hard choices.
Is the Senate democratic? Is the filibuster evil? Is the United States a republic or a democracy?
Update | 11:08 p.m. Read an article by Steve Lohr on keeping abreast of innovation in the Continuing Education special section.
Danny Meyer is naming his Italian restaurant in the Gramercy Park Hotel Maialino. It means "little pig" or "suckling pig."

On Tuesday I posted two maps: one showing which states' residents practice the healthiest habits (based on smoking, eating and exercise behavior), and one showing each state's per-capita health care spending. There did not seem to be a consistent relationship between a state's habits and how much it spent on health care per resident.
In the wake of Seattle voters' decisive rejection of a proposed 20-cent fee on paper and plastic bags, opponents of disposable shopping bags have vowed to press for an all-out ban on the bags.

Times reporter Joe Drape's new book, "Our Boys," which the "Today" show calls "a happier 'Friday Night Lights,' is an inspiring portrait of the extraordinary high school football team whose quest for perfection sustains its hometown in the heartland. Drape made an appearance on the "Today" show Wednesday morning.
Especially with tomatoes having a rough summer, corn salads are bigger than ever. This week's Minimalist column is one, and just by looking at it you can imagine several others.

Neither political wrangling nor a global economic crisis has managed to pull the plug on an ambitious plan by the Paris mayor's office to bring zero-emission car-sharing to the French capital by 2011. The concept is championed by Mayor Bertrand Delanoë as another step in the city's efforts to promote eco-minded alternatives to traditional urban transportation.
An occasional assemblage of overheard or underappreciated words - generously submitted by co-vocabularists.

It pains me to install electric wiring in the cabin -- all of those holes in my studs and beams! Yes, the cabin's structural integrity remains intact, but still, a two by four with a three-quarter-inch hole bored through its center (to provide passage for a wire) is not the sturdy soldier it once was. But drill I must. So that's how I spent most of Sunday: boring holes and pulling wire.

To follow up on Monday's Lede post about a new law that restricts the rights of Shiite women in Afghanistan, we should note that in some Afghan cities women have managed to take part in the country's post-Taliban government. In this BBC video report from Herat, Jane Corbin reports on the work of the city's first female prosecutor, Maria Bashir. Ms. Bashir is Herat's top law-enforcement official, but, because of threats, she is forced to live and work surrounded by armed guards, and her children are unable to leave their home to go to school.

The fastball that left David Wright with a concussion last Saturday was the latest blow to the Mets in a year that has alternated between bad comedy and minor catastrophe. It brought the season full circle because Wright was also the Mets' first victim of 2009, a power hitter who could not cope with Citi Field's oversize dimensions.

You're not supposed to judge a book by its cover, but that advice sometimes goes out the window at a comic book store. With racks and racks of new issues, a great cover is sometimes the best way to hook a new reader. And when you want your book to pop out, who better to turn to than the esteemed graphic designer Chip Kidd?
The cabinet of German Chancellor Angela Merkel is seeking to put one million electric cars on the country's roads by the end of the next decade.

Updated, 4:15 p.m. | More than 100 trees were toppled and hundreds more were damaged in Central Park during the fierce thunderstorm that moved over New York City on Tuesday night. It was the most severe destruction that the park's trees had sustained in at least 30 years, according to officials at the city's Department of Parks and Recreation and the Central Park Conservancy, which manages the park.

In these final dog days of summer, while the rest of us are indulging in minor enthusiasms, or zoning out entirely, T's columnists have been busy at work: thinking! (So you don't have to.) Suzy Menkes, who lived through the 1980s and still has the proof stuck in her closet, is contemplating how to wear big shoulders again. Courage, Suzy. Alice Rawsthorn explains how a midcentury potter can be relevant to a fashion visionary like Raf Simons. And Holly Brubach discovers the anti-Didion, a forgotten writer named Eve Babitz, who makes the case for L.A. in the most beguiling way. Finally, there is the Samurai Shopper, as curmudgeonly as ever. She's slathering herself with lotions and potions, and cursing the naming gods for calling a furrow, or a crevice, an indentation, a pleat, a crease, a crater, exactly what it is: a wrinkle. Poor S.S. Fair.

There's a mesmerizing book out called "Running the Numbers, an American Self Portrait" by the visual artist Chris Jordan, who manipulates digital images of thousands -- sometimes millions -- of cigarette packs, pencils, drink containers and other artifacts of modern living to convey the massive scale of our impact on the environment. (Here he is on coal consumption.) Click on this slide show for a zooming look at "Gyre," his effort to bring meaning to the diffuse and distant problem of plastic pollution in the Pacific Ocean. This piece, which is 8 by 11 feet on a wall, is from a followup collection, "Running the Numbers II."
Don Hewitt, who changed the course of broadcast history with the revolutionary newsmagazine "60 Minutes," died Wednesday at his home in Bridgehampton, N.Y. The cause was cancer.
UPDATE: The winners and honorable mentions have now been posted on this blog.
Rifles and machine guns are the most lethal weapons in conventional ground war. Why have their bullets been more lethal against Americans in Iraq than in Afghanistan?

It's not every day that members of a Board of Education get assigned "homework." So there was something satisfying last night when Judith Ferguson from Hazard, Young, Attea & Associates, the firm hired to assist the search for the new Millburn schools superintendent, asked the Board of Education to get busy -- and during summer vacation! -- to come up with a wish list of attributes.
NYC & Company, the city's tourism organization, has partnered with American Airlines to offer discounted fares to New York City this fall. One-way fares, for travel Sept. 15 to Dec. 12, include:
What we're looking at on the Web today ...
On Wednesday, R.R. Donnelley & Sons began an offer to repurchase outstanding debt and said it would sell another $350 million in debt to finance the offer, The Associated Press reported.

Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on CBS: You think it's hot here in New York City, it's also hot down in Washington, D.C. It's so hot in Washington, D.C. that today, President Obama invited Professor Henry Louis Gates Jr. and Sergeant Crowley to the White House to run through the sprinkler.

Tom Sherak, a veteran film executive who was long associated with 20th Century Fox and then Revolution Studios, was named president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences in a changing of the guard that followed the unusually active term of Sidney Ganis, a film producer whose four-year run in the presidency expired on Tuesday. Mr. Sherak was voted into office by the academy's board of governors at a meeting in Beverly Hills, Calif., on Tuesday evening.

LONDON | Greyhound may be an icon of American culture, but expect to see the brand's buses on British roads starting next month. As The New York Times reports, Greyhound will begin runs connecting London with Southampton and Portsmouth beginning Sept. 14. Ticket prices will start at £1 (about $1.66).

Our colleague Sam Dagher reports from Baghdad on a string of truck bombings and other attacks that rocked areas around official buildings in central Baghdad, killing scores and wounding hundreds. As Mr. Dagher notes, the attacks, taken together, were among the most devastating in Baghdad since the withdrawal of American forces from street patrols at the end of June.
Q.
For a multibillion dollar business, the food industry can move swiftly when it wants to.
T Magazine's beauty/style director, Sandra Ballentine, opens up her little black book of tips on where to go, what to buy and whom to know.
President Obama will sit down with conservative radio host Michael Smerconish on Thursday in what will be the first radio show broadcast from the White House since Mr. Obama took office.

Richard B. Stewart, a former vice chairman of Lehman Brothers, and Peter Monroe, a former president of the Resolution Trust Corporation's oversight board during the savings-and-loan crisis in the early 1990s, said they have formed a $1.5 billion joint venture to buy and sell distressed residential real estate assets.

On Wednesday in Tehran, the reformist cleric Mehdi Karroubi asked to meet with President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and other senior Iranian officials to present "documents and evidence" supporting his claims that some protesters detained during post-election demonstrations in Iran had been raped in custody.

Former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo rarely plays the endorsement game when it comes to Democratic primaries. In fact, he can't remember the last time he endorsed a candidate for a New York City race. But on Wednesday, he threw his weight to the race for public advocate on behalf of someone he and his son, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo, like a lot: City Councilman Bill de Blasio.

Having waited nearly a year for the new season of "Mad Men" to have its premiere last Sunday, some fans of that AMC drama discovered on Tuesday that they were briefly able to download the third episode of the new season from the Apple iTunes store, nearly two weeks before the episode is scheduled to be broadcast on television.

On Wednesday, the Swiss banking giant UBS reached a final deal with the Justice Department and the Internal Revenue Service in which it will ultimately disclose names and account details for more than 4,000 wealthy Americans suspected of tax evasion.

Americans owning soccer teams overseas is nothing new: three of the top four English Premier League teams -- Manchester United, Liverpool and Arsenal -- are owned entirely or in large part by American businessmen. The Cleveland Browns' owner, Randy Lerner, owns Aston Villa.
From our colleagues at DealBook:

Every day, it seems, we get more information about how the economy is doing. Some days, the reports make it sound as if we've at least hit bottom and things might be improving. Other days, there's more cause for concern.

To follow up on Monday's Lede blog post about a new law that restricts the rights of Shiite women in Afghanistan, we should note that in some Afghan cities women have managed to take part in the country's post-Taliban government. In this BBC video report from Herat, Jane Corbin reports on the work of the city's first female prosecutor, Maria Bashir. Ms. Bashir is Herat's top law-enforcement official, but, because of threats, she is forced to live and work surrounded by armed guards, and her children are unable to leave their home to go to school.
The debate over whether the government should offer a public insurance plan is all about competition. How competitive is the private insurance market right now? It depends on where you live.
Update | 12:15 p.m. Happy birthday, GOOG.

In response to my column and post on climate engineering, Charlie offered a comment: "I am really surprised that a libertarian and climate skeptic such as yourself does not react with horror at the concept of geoengineering." He chastised me for putting too much faith in the computer climate models that would be used to engineer the climate, and for not being skeptical of "willful intrusion by state actors in a complex, chaotic, global system."

High school and college students who take the opportunity to "shadow" a person at their place of business find that this helps them explore their passions and interests and how they can connect their academic strengths to real world careers. As a great percentage of freshmen and sophomores have not chosen a major, exploring how they feel in a variety of settings can aid decision-making.
The Trabant, one of the enduring relics of the cold war, was brought into existence when East Germany converted a motorcycle and tractor plant to make cars.
Environmental opposition often means that new hydropower facilities are non-starters. But there may be a way around that: retrofitting existing dams.
If it's opinions you want about health care - whether to nod in agreement or gnash your teeth - today's Times editorial and op-ed pages are ready to serve.

In the five months since Matt Gross, the Frugal Traveler wrote about cheap ways to phone home in "Staying in Touch Internationally, on the Cheap" (March 24), much has changed in the world of making affordable, even free, calls while traveling. And not all of it is good. Read the full post.

A review of how New York City's $80 billion system has performed since William C. Thompson Jr. took office as comptroller shows it has consistently lagged behind many of its public pension peers even as the city tripled the number of money managers it uses and the fees that it pays those companies.
President Obama will try to pump some gas into overhauling health care again on Wednesday, but not before he greets a few citizens who make a living pressing the pedal to the floor.

Details of the landmark settlement of the United States tax case against UBS are expected this week, which should help the bank restore its image and open the way for the Swiss state to sell its UBS stake, Reuters reported.
Q.
Oncology nurse Theresa Brown is a regular contributor to Well.

Brad Liljequist, the project manager overseeing the development of several so-called zero-net energy homes -- that is, super-efficient homes promising to consume less energy than they generate through solar power and other means -- recalled with chagrin a groundbreaking ceremony for a project in Issaquah, Wash., last fall.

Wealthy United States citizens using a tax-evasion amnesty program have identified nearly 10 Swiss and European banks where their accounts are held, including the Credit Suisse Group, Julius Bär Holding, Zürcher Kantonalbank and Union Bancaire Privée, The Wall Street Journal reported on Wednesday, citing undisclosed sources.

The Lincoln Financial Group, the Philadelphia insurer, said on Wednesday that it had agreed to sell its asset-management unit, Delaware Management Holdings, for $428 million to the Australian banking giant the Macquarie Group.
The United States is building criminal cases against more than 150 American clients of UBS as part of a crackdown on tax evasion now made easier by a deal over access to secret account information.

The Macquarie Group, the largest Australian bank, has entered into a venture with China Everbright to form two funds that will seek a total of $1.5 billion for infrastructure projects. The pairing is the fourth and most ambitious group to announce major new plans for mainland China this month.

The Phoenix Group, the German drug wholesaler started by the late billionaire Adolf Merckle, is considering an initial public offering as well as a sale, two people familiar with the plans told Bloomberg News.
Carlene Bauer is the author of a memoir, "Not That Kind of Girl."

Investcorp of Bahrain has posted a loss of $780.6 million for its fiscal year as its holdings in the West were struck by the "severe impact" of the world financial crisis, The Associated Press reported.

Turning the tables on recent events, an investment bank is coming to the government's rescue, The Los Angeles Times reported. The government in question is that of the state of California which got the cold shoulder last month when it asked banks to continue cashing its I.O.U.s.

A flock of private equity firms are planning I.P.O.s to capture what they believe could be the biggest buying spree of troubled real estate assets since the early 1990s, Time Magazine wrote on its Web site.

Today's idea: The Harry Potter series -- once shunned in the religious world for its positive depiction of wizardry -- is being reconsidered in a kinder light as studies of religion in popular culture expand.
The cartoonist Hergé is popular again, as is his adventurous reporter Tintin, who will be featured in a Steven Spielberg movie due out in 2011.

From an innocuous 1988 meeting to flirtation, lunches -- along with other afternoon delights -- and, ultimately, betrayal, Sheryl Weinstein recounts her recently disclosed affair with convicted Ponzi schemer Bernard L. Madoff in her new book, "Madoff's Other Secret: Love, Money, Bernie, and Me."
President Obama plans two major public outreach events in the next two days to try to galvanize support for overhauling the health care system.
Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

BERLIN | In 1982, without knowing the Berlin Wall would fall only seven years later, the East German writer Volker Braun penned a play called "Die Übergangsgesellschaft" ("Society in Transition"), a scathing comedy that dissected life in what was then East Germany.
Pulte Homes' $1.53 billion takeover of the rival Centex was approved by shareholders of both companies on Tuesday, creating the largest home builder in the United States.

Anschutz has sued Standard & Poor's, Moody's Investors Service and Fitch Ratings more than $59 million in losses from auction-rate securities underwritten, rated and sold by the companies, Bloomberg News reported.
HSBC is in advanced talks with China's Industrial Securities to create an investment banking venture, Reuters said, citing a report from Hong Kong's Apple Daily.

Itochu, the Japanese trading firm, and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts are discussing putting forth a joint bid for Citigroup's Bellsystem24, in what could prove to be the largest private equity deal in Japan this year, sources told Reuters.

Sinopec Group said Tuesday it has completed its $7.5 billion acquisition of Addax Petroleum, obtaining new reserves in Africa and the Middle East in China's biggest foreign corporate takeover to date.
Freddie Mac, the American mortgage giant, on Tuesday named Bruce Witherell as its new chief operating officer, effective Sept. 14.
Hedge funds are having their best year since 1998, yet most fund managers still are well below their peaks before the market's meltdown last year, industry analysts said.
iBasis said on Tuesday it is suing its majority owner Royal KPN in an effort to stop a hostile takeover bid.
Sequoia Capital, one of the most successful Silicon Valley venture capital firms, has redesigned its Web site's home page, reducing it to a simple search bar, VentureBeat writes.

I was 9 years old, living in a small town in south Florida, when I read Grey Villet's "Lash of Success" in Life magazine - one of the very few extras my family could afford. The pages of Life were filled with images of President John F. Kennedy, the space program and rising stars of television. Yet it was the subject and style of "Lash" - about a businessman sacrificing his humanity in pursuit of success - that had the greatest impact upon me. I have never forgotten it.

An article on Tuesday about “The House of God,” a novel popular for three decades among medical students and professionals, misstated the affiliation of one doctor and referred incorrectly to his relationship to the characters in the book. Dr. Robert Press is an internist in Manhattan, not a psychiatrist in Denver. And while he was one of the people whose experiences were fictionalized in the book, he was not the basis for the character of Runt.

An article on Saturday about the Oregon Shakespeare Festival and its artistic director, Bill Rauch, who acknowledged that his casting of nonwhite actors in revivals of American classics has been controversial, incompletely quoted a review that commented on the African-American actress Gwendolyn Mulamba’s performance as Marian the Librarian in the festival’s production of “The Music Man.” While the review, by Misha Berson of The Seattle Times, said that Ms. Mulamba “was a very fine O.S.F. actress” who had been “sorely miscast,” it also made clear that the “sorely miscast” comment was based on her acting and singing in the production, not her race.

A picture caption on June 4 with an article about a verdict in a murder case against Darryl Littlejohn, a former bouncer at a SoHo bar accused of killing a graduate student, overstated the charges for which he was convicted. He was found guilty only of first-degree murder, not first-degree murder and sexual abuse. (A finding of first-degree murder means that the crime took place during the commission of another felony — in this case, sexual abuse.) A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message on Monday.

Michael Jackson will be buried on what would have been his 51st birthday, publicists for the Jackson family said on Tuesday. The publicity firm Sunshine, Sachs & Associates announced that Mr. Jackson would be buried on Aug. 29 at 10 a.m., at Forest Lawn Memorial Park, above, in Glendale, Calif. The firm said that the burial ceremony would be private — limited to the Jackson family and close friends — but that there would be nearby accommodations for the news media. The Jackson family, the announcement said, “once again wishes to express its gratitude to Michael’s fans around the world for their support during these difficult times.” Also on Aug. 29, The Associated Press reported, the filmmaker Spike Lee, right, will host a block-party-style celebration in Brooklyn to commemorate Mr. Jackson’s birthday. Mr. Jackson died on June 25 after suffering cardiac arrest; the Los Angeles County coroner’s office has not released the results of its investigation into his death. He was honored at a public memorial on July 7 at the Staples Center in Los Angeles.

Gen Art, the company that produces the independent Gen Art Film Festival, is to announce on Wednesday that it is merging with Rock Media & Entertainment, which also specializes in media and fashion events, the companies said. The new company will be called RMGA and will continue to produce content and events under the Gen Art and Rock Media brands. It will be run by executives from both companies, and combine offices in New York, Los Angeles and Miami.

Nicholas D. Kristof, a columnist for The New York Times, and Sheryl WuDunn, a former reporter and editor for The Times, were named the recipients of the 2009 Dayton Literary Peace Prize for Lifetime Achievement, its organizers announced on Wednesday. The prize’s committee said that Mr. Kristof and Ms. WuDunn, who shared a Pulitzer Prize in 1990 for their coverage of the democracy movement and its suppression in China, were chosen “in recognition of their work chronicling human rights in Asia, Africa, and the developing world.” The prize committee also announced the finalists for its fiction and nonfiction categories. The fiction nominees include “Peace” by Richard Bausch; “The Plague of Doves” by Louise Erdrich; and “Beijing Coma” by Ma Jian. The nonfiction finalists include “Human Smoke: The Beginnings of World War II, the End of Civilization” by Nicholson Baker; and “Hot, Flat, and Crowded” by Thomas L. Friedman, a columnist for The Times. A winner and a runner-up in both categories will be announced on Sept. 22.

After returning to his native India on Tuesday, the Bollywood star Shah Rukh Khan said that his detention by immigration officials at Newark Liberty International Airport had been blown out of proportion, but that he would limit his future visits to the United States, The Associated Press reported. Speaking to reporters, Mr. Khan said, “Of course I will visit the U.S. if I have to go for my work, but I will go less often,” according to The A.P. He also asked his fans to cease their protests. “Let’s put this behind us,” Mr. Khan said, “think positively and move ahead.” The actor was detained on Friday for about an hour at the Newark airport after United States immigration officials said his name had come up on a routine alert list. He was promoting his film “My Name Is Khan,” which addresses the racial profiling of Muslims after Sept. 11, 2001.

A Scottish court said Tuesday that it would allow the only person jailed for the 1988 Lockerbie bombing to abandon an appeal against his conviction, technically removing one of several obstacles to the man's early return home to Libya. But with American opposition building to any early release of the prisoner, Abdel Basset Ali al-Megrahi, there was no clear indication whether the court's decision would accelerate his release from Greenock prison in Scotland, where he is serving a minimum 27-year term imposed in 2001. His lawyers maintain that he is close to death from terminal prostate cancer.

SEMMEL--Bernard. The family of Bernard Semmel, who died August 18, 2008, would like to thank friends, colleagues, and students who have shared reminiscences this past year. A remarkable historian, he was thoroughly decent, kind, and warm, ready to share his wit and joyful song with all. Born in the Bronx in 1928, he graduated from CCNY, received his Ph.D. from Columbia University, and did further study at the London School of Economics. A member of the history department at SUNY Stony Brook from 1960-90, he then served as Distinguished Professor of History at the CUNY Graduate School until retiring in 1996. He received fellowships from the Rockefeller Foundation, the American Council of Learned Societies, the Guggenheim Foundation, and the National Humanities Center. He was the editor of the Journal of British Studies, a Fellow of the Royal Historical Society, and served on the professional division of the American Historical Association. He published 11 books, among them Imperialism and Social Reform, Jamaican Blood and Victorian Conscience, The Rise of Free Trade Imperialism, The Methodist Revolution, John Stuart Mill and the Pursuit of Virtue, and George Eliot and the Politics of National Inheritance. His historical scholarship was driven by a love of the past for its own sake, but also by the conviction that its study could shed light on contemporary problems, not least the tension between democratic politics and geopolitical power. He loved New York and London and made his home in Stony Brook for over 40 years. He was devoted to his family, and they to him. In loving memory, Maxine, Stuart, Tina, Tovah, Natalie, Eli, and Ada.

HAMLIN--Joanne Capen, on August 11, 2009. Wife of the late George Hamlin, Jr., mother of Jeffrey Hamlin, grandmother of James Hamlin. Many will remember Joanne as an actor, others as a high school and Sunday school teacher and others as a writer. All who knew her will remember Joanne's remarkable capacity for friendship, her interest in and support of all those she knew as well as her spirited and inquisitive nature. In a role she performed to great acclaim, Winnie, in Samuel Beckett's Happy Days, captures Joanne's essence when she says "That's what I find so wonderful that not a day goes by-to speak in the old style-hardly a day, without some blessing...in disguise." God speed Joanne and flights of angels sing thee to thy rest.

SINEK--Marion, passed away peacefully on August 17th, 2009 after a long illness. She was 78 years old. Born in Berlin, Germany, she came to the US just before WWII. She graduated from Syracuse University. After graduate work at the London School of Economics, she worked for Radio Free Europe and the UN Assoc.-USA. Marion later became very active in public affairs, serving as President of the LWV of NY. She ran for office, serving as a Town Board member in New Castle before becoming its Supervisor for two terms. She later worked with Sen. Hillary Clinton on election law issues, and remained active in Democratic politics and other organizations. Her husband Herbert predeceased her; she is survived by children Ron and Nicole (Arnaboldi), their spouses Jennifer and Leo, and seven grandchildren. Burial will be private. A memorial will be held in September. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

The debate over whether the government should offer a public insurance plan is all about competition. How competitive is the private insurance market right now? It depends on where you live. As a general rule, the larger, more densely populated states have the most choice -- and even the biggest insurer controls only a minority share of the market. According to statistics from the American Medical Association, the leading insurance provider in California covers 24 percent of the population, while in New York the figure is 26 percent and in Florida, 30 percent.

A member of the faculty for more than three decades, he taught many of today's leading Jewish educators and scholars, and his constant inquiry into new ideas and methods made him an extraordinary role model for Jewish educators throughout the world. Several of the franchises in Women's Professional Soccer have lost twice as much revenue as expected this season, mainly because of a lack of local sponsorship deals, according to Tonya Antonucci, the league's commissioner. Those franchises, she said, had lost $1 million to $2 million. Although the league has landed big-name sponsors like Puma, teams have had a difficult time signing local sponsors.

After a year of negotiations, Amcor, the Australian packaging maker, has entered a binding offer to buy parts of Alcan Packaging, a unit of Rio Tinto, for slightly more than $2 billion, the companies announced on Tuesday. For Amcor, the deal offers the prospect of a larger role in the global packaging industry as well as an improvement in its earnings a share. For the mining company Rio Tinto, the sale would provide cash to pay down its huge debt, which it estimated at $23.2 billion in June.

STERN--Anne Bigelow, 92, died August 15, 2009 in Blue Hill, Maine. Born Anne Bigelow Rosen on June 21, 1917 in New York City, she graduated from The Brearley School in 1934 and attended Barnard College. From her earliest years she led a life steeped in the arts. Her father, Walter Tower Rosen, was a noted collector of decorative arts and accomplished amateur pianist and her mother, Lucie Bigelow Dodge Rosen, was a pioneer of early electronic music, playing the Theremin and touring internationally. In 1937 Anne married her first husband, Hungarian cellist and art historian Janos Scholz, and in 1957 married Carl Stern, first cellist of the New York Philharmonic. She was an active patron of the arts and education. After her mother's death in 1968, she worked to realize her parents' vision of converting their home into a public museum to compliment the summer music festival they began there in 1945, serving the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts as president and board member for more than 20 years. She was a trustee of The Brearley School for 17 years, receiving the Frances Riker Davis Alumnae Award in 1971 for her dedication. She was the first woman to join the board of the Musician's Foundation in the 1960s and served as its president. She also served as president of the board of Kneisel Hall Chamber Music School and Festival, sitting on the board for more than 25 years. In 1997 she was given the Maine College of Art award for Community Leadership in Music and the Arts for her life-long support of the arts and education. She was a member of the Cosmopolitan Club and the Grolier Club. She is survived by her son, John Bigelow Scholz, and his wife, Margaret E. Barclay, of Camden, Maine and her granddaughter Lucie Anne Scholz of Portland, Maine. She was predeceased by her brother, Flying Officer Walter Bigelow Rosen, R.C.A.F.; her son, actor Walter Rosen Scholz; and her two husbands. A service will be held at St. Matthew's Church in Bedford, New York, this autumn. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Kneisel Hall, P O Box 648, Blue Hill, ME 04614 (www.kneisel.org), Musicians Foundation, Inc. 875 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10001-3507 (www. musiciansfoundation.org), or The Brearley School, 610 E. 83rd St., New York, NY 10028-7988 (www.brearley.org) Condolences may be expressed at www.jordanfernald.com

RUBIN--Robert Michael, at the age of seventy-five passed away peacefully at New York University Hospital on Sunday August 16th in the presence of his family. He lived a life full of rich experiences with family and friends. His home in Weston, CT serves as a gathering place, weekend retreat, and spa. A graduate of the Birch Wathen School in New York City in 1952 and of Brown University in 1956, Mr. Rubin had a successful career as the President of Whitney Stores, Incorporated. Upon his retirement from retailing, Mr. Rubin pursued his interest in African art through a long association with the Museum for African Art in New York, holding the position of Honorary Life Trustee at the time of his death. In addition, his love of African art resulted in numerous trips to different areas of the continent as well as pursuing a private collection. His generosity in loaning a variety of pieces to museums around the world has allowed others to share in his love of African art. He was also a founding board member of the Prison University Project in California of which his stepdaughter Jody Lewen is Executive Director. His contributions were pivotal to the expansion of that organization. Son of the late Doris and Harry and brother to Richard and the late Stephen, he was devoted to his family. Robert is survived by his brother Richard, wife Lynne, two sons David and Joseph, and three stepdaughters, Merrill, Jody, and Donna Lewen. His beloved grandchildren, Laura and Eric, Rachel and Jalen, Hannah and Eden and Carina will miss him terribly. In August 2008, Robert received the tremendous gift of a kidney transplant from Claire Theroux Oliver, which provided him the precious opportunity to enjoy numerous events over the remaining portion of his life. Robert's family wishes to recognize and thank the Oliver family for the freedom and opportunities that they gave Robert. Family will received friends on Tuesday 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Services Wednesday, August 19th, 10am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave, at 65th St.

Of course, I don’t know if I ever recovered from first seeing the image, shown here again, of Ms. Suleman’s Hyundai-sized belly during her final months of pregnancy, ridden with enough stretch marks to look like a Nascar track.

Quentin Tarantino‘s new World War II movie “Inglourious Basterds” has received its share of praise and pans from critics in the United States (The Times’s review by Manohla Dargis can be found here). But the film is being received with particular enthusiasm by German reviewers, who are cheering its decidedly unflattering depiction of the Nazi regime, Agence France-Presse reported.

More than 40 years after Old Fred fired up the titular vehicle of “Yellow Submarine” and used it to round up four Liverpool lads who would defend Pepperland from the Blue Meanies, Disney is preparing a remake of the Beatles’ 1968 animated movie, Variety reported.

For the past 25 years, Works & Process at the Guggenheim has been offering a close-up look at artists and their work. The coming season will be no exception. Isabella Rossellini, Isaac Mizrahi, Karole Armitage and Steve Reich are just a few of the artists who will be taking part, beginning Sept. 11. In conjunction with the Kandinsky retrospective at the museum, the artist Rafael Lozano-Hemmer has created an interactive light installation inspired by Kandinsky’s “Yellow Sound” where colors are derived by the human voice and which features a reading by Ms. Rossellini. Another Kandinsky-inspired program will feature Armitage Gone! Dance and the Brentano String Quartet. Additional highlights include a new dance commission featuring Larry Keigwin and Peter Quanz to music by Mr. Reich; the world premiere of Elliott Carter’s “Duettone;” performances by Shen Wei Dance Arts and American Ballet Theater; a discussion of New York City Opera’s revival of “Esther” and more.

When Marjane Satrapi‘s graphic-novel memoir “Persepolis” was first published (reaching the United States in 2003), it was praised as an authentic look at life in Iran during that country’s 1979 revolution and its war with Iraq. Now, with Ms. Satrapi’s permission, an updated version of the book has been created, combining Ms. Satrapi’s illustrations with new text to tell the story of Iran’s recent presidential election, Agence France-Presse reported.

The largest contemporary art show in India opened Thursday in New Delhi without the works of one of the country’s best regarded painters, amid concerns that his paintings will prompt attacks by religious extremists, Agence France-Presse reported. Organizers for the three-day India Art Summit said that they would not display works by Maqbool Fida Husain, the 94-year-old Muslim painter known as the “Picasso of India,” whose paintings portray Hindu deities, sometimes in the nude or in sexually suggestive poses. “We acknowledge the iconic stature of Husain, but are unable to put all the people and art work at risk,” said Neha Kirpal, the show’s associate director, according to Agence France-Presse. Last year, some of Mr. Husain’s paintings were attacked by members of Bajrang Dal, a right-wing Hindu group, at an event in New Delhi. Religious hardliners have also filed more than 800 court cases against him and vandalized his house.

Big buzz preceded the Fringe Festival show “Abraham Lincoln’s Big Gay Dance Party.” A successful run last year at the SF Playhouse in San Francisco and a glowing review in Variety helped the show sell out its Fringe run well before Tuesday night’s first performance.

Though his run on the cult HBO series “Lucky Louie” wasn’t especially fortunate, the comedian Louis C.K. will return to cable television next year in a new FX series called “Louie,” the network announced on Thursday. And its star and creator is already promising a series unlike anything he’s done before.

Don Hewitt will be remembered by the program he founded, “60 Minutes,” on Sunday evening. Mr. Hewitt died Wednesday at the age of 86. CBS said that the correspondents for the pioneering newsmagazine, including Steve Kroft, Morley Safer and Lesley Stahl, were preparing segments that would detail Mr. Hewitt’s life and his “lasting contributions to the television news industry.”

Doug Pray has made movies about surfers, truck drivers and rock musicians. Yet making a positive movie about advertising may have been one of his greatest challenges. In “Art & Copy,” Mr. Pray conducts interviews with some of the most influential players in the advertising industry, including Dan Wieden and David Kennedy, whose firm coined the “Just do it” campaign for Nike. Mr. Pray recently answered questions about his film, which was commissioned by The One Club, an organization that promotes excellence in advertising.

Those who didn’t catch the musical “Passing Strange” when it was both on and Off Broadway, will now have a chance to get a close-up look at the show. Spike Lee’s filmed version of the musical opens in theaters Aug. 21, and merges his talents with those of Stew, the star and co-writer of this semi-autobiographical story.

Team Canada are the odds-on favorites to win the gold medal at home this February, but they'd be favored even if the Olympics were being held just about anywhere else in the world other than Vancouver (possible exception: Moscow). Emory Douglas, the minister of culture for the Black Panthers in the 1960s and 1970s, defined the party's visual identity by drawing bold, graphic images - women bearing rifles, men and women draped in bandoliers - that aimed to empower a group that felt powerless. (He was also known for rendering politicians as rats and policeman as pigs.) Thirty years after the Panthers disbanded, and in conjunction with the retrospective "Emory Douglas: Black Panther" currently on view at the New Museum of Contemporary Art (through Oct. 18), the revolution begins again. A group of Harlem teenagers have remixed three of Douglas's earlier images from the newspaper The Black Panther with some of his more recent images to create a mural that addresses local community concerns - education, health care and unity. In partnership with the New Museum, the Studio Museum in Harlem and Groundswell, a nonprofit organization that brings artists and communities together, the mural, titled "What We Want, What We Believe," will be the first public artwork celebrating the work of Douglas in New York City. You can check it out at VIM Store, 2253 Third Avenue.

The world's savviest hackers are on to the "real-time Web" and using it to devilish effect. The real-time Web is the fire hose of information coming from services like Twitter. The latest generation of Trojans - nasty little programs that hacking gangs use to burrow onto your computer - sends a Twitter-like stream of updates about everything you do back to their controllers, many of whom, researchers say, are in Eastern Europe. Trojans used to just accumulate secret diaries of your Web surfing and periodically sent the results on to the hacker.

Taiana Giefer is only 21 years old, but her edgy, felted merino wool textiles have already captured the attention of some pretty influential fashion folk. Francisco Costa collaborated with the New York-based designer on custom fabrics for his fall Calvin Klein collection, and Rick Owens liked her cloud-soft creations so much that he decided to sell them at his Paris boutique. Giefer -- whose boyfriend is the artist and Abraxas Rex jewelry designer Paris Kain -- also sells her hand-woven scarves, throws and blankets at Maxfield in Los Angeles. Each richly textured piece is one of a kind and takes up to a week to make. "I love creating things that are new and innovative, but really show off the handwork that went into them," she says. Get them while they're relatively affordable: prices start at $300 for a small scarf and go up to $3,000 for a large blanket or tapestry. Go to taianadesign.com for more information.

My friend the photographer Dominic Mondavi, who took the photographs above and below, recently spent a week in Kiev, Ukraine, and reported back on what's making the city tick during these last weeks of summer. He says anyone who's not working (which is basically everyone, this being August in Europe) is probably at the Hydropark, a bosky island getaway in the middle of the Dnieper River. To get there you cross the Metro, Venetian or Rusanivka bridges, which link you to green dales, wide stretches of yellow sand beach and cracked, cement embankments from the Soviet era, where thousands of people swim and sunbathe within comfortable reach of the city.Every tribe has their section of beach: gays, nudists, families, young hipsters, old men and women with their naked grandchildren building sand castles. On a hot summer day in Kiev, you're here or you're nobody. Hydropark Island is also something of a stage for showing off that mesh outfit that, if you're Ukrainian, you've had in your closet since last summer (for everyone else, since 1980). Dominic says mesh T-shirts and tanks made by a nondescript brand called Sports Company are all the rage among older men, young guys and even daring women. "I don't know if it's really so much a style as it is a lifestyle," he says, reminding me of Ukraine's long, withering winters and suggesting that the second it gets warm in Kiev, everyone shows as much skin as possible.

A restaurant critic who struggles with food and binge eating? It sounds like fiction, but it's the real-life story of New York Times restaurant critic Frank Bruni. It seems smart to focus on what the editors of American Vogue do best: put out blockbuster issues that remind everyone else - the competition, the trembling designers, the fawning retailers - of their editorial power. And no issue in Vogue's history was bigger than the September 2007 issue. R.J. Cutler's documentary is not, then, about Anna Wintour, the magazine's editor in chief. She dominates the opening scenes; he asserts that she has papal powers and that her short attention span and dislike of dark colors make designers cluck like chickens before the dinner hour (the scene when she visits YSL designer Stefano Pilati for a preview of his collection is alone worth the price of admission). But Mr. Cutler seemed to realize that he couldn't handle everything in his movie. Besides, the popular view of Ms. Wintour as an ice queen of chic has already been covered in another film, "The Devil Wears Prada." Mr. Cutler would have farce if he lingered there - Ms. Wintour imitating Meryl Streep imitating Miranda Priestley. As it is, there are a number of joyless scenes of Ms. Wintour walking alone through the Vogue hallways or being driven in her car, life happening elsewhere.
