In the latest setback to Switzerland's tradition of banking secrecy, UBS, one of the nation's largest banks, agreed on Wednesday to turn over information on more than 4,400 American clients suspected by the Internal Revenue Service of using Swiss accounts for tax evasion.

Above: In the first of a two-part series on the Bang Bang Club, Joao Silva discusses his photography in South Africa in the 1990s. Tomorrow we will bring you the photography of another member of the informal club -- Greg Marinovich.

Alleged to have bilked more than 60 investors of millions out of dollars, Shawn Merriman was charged on Wednesday with one federal count of mail fraud and one count of asset forfeiture, The Denver Business Journal reported.
American Capital, the private equity firm, registered on Wednesday to offer up to $1.5 billion in common stock, preferred stock and debt securities, The Washington Business Journal reported.
Citing a report by Hedge Fund Research, The Wall Street Journal said that 24 percent of Asia-focused hedge funds now are located in China -- a jump of 5 percent in the last year.

PBM Products, a maker of private-label baby foods, is seeking to arrange for a buyout or partial sale of the company with food manufacturers and private equity firms showing interest, The Wall Street Journal said, citing people familiar with the matter.

Corus Bankshares said Wednesday it got a notice from the Nasdaq stock market that it was out of compliance with rules for listing its stock after failing to file a quarterly financial report on time, The Associated Press reported.

If you missed Woodstock, don't worry. You are in good company. Bob Dylan wasn't there, either. Or for that matter Joni Mitchell, Michelle Phillips or Jim Morrison. And while tie-dyes and bell bottom jeans are so summer of '69, the style of these musical icons is very fall 2009. Here's how to get their looks.
U-Store-It Trust, a self-storage company, said Wednesday that it made $161.2 million from a public offering of 32.2 million common shares.

Skyblox, an Atlanta company that provides Wi-Fi coverage to restaurants and retail stores, says it accepted funding money over Twitter using a service called Twitpay, thus becoming the first company to raise a round of funding using micro-blogging.

Bankers who spent the last few years stuffing companies with debt are now hoping to drain some out. Even advisory shops like Lazard, which just hired a former Goldman Sachs capital markets specialist, are looking to cash in on what Wall Street has called the "re-equitization" trend. But once again, bankers may end up doing better than their clients, Breakingviews.com writes.

Bowne, which provides shareholder and marketing communications services, said Goldman Sachs, the underwriter on its offering of 10.5 million shares, bought another 792,273 shares in a transaction that closed on Wednesday, The Associated Press reported.

John Madden is adjusting to retirement by acting almost as if he weren't retired. He has been on the bus; he's promoting Madden NFL 10, the latest edition of his EA Sports video game; and he's preparing for the season. Where that preseason preparation leads him, he doesn't know.

John A. Paulson and Sallie L. Krawcheck are staking a lot on the revival of Bank of America's fortunes, Breakingviews.com writes. Mr. Paulson, the billionaire hedge fund manager, is now the bank's fourth-largest shareholder.

The suspect’s two brothers and a sister were injured in the knife attack and taken to the hospital.

Defender Keeley Dowling took a pass from Yael Averbuch and beat goalkeeper Hope Solo with a bending shot to the near post in the 30th minute as visiting Sky Blue F.C. defeated St. Louis Athletica, 1-0, Wednesday night in Fenton, Mo., to advance to the inaugural championship game of Women’s Professional Soccer.
The Orlando Magic announced the signing of guard Jason Williams, who retired last September after playing a season for the Miami Heat.
Newly promoted Burnley beat Manchester United, the defending Premier League champion, for the first time in 41 years, by 1-0.
Dinara Safina, the top-ranked women’s player in the world, lost to 39th-ranked Aravane Rezai of France, 3-6, 6-2, 6-4, in a second-round match at the Rogers Cup.

I have survived over 40 years of ill health. Even so I have learned to live a life of chronic patienthood where I am not dominated by illness. I have managed to focus on goals that have nothing to do with illness. Living life for me is learning to surf above the uneven terrain of my health.
Friday, Aug. 20, 1909(use this link to access today's entire issue)
Derek Jeter was the Yankees’ designated hitter on Monday, and he joked with Manager Joe Girardi that it was such an easy workday, he could do it for five years.
Transcripts reveal an air traffic controller at Teterboro Airport joking on the phone just minutes before a plane and helicopter collided over the Hudson River.
Wendell O. Scott, once barred from some races, is not among the 25 nominees for one of the first five seats in the Hall of Fame.
The highly anticipated trial of the legal challenge to California’s voter-approved ban on same-sex marriage is to start Jan. 11, a federal judge announced.
John Yettaw, who illegally swam across a lake in Myanmar and violated the terms of Aung San Suu Kyi’s home confinement, arrived in Springfield, Mo., on Wednesday night.
NATIONAL.
An obituary on Monday about the musicologist David Drew misspelled the surname of a composer for whom he made a case in several articles. He was Olivier Messiaen, not Messaien.

An article on Sunday about a new video game, Beatles: Rock Band, misattributed a comment about dreams from the book “Grapefruit,” by Yoko Ono, which compared the interactive nature of the video game to the book’s theme that art gains by being shared. It was a line within the book itself, written by Ms. Ono; it was not a blurb written for the book by John Lennon.

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about a new theory of what killed Mozart misidentified the country that is home to the spa town of Baden where he visited his wife shortly before he became ill. It is in Austria, not Germany.

An article on Tuesday about Y. E. Yang’s victory against Tiger Woods in the P.G.A. Championship referred incorrectly to the career performance of Tom Watson, who led the British Open earlier this summer before faltering. A victory would have given Watson six British Open titles and nine major championships; it would not have been his sixth major title.
An international tribunal for detainees would bring the nation back within the tradition of law and justice that it so forcefully defended six decades ago.
People — especially when they are sick — shouldn’t need to rely on state agencies to help them decipher their insurance policies.
Tom DeLay is going to be a contestant on “Dancing With the Stars.” Reality TV plus politics — this could be the start of something big.

The beauty and the pristine authority of Robert Capa’s “The Falling Soldier” would be tragically undermined if it turned out that this picture had been staged.
New York City’s oversight of the concrete industry needs to be tightened so that wrongdoers are pushed out of the system and never get back in.
Charles Schwab, the investment brokerage, clearly failed in its task to explain all the risks inherent in the securities it sold.
If federal regulators don’t act quickly to enforce new overdraft rules that could provide more transparency, Congress should step in.

An article on Aug. 11 previewing the men’s World Cup soccer qualifying match on Aug. 12 between the United States and Mexico misstated the Americans’ record at Estadio Azteca. The United States team was 0-8-1 at the stadium entering the game — not 0-18-1, which was its overall record in Mexico City. (After losing by 2-1, the United States fell to 0-9-1 at Azteca and 0-19-1 in Mexico City.).

An article on Tuesday about DreamWorks Studios’ completion of a round of financing its and announcement of some film projects included an incorrect title for one of the movies. It will be called “Dinner For ********,” a Yiddish vulgarism meaning jerks, used only once in the article. The film is not “Dinner With ********.”.
When government scientists went looking for mercury contamination in fish in 291 streams around the nation, they found it in every fish they tested, the Interior Department said.

An article on Wednesday about the oil industry’s backing of protests against climate change legislation misstated the number of fake letters sent to members of Congress by a pro-coal industry group, the American Coalition for Clean Coal Electricity. A Congressional inquiry has determined that 13 letters — not 58 — sent by a public relations company, Bonner & Associates, on behalf of the coalition were forgeries. Forty-five other letters sent by the company remain under investigation.
Two members of a family that owns an engine manufacturing company pleaded guilty Tuesday to federal charges of knowingly hiring illegal immigrants.

A picture caption on July 22 with an article about the popularity of the High Line, an elevated park in Manhattan, misstated the location of a staircase from which a man was leaving the park. It is above Washington Street, not above 10th Avenue.
Florida’s “stand your ground” law allows the use of deadly force for self-protection even if an attacker or intruder is in retreat, an appellate court said.

An article on Wednesday about the hidden fees in health care misstated the name of a company in San Francisco that hopes to help people estimate ahead of time what prices have been negotiated and what they would pay for services outside an insurance network. It is Ventana, not Ventura.

An article on Tuesday about people who have died in immigration detention in the last six years referred incorrectly to the nationality of one person on a list of 10 whose names had been omitted from a public roster of such fatalities. The list showed one Mexican, one Ecuadorean and eight Cubans; it was not made up of one Ecuadorean and nine Cuban nationals.
It’s time for a re-evaluation of the criminal justice system to determine how squandered money could be better spent.

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about federal stimulus money for projects that have been praised locally but criticized nationally omitted, in some copies, the surname of a sociologist who wrote a book about public works projects. He is Robert D. Leighninger Jr.

The Skin Deep column last Thursday, about sunless tanning products, misidentified the active ingredient used in most tanning sprays and creams. The ingredient is dihydroxyacetone, known as DHA, and it is derived primarily from plants; it is not docosahexaenoic acid, also known as DHA, an omega-3 fatty acid found in fish oils.

Les Paul, the guitarist and musical innovator who was a pioneer of the solid-body electrical guitar, will have one last tour before he is finally laid to rest, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Paul, who died on Thursday at 94, was honored Wednesday at a funeral service in New York, followed by a reception at the Gibson Showroom in Manhattan. On Friday morning the Discovery World museum in Milwaukee will hold a public viewing that members of Mr. Paul’s family are expected to attend, and will feature an exhibition on his life and music, including the guitar he played each week at the Iridium jazz club in Manhattan. Later that day Mr. Paul will be buried at a private family service at the Prairie Home Cemetery in Waukesha, Wis., his hometown.

The Italian conductor Riccardo Muti, above, will lead the Teatro dell’Opera di Roma, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Muti, who last year agreed to become the music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra starting with its 2010-11 season, would hold both positions after joining the Roman opera house in December 2010. Citing a news release from city officials, The A.P. said that Gianni Alemanno, the mayor of Rome, had met with Mr. Muti in Austria to discuss the arrangement. Mr. Muti has served as the principal conductor of the New Philharmonia (now Philharmonia) Orchestra in London and the music director of the Philadelphia Orchestra. He turned down the music directorship of the New York Philharmonic in 2000, and in 2005 resigned from La Scala in Milan amid a heated dispute with its musicians and house workers.

After making us wait a few extra months for the premiere of the new Douglas Carter Beane comedy “Mr. & Mrs. Fitch,” Second Stage Theater has announced the cast for the play. John Lithgow and Jennifer Ehle will star as a husband-and-wife team of gossip columnists who discover, according to a news release, that “great celebrity can appear out of thin air” when “the social circuit no longer provides any scandalous news.” The play is Mr. Beane’s first for Second Stage since “The Little Dog Laughed,” which opened in 2006, and the production will reunite him with its director, Scott Ellis, whose recent stint on the Showtime series “Weeds” prompted Second Stage to delay “Mr. & Mrs. Fitch” until its 2009-10 season. The play begins previews on Jan. 26 and open on Feb. 22.

For only the second time in two months someone has sold more records than Michael Jackson. The first to do so, a month ago, was Daughtry, and this week the country hero George Strait, right, has the best-selling album in the country with “Twang” (MCA Nashville), which opens at No. 1 on the Billboard chart with 155,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan. No. 2 is Neil Diamond’s new CD/DVD package “Hot August Night/NYC” (Sony), recorded live at Madison Square Garden last year. Available only at Wal-Mart and Sam’s Club stores, it sold 57,000 copies. The Black Eyed Peas are No. 3 with “The E.N.D.” (Interscope), selling 45,000 copies, and the rock band Cobra Starship opens at No. 4 with 42,000 sales of its new “Hot Mess” (Fueled by Ramen/Decaydance). Kings of Leon’s “Only by the Night” (RCA) is fifth with just under 42,000, which brings that album’s 47-week total to more than 1.3 million. Sales of Mr. Jackson’s albums have been slipping in recent weeks but are still strong. “Number Ones” (Epic) sold 80,000 copies, and was technically the second-best selling album in the United States last week. (Like most of Mr. Jackson’s titles it is too old to qualify for Billboard’s standard album chart.).
A two-hour installment of “America’s Got Talent” averaged 11.6 million viewers on Tuesday, lifting NBC to first place in the night’s ratings, according to Nielsen’s estimates.

Already known for his opinionated — some would say imaginative — takes on notable American events and figures, the filmmaker Oliver Stone, below, will be hitting the history books again in a new television series for Showtime, Reuters reported. For the series, “Oliver Stone’s Secret History of America,” Mr. Stone will create 10 documentary films that will focus on different episodes in United States history. Reuters said topics would include the cold war, President Harry S. Truman’s decision to drop atomic bombs on Japan and the global role of the United States since the fall of Communism. Mr. Stone has been criticized for his depictions of John F. Kennedy’s assassination and George W. Bush’s presidency in the films “JFK” and “W.”.

KAMINSKAS--Chris. The Officers and Members mourn the passing of our General Manager and dear friend, Chris Kaminskas. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his wife, Ariana; his children, Matthew and Jesse and his entire family. Richard Fleder, President.

CUMMINS--Naomi, died peacefully at home on August 19, the loving wife of the late Irvin M. Cummins, devoted mother to Nancy, David, Leslie, and Cathy, and proud grandmother of nine wonderful grandchildren. Memorial donations may be made to VNS Hospice Care, 1250 Broadway, New York, NY 10001.

Even before the last wisps of bipartisanship were evaporating from the health care debate, Senator Jim DeMint, Republican of South Carolina, had made clear he opposed President Obama's overhaul effort. It was Mr. DeMint who declared last month, ''If we're able to stop Obama on this, it will be his Waterloo.'' Now, you can watch Mr. DeMint as he tries to ride the road to Waterloo. On Thursday night, the senator plans a virtual town hall meeting from 6 to 7 p.m. He will take questions via Twitter and UStream.

HANRAHAN--William B. CCS, the international fund-raising consulting and management firm, deeply regrets the passing of its Chief Executive Officer, William "Bill" B. Hanrahan. Bill was a highly respected leader in the non-profit community who passed away Monday evening, August 17, at his home in Manhattan. Bill Hanrahan joined CCS in 1957. He became one of the principal owners of the company in the mid-1970s and led the firm to preeminence in its field for the next 30 years. He advised many of the nation's leading non-profit organizations, developed ground-breaking fund-raising strategies and plans, and was himself a generous philanthropist. Among his most significant professional achievements were the design of the fund-raising programs for Rotary International's "PolioPlus Campaign," which provided oral polio vaccine to newborns in the developing world and has protected more than one billion children to date; and for Lions Clubs International, which has saved the sight of more than 50 million people, while improving eye care for hundreds of millions more. Bill served on the Boards of numerous non-profit organizations and was a Knight of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta. Bill was predeceased by his first wife, Helen M. Hanrahan in 1999; his daughter, Colleen Hanrahan; his parents, J.V. and Gertrude Hanrahan; sister, Patricia A. Lee, and brother, Joseph V. Hanrahan. Bill is survived by his wife Theresa Katchen-Hanrahan; children Janine Triano and her husband, Stephen L., Aileen Dentroux and her husband, Dr. Wayne M., Erin C. Gallo and her husband, Gerard F., William "Bill" B. Hanrahan, Jr. and his wife, Dana Hopkins-Hanrahan; stepson, Dr. Nicholas S. Katchen; grandchildren Stephen W. and Nicholas W. Triano, Gerard F. and Sean R. Gallo, Cody M., Shannon M. and Samantha M. Dentroux, William B. III, and Patrick S. Hanrahan; stepgrandchildren Amanda and Ashley; great-grandson Benjamin; brother, Thomas F. Hanrahan, Sr., sister, Kathleen Hagen, and countless others in his extended family. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations can be made to Little Sisters of the Poor, Queens Village, 110-30 221st Street, Queens Village, NY 11420, or Little Sisters of the Poor, Bronx, 2999 Schurz Avenue, Bronx, NY 10465.

LEARNING is good for you, as any pupil knows, but heavy books can be bad -- for your back, at least. Well-made backpacks are supposed to help. Worn properly, backpacks can evenly distribute loads, thanks to such features as lightweight yet durable fabrics, strategically placed padding, and sternum straps. Some packs have retractable handles and wheels that convert them to rollers. The American Physical Therapy Association recommends that children carry no more than 15 percent of their body weight on their backs, said Mary Ann Wilmarth, a spokeswoman for the group. ''Otherwise they risk injury, mainly to the back and shoulders,'' said Dr. Wilmarth, who directs one of Northeastern University's doctorate programs in physical therapy and has written several studies on the effect of backpack use on children.

HAMLIN--Joanne Capen, on August 11, 2009. Wife of the late George Hamlin, Jr., mother of Jeffrey Hamlin, grandmother of James Hamlin. Many will remember Joanne as an actor, others as a high school and Sunday school teacher and others as a writer. All who knew her will remember Joanne's remarkable capacity for friendship, her interest in and support of all those she knew as well as her spirited and inquisitive nature. In a role she performed to great acclaim, Winnie, in Samuel Beckett's Happy Days, captures Joanne's essence when she says "That's what I find so wonderful that not a day goes by-to speak in the old style-hardly a day, without some blessing...in disguise." God speed Joanne and flights of angels sing thee to thy rest.

''PUT up your dukes,'' Pat Benatar challenged the mobs that turned out to hear her in concert Aug. 13 at Asser Levy/Seaside Park in Coney Island. ''Hit me with your best shot.'' Some fans interpreted her raucous lyrics as an invitation to show their fashion audacity. Obligingly, they revisited the 1980s, trotting out their brashest in neon, faux leopard and satin-bright spandex. Debbie Harry, who also performed that evening, influenced legions of imitators to paint on waxy pouts and flip wayward bangs, while Jennifer Beals fans flaunted slouchy ''Flashdance'' T-shirts and leggings that seemed lacquered to their flanks.

POTTER--Clarkson Andreas, departed our world unexpectedly a year ago to join God's Kingdom. Andreas continues to live in the hearts and cherished memory of his wife Dimitra, his children George, Christina, Anastasia, Alexandros, his grandchild Josephine, brother John, family and his friends.

HANRAHAN--William B. The Partners of CCS sadly mourn the loss of our steadfast leader, dedicated colleague and dear friend, William "Bill" B. Hanrahan and extend our condolences to his devoted family. Bill was passionate about his work and spent a lifetime dedicated to developing new ground-breaking strategies for raising funds to support the causes that he held dear: humanitarian, education, religion, conservation, and healthcare. He was both teacher and student, and brought his deliberate thoughtfulness and questioning to every interaction. At his core, Bill was a true leader, inspiring dedication, fostering goodwill, and eliciting the best ideas and solutions among those who worked for and with him. Bill was truly a pioneer in the field of fund raising and consulted frequently with fund-raising leaders across all non-profit sectors. He was a past Board member of the Association for Healthcare Philanthropy Foundation; Riverview Medical Center, New Jersey; Queen of Peace Home, Queens, New York; American Liver Foundation; Association of Fundraising Professionals Foundation (Past Chair); Greater Washington Society of Association Executives; and Operation Smile International. Bill was a Knight of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta. He was instrumental in the development of a number of critical campaigns that were pivotal to the growth of the firm. Bill was also a dedicated philanthropist who provided support and guidance to many organizations, including the Little Sisters of the Poor, Fox Chase Cancer Center, Jersey Shore University Medical Center, Riverview Medical Center, and Pope John Paul II Cultural Center, among others. We will miss Bill's wisdom, curiosity, and compassion. He was a great mentor, a thoughtful friend, and a true leader and his legacy will live on through the countless people he touched throughout his lifetime.

Lawrence Lucie, a guitarist whose career began in the early years of jazz and continued into the early years of the 21st century, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 101. His death was confirmed by Sharon Linder, an administrator at the Kateri Residence, the nursing and rehabilitation center in Manhattan where Mr. Lucie lived in recent years.

Perhaps sensing that insurers are winning the health care debate, top House Democrats are demanding to look inside industry executives' wallets. The House Energy and Commerce Committee has sent letters to the 52 largest insurers, asking them to detail the salaries, bonuses and stock options they pay their executives and to itemize the companies' revenue and profits. The committee is one of three House panels that have drafted legislation to overhaul the health care industry and rein in insurers.

From the Ground Up is about the writer's construction of a cabin in the Maine woods and offers advice for those thinking of building their own cabin. An excerpt: IT pains me to install electric wiring in the cabin -- all of those holes in my studs and beams! Yes, the cabin's structural integrity remains intact, but still, a two by four with a three-quarter-inch hole bored through its center (to provide passage for a wire) is not the sturdy soldier it once was. But drill I must. So that's how I spent most of Sunday: boring holes and pulling wire.

LEAGUE LOOKS AT RAIDERS FIGHT Commissioner Roger Goodell said he was still gathering information about a reported fight in Oakland, where a Raiders assistant coach sustained a fractured jaw. A report by AOL FanHouse said Coach Tom Cable punched the defensive assistant Randy Hanson, causing the broken jaw that sent Hanson to the hospital. But Cable has denied punching Hanson and called the issue an internal matter. If the league determines that Cable assaulted Hanson, it could impose discipline. JUDY BATTISTA OWNERS DISCUSS SALARY CAP League owners met in Chicago, and much of the five-hour meeting was spent talking about the labor situation. This is the final year games will be played under the salary cap if no deal is reached by March. There have been two negotiating sessions. The union's executive director, DeMaurice Smith, has said that he thinks owners are preparing to lock out players in 2011.

BEHRENS--Hildegard. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the untimely death of Hildegard Behrens, who was among the foremost Wagnerian sopranos of her generation and a beloved colleague of our company. As Brunnhilde in the Met's historic first telecast and first audio recording of the complete "Ring" cycle, she was the epitome of a singing actress, taking on the daunting role with intense musicality and total dramatic commitment. In all, she sang 15 roles at the Met, including Isolde, Elektra, the title roles in "Fidelio" and "Tosca", Elettra in the company premiere of Mozart's "Idomeneo" and Giorgetta in "Il Tabarro", her Met debut role in 1976. We offer our heartfelt condolences to her children, Sara and Philip, and her grandchildren Maria and Anthony. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director

SINEK--Marion, passed away peacefully on August 17th, 2009 after a long illness. She was 78 years old. Born in Berlin, Germany, she came to the US just before WWII. She graduated from Syracuse University. After graduate work at the London School of Economics, she worked for Radio Free Europe and the UN Assoc.-USA. Marion later became very active in public affairs, serving as President of the LWV of NY. She ran for office, serving as a Town Board member in New Castle before becoming its Supervisor for two terms. She later worked with Sen. Hillary Clinton on election law issues, and remained active in Democratic politics and other organizations. Her husband Herbert predeceased her; she is survived by children Ron and Nicole (Arnaboldi), their spouses Jennifer and Leo, and seven grandchildren. Burial will be private. A memorial will be held in September. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

Brazil said it would file a complaint at the World Trade Organization against the United States over its antidumping methodology on orange juice shipments. Brazil disputes the use of a method that considers the difference between the price of a product in its home country and in the United States, except when the product is sold at a higher price in the United States. The practice is used by the Commerce Department and hurts Brazil exports, the ministry said, adding that W.T.O. has condemned the practice on several occasions.

Interment, with full military honors, will take place at a later date at Arlington National Cemetery.

NBC KEEPS SUNDAY NIGHTS NBC extended its deal with the N.F.L. for two years, through 2013. The network's rights fee to carry ''Sunday Night Football'' will increase by 2 percent a year. Under its current agreement, it pays the league an average $600 million a year. NBC's extension comes three months after CBS and Fox agreed to add two years to their contracts, paying about the same increase as NBC.

A top Senate Democrat is not optimistic that major changes to the health care system can be achieved this year. Speaking to a small, friendly group of about 35 people at home in Wisconsin on Monday, the senator, Herb Kohl, said that a health care revamping ''won't be earth-shattering'' because ''there are too many politics involved,'' The Eau Claire Leader-Telegram reported.

It has been suggested that Verbatim's new external hard drive, the InSight, looks like a cheese tray. To me it more resembles a fancy door stop. At the least, it's a unique shape. It's a rough life out there for external drives. So many capacities, so many prices. And there is the prospect of the solid-state drive eventually eclipsing the less reliable spinning disk drive as the predominant device for data storage.

The defense minister and the head of the cabinet in Taiwan reportedly offered to resign as the government continued to reel under growing criticism of its lackluster response to Typhoon Morakot. Three television stations in Taiwan reported that Prime Minister Liu Chao-shiuan was considering the resignation letters. ''When we discuss a cabinet reshuffle in early September, we will consider these offers,'' Mr. Liu said at a news conference, according to Reuters. President Ma Ying-jeou, above, has apologized for what he called the ''mishandling'' of relief efforts after the storm, which lashed the island for four days this month and is thought to have killed more than 500 people.

The SkyPower Corporation, Canada's leading developer of renewable-energy projects, sought bankruptcy protection from American creditors. SkyPower is developing projects in Canada, the United States, India and Panama. SkyPower listed as much as $500 million in both assets and debt in documents filed in United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del. SkyPower is based in Toronto and is a unit of Lehman Brothers Holdings, which filed for bankruptcy last September. The unit sought protection in Canada under the Companies' Creditors Arrangement Act on Aug. 12.

Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY. Services entrusted to Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, NY.

Nokia, the world's biggest maker of mobile phones, will offer microfinancing to help customers in rural India afford mobile phones. The plan will be available in 12 Indian states and is aimed especially at women in villages, Nokia said in a statement. Customers in a pilot plan paid 2,500 rupees ($51.23) in 25 weekly installments for a handset, the company said. The financing is provided in cooperation with local microfinance institutions, Nokia said. ''The communication sector will continue to be an engine of the Indian economy over the next years,'' Olli-Pekka Kallasvuo, Nokia's chief executive, said in a statement. ''There is plenty of potential for growth in the sector.'' (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

Defender Keeley Dowling took a pass from Yael Averbuch and beat goalkeeper Hope Solo with a bending shot to the near post in the 30th minute as visiting Sky Blue F.C. defeated St. Louis Athletica, 1-0, Wednesday night in Fenton, Mo., to advance to the inaugural championship game of Women's Professional Soccer. Sky Blue will play the league's top team during the regular season, the Los Angeles Sol, at the Home Depot Center in Carson, Calif., on Saturday.

Exxon Mobil's $41 billion deal to supply PetroChina with liquefied natural gas is likely to get Australian government approval, Lindsay Tanner, left, the country's finance minister, said. Exxon agreed this week to sell 2.25 million metric tons a year of natural gas from Australia's Gorgon project to PetroChina. It has to go though an environmental assessment before it is approved, Mr. Tanner said. Foreign Minister Stephen Smith told Parliament this week that the nation's relationship with China had been strained by the detention of a Rio Tinto Group executive, Stern Hu, as well as by a visit to Australia last week a leader of Uighur minority in China.
I often buy more fruit than my daughter and I can eat before the fruit flies take over. Now Martha Rose Shulman offers a solution — fruit soups for the summer.
The fall is shaping up to be incredibly busy for financial aid offices around the country, as more students affected by the recession seek money to help pay for school.

This week: Frank Bruni, author of “Born Round”; Sir Harold Evans on the future of the news industry; Motoko Rich with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of the Book Review, is the host. (Podcast Archive )

More than 10 years and $200 million dollars after “Titanic,” the director James Cameron gave moviegoers an early look Friday at “Avatar,” his new 3-D science-fiction feature that 20th Century Fox will open on Dec. 18. In a promotional event held at movie theaters around the country, about 100,000 viewers who signed up for free tickets were shown an extended preview of the movie on giganto-size Imax screens, 3-D glasses and popcorn included.

The news about The Walking Dead, a grim tale about a group of survivors in a world overrun with zombies, keeps getting brighter. Last week it was announced that the comic would be developed into a television series for AMC, the home of “Mad Men,” to be written and directed by Frank Darabont (“The Shawshank Redemption,” “The Green Mile.”) This week, the 10th volume of the series is No. 1 on our paperback list.

The documentary compiled from Michael Jackson‘s rehearsals for the concert series he was preparing when he died will be released in theaters earlier than expected and will be shown for only two weeks. In a news release, Sony Pictures Entertainment and Sony Music Entertainment said that the documentary, called “Michael Jackson THIS IS IT,” would open on Oct. 28, two days sooner than originally announced, and that tickets for the film would go on sale Sept. 27 in most cities. The movie will be directed by Kenny Ortega, the director and choreographer who was working with Mr. Jackson on his planned “This Is It” concerts, a series of 50 shows that Mr. Jackson was to have performed at London’s O2 Arena beginning in July. Sony which paid $60 million for the film in a deal between the studio, the Jackson estate and the concert promoter AEG Live, said the documentary would draw upon more than 100 hours of behind-the-scenes footage and rehearsals shot between April and June.

What we’re reading on Friday morning.‘Wake-Up Call’ on Reality Contestants Reality television producers are reacting to the news that Ryan Alexander Jenkins, who appeared on the VH1 series “Megan Wants a Millionaire,” was charged Thursday with the murder of his ex-wife, whose body was found Saturday, The Associated Press reports. One producer calls the incident “a big wake-up call,” and most agree that the industry must get tougher with its background checks on contestants. The show has been pulled from VH1’s schedule.Hollywood Deals: The Hollywood Reporter says that the “Twilight” director Catherine Hardwicke is likely to direct “The Girl with the Red Riding Hood,” a gothic take on the “Little Red Riding Hood” fairy tale. The trade publication also reports that Bryan Singer, who last week signed up to direct a new “Battlestar Galactica” movie, will produce a remake of “Excalibur,” about King Arthur and the knights of the Round Table.What’s Up Their Sleeves? The Guardian reports that a consortium of magicians in Spain would like to see a television series that is giving away the secrets to their acts disappear. They say the show, “Magic Without Secrets,” and its anonymous host, the Masked Magician, are infringing on their intellectual property.

If you’ve watched Alan J. Pakula‘s film adaptation of “All the President’s Men” so often that you have come to believe that Robert Redford played a crucial role in revealing the Watergate scandal and bringing down the Nixon administration, well, a planned screening of the movie at BAM Rose Cinemas in Brooklyn will not help dispel that illusion. The academy’s BAMcinématek film program said in a news release that on Sept. 12 it would present a special showing of the 1976 film, in which Mr. Redford and Dustin Hoffman played The Washington Post reporters Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein, followed by a Q&A session that will feature Mr. Redford, Mr. Woodward and Mr. Bernstein. The event is part of a larger BAM event, called “Robert Redford: Artist & Activist,” that runs from Sept. 8 through 16. The series will also offer on Sept. 13 a conversation with Mr. Redford about his work, after showings of his films “Out of Africa,” “The Natural,” “The Electric Horseman” and “The Way We Were.” More details can be found online at BAM.org/bamcinematek.

Has there been a more historic week for English-speaking all-male comedy troupes who sometimes like to dress up as women? First we learned that Monty Python would be reunited, and now it has been announced that the Kids in the Hall, the Canadian quintet of occasional cross-dressers, have gotten back together for a new movie. In a news release, the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Toronto ­Accent Entertainment said that principal photography began on Thursday for “Death Comes to Town,” a comedy created by Dave Foley, Bruce McCulloch, Kevin McDonald, Mark McKinney, and Scott Thompson, who starred in “The Kids in the Hall” in the late 1980s and early 90s, as well as an ill-fated 1996 feature, “Kids in the Hall: Brain Candy.” The new movie is described as an eight-part comic murder mystery in which Death arrives (via a Greyhound bus) in the small town of Shuckton, Ontario, and one of its most distinguished citizens is found murdered. It is directed by Kelly Makin, and is expected to have its premiere on the CBC in January. Plans for an American release or broadcast were not immediately announced.

Hey hey hey! An all-star lineup of performers and fellow comedians will be on hand to salute Bill Cosby when he receives the Mark Twain Prize for American Humor, the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts said in a press release. Among the stars who are expected to be on hand for the event, which will take place on Oct. 26, are his “Cosby Show” co-stars Phylicia Rashad and Malcolm-Jamal Warner; the actors Danny Glover and Rita Moreno (who appeared with Mr. Cosby on “The Electric Company”); the musicians Wynton Marsalis and Willie Nelson; and the comics Chris Rock, Jerry Seinfeld, Dick Gregory, George Lopez, Carl Reiner and Sinbad. The ceremony is scheduled to be broadcast Nov. 4 on PBS. Previous recipients of the prize have included Richard Pryor, Bob Newhart, Steve Martin and George Carlin.
An author who accused Stephenie Meyer, the writer of the best-selling “Twilight” novels, of plagiarism has filed suit against her, Reuters reported.

While his onetime screenwriting partner Quentin Tarantino was preparing this week for the release of his latest movie, Roger Avary was pleading guilty to charges of vehicular manslaughter and drunken driving, The Ventura County Star reported. Mr. Avary, who in 1995 won an Academy Award for writing the screenplay for “Pulp Fiction” with Mr. Tarantino, entered the plea on Tuesday in Ventura County Superior Court in California. The charges stem from an accident on Jan. 13, 2008, when Mr. Avary’s car hit a telephone pole in Ojai. A passenger, Andreas Zini, was killed in the crash and Mr. Avary’s wife, Gretchen, was injured. Mr. Avary pleaded not guilty to the charges in December but has apologized for the accident. He remains free on bail and is scheduled to be sentenced on Sept. 29.

Updated | 7:02 p.m. Despite an earlier announcement that Michael Jackson would be buried on Aug. 29, publicists for the Jackson family said on Friday that the singer’s burial had been rescheduled for Sept. 3. In a news release, the publicity firm Sunshine, Sachs & Associates said that the burial would take place at 7 p.m. Pacific time, at the Holly Terrace in the Great Mausoleum at Forest Lawn Memorial Park in Glendale, Calif.

Another Saturday, and time to review another book we haven't read - except that, unlike Dick Cheney's memoir, this one's already been written. Also unlike Dick Cheney, the author of this book, former Homeland Security Secretary Tom Ridge has never been a real favorite of conservatives, or even moderate Republicans. This left the Opinionator wondering who was really going to buy the tell-all of Mr. Ridge's White House years. The answer, apparently, is liberal Democrats.

Hockey Canada has stepped forward to fill the void after the N.H.L.'s assertion last month that its insurance coverage did not extend to those players who attend pre-Olympic orientation camps this summer.

The Federal Reserve on Friday lifted an estimate of the value of Bear Stearns and American International Group assets used to secure their rescue last year, potentially reducing losses to United States taxpayers, Reuters reported.

James E. Press, the last holdover among top executives from Chrysler's prebankruptcy days, is expected to leave within three months, The New York Times's Nick Bunkley reported, citing a person with knowledge of his plans.

There are reports that News Corporation is shopping Dow Jones's index business. The money in that business comes from licensing the indexes for futures and options, but there is also the prestige, and the free advertising. Every time you hear or read a stock market report, there is a plug for Dow Jones and its industrial average.

In 2007, Chrysler tried to get a leg up on its competitors by extending powertrain warranties on all new cars and trucks to cover the life of the vehicle. But this week, the company announced that the lifetime coverage will cease to exist for the 2010 fleet and beyond.

The News Corporation is in talks to sell its Dow Jones stock-market index business, potentially separating the famous Dow Jones Industrial Average from the newspaper that has long controlled it, The Wall Street Journal, people briefed on the matter told DealBook.

Correction appended | In the second of a two-part series on the Bang Bang Club - a group of four young photographers who unblinkingly chronicled the upheaval in South Africa in the 1990s - Greg Marinovich recalls the torment of watching deadly violence unfold before him. In an instant, he had to decide whether he could do more good by intervening personally or by chronicling the moment to let the world know what was happening. His pictures of a man being burned alive won a Pulitzer Prize in 1991. Readers are cautioned that this scene and several others in the audio slide show are quite disturbing.

He was noncommittal about whether he would have preferred to be traded to a contender. According to SI.com, the Giants were the team that claimed him.

Not much has changed since my last update on Wednesday. The storm has weakened a bit to 95kts and 957mb, and has begun its more northerly track to the west of Bermuda and to the east of the US coast... it's currently about 700 miles southeast of the North Carolina coast. Although it won't make a direct landfall on Bermuda or the US, it will (and has been) produce very large waves on Bermuda and all along the entire eastern seaboard of the US and Canada.

Despite the horror - nearly 100 dead, with American soldiers helpless to act as their role in Iraq has shrunk - the huge bombings on Wednesday did nothing to alter the debate back home. Americans want to get out of Iraq (even if they are less certain they want to dig deeper in Afghanistan). The mood was summed up by the crowd's reaction this week when President Obama repeated his resolve to remove all American forces from Iraq by the end of 2011. There was much applause.

Two new navigation apps aim to put traffic reporting in the hands of drivers. The result could a be ubiquitous network that reliably reports tie-ups instantly, even on smaller roads where there are no traffic sensors and on side streets that traffic-reporting services seldom monitor.

I recently took my sons, 7-year-old twins, to P.S. 1, one of my favorite places in New York to see contemporary art. We quickly encountered what appeared to be an indoor swimming pool - only it turned out to be an illusion (a glass sheet mounted in the floor, with a bit of water running over it). A stairway made it possible to see the "pool" from "underwater." Jake and Aaron ran up and down the stairs a dozen times, gleefully posing for photos.

Beyond the companionship dogs provide, our four-legged friends have a long tradition of service in the medical world. Dogs see for the blind, hear for the deaf, assist people in wheelchairs and alert people with diabetes of an impending health crisis. People with autism or attention deficit hyperactivity disorder also can benefit from service dogs.

Today's practice session at the European Grand Prix in Valencia was an interesting study in the relative irrelevance of youth, age and experience in Formula One today. For a few minutes toward the end of the second session I saw the three least experienced drivers at the bottom of the time sheet. (With the exception of Lewis Hamilton, who had not run much of the session thanks to a problem with the car after a spin.) It was Romain Grosjean, the new young driver at Renault, Luca Badoer, the old driver - at 38 - who has not raced for a decade, and Jaime Alguersuari, who at 19 is the youngest driver ever, and is only racing in his second race. Then suddenly, Grosjean shot up to finish in 13th position. So, all right, it wasn't a question of experience just yet. Or not entirely.

Volkswagen is recalling 13,500 of its 2009 and a few 2010 models because of a problem with its fast-shifting DSG automatic transmission. The vehicles covered are the Jetta, Jetta SportWagen, GTI, and Eos built between September 2008 and August 2009.

Update | 12:31 p.m.

Twenty years ago this month, a black teenager, Yusuf K. Hawkins, was shot to death after being taunted by a mob of bat-wielding white youths in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn. The racially motivated killing horrified New Yorkers, galvanized civil rights leaders and helped undermine Mayor Edward I. Koch's bid for a fourth term. Weeks after the killing, the mayor was defeated in the Democratic primary by David N. Dinkins, who went on to become the city's first (and so far only) African-American mayor.

A subsidiary of Las Vegas Sands has filed an application for a possible listing on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange, the company said Thursday. Shares in the casino operator rose 3.5 percent after the announcement, Reuters reported.

Silverfleet Capital has acquired German sausage-skin manufacturer Kalle for 212.5 million euros ($303.4 million), The Daily Telegraph reported. The buyout shop picked up Kalle from Montagu Private Equity.

American International Group dismissed as without merit a suit brought by two policyholders who say they are entitled to recoveries of funds they claim to have lost with convicted Ponzi-scheme operator Bernard Madoff, The Wall Street Journal reported.

Candover Investments, the private equity firm, announced a wholesale shake-up at the top of the firm on Friday, as it looks to repair its damaged reputation and salvage its 2008 fund, Reuters reported.
CIT Group may have narrowly averted a bankruptcy filing, but TheStreet.com says the lender's bondholders are actually well positioned to profit.

After seeing its plans to unload Stella D'Oro Biscuit nearly collapse, Brynwood Partners may now have found a local buyer for the cookie maker. Nonni's Food is said to be in talks to buy the operation, The New York Post reported.

A notable phenomenon has come to light during the recent round of second-quarter financial filings:Corporations are quietly buying back bonds on the cheap in the open market as the financial system works its way out of crisis mode, The Wall Street Journal reported.
Blackrock has reduced its stake in Regus by half, The Daily Telegraph reported. The group brought its holdings down to 46.1 million shares from the 90.8 million it had held since February 2007.

As Tribune Co. emerges from bankruptcy-court protection, its ownership structure is likely to change, Tribune chief operating officer Randy Michaels said in a note to employees. The results of that change could include a shift of the company to the hands of its lenders, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

As Bernard L. Madoff memorabilia continues to flood the market -- from Smash-Me Bernie dolls to mugs, T-shirts and salacious tell-alls -- a new prize is available on the open sea. The Daily Telegraph reported that one of Mr. Madoff's favorite toys, a 90-foot yacht called Leopard Bull, has been released by administrators to be put up for sale.

Amazon, Microsoft and Yahoo are planning to join a coalition of nonprofit groups, individuals and library associations to oppose a proposed class-action settlement giving Google the rights to commercialize digital copies of millions of books, The New York Times's Miguel Helft reported.

Faced with a growing wave of bank failures, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is taking extraordinary steps to attract buyers for troubled institutions to keep the fund that makes depositors whole from being drained, Eric Dash reported in The New York Times.

China's securities commission plans to review next week an application by Metallurgical Group of China for an initial public offering that aims to raise around 16.85 billion yuan ($2.5 billion),the regulator said.

The rich have been getting richer for so long that the trend has come to seem almost permanent.But economists say - and data is beginning to show - that a significant change may in fact be under way. The rich, as a group, are no longer getting richer. Over the last two years, they have become poorer. And many may not return to their old levels of wealth and income any time soon, The New York Times's David Leonhardt and Geraldine Fabrikant wrote.

A real estate lawyer has been sentenced to 10 years and one month in prison after he was convicted of running a $40 million Ponzi scheme that duped 125 investors, The Atlanta Business Chronicle reported.

When it comes to kitchen tools, design often trumps function. And since I'm a fairly practical cook, I choose function over design. This means I often end up with useful but not-so-stylish products like the Stretch-Tite dispenser. My Sori Yanagi bowls, on the other hand, are a perfect example of the rare instances when function and design align in the kitchen. They're sexy yet lightweight and stackable.

Expresso Fitness has raised $6 million in Series D financing with existing investors Sierra Ventures, Physic Ventures and Enterprise Partners Venture Capital participating in the round, the company said.

Coherex Medical has raised $16.5 million in a Series B round of financing co-led by Oxford Bioscience Partners and vSpring Capital. Tullis Health Investors also participated in the round, The Boston Business Journal reported.
Adamas Pharmaceuticals closed a $40 million Series D round of funding earlier this week, the company said in a news release.

The Swiss have managed the global financial crisis with a certain delicate precision. The latest sign is the government's exit from UBS, a decision that puts the country's top bank back on its own two feet. That's no small accomplishment, Breakingviews.com writes.

Talk about Lone Star luck. BBVA is said to be poised to swoop in on one of the biggest independent banks in Texas, Guaranty Financial, in a deal that would be the first for a foreign bank brokered by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, Breakingviews.com writes.

NATIONAL.

An appraisal on Thursday about the career of Don Hewitt, the CBS News producer and creator of “60 Minutes,” who died on Wednesday, erroneously included a documentary among the shows that Mr. Hewitt produced. A documentary about Gen. William C. Westmoreland, the American commander in Vietnam, was produced in 1982 by George Crile for “CBS Reports;” it was not the work of Mr. Hewitt or “60 Minutes.”.

An Associated Press report in some editions of the soccer roundup on Sunday about Arsenal’s 6-1 victory against Everton in England’s Premier League described the margin of victory incorrectly. Other games have featured a larger margin since the league was formed in 1992; the five-goal difference in this game did not match the previous “biggest victories.”.

An article on Sunday about the high expectations for the University of Florida football team misstated the name of the poll in which the Gators are ranked No. 1 this preseason. It is the USA Today Top 25 Coaches’ Poll, not the ESPN/USA Today coaches poll. (ESPN and USA Today do, however, collaborate on a college basketball poll.).

The Sports of The Times column on Wednesday, about the challenge of encouraging athletes to use a more protective helmet, misstated the size of the National Hockey League when Ed Johnston — a retired goaltender who is a proponent of safer headgear — helped the Boston Bruins win Stanley Cup titles in 1970 and 1972. The league had 12 teams in the 1969-70 season and 14 in 1971-2; it was not still a “six-team” league.

An article on Wednesday about the overturning on appeal of the conviction of Gregory L. Reyes, former chief executive of Brocade Communications Systems, on charges relating to the illegal backdating of stock options misstated the reason for an accounting rule that requires the options be recorded as a noncash expense. The rule is to guard against the possible inflation of a company’s profit, not its revenue.
The State Department issued a permit for the construction of a new pipeline to bring crude oil from Western Canada to the United States.

The Media Equation column on Monday, about the growing amount of Web content generated by AOL, misspelled the surname of a founder of Weblogs, an online content company that AOL purchased in 2005. He is Jason Calacanis, not Calcanis. The column also referred incompletely to the sale of the company. AOL bought Weblogs from its co-founders, Mr. Calacanis and Brian Alvey — not just from Mr. Calacanis.

An article on Aug. 9 about New York S.U.V. clubs that have added community service to their activities misstated the surname of an officer of one of the clubs, Escalade Krown Holdaz. He is Scott Killiebrew, not Killiebrand. The error also appeared in a picture caption in some editions.
The Yankees will arrive in Boston with a six-and-a-half-game lead in the A.L. East, after leaving Seattle and Oakland with a 5-2 record.

An article on Aug. 9 about students who are paying services to help them land unpaid internships rendered the name of one student’s college incorrectly. It is the College of William & Mary, not William and Mary College.

“Octomom: The Incredible Unseen Footage,” the Fox documentary about Nadya Suleman, attracted just 4.2 million viewers on Wednesday, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The two-hour special on Ms. Suleman, who became a tabloid fixture after giving birth to octuplets in January, gave Fox a fourth-place finish on the night. By comparison, NBC’s “America’s Got Talent,” which led the night over all, delivered 10.3 million viewers, helping NBC rank first. CBS and ABC finished in a virtual tie for second place. CBS broadcast an all-repeat lineup, while ABC earned its best ratings with “Who Wants to Be a Millionaire” (6.9 million).

Though his run on the cult HBO series “Lucky Louie” wasn’t especially fortunate, the comedian Louis C. K. will return to cable television next year in a new FX series called “Louie,” the network announced on Thursday. And its star and creator is already promising a series unlike anything he’s done before. “It’s not like other shows, and I don’t mean to brag,” he said in a telephone interview. “I just mean that it’s hard to describe.” He said the show would combine short autobiographical comedy films, about his life as a single divorced father and a comedian, with segments of him performing stand-up routines that would be thematically tied to the films. “It’s very vignette-y,” he. said. “It’s very vérité. All those French words. I use ’em all.” Production for “Louie” is planned to begin in November, after Louis C. K. finishes shooting a recurring role for the NBC sitcom “Parks and Recreation” The show is expected to make its debut in 2010.

For the past 25 years, Works & Process at the Guggenheim Museum has been offering a close-up look at artists and their work. The coming season will be no exception. The actress Isabella Rossellini, the fashion designer Isaac Mizrahi, the composer Steve Reich and the choreographer Karole Armitage, clockwise from top left, are among those who will be taking part, beginning Sept. 11. In conjunction with the Kandinsky retrospective at the museum, the artist Rafael Lozano-Hemmer has created an interactive light installation inspired by Kandinsky’s “Yellow Sound” in which colors are derived from the human voice, which features a reading by Ms. Rossellini. Another Kandinsky-inspired program will feature Armitage Gone! Dance and the Brentano String Quartet. Additional highlights include a new dance commission featuring Larry Keigwin and Peter Quanz to music by Mr. Reich; the world premiere of Elliott Carter’s “Duettone”; performances by Shen Wei Dance Arts and American Ballet Theater; and a discussion of New York City Opera’s revival of “Esther.”.

The largest contemporary art show in India opened Thursday in New Delhi without the works of one of the country’s most well-regarded painters, amid concerns that his paintings would prompt attacks by religious militants, Agence France-Presse reported. Organizers for the three-day India Art Summit said that they would not display works by M. F. Husain, above, the 94-year-old Muslim painter known as the Picasso of India, whose paintings portray Hindu deities, sometimes in the nude or in sexually suggestive poses. “We acknowledge the iconic stature of Husain, but are unable to put all the people and art work at risk,” said Neha Kirpal, the show’s associate director, according to Agence France-Presse. Last year some of Mr. Husain’s paintings were attacked by members of Bajrang Dal, a right-wing Hindu group, at an event in New Delhi. Religious hard-liners have also filed more than 800 court cases against him and vandalized his house.

More than 40 years after Old Fred fired up the titular vehicle of “Yellow Submarine” and used it to round up four Liverpool lads who would defend Pepperland from the Blue Meanies, Disney is preparing a remake of the Beatles’ 1968 animated movie, Variety reported. The original film was a traditional (if thoroughly trippy) 2-D cartoon directed by George Dunning and designed by Heinz Edelmann, in which the Beatles appeared only in a live-action segment at the end. The planned remake, to be directed by Robert Zemeckis (“Forrest Gump,” “Who Framed Roger Rabbit”), will be a 3-D animated feature that will use the performance-capture technology seen in Mr. Zemeckis’s “Beowulf” and his coming remake of “A Christmas Carol.” The Variety report said that Disney was seeking rights for the Beatles music that was used in the original “Yellow Submarine” film, including the title song and tracks like “Lucy in the Sky With Diamonds” and “Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band.” The remake is being planned for a 2012 release.

Don Hewitt will be remembered by the program he founded, “60 Minutes,” on Sunday evening. Mr. Hewitt, below, died Wednesday at 86. CBS said that the correspondents for the pioneering newsmagazine, including Steve Kroft, Morley Safer and Lesley Stahl, were preparing segments that would detail Mr. Hewitt’s life and his “lasting contributions to the television news industry.” Jeff Fager, the executive producer of “60 Minutes,” will produce the hourlong show, to be titled “Remembering Don Hewitt.” In a statement, Mr. Fager said Mr. Hewitt “will always have an impact on this broadcast — there’s a part of him in every one of us, and it affects every decision we make.”.

The sister act of Nora and Delia Ephron have added a mother-daughter team to their coming Off Broadway show, “Love, Loss and What I Wore,” the show’s publicists said. Rhea Perlman, right, and Lucy DeVito have been added to the cast of the show, a collection of vignettes and monologues based on the Ilene Beckerman book (as well as on the recollections of the Ephrons’ friends). Ms. DeVito has appeared in Ensemble Studio Theater’s production of “Lucy” as well as the television comedy “It’s Always Sunny in Philadelphia” (which also features her father, Danny). Ms. Perlman was a star of “Cheers,” which we understand was a popular NBC sitcom about a bar. “Love, Loss and What I Wore” is to begin previews at the Westside Theater on Sept. 21 and open on Oct. 1.

Some House Democrats are holding on to the idea of a public insurance option despite growing concern that their stance could jeopardize President Obama's effort to overhaul the health care system. Representative Raúl M. Grijalva, Democrat of Arizona, the co-chairman of the Congressional Progressive Caucus, and Representative Keith Ellison, right, Democrat of Minnesota, said Thursday that they would not support a bill that replaced the public insurance option with health insurance cooperatives. They called the co-op idea, favored by the Senate Finance Committee, a toothless substitute for a government-sponsored alternative.

KLEEBERG--Irene Cumming. Freelance writer and editor died on August 18, 2009 in New York, NY. Daughter of the late James and Ducksilla (nee Elsie Battin) Cumming, born April 21,1932 in Chicago. She graduated from Summit (NJ) High School and earned a B.A. from Wellesley College in 1954. Published books from Christianity to The Butterick Fabric Handbook. Volunteer work included UN families, East Side Community Center, P.S. 59 PTA, NYPD's 17th Pct Comm Council, Romance Writers-NYC, Editorial Freelancer's Assoc and Sisters in Crime. A blogger who criticized the government's handling of an accident at a Siberian hydroelectric plant, which trapped dozens of workers in a flooded chamber on Monday, was charged by local authorities on Thursday with libel of the Sayano-Shushenskaya plant's owners. The blogger, Mikhail Afanasyev, the editor in chief of the online publication New Focus, claimed that the number of missing workers far exceeded the official toll. The charges came a day after the emergency situations minister, Sergei K. Shoigu, said rumors were impeding the work of rescuers and causing panic, adding that ''the gossips should be found and punished.''

(Showtime) THE POPE OF GREENWICH VILLAGE (1984) In this drama directed by Stuart Rosenberg, Mickey Rourke plays Charlie, a cool-headed neighborhood guy who dreams of owning a restaurant. Between a heist and a horse race, his scheming cousin Paulie (Eric Roberts) may have found a way to get Charlie the necessary start-up capital. But Paulie's plan was half-baked, and now the Mafia is after them. ''When are you going to outgrow him?'' asks Charlie's girlfriend, played by a 24-year-old Daryl Hannah with frizzy hair. ''Maybe WASPs outgrow people,'' Charlie says. ''Italians, they outgrow clothes.''

And unaccompanied ladies were welcome.

LESE--William Morris, devoted husband, father and grandfather died peacefully on August 19 at the age of 84. He served in the United States Army from 1943 to 1945 as a reconnaissance scout and received a Purple Heart after being wounded in action in Germany on his 20th birthday. After the War, he went on to become an accomplished real estate investor and commercial broker, twice winning The Real Estate Board of New York's Most Ingenious Deal of the Year Award. He was a philanthropist, avid outdoorsman, fisherman, antiquarian book collector, gourmet chef and worldwide adventurer. He was a true renaissance man who delighted in planning and sharing hid adventures with family and close friends. He had a love affair with life and a youthful charm that touched people all over the globe as well as at home. He is survived by his wife, Sahra; sons, Bill and Peter; daughters, Danielle and Claudia and nine grandchildren. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, August 23 at 10:00am at Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue and 55th Street. Donations in his memory can be made to Central Synagogue, Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center or the Loomis-Chaffee School.

She worked at Electronics, Electronic Design, Electronic Products, and IEEE Spectrum magazines. She leaves her brother John Eastman, nephews Thomas Eastman and John Eric Eastman, niece Anna Sirvent, great-nephew Eric Sirvent and great-niece Carla Sirvent, all in Alicante, Spain. Memorial service Thursday, August 27, 11:00am, at John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 1st Ave. (70th St.).

Anderson; brother of the late Cyrena Anderson. Memorial service will be held Saturday, August 22 at 4pm at Westminster Presbyterian Church, 724 Delaware Ave., Buffalo, NY. Mr. Anderson was educated at the Lawrenceville School, Williams College and recipient of an Honorary Degree from the University of Buffalo. MEYER--Christopher, age 28, died August 8th, 2009 of a brain tumor that was first diagnosed in 2002. During those seven years, his illness never diminished the power of his intellect and he never defined himself by his illness. He lived all of his life with grace, humor and a sunny disposition. In 2003 he finished his B.A. in art history at Stanford and was initiated into Phi Beta Kappa. He was a semi-finalist for a Rhodes scholarship. He was a sports writer for The Stanford Daily covering men's tennis. Chris had been a member of the 1999-2000 team when Stanford was the NCAA Champion as well as the 2001-2 team when he returned from spending his junior year in Paris. While in Paris, Chris had been an intern at the Musee D'Orsay and Rodin Museum. He spent the summers of 2002 and 2003 in Antibes, France as a counselor for Abbey Road, an exchange program for American teenagers In 2004, he graduated from Stanford with a M.A. in Humanities. He was a research assistant at the Metropolitan Museum in New York, the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art and the California Palace of the Legion of Honor. In 2005, he began a Ph.D. program in art history at Harvard and received a Harvard Presidential Fellowship. He also received a Mellon Fellowship that same year. While at Harvard, he successfully completed his course work, acted as a teaching fellow, submitted his qualifying paper, received a Mellon summer fellowship at the Getty Museum in 18th Century studies and completed his orals. This year he finished most of the first chapter of his dissertation. Most importantly during those seven years, he met and married Monica Lara Cordoba. Christopher and Monica brought out the best in each other just as Christopher has brought out the best in all of us and just as he has always demanded the best of himself. We are going to miss him so very much. Christopher is survived by his wife, Monica, of San Francisco; his parents, Michael and Tina, of Berkeley; his brother, Joshua and his sister-in-law Fleur and his nephew, Theodore, of Paris, France.

In the fall of 2006, a man's death brought a team of federal investigators to the large, privately run immigration jail in Eloy, Ariz. Medical care was so poor, the team later warned immigration officials, that ''detainee welfare is in jeopardy.'' An Associated Press report in some editions of the soccer roundup on Sunday about Arsenal's 6-1 victory against Everton in England's Premier League described the margin of victory incorrectly. Other games have featured a larger margin since the league was formed in 1992; the five-goal difference in this game did not match the previous ''biggest victories.''

Saab has exited the Swedish equivalent of Chapter 11 bankruptcy, filing papers with a district court saying that it will not seek to extend its so-called reconstruction period. But its future is still uncertain, because Stockholm has refused a request for a government loan to help wrap up the sale of the company. The court filing Wednesday -- just a day after General Motors formally agreed to sell the troubled carmaker to a much smaller Swedish automaker, Koenigsegg -- ended six months of reorganization and could bring a fresh start for Saab.

FULD--Kenneth. The Directors, Officers and Employees of the Beth Abraham Family of Health Services and The Center for Rehabilitation and Nursing (CNR) sadly mourn the passing of Kenneth Fuld, CNR Chairman of the Board. A long-time member of the Board of Beth Abraham Family of Health Services (CNR's parent organization), Ken is remembered as a dear and generous friend, a supporter and leader who provided guidance, encouraged excellence and fulfilled a personal commitment to enhance the lives of people in the Brooklyn community. Ken consistently emphasized the need to show concern and improve the quality of life for those we care for and about. He has enriched the lives of thousands of people, from patients and staff members to young children to whom he gifted computers and for whom he established the Ken Fuld Scholarship Award. Under Ken's stewardship and by his example, CNR grew from a nursing home to a vital community organization, providing a wide network of programs and services. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Margo, children, Jeffrey, Elaine and Steven, five grandchildren and brother Gilbert. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Michael R. Potack, Chairman of the Board Michael S. Fassler, President and CEO

An Op-Ed article on Friday, about Hawaii’s 50th birthday, incorrectly described the Japanese-American 442nd Regiment in World War II. Not all of the men in the regiment were from Hawaii. It also misspelled the name of an Air Force base on Oahu. It is Hickam, not Hickham.

Schedule information on Friday with an art review of “Intersections Intersected: The Photography of David Goldblatt,” at the New Museum on the Lower East Side, misstated the museum’s telephone number. It is (212) 219-1222.

The Advertising column on Thursday, about a new documentary on the advertising world, misspelled the surname of the filmmaker in one reference in some editions. The error also appeared in an accompanying caption. As the column correctly noted elsewhere, the filmmaker is Doug Pray, not Pay.

An article on Friday about Dollar General’s filing for an initial public offering misstated the plans of the Carlyle Group for the government consulting business it acquired from Booz Allen Hamilton. The Carlyle Group plans to hold the business for the foreseeable future; it is not planning a public offering.

A chart with the continuation of an article on Friday about the weak box-office performance of some summer movies featuring major stars like Denzel Washington and Tom Hanks misidentified, in some copies, the film in which Arnold Schwarzenegger was shown in a scene. Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin went to Siberia on Friday to visit the site of a catastrophic accident at the country's largest hydroelectric dam, pledging to assist victims' families but also conceding that there was little hope of finding survivors. The death toll rose to nearly 50 people, with more than 20 still missing, officials said. Mr. Putin met with workers and said the accident on Monday was ''a huge tragedy.'' On Thursday, Mr. Putin criticized the state of the Russian infrastructure, saying that it needed to be checked and improved. The cause of the burst in the dam has not been determined.

There is no question that older Americans are worried that any health care overhaul may end up cutting their benefits, even if the worst of those fears are being stoked by misinformation. What may puzzle more is the confusion among Medicare recipients about what the program is and how it works, as evident in the variations of ''Keep government out of Medicare!'' shouted at town-hall-style meetings.

Some time back, a reporter visiting Libya made a phone call to an American there whom the authorities wanted to keep quiet, in public at least. Almost before the reporter had lowered the handset, the phone rang. If the journalist persisted with his overtures, said an official who had secretly monitored the conversation, he would be dealt with by ''the Libyan method.'' There was no ambiguity about what that might mean. In the 1980s, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi ran what Dana Moss, an expert on the relationship between Libya and the United States, called ''a rogue regime which used terror as its main tactic of foreign policy.''

A drone attack on a village near the Afghan border in North Waziristan killed 12 people early Friday, Pakistani security officials said. The village, Dande Darpa Khel, is part of the stronghold of Jalaluddin Haqqani, an Afghan fighter and senior Taliban member. The missiles hit a compound near an Islamic school that Mr. Haqqani had set up, and women and children were among the dead, Pakistani officials said.

O'SHEA--Francis J. (Frank), of Hillsdale, NJ, passed away August 20, 2009 age 82. He was born in Manhattan on February 4, 1927, son of the late Delia and John G. O'Shea. He is survived by his beloved wife of 57 years, Rose (Reilly), his brother John (Jack) and sister-in-law Kathleen (Kay) of Long Beach, NY, his brother-in-law Jeremiah Mullins and his wife Mary of Woodcliff Lake, NJ, and his six loving children and 13 grandchildren. Viewing will be held at Becker Funeral Home August 23, 2009. 201-664-0292

LESE--William Morris, devoted husband, father and grandfather died peacefully on August 19 at the age of 84. He served in the United States Army from 1943 to 1945 as a reconnaissance scout and received a Purple Heart after being wounded in action in Germany on his 20th birthday. After the War, he went on to become an accomplished real estate investor and commercial broker, twice winning The Real Estate Board of New York's Most Ingenious Deal of the Year Award. He was a philanthropist, avid outdoorsman, fisherman, antiquarian book collector, gourmet chef and worldwide adventurer. He was a true renaissance man who delighted in planning and sharing his adventures with family and close friends. He had a love affair with life and a youthful charm that touched people all over the globe as well as at home. He is survived by his wife, Sahra; brother John, sons, Bill and Peter; daughters, Danielle and Claudia and nine grandchildren. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, August 23 at 10am at Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue and 55th Street. Donations in his memory can be made to Central Synagogue, Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center or the Loomis-Chaffee School.

Suicide bombers on bicycles killed at least four police officers in attacks in Chechnya's capital on Friday, officials said. At least two bombers approached police officials in different parts of the capital, Grozny, and detonated their explosives, the investigative wing of the Prosecutor General's Office said in a statement. Friday's attacks came just days after a suicide truck bombing at a police headquarters in neighboring Ingushetia that reportedly killed at least 25 people and wounded about 280.

Even with the text of the House health care bill on the desk in front of them, they could not agree on what it actually said. Jon Stewart, the ''Daily Show'' host, and Betsy McCaughey, a vocal opponent of the health care overhaul, faced off Thursday on the show.

So are Democrats going to insist on a government-run public insurance plan or not? The House majority leader, Representative Steny H. Hoyer, Democrat of Maryland, suggested Friday that a public insurance option might have to be discarded to ensure the passage of health care legislation. But that position seemed to contradict the stance taken by Speaker Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California, who said Thursday that the House would not pass a package that did not include a public plan.

VOLLINS--Steven Louis, age 45, on August 19, 2009. Beloved son of Ruth and Edward. Brother of James and his wife Beth, uncle of Charlotte and Sarah Grace. Graduate of Brown University and Harvard Law School. Service Friday, 11:30am at "The Riverside", 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions to a charity of your choice.

BOURNE--Carole Nimmo, devoted wife of the late Kenneth Barnes Bourne Jr. of New York, died of cancer in The New York University Hospital on August 20, 2009. Carole fought leukemia for many years with great strength and courage. Upon retirement from The Ford Foundation, she took a number of courses in history and in the history of art, her favorites featured at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Her travels included Alaska, Europe, the Middle East and the Far East where her husband had worked for the Singer Sewing Machine Company. She was a member of the Lotos Club of New York and enjoyed their many interesting functions. She was a kind and loyal person who celebrated life and who will be missed by those who knew and loved her. Interment will be private. Donations in her memory may be made to: The ASPCA Foundation.

ROTHMAN--Bernard, on August 20, 2009. Beloved father of Eve and Marian. Loving companion of Blessed. Much loved grandfather of Alexa and Steven. Dear uncle and friend. Service Sunday, 9:30am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

HANKS--Edgar C.,M.D. Born in Johnstown, PA, Professor Emeritus of Clinical Anesthesiology, College of Physicians & Surgeons, Columbia University, passed away on August 21, 2009, two days before his 88th birthday. Dr. Hanks graduated from Jefferson Medical College in 1947 and was Attending Anesthesiologist at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center until his retirement in 1986. Loving son of the late Homer and Edna. He is survived by his beloved wife Audrey (Forker), his daughter Elizabeth Lonsberry and her husband George and his grandsons Carter and his wife Christine, Hunter and Gardner and the late Christopher and two great-grandsons, Devin and Cody. Visitation at The Riverdale Funeral Home Inc., 5044 Broadway cor West 214th Street on Sunday, 3-6pm. Graveside Ceremony Monday, 2pm at the Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, NY. Donations to Holy Apostles Soup Kitchen, 296 9th Avenue, New York, NY 10001.

KRAM--Hon. Shirley Wohl, passed away Friday morning, August 21. Beloved wife of the late Bernard, dear mother of Steven Kram (Marilyn), loving sister of Harold Wohl, devoted grandmother of Natalie and Benjamin. Judge Kram was appointed as a United States District Court Judge for the Southern District of New York in 1983. Prior to that, she served as a New York State trial judge for over ten years. Judge Kram was a graduate of Brooklyn Law School, and was co-author of "The Law of Child Custody." Services will be held Sunday, August 23, 10:00am at "The Riverside", 180 West 76th St. at Amsterdam Ave., NYC.

KARPATKIN--Simon. It is with deep sorrow that the ACLU mourns the death of Dr. Simon Karpatkin, one of our most passionate and committed supporters. A devoted civil libertarian, Simon was a lifelong and generous friend of the ACLU. Simon and his wife Margaret established a Karpatkin Fellowship in memory of Simon's brother, Marvin, late General Counsel of the ACLU. Simon had a keen intellect and an unwavering passion for fairness and justice. The Karpatkin Fellowship will continue as a resonant reminder of Simon's resolute belief in the work we do. The ACLU extends its deepest sympathy to Margaret and the entire Karpatkin family for the loss of one of America's most sensitive defenders of liberty.
