DELMAN--E. Elizabeth R. Glaser, at 97, August 11, 2009. Mother of Emily, Peter, and John, grandmother of John and Catherine. Economist, integration activist, English chair at The Hewitt School, she loved teaching, art, theater, and finding presents for her family.

KARPATKIN--Simon, died on August 21, 2009. He was 75 years old. Dearly loved husband of Margaret, cared for deeply by his children David and Judy, and son-in-law Larry Katzman. Dr. Karpatkin was a Professor of Medicine and Director of the Division of Hematology at NYU Medical School. He was an internationally known scientific investigator and author of numerous scholarly publications based on his extensive hematological research. He was an avid sailor and an enthusiastic skier. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street, New York, on August 25, 2009 at 10am. The family will receive at their home on Wednesday, August 26, 2009, 12pm-9pm. Donations in his memory can be made to the ACLU/Marvin M. Karpatkin Fellowship, 125 Broad Street, 18th floor, New York, NY 10004.

(CUNY) LINK TV'S CINEMONDO:MY MARLON AND BRANDO (2008) Peter Scarlet, the former director of the Tribeca Film Festival, introduces this film about a Turkish actress, Ayca Damgaci, whose real-life love affair with a Kurdish Iraqi took a dramatic turn after the American invasion in 2003. The film blends re-enactment and documentary; Ms. Damgaci, above, plays herself, and the real video diaries sent by her boyfriend, Hama Ali Khan, are included. The dialogue is in Kurdish, Turkish and broken English (the lovers' only common language). Huseyin Karabey, who directed and wrote the script with Ms. Damgaci, is interviewed after the movie. 7 A.M. KARPATKIN--Simon. The Department of Medicine at the New York University Langone Medical Center mourns the passing of Simon Karpatkin, M.D, our longtime Director of the Division of Hematology. An alumnus of this school, Dr. Karpatkin served on the faculty for 45 years and made notable contributions to the science of blood coagulation and its disorders. He was a consummate scientist and physician, and will be remembered for his intellectual rigor and for his generous nature. He left behind a legacy of discovery, numerous trainees and students, and many devoted colleagues. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Margaret, also a member of our faculty, and to his entire family. Martin J. Blaser, M.D. Chair, Department of Medicine NYU Langone Medical Center

STEINBERG--Jeffrey H.,found peace August 20, 2009 after a courageous battle with cancer. He is survived by his beloved wife, Lisa, and adoring daughters, Nina and Kate. He also leaves behind his mother, Mildred, and brother, David. Jeff was born on Charlotte St. in the Bronx on July 16, 1947. He attended CCNY where he was a champion for student and civil rights. He went on to become a successful real estate builder and developer. To the end, Jeff was a devoted and selfless protector who valued his family and friends above all else, including his own comfort. The number of lives he touched in his 62 short years on earth is immeasurable, and we will forever miss and remember his kindness, humor, and loyalty. We are comforted by our certainty that he has finally been reunited with his cherished father, Irving. Services will be held August 23, 9:00am at Castle Hill Funeral Directors, 1528 Castle Hill Ave., Bronx, NY. Donations in his memory may be made to the Johns Hopkins Liver Cancer Center in Baltimore, MD or the William J. Clinton Foundation.

One of the stronger arguments for changing the health care system lies in the fact that it has left tens of millions of citizens uninsured, creating a medical underclass whose members receive care - if they receive care - mostly in expensive hospital emergency rooms. Critics of the public insurance option claim the number is inflated, as it may include large numbers of people who qualify for Medicaid but haven't applied, who are only temporarily uninsured or who are noncitizens. (Indeed, many commenters here oppose the public option because they don't want to pay for health care delivered to illegal immigrants.)

Because of an editing error, an obituary last Sunday about Riccardo Cassin, a legendary mountain climber, misstated the name of a mountain conquered for the first time via its south wall by Mr. Cassin’s five-man team. It is Mount McKinley, not Denali. (The mountain, in Denali National Park, is referred to by many as Denali but the name has not been officially changed.).

A capsule summary on Page 2 this weekend, referring to Matt Gross’s Frugal Traveler and other online features, misstates the name of a new service he uses to make long-distance calls home. It is Voxox, not Vovox. (The blog is at nytimes.com/frugaltraveler.).

An article on Page 14 this weekend about the arts impresario Serge Diaghilev misspells, in some copies, part of the name of the company he founded in 1909. It is the Ballets Russes, not the Ballet Russes. The error also appears in an accompanying picture caption and in a capsule summary referring to additional images on nytimes.com of the New York City Library’s exhibition “Diaghilev’s Theater of Marvels: The Ballets Russes and Its Aftermath.”.

A listing in the Long Island Calendar in some editions last Sunday about an exhibition of Andy Warhol’s photographs at Hofstra University Museum gave an incorrect location and telephone number. It is in the David Filderman Gallery, not the Guthart Cultural Center Theater (both are in the Joan and Donald E. Axinn Library on the university’s South Campus); the telephone number is (516) 463-5672. (The error also appeared on Aug. 2 and 9).

A chart last Sunday with an article about the paucity of left-handed catchers in major league baseball history erroneously included two players on a list of those who have played at least one game since 1900. Although pitcher Chris Short and first baseman Tom Chism were penciled in as catchers, they were replaced in the lineup before playing the position.

An article last Sunday about Renewal Farm in Garrison, N.Y., an organic vegetable farm that offers rehabilitation for addicts and alcoholics from New York City, referred imprecisely to St. Christopher’s Inn, where the program’s participants live. It was founded as a home for the Franciscan Friars and Franciscan Sisters of the Atonement, and remains a friary today; it is also used as a homeless shelter and rehabilitation center, but it did not “morph” into those functions over the years.

A picture caption last Sunday with the DVD column, about the Japanese director Ishiro Honda, was published in error. The photograph showed behind-the-scenes preparations for Mr. Honda’s 1961 movie “Mothra.” It was not a scene from the film.
A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the musician Jay Reatard misidentified the man shown playing bass at a Chicago music festival. He is Stephen Pope, not Jay Reatard.

An article last Sunday about the film “The Baader Meinhof Complex,” which focuses on the Red Army Faction in West Germany, misstated the timing of the kidnapping and killing of the industrialist Hanns Schleyer. The gang kidnapped him in early September 1977, several weeks before its imprisoned leaders — Andreas Baader, Gudrun Ensslin and Jan-Carl Raspe — died; the gang then killed him in retribution after their deaths. It did not kidnap Mr. Schleyer after the leaders died.
Is a Jets passer poised to be the next Broadway Joe?

An article last Sunday about George Steel, the general manager and artistic director of the New York City Opera, misidentified the company that commissioned “Esther,” which City Opera is performing this fall. It was the San Francisco Opera, not City Opera. (After the San Francisco Opera dropped the project, City Opera resuscitated it and gave “Esther” its world premiere in 1993.).

The 36 Hours column on Aug. 9, about Tulum, Mexico, misstated the site of full moon festivals in Thailand that some visitors to Tulum may have attended in younger days. The festivals took place on the island of Ko Phangan — not on Ko Samui, which is another island a short boat ride away. The column also misstated the price of admission to the Gran Cenote, 20 minutes from Tulum, where tourists can snorkel. It is 100 pesos, not 600.

Nicholas Kristof began writing his Times Op Ed column eight years ago, and from the start, he has regularly and incisively called attention to women’s issues, especially those in the developing world. Traveling to scores of countries, he has carefully documented and forcefully denounced the crimes and cruelties suffered by women and girls: sex trafficking and slavery; political rape; child marriage; the denial of the freedom to pursue an education or a career, or to enter a domestic relationship in which you’re not beaten by a man. It’s the way life is lived too much of the time in too many places by too many, though this has for too long not been seen as “news.” Nick, perhaps more than any other journalist working today, has begun to change that.

KARLIN--Linda Beth. Linda Beth Karlin, 49, passed away on August 8, 2009 after a 29 year battle with cancer. Linda graduated from Georgetown University and lived in Washington, DC for 31 years. She was a remarkable and vivacious woman who touched all those who knew her. Linda was an acknowledged poet and artist-in-residence with Smith Farm Center for Healing and the Arts at the Washington Cancer Institute, Washington Hospital Center. She is survived by her husband Peter Fox of Washington, DC, her mother and father, Adrienne and Dr. David Karlin, her sister Diane B. Karlin and her nephew Winston I. Karlin of New York City. Expressions of sympathy may be made to Smith Farm Center for Healing and the Arts, 1632 U St. NW, Washington, DC 20009.

SHEINBAUM--Edward. The Board of Governors and Members of The Falls Country Club, Lake Worth, FL, acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member Edward Sheinbaum. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife Lynn and their family. Edwin Levine, President

MEYER--Christopher, age 28, died August 8th, 2009 of a brain tumor that was first diagnosed in 2002. During those seven years, his illness never diminished the power of his intellect and he never defined himself by his illness. He lived all of his life with grace, humor and a sunny disposition. In 2003 he finished his B.A. in art history at Stanford and was initiated into Phi Beta Kappa. He was a semi-finalist for a Rhodes scholarship. He was a sports writer for The Stanford Daily covering men's tennis. Chris had been a member of the 1999-2000 team when Stanford was the NCAA Champion as well as the 2001-2 team when he returned from spending his junior year in Paris. While in Paris, Chris had been an intern at the Musee D'Orsay and Rodin Museum. He spent the summers of 2002 and 2003 in Antibes, France as a counselor for Abbey Road, an exchange program for American teenagers In 2004, he graduated from Stanford with a M.A. in Humanities. He was a research assistant at the Metropolitan Museum in New York, the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art and the California Palace of the Legion of Honor. In 2005, he began a Ph.D. program in art history at Harvard and received a Harvard Presidential Fellowship. He also received a Mellon Fellowship that same year. While at Harvard, he successfully completed his course work, acted as a teaching fellow, submitted his qualifying paper, received a Mellon summer fellowship at the Getty Museum in 18th Century studies and completed his orals. This year he finished most of the first chapter of his dissertation. Most importantly during those seven years, he met and married Monica Lara Cordoba. Christopher and Monica brought out the best in each other just as Christopher has brought out the best in all of us and just as he has always demanded the best of himself. We are going to miss him so very much. Christopher is survived by his wife, Monica, of San Francisco; his parents, Michael and Tina, of Berkeley; his brother, Joshua and his sister-in-law Fleur and his nephew, Theodore, of Paris, France.

NAMED for its size, ''SUMO,'' Helmut Newton's 1999 monograph, is a beast of a book. More than two feet tall, 480 pages thick and weighing nearly 70 pounds (for manageability, each of the 10,000 editions came with a stainless steel stand designed by Philippe Starck), it was the largest and most expensive book of the 20th century. A copy signed by more than 100 celebrities portrayed in it sold at auction in 1999 for $350,000. Today, issues go for $10,000 and up. Not in the budget? No matter. In celebration of the 10th anniversary of ''SUMO,'' a considerably smaller edition is now being released, priced at a relatively puny $150. ''Helmut always longed for a more democratic dispersal of his work,'' Benedikt Taschen, the book's publisher, explained. ''This new edition is the fulfillment of an ambition conceived years ago. We jokingly referred to it as 'Newton for the poor.' ''

The mayor of Riga is fed up with drunken Britons using his fair city as a public urinal. In remarks published in the Latvian magazine Laiks, which have created quite a stir in the British travel media, Nils Usakovs said that he was tired of boozing bachelors from Britain running amok in Riga. In particular, he mentioned tourists who urinate on Riga's Freedom Monument, which honors soldiers killed during the Latvian war of independence.

AS if Camembert and tasteful manicures weren't enough, here is another thing to admire about the French: nearly a quarter of the vegetables and herbs consumed in that country are homegrown. They call it the jardin potager, literally the ''soup garden,'' since most of the ingredients for those simple, delectable meals -- parsley, potatoes, tomatoes, garlic, thyme -- are right there for the picking.

HERE are highlights of other items published in the Wheels blog this week:

HOWATT--Shelby Moorman, passed away August 15th after a short battle with stomach cancer. She was born in Owensboro Kentucky on May 30, 1936 to a family with deep Southern roots. She graduated from Princeton High School and Smith College, where her love of the theater took root. Shelby married John Charles Howatt and together they raised four children. While raising her children in Pelham, New York, her natural talent and artistic passion were expressed through her writing. Featured among countless other published works, she wrote a weekly article in the Home section of the New York Times, focusing on the reality of raising a large family while juggling a stressful career. After retiring from professional writing, Shelby moved to her beloved New York City, and became a therapist, specializing in treating drug addiction as well as compulsive hair pulling. She lifted the spirits of all who had the fortune to meet her with her infectious smile and beautiful blue eyes; patiently and earnestly listening to their life stories and lending sage advice when needed. She was also a tireless volunteer, donating her time to The International House teaching ESL and helping her local library among other efforts. Shelby will be missed by her children Toddy, Daniel, Laura, and Charles; her grandchildren Matthew, James, Sam, Isabel, Sarah, Jackson, Adalene, Zachary, Layne, and Joseph; her brother Jack Moorman, her niece and her nephews. May she rest in eternal peace.

SOEIRO--Ruy, M.D.,devoted physician, teacher, husband and father-died peacefully on August 20, 2009 after a prolonged illness. Funeral services will be private. Donations in his honor can be made at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, c/o Institutional Advancement Department.

STEINBERG--Jeffrey H.,found peace August 20, 2009 after a courageous battle with cancer. He is survived by his beloved wife, Lisa, and adoring daughters, Nina and Kate. He also leaves behind his mother, Mildred, and brother, David. Jeff was born on Charlotte St. in the Bronx on July 16, 1947. He attended CCNY where he was a champion for student and civil rights. He went on to become a successful real estate builder and developer. To the end, Jeff was a devoted and selfless protector who valued his family and friends above all else, including his own comfort. The number of lives he touched in his 62 short years on earth is immeasurable, and we will forever miss and remember his kindness, humor, and loyalty. We are comforted by our certainty that he has finally been reunited with his cherished father, Irving. Services will be held August 23, 9:00am at Castle Hill Funeral Directors, 1528 Castle Hill Ave., Bronx, NY. Donations in his memory may be made to the Johns Hopkins Liver Cancer Center in Baltimore, MD or the William J. Clinton Foundation.

FUN as it may be, the sequin mini disco dress, worn with wild abandon on the red carpet this year, was never quite in tune with the times. Nowadays it seems almost sad, like a tarted-up party girl, drunk and dancing long after everyone has gone home. ''Sequins in general are done and done,'' the stylist Frances Tulk-Hart said. ''They go hand in hand with the whole '80s thing, which ought to come to an end as well.'' Not that a little glitz isn't good. The runways for fall were illuminated with shiny pieces -- loose metallic trousers in particular -- that somehow felt fresh in the way they were casually styled. At Isabel Marant (near right) and Etro (center right) they were worn with slouchy T-shirts and nubby sweaters. Off the runways, women are pairing them with breezy silk blouses and leather bomber jackets. The overall effect? A kind of stripped-down, easygoing glamour that looks right and rich in this day and age.

Expect to see more Californians on the sunny beaches of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., this winter. Virgin America recently announced that it will begin twice-daily nonstop flights to Fort Lauderdale, above, from both San Francisco and Los Angeles beginning on Nov. 18. BRISTOL--William M.,III. The Trustees, the President and the entire Hamilton College community mourn the passing of our former Chairman of the Board and Life Trustee. A longtime senior executive with Bristol-Myers Squibb, the firm founded in 1887 by his grandfather and a Hamilton classmate, "Mac" Bristol was a member of the sixth generation of a family that traces its association with Hamilton to the college's founding as the Hamilton-Oneida Academy in 1793. We will miss Mac's leadership, devotion and love for his alma mater. Our deepest sympathy is extended to his wife Mary Jayne Comey and the Bristol family.

RUPINSKI--Josephine Goodson, died at the age of 84 on August 16, 2009, in Westchester, New York, after a long illness. Born Grace Josephine Goodson in Allendale, South Carolina, to William Henry Goodson and Mary Ella Rogers Goodson, she was the youngest of five siblings. After graduating from Winthrop College in 1944, she worked as part of the Manhattan Project in Oak Ridge, Tennessee, during World War II. After the war, she met her husband, John, while they both worked for the U.S. Government in Wiesbaden, Germany, during postwar reconstruction. The couple returned to the United States, where they lived in Detroit, Michigan. Mrs. Rupinski worked as assistant to the general counsel of General Motors there before beginning a family with her husband. Relocating to Montclair, New Jersey, she taught business English and other subjects at the Katharine Gibbs School in Montclair. She also held positions in New York City over the years, including working as an advertising assistant at The New Yorker magazine, a publication she read avidly. She had a lifelong love of the English language and the written word, and was fond of reciting her favorite poems, as well as reading the works of English novelists, particularly those with an understanding of the nuances of family and social life. Upon retirement, she and her husband settled in Manhattan, where her passion for books was well served by the New York Public Library. She also enjoyed exploring the city she loved on its many public buses. All who knew her appreciated her wit, humor and judgment. Over the years, her friends, colleagues and family would often ask for her expert opinion on syntax, usage, and written style. She was predeceased by her parents, her brother Henry, and her sister Caroline. She is survived by her husband, her sister Juanita, and her brother Angus, her children Karen R. Roberts, Mark and Charles, and her granddaughters Sarah and Morgan. She will be laid to rest in her hometown of Allendale. A memorial gathering is planned for a later date. Contributions in her memory may be made to the New York Public Library.

John Madden is adjusting to retirement by acting almost as if he weren't retired. He has been on the bus; he's promoting ''Madden NFL 10,'' the latest edition of his EA Sports video game; and he's preparing for the season. Where that preparation will lead him, he doesn't know. RICHARD SANDOMIR

Jozy Altidore nearly went from the plane to the game. Altidore, the 19-year-old American striker who had to cool his heels in the United States while his work permit wended its way through the British bureaucracy, saw his first action in the English Premier League when he entered Saturday's match for Hull City in the 59th minute against Bolton Wanderers. Hull earned its first victory of the season, winning the match, 1-0, on a goal in the 60th minute by the Algerian striker Kamel Fathi Ghilas, who took a pass from Altidore.

Cities are being transformed into weekend playgrounds for the summer months. In Manhattan, imagine Broadway, from Central Park to Macy's, being turned into a mall for pedestrians and riders. It seems like everyone, with or without a safety helmet, is on wheels, from scooters and skateboards to inline skates and pedal carts. Women in skirts who ride to work are now a common sight, and a woman in a wheelchair was able to enjoy some breathing room while navigating the streets in style. Custom tricycles and bicycles -- a few carrying flowers or packages and one carrying a beloved pet, Emmett -- are the new status vehicles in a city that always goes out of its way to be on the go.

Adrian W. DeWind, an adviser to presidents and governors on tax law and an influential advocate in the human rights and nuclear nonproliferation movements, died on Aug. 7 at his home in Manhattan. He was 95. His death was confirmed by his daughter Penny DeWind.

HEADING HOME Teams like the 2007 Colorado Rockies rattled off 14 wins out of 15 games at the end of the season, ultimately propelling themselves to the World Series after they had been left to rot on the side of the road in mid-August. Making something possible in the face of the impossible is what keeps this game interesting. But still, aren't some teams just done?

THE jewelry designer Eddie Borgo has a habit of making refined, punk-inspired pieces -- slender spike earrings, metal fringe cuffs -- that cause fashion editors to go into a tizzy. Which is to say that since introducing his line in March, he has seen his pieces turn up in many a major fashion magazine, and on many a major stylist. As he modestly put it, ''I get a lot of personal orders.'' Such was indeed the case with his latest design, a leather belt adorned with silver pyramids. Mr. Borgo had been making them as one-offs for friends (Vanessa Traina, among them) until people started inquiring. Consequently his plan to expand into belts next spring was, by popular demand, amended to late this summer. Fine by him. ''I believe in an organic evolution,'' he said. ''I do things as they come.''
'I am offended. I feel what the parents are feeling. I feel what this child is going through.' LEONARD CHUENE,
Pop Nate Chinen

For decades, farmers, lawn care workers and professional green thumbs have relied on the popular weed killer atrazine to protect their crops, golf courses and manicured lawns. But atrazine often washes into water supplies and has become among the most common contaminants in American reservoirs and other sources of drinking water.

THE NEWS The Central Intelligence Agency in 2004 hired contractors from the private security firm Blackwater USA as part of a secret effort to locate and assassinate top operatives from Al Qaeda, The Times reported. BEHIND THE NEWS Current and former government officials said Blackwater executives helped with planning, training and surveillance. No Qaeda operatives were captured or killed, and it is unclear whether the C.I.A. planned to use the contractors for those purposes. A House committee is now investigating why lawmakers weren't told about the program at the time. The C.I.A. disclosed it to Congress in June after withholding details for seven years.

THE Mini E, an electric battery version of the popular retro rocket, is quite literally not for everyone. NATHANSON--Andrew J. He died August 21 from a surfing accident at the age of 51. He is survived by his loving mother Sally, his adored wife Elyse and beloved children Brian, Alison, and Kevin; his brother Larry and sister-in-law Larraine. He was a graduate of Cornell University and received a MBA from The Wharton School. He went on to become an accomplished, highly successful managing director at Drexel Burnham Lambert and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, where he was on the Investment Banking Executive Committee and held other senior positions. He was a Managing Partner of Oak Hill Capital Partners and a director of several Companies including Duane Reade, Inc. His greatest pleasure was spending time with his family. He loved watching and participating in his children's activities. He loved all outdoor and athletic activities including football, skiing, scuba diving and golf. He was adventurous and loved to travel and explore new places. He was a philanthropist and donated to a number of causes and foundations, including The Robert Cullen Fund at Cornell University. Memorial services will be held August 24 at 11am at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester 2125 Westchester Avenue East Rye, NY.

Anniversary in the Caribbean To celebrate our fifth anniversary, my husband and I have decided to go somewhere in the Caribbean in September. I wonder if we've chosen wisely, though, because so many resorts seem to shut down then for ''annual closing.'' We've sort of narrowed it down to St. Barts. But we're open to other islands as long as they fit our criteria of a nice resort for no more than $500 a night, a short flight on American Airlines, good food, great beaches and something to do if the weather takes a turn for the worse. -- Quimby Mills, Montreal

BRISTOL--William McLaren III, a former executive at Bristol-Myers Company and Chairman Emeritus and Life Trustee of Hamilton College and generous benefactor to numerous individuals and organizations, died Tuesday morning, August 18, 2009 at his home in Newtown, Pennsylvania. He was 88. The cause of death was metastatic lung cancer. Mr. Bristol spent his entire professional life with the Bristol-Myers Company, retiring as Executive Vice President, and was the third generation to lead a company founded by his grandfather in 1887. During Mr. Bristol's tenure, Bristol-Myers grew from a mid-sized drug company to become one of the largest pharmaceutical companies in the world. He also served as President of the Proprietary Association. Aside from his family, Mr. Bristol's greatest love in life was Hamilton College. He graduated in the class of 1943 and spent the rest of his life in service to his alma mater. He was a member of the Board of Trustees for over fifty years and served as Chairman from 1977 to 1990. During his tenure as Chairman, he spearheaded what was then the largest capital campaign in the College's history, concentrating throughout his years on the Board on increasing the endowment while enhancing the physical plant and campus environment. Mr. Bristol also focused his and his family's giving on financial aid, thereby opening Hamilton's doors to many who would not otherwise have been able to attend. Mr. Bristol was a fifth generation Bristol to attend Hamilton and was proud to be succeeded by a son and three grandchildren. His great-great-great-grandfather, Joel Bristol, was one of the College's original trustees. Hamilton's President, Joan Hinde Stewart, said that "Mac spent much of his life working to make Hamilton not just better, but the best college in the country. For well over half a century, he was a visible and spiritual presence on College Hill. It is hard to imagine Hamilton without his loyalty, leadership, passion, determination and competitive spirit. Put simply, he was our College's heart and soul." William McLaren Bristol III was born in Brooklyn, New York on July 24, 1921. He attended the Pingry School, in Elizabeth, New Jersey, subsequently serving as a trustee from 1959 to 1985 and ultimately as Chairman of the Board. Mr. Bristol matriculated at Hamilton College in 1939, where he majored in Latin and earned nine varsity letters in football, basketball and baseball. He left Hamilton before graduation in 1943 to serve in World War II as a member of The United States Marine Corps. Mr. Bristol fought in the Battle of Iwo Jima, served as a member of the occupation forces in Japan and was honorably discharged as a First Lieutenant in 1946. Mr. Bristol is survived by his beloved second wife, Mary Jayne Comey, whose love of Mr. Bristol embraced family, Hamilton and professional football. His first marriage, to the former Dorothea Tilton, ended in divorce. Mr. Bristol is also survived by his four children, Pamela Bristol of Ringoes, New Jersey, Brian Bristol of New York, New York, Pinny Kuckel of Deansboro, New York and Sanford Bristol of Summit, New Jersey; as well as his seven grandchildren, Nicholas Kuckel, Monica Odening, Nathaniel Bristol, Courtney Odening, Abigail Bristol, Scott Odening and Samuel Bristol. A Funeral Mass will be held Thursday, August 27, at 11:00am at St. Vincent de Paul Church, 654 Hatboro Road, Richboro, PA. 18954. A Memorial Service will be held at Hamilton College on September 12. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Hamilton College Clinton, New York 13323 and San Domenico School, 1500 Butterfield Road, San Anselmo, CA 94960, Attention Sister Gervaise Valpey, O.P. Services by Joseph A. Fluehr III Funeral Home, Richboro, PA. www.fluehr.com

The literary scholar Richard Poirier, who died last weekend at the age of 83, was one of the strong critics of his time. Like Harold Bloom, Pauline Kael and Clement Greenberg, he identified a lineage of artists and introduced a way to make sense of them. For five decades, Mr. Poirier taught literature at Rutgers University, where he founded Raritan, a quarterly named for the river that borders New Brunswick. He reached a broader public by collaborating with another man of letters, Edmund Wilson, to create the Library of America, which continues to assemble a canon of American masterworks, printed on perfectly white acid-free paper to last for the ages. These were impressive achievements. But Mr. Poirier's most important contribution came in his criticism, which tried to convey why the act of reading is -- and should be -- so difficult. The most powerful works of literature, he insisted, offer ''a fairly direct access to pleasure'' but become ''on longer acquaintance, rather strange and imponderable.'' Even as readers try to pin down what a writer means, the best authors try to elude them, using all the resources of sound, rhythm and syntax to defeat any straightforward account of what they are doing.

Is the gulf between being No. 1 and No. 2 in the world as wide as Interstates 90 and 71? Roger Federer, the top-ranked player in the world, travels the tennis circuit by private jet. Andy Murray, his closest challenger, hopped in a car -- O.K., it was a luxury sport-utility vehicle -- after winning the Rogers Cup final in Montreal and drove the roughly 800 miles to Cincinnati. ''I don't know many people that fly as much as the tennis players,'' Murray, of Scotland, said Tuesday. ''I mean, by the end of the year, you get pretty sick of it.''

SOLVE SUNDSBO'S lush, otherworldly images aren't intended for T-shirts. Nonetheless, it works. In what is one of the season's most interesting collaborations, Mr. Sundsbo, the Norwegian photographer, who has shot ads for Yves Saint Laurent and Dolce & Gabbana and fashion features for Harper's Bazaar and W, has paired with the creative studio-clothing label Surface to Air on a line of silk tops, dresses and oversize satchels, printed with three of his works. ''We were looking for images that could create surprising pieces,'' said Aldric Speer, Surface to Air's brand designer. Certainly nothing gives punch to an amorphous sac quite like Mr. Sundsbo's film still of a scarlet macaw in midflight.

LESE--William M. Our heartfelt condolences to Sahra and the entire family. Bill was a special friend who will be dearly missed. We will always have the memories of the wonderful times we shared together. Adrianne and Jerry L. Cohen and family

KARPATKIN--Simon, M.D. It is with great sadness that the NYU Hematology Division notes the passing of Dr. Simon Karpatkin. Dr. Karpatkin was the chief of the hematology division at NYU Medical Center where he has been a researcher, clinician and teacher over the past four decades. He has been at the forefront of research in several areas including the biology of platelets as well as the interaction between platelets, the immune system, the clotting system and the spread of cancer. He has been a mentor for numerous medical students, fellows and most of the faculty in the division. Our division will greatly miss our colleague and friend for his honesty, kindness, dedication to teaching, research and adherence to rigorous scientific principles. We extend our deep felt sympathies to his family, in particular, his wife Margaret, who has been our colleague as well as the director of pediatric hematology at NYU, and their two children, David and Judy.

THE J. C. Penney Company opened a new department store in Midtown Manhattan at the end of last month. It was greeted in The Times's ''Critical Shopper'' column with what many readers perceived as offensive condescension. ''Why would this dowdy Middle American entity waddle into Midtown in its big old shorts and flip-flops'' without even a makeover of its logo, asked the columnist, Cintra Wilson, a virtual sneer seeming to drip from her keyboard. She said Penney's ''has always trafficked in knockoffs that aren't quite up to Canal Street's illegal standards''; ''a good 96 percent'' of the clothing is polyester; the racks are full of sizes 10, 12 and 16, but not Wilson's 2; the petites department has plenty of clothing ''for women nearly as wide as they are tall''; and the store ''has the most obese mannequins I have ever seen. They probably need special insulin-based epoxy injections just to make their limbs stay on.''

McLAUGHLIN--Michael Oakley, a filmmaker and editor of Queens, NY, died on August 9, 2009 at the age of 38. He grew up in the shadow of Mount Tamalpais in Marin County, where his love for the outdoors was nurtured. He attended Sarah Lawrence College, and then Columbia University. His West Village home, nicknamed "The Tiny Happy," became a haven for a community of artists. With his wife Lauren, Michael created a life filled with laughter, adventure and adoration. His infectious delight in playful creativity inspired all who knew him. He will be missed by his wife Lauren McLaughlin, his mother Rohana McLaughlin, his sister Halima, his brother Marlon, his extended family, and his strong circle of friends. For memorial information, please visit www.mclaughter.com.

KLIGMAN--Dr. David, 75. Adored husband of the late Norma, loving father of Ricky (Andrew), Danny, Carin (Mark) and Barble. Devoted grandfather of Lexi, Zack, Justin and Isaac. Born in Romania, raised in Colombia, South America and educated in Canada, Dr. Kligman was a proud graduate of the University of Manitoba Medical School. He was a General Practioner in Brooklyn, NY for over forty years, a Medical Examiner for the city of New York, an Associate Professor at Downstate Medical College, an FAA pilot examiner and Staff Physician for the NYC Board of Education. He adored his family, the practice of medicine, Israel, collecting antique clocks, ivory carvings, airline miles and visiting his grandchildren. He will be remembered for his sense of humor, his brilliance as a diagnostician, the cloud of cigar smoke that surrounded him, and the force of his charm. Contributions may be made to: The Jewish Community Youth Foundation at Jewish Family and Childrens' Services, 707 Alexander Road Suite 102, Princeton, NJ, 08540, or Nashuva, PO Box 64196, Los Angeles, CA 90064. Tahti, we love you and miss you more than you could ever know. Your family.

OUTWATER--John Ogden, Jr.,Sc.D., Ph.D., died in Shelburne, VT on August 12, 2009 at age 86. He was born in London, England and grew up in London, New York and Norway. He was the son of Nenny Boe and John Ogden Outwater. During World War II his parents and younger brother returned to the US while John finished Stowe School in England. Students were assigned night watches on the roof while London burned in the distance, to look for German parachutists; the boys sat with a bucket of water to douse any incendiary bombs. Most classmates were drafted straight into the army but his superior grades allowed him two years at Cambridge University in Trinity College if he majored in engineering or medicine (what the army needed). He graduated in 1943. The week before the Allied invasion, John was transferred to the British Indian Army - which he credited with his survival. Half his classmates were killed during the invasion. He left war torn England on a troop ship and spent the next four years in India keeping 200 vehicles running for the troops. He was discharged in 1947 as a Captain. Following his return to the U.S. John received his Sc.D. from MIT in Mechanical Engineering (1950) and a Ph.D. from Cambridge University in (1976). He was a professor at the University of Vermont (1955-93). He was known as the Father of Ski Safety for developing the first testing device to allow ski bindings to be set to release before the bone broke. He measured the force necessary to break the leg bone, so the bindings would release at a certain strain based on the height and weight of the person - this led to the anti-friction pad now used on all downhill skis. He built prototypes of binding testers in his basement workshop and formed the Vermont Instrument Company. He led four archeology expeditions for the Wenner-Gren Foundation to Olanaytambo, Mexico, Peru and Haiti, accompanied by Alice who always relished the adventures. His interests were wide. He approached each challenge systematically by taking summer courses, doing research that often resulted in publication of scientific papers of which he had scores. He was fascinated by the law and was an expert witness concerning ski accidents in nearly 1,000 cases. He was a lifelong chess player and Vermont Champion twice. He leaves Alice, his beloved bride of 58 years, and four children, Dr. Anne Hooker Outwater of Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, Catherine Boe of Santa Monica, CA and her son Arthur Boe Colby of Washington, DC, Alice Brookfield Outwater and her husband Robert B. Lang and son Samuel Outwater Lang of Durango, Co, and Dr. John Ogden Outwater III of Cambridge, MA; his brother Eric B. Outwater of Center Valley, PA. He was a member of the Holland Society and St. Nicholas Society of New York. He was listed in Who's Who of the World. John felt fortunate to have lived during this extraordinary time in history, which he did with vigor and grace, hoping to leave a mark on the world.

VOLLINS--Steven Louis, age 45, on August 19, 2009. Beloved son of Ruth and Edward. Brother of James and his wife Beth, uncle of Charlotte and Sarah Grace. Graduate of Brown University and Harvard Law School. Service Friday, 11:30am at "The Riverside", 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions to a charity of your choice.

To the Sports Editor: If a person serves prison time for committing a crime, that should be the end of the issue, at least for a first-time offender. In fact, a person leaving prison is branded as an ex-con and must report that status when applying for a job. That can limit a person's ability to find meaningful employment, which is further punishment.

LESE--William Morris, devoted husband, father and grandfather died peacefully on August 19 at the age of 84. He served in the United States Army from 1943 to 1945 as a reconnaissance scout and received a Purple Heart after being wounded in action in Germany on his 20th birthday. After the War, he went on to become an accomplished real estate investor and commercial broker, twice winning The Real Estate Board of New York's Most Ingenious Deal of the Year Award. He was a philanthropist, avid outdoorsman, fisherman, antiquarian book collector, gourmet chef and worldwide adventurer. He was a true renaissance man who delighted in planning and sharing his adventures with family and close friends. He had a love affair with life and a youthful charm that touched people all over the globe as well as at home. He is survived by his wife, Sahra; brother John, sons, Bill and Peter; daughters, Danielle and Claudia and nine grandchildren. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, August 23 at 10am at Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue and 55th Street. Donations in his memory can be made to Central Synagogue, Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center or the Loomis-Chaffee School.

BERTSCHE--Louise Copeland (Gray), 91, died peacefully in her sleep Tuesday, August 18, 2009, in West Caldwell, New Jersey. She lived a life filled with love and dignity. A longtime resident of Montclair, New Jersey, she worked for 17 years in the student accounts office of Montclair State College. Daughter of the late Frances Louise (Copeland) Gray and sister of the late Julia (Gray) Butler, she was predeceased by her son, William North Bertsche, who died in 2006. She is survived by her children Copeland G. and Andree (Wright) of Montclair, N.J., Harriet (Epstein) of Chicago, IL, Alyce Louise of Germantown, MD, and Robert A. and Lynn Abrahams of Needham, MA; by her grandchildren Lanie, Brit, Torie, Jessa, Alex, Rachel, Joshua, and Jeremy; by her great-grandchildren Sophie Louise, George, Anna, Karl, Greta, Coleman, Julia Copeland, and Abigail; and by numerous nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held in the fall. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Union Congregational Church, 176 Cooper Ave., Montclair, NJ 07043.

How thoroughly versed is the “Mad Men” writing team in the history of New York? If you’ve seen Sunday night’s episode, you’ll recall it started with a tense meeting between Pete Campbell and Paul Kinsey and executives from Madison Square Garden, who hope that the city’s denizens will warm to their plans to demolish Penn Station and replace it with a new entertainment arena. (Wonder how that turned out?) Among the negative responses to the plan that the executives discuss is an article from The New York Times written by Ada Louise Huxtable, the future Pulitzer Prize-winning architecture critic.

The New York Philharmonic isn’t the only arts organization planning a high-profile visit to Asia this fall. American Ballet Theater has announced that it will make its first visit to Beijing in November. The six-performance engagement will be the first by an American ballet company at the National Center for the Performing Arts, also known as The Egg. Performances begin on Nov. 12 and run through Nov. 15, and include four performances of the full-length ballet “Don Quixote,” staged by Susan Jones and Kevin McKenzie, the company’s artistic director, and two repertory programs, including works by the company’s artist in residence, Alexei Ratmanksy, as well as Aszure Barton and Benjamin Millepied. The company previously performed in Hong Kong and Shanghai in 2000.

The Christmas season starts earlier every year: on Monday it was announced that the musical “Irving Berlin’s White Christmas” would make its return to Broadway in November, publicists for the show said in a news release. The musical, adapted from the 1954 movie that starred Bing Crosby, Danny Kaye and Rosemary Clooney, will once again play at the Marquis Theater, where it will run from Nov. 13 through Jan. 3. As in the film, the stage show follows a pair of popular song-and-dance men who attempt to save a Vermont inn from closure while they also woo a pair of everlovin’ sisters. Structured around a score of Irving Berlin standards, the Broadway production is directed by Walter Bobbie, with a book by David Ives and Paul Blake, and choreography by Randy Skinner. Last season’s Broadway production starred Stephen Bogardus, Jeffry Denman, Kerry O’Malley and Meredith Patterson. Casting for the 2009 run has not yet been announced.

The rapid resurrection of Vibe magazine continues: on Monday the new owners of the revived hip-hop and R&B magazine said that they had chosen Jermaine Hall as the editor in chief of Vibe and its Web site, vibe.com. Mr. Hall has previously served as the editor in chief of King magazine, a monthly title geared towards African-American men which ceased publication earlier this year. He was also music editor at the rap music magazine The Source and the webmaster at Vibe.

Feel free to shed a quiet tear from either of your unevenly spaced, asymmetrical eyes: the Picasso Museum in Paris closed its doors on Sunday and will not reopen them to visitors for more than two years as it undergoes an extensive renovation, The Associated Press reported. The 32,000-square-foot museum, which opened in 1985 in Paris’s Marais district, holds about 5,000 pieces of art by Picasso, including paintings, sculptures and sketches, but was only able to display between 250 and 300 at a time. During the renovation, which is expected to cost about $28 million and begin next year, the museum will be expanded and made more accessible, as well having electrical problems fixed. In the meantime, the museum will stop lending out its artworks as experts update its inventory, after which the works will be packaged and shipped to storerooms managed by France’s museum authority. The museum offered free admission to its visitors on Sunday, the last day before its renovations began.

An American company is teaming up with two British groups to begin recording three-dimensional models of global historical sites that could be used to restore the sites if they are damaged by natural or man-made conditions, The Guardian reported. CyArk, an Orinda, Calif.-based nonprofit, will begin working with Historic Scotland, the Scottish government’s heritage agency, and the Glasgow School of Art in September to produce a 3-D model of Mount Rushmore National Memorial in South Dakota that would be accurate to about one-tenth of an inch. That model can then be used by archaeologists to repair the granite portraits of Washington, Jefferson, Lincoln and Theodore Roosevelt. CyArk, which hopes to create 500 models of famous locations and monuments around the world, said that other sites could be at risk, including the Acropolis in Athens, which is threatened by acid rain, and Machu Picchu in Peru, which suffers from excessive tourism. The scan of Mount Rushmore is expected to be completed in October.

Dianne Wiest will set aside the therapist’s chair for a trip to feudal Russia when she stars in a coming production of Alexander Ostrovsky’s “The Forest” for the Classic Stage Company, the theater company said Monday in a news release. Ms. Wiest, a star of the HBO series “In Treatment,” is the first cast member to be announced for the Ostrovsky play, a romantic comedy about an imperious widow, her ward and two vagabond actors posing as wealthy nobles. The production, adapted by Kathleen Tolan, will run at Classic Stage Company from April 14 through May 23. The theater group said that its coming season would begin on Nov. 4 with “The Age of Iron,” a hybrid of Shakespeare’s “Troilus and Cressida” and Thomas Heywood’s “Iron Age” adapted and directed by Brian Kulick, which runs through Dec. 13. It will also feature a new play, “Venus in Fur,” by David Ives, adapted from the erotic novel “Venus in Furs,” and directed by Walter Bobbie. Mandy Patinkin, who last season starred in the theater company’s production of “The Tempest,” will be featured in an open rehearsal series on “Much Ado About Nothing” that will begin in January.

The Port Authority has finally completed the excavation at ground zero for three office towers, after 14 months of delays and $130 million in penalties.The authority officially turned over the last of the three sites Monday to the developer Larry A. Silverstein, saying that Mr. Silverstein now had until 2014 to build the towers.

The chief suspect in the hit-and-run death of a Seton Hall parent was indicted Friday on 13 criminal counts including first degree aggravated manslaughter and second degree vehicular homicide. The man, Frank Bradley, 30, of Newark, is accused of striking James Walsh, of South Plainfield, with his car at South Orange and Vose avenues on Feb. 9, at around 8:15 p.m., then fleeing the scene. Mr. Walsh died shortly after the accident. Witnesses told the police they saw a black Honda Civic driving away. The police said the same vehicle was involved in a previous motor vehicle offense in Orange, and that a severely damaged car was found outside of Mr. Bradley's Newark home soon after the accident. Officials said there were three children in the car with the driver at the time of the hit-and-run. Mr. Bradley is being held in the Essex County jail on $150,000 bail. If convicted, could face up to 30 years in prison. -- Alex Flanders

In 2006, health care expenses among half the United States population totaled less than $800 per individual, according to the federal Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality. But the expenditures were not uniformly distributed throughout the overall population. Spending was far higher among the elderly, the obese and people who identified themselves as unhealthy. Median spending in those groups totaled $2,300 per individual. Although these patients represent just one-third of the population, they accounted for almost 60 percent of health care spending.

"As a kid, when I came home from staying at a friend's house, my mother would make me write a 'bread and butter letter,' " says Deb Wood, the design director at Princeton Architectural Press. PARIS | Popular myth suggests that through the medieval era personal hygiene was far from a priority. But an exhibition at the Musée du Moyen Âge (6, place Paul-Painlevé; 33-1-53-73-78-00; www.musee-moyenage.fr) testifies to the era's surprisingly involved beauty and grooming culture. From ancient hair dying techniques to fourth-century ear picks (the predecessor of the Q-tip), "The Bath and the Mirror: Body Care and Cosmetics from Antiquity to the Middle Ages" showcases the tools of vain medieval maidens.

What: WAH Nails, East London's first hipster nail bar, also serves as the headquarters of WAH Magazine, an online 'zine that could be Nylon's chicer, more urban little sister.Who: Sharmadean Reid, the 25-year-old proprietor, is the sportswear editor of Arena Homme Plus - and arguably one of the coolest girls in town.Where: 420 Kingsland Road; London E8 4AA; (011) 44 20 7812 9889. Lined with Vietnamese nail salons, chicken joints and wig shops, the edgy streets of Dalston are the fashion world's latest stomping ground. Young designers like Christopher Kane and Gareth Pugh keep studios here, and there are countless trendy bars and clubs. Despite the press hype, street crime and the lack of a convenient tube station help keep away the hordes.Why Bother: The salon's handiwork is sure to be a fixture at London Fashion Week's off-schedule shows. (Bonus: Pre-nightfall, Dalston is the best place to experience London's particular hybrid of high fashion and new-wave street style.)When: WAH is open from noon to 8 p.m., Monday through Saturday.Who Goes There: Early '90s hip-hop revivalists, "Work It" DJs and "Cassette Playa" designer Carri Mundane are already fans.What Kind of Nails Do They Get? The most popular finishes are Leopard, Candy and Chanel's double-C logo.How Much: Nail art from £8; extensions from £30.

I spent some time in the Boundary Waters area of Minnesota last month, and when I got back, to the usual "How was vacation?" questions, it was not the Unspoiled Natural Beauty or the time on the teensy beaches or the food or the family that dominated conversation, but: the bugs. Bugs! I'd been warned they existed - ticks, mosquitoes, black flies. I arrived packing an arsenal of Off. I expected to be bitten. But no one told me about the bugs my niece now calls "vampire gnats" (also no-see-'ems, or sand flies, or evil nibbling nasties) - things that you can't feel biting, but which draw blood (yes, usually around the neck), so that you'll be in the middle of a conversation and all seems fine, tra-la, tra-la, until your conversee starts pointing and goes, "Um, is that blood on your face?" Also: No one really warned me about the Midwest's particular brand of mosquito. If only I'd heard before I left that it was known as the State Bird of Minnesota, I might have chosen to vacation elsewhere. Like, the South Pole.

When Hideki Aoyama, the director of the Aoyama Meguro gallery in Tokyo, decided to join the citywide Architecture Japan 2009 exhibition going on this month, he wanted to do something different than presenting the standard miniature model. And he didn't have to look far for ideas: his gallery shares a building with the progressive Schemata Architecture firm. So Aoyama and Schemata's Jo Nagasaka teamed up to create a full-scale walk-in, sleep-in architecture exhibit, the Happa Hotel. "We chose a hotel instead of, say, a living room, because hotels represent a space where a great number of people come in contact with architecture," Aoyama said.The two single rooms are arranged vertically, with treehouse-style platforms forming the tables, chairs and nightstands. The whole construction (except for the hammock that serves as a bed) is made of the Styrofoam used in architecture models, reinforced with wood and metal screws. (This is earthquake territory, after all). At night the steel shutters go down, sealing off hotel guests behind the front windows of the gallery in a space four meters tall and only 55 centimeters deep. The brave individuals who sign up to be living displays are afforded some token privacy - a small curtain and a key to the front door that also opens the bathroom - not to mention a cool location in Nakameguro and what is probably the lowest room rate in Tokyo: 3,000 yen (about $32).

KARPATKIN--Simon, died on August 21, 2009. He was 75 years old. Dearly loved husband of Margaret, cared for deeply by his children David and Judy, and son-in-law Larry Katzman. Dr. Karpatkin was a Professor of Medicine and Director of the Division of Hematology at NYU Medical School. He was an internationally known scientific investigator and author of numerous scholarly publications based on his extensive hematological research. He was an avid sailor and an enthusiastic skier. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street, New York, on August 25, 2009 at 10am. The family will receive at their home on Wednesday, August 26, 2009, 12pm-9pm. Donations in his memory can be made to the ACLU/Marvin M. Karpatkin Fellowship, 125 Broad Street, 18th floor, New York, NY 10004.

DRAKOS--William J.,of North Stonington, Connecticut passed away peacefully with his family around him on August 21st, 2009. He was born in Hartford, on September 15, 1921 and was the son of the late James and Anthe (Kastrinos) Drakos. Bill attended Yale University in the V-12 Officer's Training Program and served in the United States Marine Corps in Okinawa during World War II. After the war, he returned to Yale where he graduated in 1947. He entered the shipping business in New York as a young man and went on to become a successful ship broker, founding his own firm, Tricontinental Shipping Corp., in 1960. Over the years, he invested wisely and became a well respected and skilled ship owner. Bill was a member of the Board of Trustees of the Mystic Aquarium, Anatolia College in Thessalonika, Greece and served on various Unicef Committees. He was also a longtime member of the Watch Hill Yacht Club. Bill leaves behind his wife, Teeny of 62 years; three sons and their wives, all of Connecticut, James and Karen Drakos of Greenwich, Andrew and Debra Drakos of Mystic, and Peter and Shonah Drakos of New Canaan; and eight grandchildren. He was predeceased by his sister, Effie Drakos Reilly. Bill will always be remembered for his integrity, warmth, and courage. He was loved by his family and friends and will be greatly missed. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, August 26, 2009 at 11am at Calvary Church 27 Church St. Stonington. Burial will follow at Stonington Cemetery with full military honors. The family will receive friends Tuesday from 5-9pm at the Mystic Funeral Home Route 1 Mystic (51 Williams Ave.) In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Mystic Marine Aquarium www.mysticaquarium.org. The Drakos family invites you to visit www.mysticfuneralhome.com to share an online message of condolence and directions to the funeral home.

The soundtrack to ''Taking Woodstock'' will be released Tuesday. The film, starring Eugene Levy, above left, and Demetri Martin, tells the story behind the festival. As a companion album to the film, the soundtrack features songs by many artists who performed at Woodstock and others from the era. It is not a concert recording. The best-selling soundtrack is for ''The Bodyguard,'' which sold 11.8 million albums for a movie that took in $122 million in domestic ticket sales, followed by 10.1 million in album sales for ''Titanic,'' the reigning box office giant ($601 million). SHELLY FREIERMAN

KRAUSE--Ira H.,of Great Neck, NY passed away at home on August 21, 2009. A devoted husband and father, he is survived by his loving wife Suzanne, beloved son Andrew, and cherished daughter-in-law Erica Helms. Born May 29, 1944 in the Bronx, Ira graduated from Queens College and was a Volunteer in Service to America for two years in Pittsburgh and Brooklyn. He continued his public service career working for the Model Cities program and the U.S. Commission on Civil Rights. Ira then shifted his professional focus to the private sector and began working as a management consultant, often with family businesses. He founded Weston Partners and the Business Growth Network, which specialized in helping to build relationships among diverse professional groups. Ira was pre-deceased by his adored sister Barbara, and is also survived by his brothers-in-law Harold Leitenberg, Frank and Daniel Sausedo, sister-in-law Elyse Sausedo, and eight nieces and nephews. His optimism, compassion and charisma will be sorely missed by his many close friends and colleagues. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. Donations in his memory can be made to the Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation or the Chronic Disease Fund.

England regained cricket's most storied trophy, the Ashes, as it beat Australia by 197 runs at The Oval in London to clinch the five-match series by 2-1 with 2 drawn. The victory was accomplished amid tumultuous scenes on the same ground on which England regained the Ashes in 1926, 1953, 1985 and 2005. The trophy changed hands for the third series running, the first such sequence since 1934.

NATHANSON--Andrew J. He died August 21 from a surfing accident at the age of 51. He is survived by his loving mother Sally, his adored wife Elyse and beloved children Brian, Alison, and Kevin; his brother Larry and sister-in-law Larraine. He was a graduate of Cornell University and received a MBA from The Wharton School. He went on to become an accomplished, highly successful managing director at Drexel Burnham Lambert and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, where he was on the Investment Banking Executive Committee and held other senior positions. He was a Managing Partner of Oak Hill Capital Partners and a director of several Companies including Duane Reade, Inc. His greatest pleasure was spending time with his family. He loved watching and participating in his children's activities. He loved all outdoor and athletic activities including football, skiing, scuba diving and golf. He was adventurous and loved to travel and explore new places. He was a philanthropist and donated to a number of causes and foundations, including The Robert Cullen Fund at Cornell University. Memorial services will be held August 24 at 11am at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester 2125 Westchester Avenue East Rye, NY.

BENDHEIM--Robert, former president and chairman of M. Lowenstein Corporation, died on Friday, August 21st in Greenwich, CT. He was 93. Mr. Bendheim lived in Greenwich, and had a home in Lyford Cay, Nassau. The Lowenstein Company was a major textile firm, which manufactured apparel and industrial fabrics, and Wamsutta and Pacific home furnishings. Mr. Bendheim started with the company as a trainee in 1946, and served as its chief executive officer from 1972 until 1985, when the company sold to Springs Industries. During this same period, Mr. Bendheim was also an officer and director of the Leon Lowenstein Foundation, Inc., serving as its president since 1976. The Foundation bears the name of Mr. Bendheim's uncle, Leon Lowenstein, who started the Foundation in 1941. The Foundation's principal grants are for medical research and education. Over the years, large grants have been given to Mt. Sinai, Columbia Presbyterian, and Sloan Kettering medical centers, and in education, to Princeton and Fordham universities, the Wharton School of Economics, and programs for improvement of the New York City public schools. Mr. Bendheim graduated from Princeton University in 1937 and attended the Harvard Business School. He served in the United States Navy as a lieutenant from 1942 to 1946, and he received an honorary degree of Doctor of Humane Letters from Fordham University in 1966. He was on the Board of Trustees of Mt. Sinai Hospital, the Boards of Fordham University, and United Way of New York, and served on various committees of Princeton University. His clubs included the Round Hill and Stanwich in Greenwich, Lyford Cay in Nassau, the Princeton Club and the River Club in New York City. He is survived by his beloved wife, Jane, his two daughters by a previous marriage, Lynn Bendheim Thoman and Kim Bendheim, his step-daughter, Josephine Poole, his brother, John M. Bendheim of Scarsdale, New York, and four grandchildren. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st Street on Thursday, August 27th, at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Bendheim Finance Center at Princeton University, or Princeton University, Princeton, New Jersey 08544.
Can the foods you eat influence your level of arthritis pain? That’s the question tackled today by Anahad O’Connor in his Really? column.

In a medical advance inspired by recessionary thinking, researchers from the Nicholas Institute of Sports Medicine and Athletic Trauma at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York City announced last month that they’ve developed an effective and supremely cheap treatment for chronic tennis elbow. Huddling a while back to brainstorm about inexpensive methods for combating the injury, the scientists glanced around their offices and noticed a homely, low-tech rubber bar, about 8 inches long, which, at the time, was being used for general physical therapy programs. The researchers wondered whether the ribbed, pliable bars, available for less than $20, might be re-purposed to treat tennis elbow. The answer, it soon become clear, was a resounding yes.

Last year, The New York Times ran a lengthy and troubling series of stories about the consequences of concussions in young athletes. Today, Jane Brody reviews the advice and warnings about high school sports and concussions, urging parents and coaches to take a proactive stance.

Well before its opening on Broadway, the revival of “West Side Story” now playing at the Palace Theater had been touted for the fact that some songs and dialog performed by its Puerto Rican characters would be delivered in Spanish. But on Tuesday, publicists for the musical said that some of these sections have been changed back to English, as they were originally performed on stage and in the well-known “West Side Story” film.

If Anna Wintour‘s appearance Monday on CBS’s “Late Show” wasn’t the “Frost/Nixon”-style showdown some were hoping for, it did succeed at making the Vogue editor seem approachable and down-to-earth, at least in the presence of David Letterman.

What we’re reading on Tuesday morning.Christie’s Goes Red Hook: In the Metro section of Tuesday’s New York Times, Diane Cardwell reports from Red Hook, Brooklyn, on the arrival of Christie’s, where the auction house is in the process of renovating a high-tech warehouse that will store manuscripts, furniture, rare cars and of course art — collections of work by van Gogh, Monet, Picasso and Brancusi that could each be worth more than the building itself.Polishing the Brass on ‘Avatar’: In The Hollywood Reporter, Gregg Kilday rounds up the mixed reactions that have greeted the trailer for James Cameron’s costly science-fiction feature “Avatar,” and compares them to the withering criticism that the director received in advance of the opening of “Titanic.” (He writes: “Assessing the movie’s commercial prospects, Entertainment Weekly sniffed, ‘No A-list boxoffice stars.'”)Hitler and Art: Der Spiegel has an English-language interview with Birgit Schwarz, the art historian and author of “Delusions of Genius: Hitler and Art,” who says that Hitler not only considered himself an artistic genius — “a strong personality who outshone everything else” and “could do anything he pleased” — but possessed a genuine lifelong interest in art. “Art was part of his life until his last hours,” Ms. Schwarz says, “even playing a role in his private will, in which he mentions his collections.”Dissertations as Poetry: The Book Bench blog of The New Yorker introduces us to Dissertation Haiku, a Web site where graduate students are asked to summarize their thesis papers as haiku poetry. An ecology student at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, reduces her dissertation to the following poem:

Siemens AG, the German engineering firm that sponsors the Bayreuth and Salzburg festivals, said that its support of both events would continue despite the economic hardships that the company has faced, Bloomberg News reported. Among the events that Siemens financed at this year’s Bayreuth festival were a public screening of “Tristan und Isolde” and an Internet opera-on-demand broadcast. The company also funds an international promotional campaign for the annual Wagner celebration. In July Siemens reported a decline of 28 percent in its third-quarter orders, and last year it cut 17,000 jobs and placed 15,000 workers on reduced hours. Even so, the company told Bloomberg that it would maintain a $72 million budget for aid, education and arts patronage, and provide sponsorship for the Salzburg festival “in the lower six-digit euro range.” “Bayreuth takes place practically in our own backyard,” Stephan Heimbach, the head of corporate communications and government affairs at Siemens told Bloomberg. “We’re helping bring this world-class cultural event close to a wider global audience.

Trouble seems to follow the mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato wherever she goes. A month after she fractured her fibula at the Royal Opera House in London during a production of Rossini’s “Barbiere di Siviglia” (and finished it on crutches), her performance Saturday at the Edinburgh International Festival was interrupted when the newly reopened Usher Hall was plunged into darkness for about half an hour, The Scotsman reported. The general manager for the concert hall, which recently completed a $41 million renovation, went on stage to explain that a blown fuse was to blame, and Sir Roger Norrington, the conductor of the Orchestra of the Age of the Enlightenment joked with the audience until the lights were restored. When the concert resumed, Ms. DiDonato was given a standing ovation and a broken lighting board was later replaced.

The economic recovery continues: Instead of taking a few weeks to appreciate her unemployment, sleep in late and catch up on her daytime television while eating breakfast cereal in her pajamas, Paula Abdul will resume collecting a paycheck as the host of next month’s “VH1 Divas” concert. After announcing via her Twitter feed that she was stepping down as a judge on Fox’s “American Idol,” Ms. Abdul once again preempted her employer, posting a note on the online social network on Monday night that said she was “really excited 2 announce ill b hosting” the concert, which takes place on Sept. 17. On Tuesday, VH1 confirmed Ms. Abdul’s announcement in a news release. The concert, which will feature performances by Adele, Kelly Clarkson, Leona Lewis, Miley Cyrus and Jordin Sparks, will be broadcast live from BAM’s Howard Gilman Opera House in Brooklyn.

The next time you get lost on a drive through unfamiliar terrain, blame Bob Dylan. The singer-songwriter said on a recent broadcast of his radio show that he may lend his distinctively gravelly voice to a satellite navigation system for cars, Agence France-Presse reported. In the latest edition of his “Theme Time Radio Hour” program, Mr. Dylan said, “I’m talking to a couple of car companies about being the voice of their GPS system,” according to Agence France-Presse. He joked that his instructions might not be the most reliable: “Left at the next street. No, right. You know what? Just go straight,” he said. “I probably shouldn’t do it because whichever way I go, I always end up at one place — on Lonely Avenue,” he said, adding: “Luckily I’m not totally alone. Ray Charles beat me there.”

As expected, Sony Electronics unveiled a wireless touch-screen electronic reading device on Tuesday, dubbed the Daily Edition, which it plans to sell starting in December in time for the holiday season.

The Apollo Theater, which after Michael Jackson‘s death became a de facto mourning place and gathering site for the singer’s fans, will induct Mr. Jackson into its Apollo Legends Hall of Fame, the theater said Tuesday in a news release. The Harlem nonprofit theater said that Mr. Jackson’s posthumous induction would take place at a gala next year. Mr. Jackson will also receive a spot on the Apollo’s Walk of Fame, which is scheduled to be constructed in the fall, and in the spring, he will be given a memorial plaque at the theater alongside fellow inductees like James Brown and Ella Fitzgerald. The Apollo also said that its archives would take possession of a 100-foot long blue plywood wall outside the theater that was used as a memorial by Mr. Jackson’s fans after his death in June, and which was donated to the theater by the owners of an adjacent property. Mr. Jackson began performing at the Apollo in the late 1960s as a member of the Jackson 5, which won the theater’s amateur night competition.

A judge sentenced the R&B singer Chris Brown on Tuesday to five years of probation and six months of community labor for his assault on the pop star Rihanna, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Brown will be allowed to serve his sentence in his home state of Virginia but will have to make return trips to Los Angeles to update a judge on his progress.

A lawsuit filed against the design company of Frank Gehry involving a dispute over the right to use the architect’s illustrations on jewelry was dismissed Monday in Los Angeles. Circa Publishing Enterprises, a company based in Culver City, Calif., filed suit against Gehry Design in 2007 after Mr. Gehry struck a deal with Tiffany & Co., allowing that company to create jewelry based on his fish shapes and other designs. Circa Publishing said in its suit that it already had an exclusive deal with Mr. Gehry to create and sell jewelry and gift items featuring his trademarks. But lawyers for Mr. Gehry said that the agreement with Circa Publishing was terminated when the architect entered into his deal with Tiffany. Judge Jane Johnson of Los Angeles County Superior Court granted a motion to dismiss the case on Monday after both sides gave testimony but before closing arguments had been made.

In the heat of midday Cambodia on Dec. 31, 1999, I was standing among the tree-eaten ruins of Ta Prohm, one of the many temples that make up the ancient Khmer city of Angkor. I had come a long way from New York to meet a group of friends and celebrate the millennium at the temples, where 10,000 monks would be chanting that night by candle light. But all of a sudden, I felt woozy and had to sit down. Soon, I knew, I wouldn't be celebrating. I asked a friend to take me back to our hotel room, where I lay under the covers, shivering and sweating for the next 24 hours, missing out on all the fun. I had the flu.

Recently back in New York from Los Angeles and cruising Chelsea, I found this year's summer group shows to lack the dynamic curatorial freshness they had gained in recent years. Nonetheless, two in particular stood out.At Andrea Rosen, the artist Rita Ackermann and Rosen put together a satisfyingly organic grouping, mostly by women, of work that, for want of a more formalized phrase, hangs on some idea of chicks and smoking. The stunner of the bunch is a delicately scarred burn drawing by Aurel Schmidt. In contrast to the almost bodily materiality of the Rosen show, Kate Levant's exhibition at Zach Feuer is a cerebral musing on perception. Levant's minimal assemblages of quotidian materials reminded me somewhat of Gedi Sibony, where the seemingly banal gesture or material suddenly takes on a near-breathless effect by virtue of its utter precision of placement.

The former chairman of the North Shore Music Theater, the Beverly, Mass., institution that was once the region's largest nonprofit theater, said that its property and assets would be sold at a coming foreclosure auction, The Salem News reported. The theater, which opened in 1955, announced in June that it was unable to raise enough money to finance its summer season and was shutting down, facing debts of about $10 million. David Fellows, the theater's former chairman, told The Salem News that its board of trustees had turned the property and assets over to Citizens Bank, including three buildings - a theater-in-the-round, a restaurant and an education building - as well as costumes, lighting and sound equipment. Mr. Fellows said that the bank is in the process of foreclosing on the theater's two mortgages, which total about $5.2 million, and that the theater owes another $5 million to subscribers and vendors that will be repaid if the auction raises enough money. He said that four groups with theater backgrounds had expressed interest in buying the property and continuing to operate it as an arts center, but declined to name the groups.

Bradley Ruderman, founder and manager of two Beverly Hills hedge funds, pleaded guilty Monday to two counts of wire fraud, two counts of investment adviser fraud and a misdemeanor count of failing to file income taxes in 2007.

The Securities and Exchange Commission and Bank of America on Monday defended the fairness of their proposed $33 million settlement over executive bonuses paid out by Merrill Lynch, and the bank maintained it didn't mislead investors in the affair, The Associated Press reported.
A judge presiding over Tribune Co.'s bankruptcy case has agreed to expedited procedures regarding the company's sale of the Chicago Cubs baseball team, The Associated Press reported.

Investment banks that manage funds of hedge funds were among the hardest hit as investors withdrew an estimated $200 billion from these pools between September 2008 and June 2009, data from The Hedge Fund Journal and Newedge Prime Brokerage show.
Daewoo International is expected to set up an Australian unit in order to acquire a 5 percent stake in a coal mine there, the South Korean news service Yonhap reported.

Times Ltd., the Chinese supermarket chain, has been put on the block with its majority shareholder inviting bidders to make offers, The Wall Street Journal reported. Citing people familiar with the situation, the newspaper said the targeted sale price would be above $560 million.
In Australia, UBS has moved quickly to replace its real estate investment team by picking up Tim Church and seven colleagues from JPMorgan.

Smith & Tinker has raised $29 million in funding, according to a report in The Wall Street Journal. The start-up toy maker, run by veterans of the toy and video game industries, intends to court children by bridging the online and offline worlds.

Citadel Investment Group is seeking to recover as much as $470.5 million that it believes it is owed from contracts tied to Lehman Brothers, according to a court filing, The Wall Street Journal reported.
New tax rules soon to be implemented in Britain have sent hedge-fund managers and other financial-services professionals on a mass exodus, The Wall Street Journal reported.

Centrica has prevailed in its £1.3 billion ($2.1 bilion) hostile takeover bid for a North Sea gas producer, Venture Production, The Daily Telegraph reported. Centrica won the bid despite strong opposition from Venture's management.
Federal prosecutors have charged a woman who once advised Michael Vick and several other football players with stealing $3 million from eight victims in a Ponzi scheme.
The finger-pointing in Merrill Lynch's bonus troubles shifted to a new target on Monday in two courts that essentially said: blame the lawyers, The New York Times's Louise Story reported.
Tibco Software has bought DataSynapse, a cloud computing software company whose investors include Goldman Sachs, in a $28 million deal.

Now that the intense financial pressure on General Motors has eased, the automaker has the luxury of time to consider new alternatives for selling its Opel unit, Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley wrote in The New York Times.

Earl Scioneaux III is not a famous music producer like Quincy Jones. He is a simple audio engineer in New Orleans who mixes live albums of local jazz musicians by day and creates electronic music by night. He had long wanted to pursue his dream of making his own album that married jazz and electronica, but he had no easy way to raise the $4,000 he needed for production, The New York Times's Jenna Wortham wrote.
Vitacost.com has filed for an initial public offering that aims to raise about $48.5 million based on a share price of $12, The Associated Press reported.

My friend and onetime colleague at Domino, Tom Delavan, has just renovated his studio apartment. As you might expect (or know), he has the most incredible taste, particularly when it comes to creating kitchens out of thin air and choosing the right shade of gray, a peculiarly difficult thing to get right.

Complete Genomics has raised $45 million in its fourth round of venture funding, The San Francisco Business Times said. The human genome sequencing business welcomed two new investors to the round:Essex Woodlands Health Ventures and OrbiMed Advisors.
