Fortis Healthcare agreed Monday to buy 10 hospitals in India for 9.09 billion rupees ($187 million), The Wall Street Journal reported. The move was part of an overall design to foster rapid expansion of Fortis's private hospital chain.

JPMorgan stopped doing big leveraged buyouts on its own five years ago, after its takeover of Warner Chilcott, a pharmaceutical company, annoyed big clients like TPG, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the Blackstone Group, Breakingviews.com writes.
BancTec said Monday it is planning an initial public offering of up to $50 million in common stock, The Associated Press reported.

Only a mind reader could say Rex Ryan saw enough from Mark Sanchez against the Ravens to name him the starting quarterback. So let's try making two cases: One, that Ryan should name him the starter now and 2) that Ryan should wait until after Saturday's game against the Giants to make his decision.

This is the first in what will be a regular series of moderated forums on "At War" by Timothy Hsia, a U.S. Army active duty infantry captain. Captain Hsia will pick topics on the military, including strategy, combat and the stress families face during long and regular deployments, and ask soldiers, their families and anyone else to submit comments. We hope to provoke a lively - and civil - debate.

An article on Sunday about the arts impresario Serge Diaghilev misspelled, in some copies, part of the name of the company he founded in 1909. It is the Ballets Russes, not the Ballet Russes. The error also appeared in an accompanying picture caption and in a capsule summary referring to additional images on nytimes.com of “Diaghilev’s Theater of Marvels: the Ballets Russes and Its Aftermath.”.

Major League Soccer officials said they would not make a bid to absorb the United Soccer Leagues or add it as part of a promotion-relegation setup.

An article on Monday about the Warner Brothers Television Group misstated the financial performance of Warner Brothers. The studio’s annual revenue — not its profit — is $10 billion.

A picture caption on Friday with an article about a local development corporation that lobbied on behalf of New York City’s plan to revitalize the area around the new Mets stadium misidentified the man shown in his waste transfer business. He is David Antonacci, a member of Willets Point United, a business owners’ group trying to stop the plan. He is not Gerald Antonacci, David’s brother and the president of Willets Point, who is quoted in the article. (The brothers run Crown Container, one of the area’s more than 250 companies that will be required to move when construction begins.).

An article on Sunday about a last-minute rush to take advantage of the government’s cash for clunkers program misidentified the car being traded in by Chris Bonk, a talent agent. It was a Chevrolet Blazer, not a Ford Bronco.

An article on Wednesday about a deadly accident at a hydroelectric plant in Siberia misstated the given name of the acting chief executive of the company that owns the plant, who said most of the workers trapped inside probably had drowned. He is Vasily Zubakin, not Vitaly.

An article on Aug. 15 about efforts by the breakaway Georgian republic of South Ossetia to disarm its residents referred incorrectly to the bullet-cartridge diameter used to identify a World War II-era Soviet machine gun owned by a woman who reminisced about her purchase of the weapon. It is 12.7 millimeters; there is no 12.7-caliber.

A chart with the continuation of an article on Sunday about the weed killer atrazine in drinking water, showing where large numbers of people are exposed to the herbicide, labeled Arizona and Minnesota incorrectly in some editions. A corrected chart is at nytimes.com/business.

Dianne Wiest will set aside the therapist’s chair for a trip to feudal Russia when she stars in a production of Alexander Ostrovsky’s play “The Forest” for the Classic Stage Company, the theater company said Monday. Ms. Wiest, right, a star of the HBO series “In Treatment,” is the first cast member to be announced for the Ostrovsky play, a romantic comedy about an imperious widow, her ward and two vagabond actors posing as wealthy nobles. The production, adapted by Kathleen Tolan, will run at Classic Stage Company from April 14 through May 23. The theater group announced that its coming season would begin on Nov. 4 with “The Age of Iron,” a hybrid of Shakespeare’s “Troilus and Cressida” and Thomas Heywood’s “Iron Age” adapted and directed by Brian Kulick, which runs through Dec. 13. It will also feature a new play, “Venus in Fur,” by David Ives, adapted from the erotic novel “Venus in Furs,” and directed by Mr. Bobbie. Mandy Patinkin, who last season starred in the company’s production of “The Tempest,” will take part in a series of open rehearsals for “Much Ado About Nothing” to begin in January.

Comedy Central’s hit late-night show “The Colbert Report” announced Monday that the executive most closely associated with the show, Allison Silverman, was leaving her position as executive producer, effective immediately. No official reason was given for Ms. Silverman’s departure, nor was a replacement named. A Comedy Central spokeswoman said that with the series on hiatus for three weeks, no one was available to comment. But one executive from the cable channel said Ms. Silverman herself had initiated the change because she was seeking a respite from the exhausting demands of the job. In an official statement, the show’s Stephen Colbert said, “I am happy for my dear friend, but I will miss her.” In her official comment, Ms. Silverman said, “For me, the only thing that could top working with Stephen Colbert would be having Stephen Colbert as a lifelong friend, and I am very excited to start that project.” Ms. Silverman has been with the show since it began in October 2005, originally as co-head writer. She became executive producer in 2007.

The rapid resurrection of Vibe magazine continues: on Monday the new owners of the revived hip-hop and R&B magazine said they had chosen Jermaine Hall as editor in chief of Vibe and its Web site, vibe.com. Mr. Hall has previously served as the editor in chief of King magazine, a monthly title geared to African-American men that ceased publication earlier this year. He was also music editor at the rap magazine The Source and the webmaster at Vibe. In a telephone interview, Brett Wright, co-chief executive of the Vibe Lifestyle Network, said that vibe.com would provide coverage of urban music and entertainment on a “regular, daily, hourly, by-minute basis” while the print magazine would focus on investigative reporting and long-form stories. The first issue of the new quarterly Vibe magazine is planned for a November release. The long-running publication shut down in June when its previous owners said they could not find new buyers or restructure the company’s debt. It was bought this month by InterMedia Partners, a private equity fund.

Feel free to shed a quiet tear from either of your unevenly placed, asymmetrical eyes: the Picasso Museum in Paris closed its doors on Sunday and will not reopen them to visitors for more than two years as it undergoes an extensive renovation, The Associated Press reported. The 32,000-square-foot museum, above, which opened in 1985 in the Marais district of Paris, holds about 5,000 pieces of art by Picasso, including paintings, sculptures and sketches, but was able to display only between 250 and 300 at a time. During the renovation, which is expected to cost about $28 million and begin next year, the museum will be expanded and made more accessible; the electrical system will also be upgraded. In the meantime, the museum will stop lending out its artworks as experts update its inventory, after which the works will be packaged and shipped to storerooms managed by France’s museum authority. The museum offered free admission to its visitors on Sunday.

The Christmas season starts earlier every year: on Monday it was announced that the musical “Irving Berlin’s White Christmas” would make its return to Broadway in November, publicists for the show said in a news release. The musical, adapted from the 1954 movie that starred Bing Crosby, Danny Kaye and Rosemary Clooney, will once again play at the Marquis Theater, where it will run from Nov. 13 through Jan. 3. As in the film, the stage show follows a pair of popular song-and-dance men who attempt to save a Vermont inn from closing while they also woo a pair of everlovin’ sisters. Structured around a score of Irving Berlin standards, the Broadway production is directed by Walter Bobbie, with a book by David Ives and Paul Blake, and choreography by Randy Skinner. Last season’s Broadway production starred Stephen Bogardus, Jeffry Denman, Kerry O’Malley and Meredith Patterson. Casting for the 2009 run has not yet been announced.

The New York Philharmonic isn’t the only arts organization planning a high-profile visit to Asia this fall. American Ballet Theater has announced that it will make its first trip to Beijing in November. Its six-performance engagement will be the first by an American ballet company at the new National Center for the Performing Arts, also known as the Egg. The Beijing run, to take place from Nov. 12 to Nov. 15, will include four performances of the full-length ballet “Don Quixote,” staged by Susan Jones and Kevin McKenzie, the company’s artistic director, and two repertory programs, including works by the company’s artist in residence, Alexei Ratmanksy, as well as dances by Aszure Barton and Benjamin Millepied. (At right, the company’s Misty Copeland and Carlos Lopez.) The company performed in Hong Kong and Shanghai in 2000.

Jane Friedman, the charismatic former chief executive of HarperCollins who abruptly departed the company nearly 15 months ago, has raised $3 million for a new company, OpenRoad Integrated Media, that is developing a platform for e-book publishing and marketing. According to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Ms. Friedman, above, who is chief executive of the new company, has joined with Jeff Sharp, an independent film producer who previously partnered with HarperCollins to develop some of the publisher’s books into movies, and Chris Lederer, a former consultant to HarperCollins. Both are listed as executive officers of the company, with Ms. Friedman as chief executive. Kohlberg Ventures has provided the financing and its chairman, James Kohlberg, is listed as a director. Ms. Friedman, through a publicist, declined to comment.

The finale of ABC’s two-week revival of “Who Wants to Be a Millionaire” eked out a victory as Sunday’s most-watched show. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 7.6 million viewers tuned in to the game show’s last episode. But CBS ranked No. 1 for the night over all, drawing nearly equal audiences for a “60 Minutes” tribute to the show’s creator Don Hewitt, who died on Wednesday, and the reality show “Big Brother.” ABC was second, and NBC finished third with its final two episodes of “Merlin,” followed by the Miss Universe Pageant (5.8 million). Fox was fourth over all with comedy repeats.

HILL--Christian Matthew Gerard, of Frelsburg, TX passed away peacefully in the early morning hours of August 18, 2009. A loving and giving father, attorney and patriot, he was forever faithful to his family, clients and his nation. He will be sorely missed. Holy Mother of God, do pray for his loving soul, for it is rare that the world comes to know such a selfless individual. JGH, Pray for Us.

KAPLAN--Stanley H. The staff of Kaplan, Inc. mourns the death of Stanley H. Kaplan, founder of our company and entrepreneur who created the test preparation industry. For nearly seven decades, Stanley was a champion of educational opportunity for all students. A passionate teacher and tireless leader, he was a true pioneer. As one of the earliest for-profit education providers, he paved the way for greater transparency in college admissions. He will be remembered fondly by his students and all who continue to benefit from his legacy. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his entire family. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions be made to The City College of New York c/o The Stanley H. Kaplan Institute for the Advancement of Mathematics Education in Middle Schools, the Jewish Theological Seminary c/o Paul A. Kaplan Clinical Pastoral Counseling Program and NYU Langone Medical Center, c/o Rita J. and Stanley H. Kaplan Stem Cell/Bone Marrow Transplant Center.

The Obama administration will continue the Bush administration's practice of sending terrorism suspects to third countries for detention and interrogation, but pledges to closely monitor their treatment to ensure that they are not tortured, administration officials said Monday. Human rights advocates condemned the decision, saying that continuing the practice, known as rendition, would still allow the transfer of prisoners to countries with a history of torture. They said that promises from other countries of humane treatment, called ''diplomatic assurances,'' were no protection against abuse.

BARBIERI--Theresa M. (Terri), of Greenwich Village, on August 23rd after a long illness. Terri was a gifted writer who began her career by contributing articles to the Brooklyn Eagle while still in high school. A graduate of Long Island University with a degree in English and Journalism, Terri worked as an editor until assuming the position of General Manager of Stagebill, the national publication for the performing arts. Terri was an adventurer, world traveler and passionate Yankee fan. She was devoted to her family and friends, and is survived by her loving brother Joseph P. Barbieri and sister Adelaide B. Iacono, as well as five nieces and nephews, six grandnieces and -nephews, and many dear friends here and abroad. Reposing at Perazzo Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St. Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday at 10:30am at St. Josephs, 371 6th Ave. at Washington Pl. Donations may be made to the Calvary Fund, 1740 Eastchester Rd., Bronx, NY 10461.

GELLIS--Minnie (Mussie), died at age 99 on August 21, 2009. Born June 27, 1910, she was a participant of many great events of the city of New York. She was the wife of her late husband, prominent businessman Abe Gellis, owner of the multigenerational Isaac Gellis Food Products Inc., which is now owned by Conagra Foods Inc. She was active in many charities, was an accomplished artist, dedicated matriarch of the family, loving, generous and kind to all who knew her. She was an extensive traveler but above all she was a proud New Yorker all her life. She was the mother of Lynda Guber, (Peter), Henry, and the late Samuel. She also leaves behind her granddaughters - Jodi Guber, Elizabeth Guber-Sugarman, Sammantha Harris, Jackson Guber, Samuel Guber, and great-grandson - Augustus Sugarman. She will be in our hearts and memories forever. Private service for family and friends.

BENDHEIM--Robert, former president and chairman of M. Lowenstein Corporation, died on Friday, August 21st in Greenwich, CT. He was 93. Mr. Bendheim lived in Greenwich, and had a home in Lyford Cay, Nassau. The Lowenstein Company was a major textile firm, which manufactured apparel and industrial fabrics, and Wamsutta and Pacific home furnishings. Mr. Bendheim started with the company as a trainee in 1946, and served as its chief executive officer from 1972 until 1985, when the company sold to Springs Industries. During this same period, Mr. Bendheim was also an officer and director of the Leon Lowenstein Foundation, Inc., serving as its president since 1976. The Foundation bears the name of Mr. Bendheim's uncle, Leon Lowenstein, who started the Foundation in 1941. The Foundation's principal grants are for medical research and education. Over the years, large grants have been given to Mt. Sinai, Columbia Presbyterian, and Sloan Kettering medical centers, and in education, to Princeton and Fordham universities, the Wharton School of Economics, and programs for improvement of the New York City public schools. Mr. Bendheim graduated from Princeton University in 1937 and attended the Harvard Business School. He served in the United States Navy as a lieutenant from 1942 to 1946, and he received an honorary degree of Doctor of Humane Letters from Fordham University in 1966. He was on the Board of Trustees of Mt. Sinai Hospital, the Boards of Fordham University, and United Way of New York, and served on various committees of Princeton University. His clubs included the Round Hill and Stanwich in Greenwich, Lyford Cay in Nassau, the Princeton Club and the River Club in New York City. He is survived by his beloved wife, Jane, his two daughters by a previous marriage, Lynn Bendheim Thoman and Kim Bendheim, his step-daughter, Josephine Poole, his brother, John M. Bendheim of Scarsdale, New York, and four grandchildren. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st Street on Thursday, August 27th, at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Bendheim Finance Center at Princeton University, or Princeton University, Princeton, New Jersey 08544.

An article on Sunday about the arts impresario Serge Diaghilev misspelled, in some copies, part of the name of the company he founded in 1909. It is the Ballets Russes, not the Ballet Russes. The error also appeared in an accompanying picture caption and in a capsule summary referring to additional images on nytimes.com of ''Diaghilev's Theater of Marvels: the Ballets Russes and Its Aftermath.'' And a correction in this space on Saturday and on Page A3 on Sunday misstated the name of the institution that is displaying the exhibition. As the article correctly noted, it is the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts; there is no ''New York City Library.''

KAPLAN--Stanley H.,education pioneer and founder of the test-preparation industry, passed away peacefully in his home in Manhattan on Sunday, August 23, 2009. He was 90 years old. As a child, Stanley tutored classmates in math, a talent and passion that grew into the Stanley H. Kaplan Educational Center and eventually, Kaplan, Inc. His business success gave rise to philanthropic activity through the Rita J. & Stanley H. Kaplan Family Foundation. He leaves his legacy as an imprint upon the many institutions whose development he supported. In addition to being an innovative entrepreneur and generous philanthropist, he had an infectious sense of humor and was particularly fond of puns. A gifted debater, Stanley was adept at getting others to listen to differing points of view. A lover of science and math, he enjoyed watching bridges being built. He followed and had great interests in the achievements of his students. Above all, he took great pride in his children and grandchildren. He is survived by his loving wife of 60 years, Rita; daughters Susan and Nancy; son-in-law Mark; grandchildren Scott and his wife Erica, Julie and Gila; sister Rosalie Sporn; sister-in-law Beatrice Kaplan; and toy poodle Par Par. Funeral: Tuesday, August 25, 12pm at Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 E. 51st Street. Shiva: Tuesday - following the burial until 8pm. Wednesday and Thursday - 11am-2pm and 4pm-8pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: The City College of New York Attn: Rochelle Butler, Designated to: The Stanley H. Kaplan Institute for the Advancement of Mathematics, Education in Middle Schools, 160 Convent Avenue, S-154 New York, NY 10031. Jewish Theological Seminary Attn: Marion Beinstag, Designated to: Paul A. Kaplan Clinical Pastoral Counseling Program, 3080 Broadway, New York, NY 10027. NYU Langone Medical Center Attn: Colby Collier, Designated to: Rita J. and Stanley H. Kaplan Stem Cell/Bone Marrow Transplant Center, One Park Avenue, 17th Floor, New York, NY 10016.

KAPLAN--Stanley H. President Gregory H. Williams and the faculty, students, staff and alumni of The City College of New York are deeply saddened by the death of alumnus Stanley H. Kaplan, B.S. '39, magna cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa, M.S.E. '41. Mr. Kaplan was one of the College's most dedicated and generous alumni and a member of the President's Circle. He served on the Boards of the City College 21st Century Foundation, City College Fund and City College Alumni Association, which in 1986 bestowed upon him the Townsend Harris Medal, its highest honor. In 1988, City College awarded him the Doctor of Humane Letters degree, Honoris Causa, for his groundbreaking work in the field of education. A dedicated son of City College, in 2004 Mr. Kaplan created the Stanley H. Kaplan Institute for the Advancement of Mathematics Education in the Middle School at his alma mater. To date more than 200 mathematics assistant principals, coaches and teacher leaders have been trained directly by the program. More than 1,000 middle school math teachers have benefited from this program, in turn impacting mathematics instruction for more than 100,000 students. In 1991, he endowed the City College Fund's Stanley H. Kaplan Scholarship. Stanley Kaplan represented the best of the best of our City College graduates and went on to a distinguished career that touched students across the nation. His strong support made him invaluable to the renaissance at City College. Our deepest condolences to his: wife, Rita; daughters, Susan B. Kaplan and Susan Kaplan Belsky; son-in-law, Mark Belsky; grandchildren, and great-grandchildren.

In 2006, annual health spending in this country was less than $800 per individual for half the population. But spending varies widely, and the high-cost people include the elderly, the obese and people who identify themselves as unhealthy. Median spending for those groups was $2,300 in 2006, and 10 percent of such cases exceeded $15,000. Although those groups make up only about one-third of the United States population, as shown below they account for almost 60 percent of health care spending.

After Amy Farber learned she had the rare and fatal disease called LAM in 2005, she became determined to increase and speed up research into her illness with the hope of finding a cure in her lifetime. Dr. Farber, now 39, was a law student with a doctorate in anthropology who was about to start a family. She quit law school and founded the LAM Treatment Alliance to raise money and connect a network of scientists around the world to research this mysterious disease, which destroys young women's lungs.

Iraq's top Shiite political leaders gathered in a sweltering hotel ballroom here on Monday and announced a new alliance, a new name and a new platform. The story has the elements of a corporate thriller: a cast that includes former French spies and military men, a cycling champion, Greenpeace advocates and a dogged judge whose investigation takes him from a sports doping laboratory outside Paris to a Moroccan jail and some top French corporations. Like installments in a serial novel, revelations have been seeping out since March. And while the climax is months away, the story provides a glimpse into the shadowy business of gathering what corporations call strategic intelligence.

BAGHDAD -- Insurgents set off bombs on two buses traveling from Baghdad to the mainly Shiite city of Kut on Monday, killing at least 20 passengers. At least 10 other people were wounded, according to an Iraqi security official, who said the attackers had used bombs that adhere to the underside of a vehicle.

How good for hospitals was the deal they made with the Obama administration to support the effort at a health care overhaul? Fairly good, according to a run through the numbers by one hospital association. When the White House and hospital officials announced in July that the industry would agree to $155 billion in medical cost savings over 10 years, some experts wondered what the hospitals expected in return. Now a cost-benefit breakdown posted on the Web site of the Tennessee Hospital Association fills in more of the answer.

NAEVE--Milo Merle, 77, of Kennett Square, Pennsylvania, an American art and historian, curator, and museum director, died on August 10, 2009, after a recent diagnosis of carcinoma of the lung. The youngest of three sons of Bernhardt and Fern Naeve, he was born October 9, 1931, on a ranch near Arnold, Kansas. Mr. Naeve graduated from high school in Loveland, Colorado in 1949 and received his BFA from the University of Colorado in 1953. He was a member of Delta Phi Delta, Phi Epsilon Phi, Tau Delta and Pi Kappa Alpha fraternity. He was selected a member of the second class of Winterthur Fellows receiving a MFA in 1955 from the Winterthur Program in American Studies jointly sponsored by the University of Delaware and the Henry Francis duPont Winterthur Museum. Following two years of service in the U.S. Army Medical Corps, he held curatorial and administrative positions at Winterthur Museum for the next 10 years. As Secretary of the museum from 1959-1963, he catalogued and administered Mr. duPont's gifts of his collection to the museum. He was the founding editor of the Winterthur Portfolio and was responsible for the first three volumes. Mr. Naeve was Curator of Colonial Williamsburg and Director of the Colorado Springs Fine Arts Center before being recruited to be the first curator for the newly founded American Arts Department of the Art Institute of Chicago in 1975. He was responsible for American decorative arts from the 17th c. to the present and American painting and sculpture to 1901. In 1984, he was named the Field-McCormick Curator of American Arts. Funded by Marshall Field V, President of the Board of Trustees of the Art Institute of Chicago and Brooks McCormick, Chairman of the American Arts Committee, it was the first curatorial position endowed at the Art Institute. Mr. Naeve was responsible for the concept, planning, and installation of the acclaimed Field-McCormick Galleries of American Arts, which opened in 1988 in the Daniel and Ada Rice Building, an addition to the Art Institute. At the time of his retirement in 1991, Mr. Field noted "purchases and gifts during the past 17 years have more than doubled the departmental collections and masterpieces in furniture and painting of the 17th, 18th and 19th centuries have brought national stature to those collections and pre-eminence in surveys of silver, 20th c. decorative arts and 19th c. sculpture". His service was recognized by the honorary title of Field-McCormick Curator Emeritus of American Arts. He is cited as a thorough scholar, a fine judge of aesthetic quality in a work of art, a curator's curator. In 1991, Mr. Naeve received the first Life Time Achievement Award granted by the Illinois Academy of Fine Arts for his contributions to the Arts in Illinois. In 1996, he was the recipient of the Decorative Arts Society Robert C. Smith Award for the most influential article in the decorative arts for 1996. Subsequently, he has served as Chairman of the award selection committee. He was the author of The Classical Presence in American Art, published by the Art Institute of Chicago; John Lewis Krimmel: An Artist in Federal America, University of Delaware Press and three editions of Identifying American Furniture: Colonial to Contemporary. He was researching and writing the Landscape Garden in America. He wrote numerous articles and reviews. Especially commended among the essays and frequently reprinted is one about the rarely discussed subject of connoisseurship entitled, "The A, B, C, D's of Collecting". He lectured widely in the United States and England. Mr. Naeve served on the boards of The Library Company of Philadelphia, Skowhegan School of Painting and Sculpture, and the Sewell Biggs Museum of American Art. He was a member of the editorial board for The American Art Journal and an advisor for The Art and Architecture Thesaurus of the Getty Foundation. He was a member of the Grolier Club and the Century Association in New York and of their exhibition committees. His memberships included the American Association of Museums, Museums Association of Great Britain, The Royal Oak Foundation, The College Art Association, The Society of Architectural Historians and he was a Life Fellow of the Royal Society of Arts, England. Mr. Naeve was a communicant of Christ Church Christiana Hundred. He was a member of Greenville Country Club. Mr. Naeve is survived by his wife of 55 years, the former Nancy Jammer, whom he married July 18, 1954, at St. John's Episcopal Church, Boulder, Colorado. He is also survived by his former sister-in-law, three nieces and one nephew. He was predeceased by his parents and his two brothers, Clifford Lewis Naeve and Bartley Allen Naeve. To send an online condolence, please visit www.griecofuneralhomes.com

PLAYER Striker Carlos Véla, who plays for Arsenal in England, has an injured ankle and will miss Mexico's next two World Cup qualifiers -- at Costa Rica on Sept. 5 and against Honduras on Sept. 9. Véla played in Mexico's 2-1 victory against the United States on Aug. 12, but Arsenal Coach Arsène Wenger said: ''He came back injured. This is one of the problems with international football.'' Véla is expected to be sidelined for a month. Parker Posey may be a one-woman dynamo capable of several projects at once, but even she isn’t powerful enough to overcome Lyme disease. In a statement on Wednesday, Playwrights Horizons said that Ms. Posey, a star of films like “Best in Show” and “Waiting for Guffman,” had withdrawn from the company’s coming production of “This,” a new comedy planned for its 2009-10 season. The statement said that Ms. Posey would not be able to participate “due to developing a case of Lyme disease.” The comedy, written by Melissa James Gibson and directed by Daniel Aukin, focuses on a widow (to have been played by Ms. Posey) and her circle of friends. Playwrights Horizons said that it was still planning to begin previews of the show at its mainstage theater on Nov. 6 and open the production on Dec. 2, and that it would announce a replacement for Ms. Posey shortly.

Like the man (almost) sang: Everybody must get snow. Bob Dylan plans to release a collection of familiar yuletide tunes, to be called “Christmas in the Heart,” with proceeds of the album to benefit hunger-relief charities, the singer-songwriter announced on his Web site, bobdylan.com. Among the traditional songs that Mr. Dylan will perform on the album, which Columbia Records is to release on Oct. 13, are “Here Comes Santa Claus,” “Winter Wonderland,” “Little Drummer Boy” and “Must Be Santa.” A statement on the Web site said that all of Mr. Dylan’s royalties in the United States from the album would be donated to the charity Feeding America, and that he planned to donate his international royalties to organizations in Britain and elsewhere that provide meals during the holiday season. “Christmas in the Heart” is the 47th album by Mr. Dylan.

Amid a summer in which he has tangled with several notable architects and architectural institutions, the Prince of Wales is calling for new laws in Britain that would allow the public to have more input in new building developments, The Times of London reported. Hank Dittmar, the chief executive of Prince Charles’s architectural charity, the Prince’s Foundation, told The Times of London, “People feel very disenfranchised by the planning system.” Under the proposals, residents near new developments would be asked to decide what features and architecture styles would be used in master plans, instead of being consulted after plans have been designed. Scotland has already adopted a similar system after government officials met with the prince. In June Richard Rogers accused the prince of abusing his power after he intervened to have him removed as the designer of a housing project, and earlier this month, it was revealed that the prince had sought to remove Jean Nouvel as the designer of an office and shopping complex.

Winston Smith may have learned to love Big Brother but Britain has lost its affection for the long-running reality show of the same name. BBC News reported that the coming 11th season of “Big Brother,” in which contestants are filmed while they are confined to a house and vote to evict one another, would be its last. The series started on Britain’s Channel 4 in 2000 just days after an American version began on CBS as the reality television craze got under way. It also made a celebrity out of Jade Goody, a contestant who was accused of making racist remarks about a fellow housemate and who later made a public display of her decline and death from cancer. But ratings for the show have fallen off, to about 2 million viewers an episode from a peak of 8 million in 2002. The final British season of “Big Brother” will begin next summer.

As a cost-cutting measure, the Minnesota Orchestra has canceled coming concerts that were to have featured the conductors James Conlon and Robert Spano and the violinist Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg as the orchestra weathers the economic downturn, The Star Tribune reported. The orchestra scheduled the concerts late last year; Mr. Conlon, the music director of the Los Angeles Opera, was to have conducted a program of Prokofiev and Dvorak on Oct. 29 and 30, and Mr. Spano, the music director of the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra, was to have appeared with Ms. Salerno-Sonnenberg in February. But since the concerts were announced, the Minnesota Orchestra has had to implement pay cuts for its management and musicians. Gwen Pappas, the orchestra’s director of public relations, told The Star Tribune that the schedule changes were made “for budgetary reasons.” She added: “We have not heard any protests yet.”

Updated | 1:54 p.m. Take that, J. K. Rowling, and step off, Stephenie Meyer: Lemony Snicket, the sinister pseudonym of Daniel Handler and the author of the bestselling “Series Of Unfortunate Events” sequence, will write a new four-book series, BBC News reported. The Gothic “Unfortunate Events” novels about the Baudelaire orphans, which started in 1999 with “A Bad Beginning” and ended in 2006 with “The End,” have sold more than 60 million copies worldwide. The series’ British publisher, Egmont Press, said that it would begin releasing the new books, whose titles were not given, in 2012. Mr. Handler told the BBC: “I can neither confirm nor deny that I have begun research into a new case, and I can neither confirm nor deny that the results are as dreadful and unnerving as ‘A Series Of Unfortunate Events.’ However, I can confirm that Egmont will be publishing these findings.”

Here at The Moment, where many of us are serious tennis fans, we're gearing up for the start of the U.S. Open next week. And apparently we're not alone. Along with the tennis legend John McEnroe, the three champions played mentor/coach to kids from the New York Junior Tennis League, Athletes for Charity, Mentoring USA and the New York City Parks Foundation, which each received $10,000 donations from Nike. Needless to say, the kids were psyched about their encounters with the gracious, and brightly dressed, tennis legends - not to mention all the free Nike gear. Love!

The borough of Neukolln, in the south of Berlin, has undergone something of a transformation in recent years. A working-class district with a lively mix of immigrants, starving artists and students, it's thus far resisted the glossy gentrification that's swept across former Eastern boroughs such as chic Mitte and vanilla Prenzlauerberg. But step down Emser Strasse, a typical Neukolln side street of cobbled stone and abandoned sofas, and you'll happen across WOAH, a small gallery housed in an old tailor's shop in a traditional Jugendstil-style building. It opened four months ago, thanks in part to an initiative by a local organization called Zwischennutzungsagentur, which seeks to fill the neighborhood's many empty storefronts with creative types willing to turn them into art spaces in exchange for dirt-cheap rent.WOAH is the brainchild of a group of expat art professionals - the Britons Ian Liddle and Simon Knight and the Spanish fashion designers Raquel Fernandez and Raquel Hladky - each of whom invested 300 euros to get started. Together, they've created a space that alternates monthly between a two-room exhibition/studio space showing off some of the city's rawest artistic talent and a shop selling the collective's hand-tooled clothing line. It's multidisciplinary, multimedia, multiculture and extremely loose - a perfect example of the kind of grass-roots gallery scene now flourishing in this previously neglected quarter.

"There's a certain demand that's gone with the asset destruction and the job destruction," a New York store executive told me the other day. That's the reality these days. Try as retailers might to entice customers into stores-with spiffy renovations at Saks and Bloomingdale's, some great-looking fall merchandise-there just isn't enough demand. Let's hope things pick up in September. As I've been out and about in stores (and I'm by no means done), I've been impressed with the selection. There is more to buy, in my opinion, than there was last August-and some better buys. Retailers and designers seemed to make an effort to have more dresses, for example, in the $750-to-$900 range. I noticed at Barneys a terrific Isabel Toledo jersey dress (maybe a reprise of an earlier style) for $850. And I loved all the trousers I saw around-full, pegged, skinny. And the shoes. Oh, I could go on. Sooner or later one collapses in defeat and joy before a sales counter.

BERLIN | As a young boy, Mehmet Sasmaz, who grew up as the son of Turkish immigrants in Berlin, used to mimic the moves of the bellydancers his mother would watch on television. His parents did not approve. "My mother sent me to office management school," recalled Sasmaz, now 27. But Sasmaz secretly continued to dance and eventually found a teacher. At the end of 2005 he performed publicly for the first time.

A few weeks back, You're The Boss readers rose up in mild insurrection against The Agenda. The occasion was a look at the Small Business Majority, a liberal organization trying to influence the health care debate. Readers thought The Agenda was unfair. "Subject the other business organizations to the same analysis and you would find AT LEAST as much ideology and partisan bias as the author has found on the Small Business Majority," wrote one critic. Citing the National Federation of Independent Business, she added, "A few years ago, the N.F.I.B. contributed 95% of its PAC money to Republican candidates." Another offered: "The N.F.I.B. on any piece of legislation will be slanted towards the leanings [of] the paying membership and, thus, not representative the feelings of all small businessmen."

The former chairman of the North Shore Music Theater in Beverly, Mass., once the region’s largest nonprofit theater, said its property and assets would be sold at a foreclosure auction, The Salem News reported. The theater, which opened in 1955, announced in June that it was unable to raise enough money to finance its summer season and was shutting down, facing debts of about $10 million. David Fellows, the theater’s former chairman, told The Salem News that its board of trustees had turned the property and assets over to Citizens Bank, including three buildings — a theater in the round, a restaurant and an education center — as well as costumes, lighting and sound equipment. Mr. Fellows said that the bank was in the process of foreclosing on the theater’s two mortgages, which total about $5.2 million, and that the theater owed another $5 million to subscribers and vendors that would be repaid if the auction raised enough money. He said four groups with theater backgrounds had expressed interest in buying the property and continuing to operate it as an arts center, but he declined to name the groups.

Instead of taking a few weeks to appreciate the freedom of being unemployed, sleeping in late and catching up on daytime television while eating cereal in her pajamas, Paula Abdul will resume collecting a paycheck as the host of next month’s “VH1 Divas” concert. After announcing on Twitter that she was stepping down as a judge on Fox’s “American Idol,” Ms. Abdul, right, once again pre-empted her employer, posting a note on Twitter Monday night saying she was “really excited 2 announce ill b hosting” the concert, to take place on Sept. 17. VH1 confirmed Ms. Abdul’s announcement in a news release on Tuesday. The concert, to feature performances by Adele, Kelly Clarkson, Leona Lewis, Miley Cyrus and Jordin Sparks, will be broadcast live from the Howard Gilman Opera House at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

A lawsuit filed against the design company of the architect Frank Gehry, below, involving a dispute over the right to use his illustrations on jewelry was dismissed on Monday in Los Angeles. Circa Publishing Enterprises, based in Culver City, Calif., filed suit against Gehry Design in 2007 after Mr. Gehry struck a deal with Tiffany & Company allowing Tiffany to create jewelry based on his fish shapes and other designs. In its suit, Circa Publishing said it already had an exclusive deal with Mr. Gehry to create and sell jewelry and gift items featuring his trademarks. But lawyers for Mr. Gehry said the agreement with Circa Publishing had been terminated when Mr. Gehry entered into his deal with Tiffany. Judge Jane Johnson of Los Angeles County Superior Court granted a motion to dismiss the case on Monday after both sides gave testimony but before closing arguments had been made.

The stagehands union has requested that the Joyce Theater Foundation recognize the union as the collective bargaining representative of the stagehands employed there. The request, announced on Tuesday by the union, Local 1 of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees, stated that the vast majority of the Joyce’s stagehands had recently signed authorization cards selecting the local to bargain collectively on their behalf. In an Aug. 14 letter, the union’s president, James J. Claffey Jr., suggested to the Joyce that it select a neutral third party to review the signed authorization cards. Linda Shelton, executive director of the Joyce, said in an e-mail message: “Mr. Claffey’s letter has been referred to the board members, who will discuss the matter.”.

As expected, Sony Electronics on Tuesday unveiled a wireless touch-screen reading device, which it plans to sell starting in December. The device, above, called the Daily Edition, has a seven-inch screen and a price tag of $399 and will help Sony catch up with Amazon.com’s Kindle, which has been wireless since its first version was introduced in 2007. Steve Haber, president of Sony’s digital reading business division, said there would be newspapers and magazines available on the Daily Edition, but declined to say which ones. Sony also announced a partnership with the New York Public Library to make the library’s 29,000 electronic titles available on all Sony Readers. Borrowers will be able to download digital library books onto their readers. The electronic titles, which are protected from easy copying, would expire in 21 days from the device or computer.

The Apollo Theater in Harlem, which after Michael Jackson’s death became a mourning place and gathering site for his fans, will induct Jackson into its Apollo Legends Hall of Fame, the theater said on Tuesday. The Apollo, a nonprofit theater, said Jackson’s posthumous induction would take place at a gala next year. Jackson will also receive a spot on the Apollo’s Walk of Fame, which is scheduled to be constructed in the fall, and will be given a memorial plaque at the theater in the spring alongside fellow inductees like James Brown and Ella Fitzgerald. The Apollo also said that its archives would take possession of a 100-foot-long blue plywood wall outside the theater that was used as a memorial by Jackson’s fans after his death in June, and which was donated to the theater by the owners of an adjacent property.

The next time you get lost on a drive through unfamiliar terrain, you may be able to blame Bob Dylan. Mr. Dylan, above, said on his satellite radio show that he might lend his distinctively gravelly voice to a satellite navigation system for cars, Agence France-Presse reported. In the latest edition of his “Theme Time Radio Hour,” Mr. Dylan said, “I’m talking to a couple of car companies about being the voice of their G.P.S. system.” He joked that his instructions might not be the most reliable: “Left at the next street. No, right. You know what? Just go straight. I probably shouldn’t do it because whichever way I go, I always end up at one place — on Lonely Avenue.” He added: “Luckily I’m not totally alone. Ray Charles beat me there.”.

All of the Mets' shortcomings were on display Tuesday. Everything that had come to define this lost season appeared with an exclamation point. DELANEY--Roberta Esther Bruce, "Nena", was born on April 17, 1943 to Roscoe Conklin Bruce, Jr. and Roberta McLain Bruce in Mexico City, Mexico. Roberta was the great-granddaughter of Blanche Kelso Bruce (R), the first Black Senator of the United States during the Reconstruction after the civil war. Roberta grew up with her older brother, Ronald D. Bruce (Boise, ID) in the Bronx, NY. She graduated in the top 5% of her class from Howard University with a B.S. degree in zoology and received postgraduate credits from the University of Pittsburgh, University of District of Columbia and Morgan State. She was an elementary school teacher of Earth Sciences for many years. Roberta Bruce was married to Page W. DeLaney, DDS from 1964 to 1977. She has three children, Page W. (Amy) DeLaney II, DDS of Central City, PA, Leslie Roberta DeLaney, MD of Oakland, CA and Lisa DeLaney (John) Varner of Pittsburgh, PA. Roberta moved to Pittsburgh, PA from the D.C. - Virginia area to be closer to her children, in June of 2009 and died from a sudden illness on August 14, 2009 at UPMC Passavant Hospital in Pittsburgh, PA. Roberta leaves to mourn: her brother, three sisters: Jackie Bruce, Dorothy Bruce Felter and C. Adrienne Daniels Paris; three children; two grandchildren, Haydan Horton and Hezekiah DeLaney; God-children, John (Jackie) Settles and Shaila Settles (David) Lewis as well as her best friends, Dorothy McTootle Settles and Rita Wood. Roberta is predeceased by her mother, Roberta M. Magill; fathers Roscoe C. Bruce Jr. and Isham B. Jones. May Roberta have the peace and joy in her passing that she gave us all in her life. She was truly an amazing woman and her life and love will be forever remembered by her family and friends. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, 1pm on August 29, 2009 at The Community Church of New York, 40 East 35th Street, New York, NY. with a reception to follow at the Wingate Hotel on 236 West 35th Street.

John E. Carter, whose soaring falsetto was an instantly recognizable signature on hit records by the seminal doo-wop groups the Flamingos and the Dells, died on Friday in Harvey, Ill. He was 75 and lived in Park Forest, Ill. The cause was lung cancer, family members told The Chicago Tribune.

Ernest Brown, the last surviving and most diminutive member of the Original Copasetics, an ensemble of tap-dancing stars formed in 1949 that helped to revive the art of tap, died on Friday in Chicago. He was 93 and lived in Chicago. His death was confirmed by Reginald McLaughlin, a protégé of his known as Regio the Hoofer, with whom he had performed for 16 years.

KAPLAN--Stanley H. The James Madison High School Alumni Association notes with sadness the passing of Stanley H. Kaplan, Class of 1935, esteemed founder and benefactor of the Association. He was honored by his fellow alumni on Madison's "Wall of Distinction". Richard M. Kossoff, President James Madison High School Alumni Association

CONWAY--Thomas G.,72, died on August 22, 2009 at Southampton Hospital, Southampton, New York. Beloved brother of Dr. Rosemary Conway of Manhattan and Southampton, Mr. Conway resided in Kingston. He was Counsel to the Department of Agriculture and Markets under Governors Rockefeller, Wilson, and Carey. Mr. Conway graduated from Kingston High School, Holy Cross College, and Harvard Law School in 1961. He received the Prettyman Fellowship in Trial Practice at Georgetown in the year 1961. He received his Master of Laws from Georgetown University Law Center in 1962. He was a contributing author to Law and Taxation in Federal Criminal Cases, published in 1964. For many years Mr. Conway was Chairman of New York State Right to Life and was now Chairman of its Advisory Committee. He was a member of a Board at New Paltz College of the State University of New York. He was a Knight of Malta. Calling hours at A. Carr & Son Funeral Home, 65 Lucas Avenue, Kingston, New York, will be from 4:00pm to 8:00pm on Wednesday, August 26. A Mass of Christian Burial will be at St. Joseph's Church in Kingston on Thursday, August 27, at 11:00am. Interment will follow at St. Mary's Cemetery.

Ron Williams, chief executive of the giant insurer Aetna, has been the most vocal insurance executive in favor of an overhaul of the health care system -- as long as it does not include a government-run health plan. On Wednesday, Mr. Williams plans to make that case on the Tavis Smiley talk show on PBS. In the interview, taped ahead of time, Mr. Williams acknowledged that many people, including President Obama, favor creation of a government plan to compete directly with private insurance companies. But he said that issue was a distraction from the true aim of a health overhaul.

''This Way,'' a permanent installation by Linnaea Tillett and Karin Tehve, lights the pedestrian entrance to the Brooklyn Bridge in the Dumbo area of Brooklyn. The work, at Washington and Prospect Streets, is made of LEDs, fiber optic cable, steel and aluminum, and was sponsored by the Dumbo Improvement District. Earlier Sight/Site installments: nytimes.com/lens.

PASK--Durant W. Jr.,of Morristown, NJ died August 20, 2009 at the age of 86. He was born and raised in NYC. Durant attended Parson's School of Design where he received a degree in Fine Arts and also met his wife, Trudy. During WWII he served with the British intelligence in India. After the war ended, he went back to New York City to start his career in Graphic Arts. Durant later had a second career working in security for local corporations in the Morris area until he retired from his last position as Chief of Security for Crum and Forster. In retirement he enjoyed gardening, creating a beautiful flower-filled landscape around his house with his best friend of many years, Gayle Young. Durant was predeceased by his late wife Trudy. Survivors include his son Charles Pask, his wife Janice and their children Lauren and Steven of Ashley, PA and Joanna and Diana Pask of Morristown, NJ. He is also survived by his brother Lawrence Pask. Durant was a good and loving father, husband and friend to many. The kind of person who appreciated the beauty of art and music and shared it with those around him. A private service will be held for the immediate family at the Presbyterian Church of Morristown. Those wishing to remember Durant may make a donation in his name to the Presbyterian Church of Morristown.

Democratic advocates will start fanning out across the country on Wednesday in a final end-of-summer heave to demonstrate their support for a health care overhaul. They hope to provide a bit of counterprogramming to the many skeptical and conservative voices that have slowed President Obama's push to change the health care system. The effort will promote a government-run health insurance plan -- the so-called public option, which appears to be on life-support.

A new report suggests that a drug widely used to prevent the recurrence of breast cancer may have a rare but dangerous side effect: increasing the odds that long-term users may develop an uncommon but aggressive new tumor. But medical experts were quick to question the significance and methodology of the study, saying clinical trials had repeatedly found that the drug, tamoxifen, reduced the recurrence and spread of common breast cancers and that its benefits exceeded any possible risks.

BENDHEIM--Robert. Columbia University Medical Center mourns the passing of Mr. Robert Bendheim, President of the Leon Lowenstein Foundation. A thoughtful and dedicated philanthropist, Mr. Bendheim's visionary and skillful leadership of the Foundation contributed to the success of educational, scientific and social initiatives that have enriched the lives of countless individuals in this city and across the nation. At Columbia University Medical Center, Mr. Bendheim's generosity was instrumental in the formation and advancement of research and patient care programs to reduce the effects of psychiatric conditions such as depression, and numerous neurological diseases. Driven by Mr. Bendheim's compassionate concern for those in need, the Foundation established the Robert and John M. Bendheim Clinic for Movement Disorders in 2005. The facility is dedicated to improving the standard of care available to individuals affected by movement disorders such as Parkinson's disease, and has helped the women and men we serve pursue fuller and more active lives. On behalf of my colleagues, I extend my deepest sympathies and condolences to Mr. Bendheim's family and friends. Lee Goldman, M.D. Executive Vice President for Health and Biomedical Sciences Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine

Born in Hong Kong, on December 21, 1917, he was a graduate of Canton University, Canton, China, and received his Master's Degree from New York University. A prominent businessman who dedicated his time and resources to the community, caring especially for the aged, the poor, and the helpless children. Co-Founder of the Lin Sing- K.C. Leung Foundation sponsoring needy children from China for special surgery in the United States. Charter member of the Rotary Club of Chinatown. Served as honorary chairman at many Chinatown community associations; and honored by the New York City Hall Lions Club, The Gouverneur Healthcare Service, and St. Vincent Hospital. In memory of his wife, Moo Kit Tsui, he was a major contributor toward the building of the Westchester County 9/11 Memorial. Surviving relatives include his children, Dr. Donald Leung of Denver, CO, Florence Leung of NYC, and Firman Leung of Scarsdale, NY. BERNSTEIN--Harriet, died August 12 at age 90. Loving daughter of the late Dora (Mishkin) and Irving Zatinsky and sister of the late Milton Zatinsky. Beloved wife of Leon Bernstein. LEONARD--John Harry, of Ridgefield, CT, passed away peacefully at home in the presence of his family on August 24. He was 87 and suffered from cardiopulmonary difficulties. John was born in New York City, attended public schools, and graduated from New York University with both undergraduate and graduate degrees. He served in the Army Air Force during WWII. He had a long and successful career in the advertising business, especially at Doyle Dane Bernbach from where he retired as Vice President in 1987. As important to him as his business career, he committed to providing his time and talent to many organizations. He taught at NYU's Stern School of Business, served on NYU's Board of Trustees, was Chairman of the Board of Directors at the Wartburg Home in Mt. Vernon, served many years on the Board of the American Bible Society and served in many capacities from teacher to Elder at St. Mark's Evangelical Lutheran Church in Yonkers. His enthusiasms where many, ranging from golf to reading to swimming to all things New York. He had a special love for Blue Mt. Lake in the Adirondack Mountains where he and his family have vacationed virtually every year since 1946. He was also known for his many durable friendships. He is survived by a loving family including his wife of nearly 63 years, Marjorie, his son John K., his daughter, Janet O'Loughlin, his four grandchildren, Sarah and Jen Leonard and Zachary and MacKenzie O'Loughlin and his cousin, Harry T. Bahr. A private family funeral service and interment were held August 25 and a memorial service is planned for 2pm October 3 at Christ The King Lutheran Church, Newtown, CT. Other details including memorial donations are pending.

What we’re reading on Thursday morning.Dunne Remembered: At the Web site of Vanity Fair, the magazine’s editor in chief, Graydon Carter, writes this affectionate remembrance of Dominick Dunne, who died on Wednesday. By overcoming the loss of his daughter and reinventing himself as a courtroom correspondent, Mr. Carter writes, “Dominick Dunne proved that, yes, there are second acts in American lives, and they can indeed be great.”

A recent exhibition on Frank Lloyd Wright went very right indeed for the Guggenheim Museum: it was the highest-attended exhibition in the museum’s history since it started keeping track of such figures in 1992, the museum said. In an email message, a publicist for the Guggenheim said that “Frank Lloyd Wright: From Within Outward,” a retrospective of Wright’s work timed to the museum’s 50th anniversary that included drawings and models (including his original model for the Guggenheim Museum itself) drew 372,000 visitors for the 87 days it ran there, from May 15 through Aug. 23. The exhibition is now on its way to the Guggenheim Museum Bilbao, where it will be shown from Oct. 22 through Feb. 14. The museum said that prior to “From Within Outward,” its best-attended exhibition had been “Frank Gehry, Architect,” which it ran in 2001, followed by “Cai Guo-Qiang: I Want to Believe” in 2008, “Giorgio Armani” in 2000 and “The Art of the Motorcycle” in 1998.

The government in Malaysia has forbidden Muslims to attend a concert that the Black Eyed Peas will play there next month — not because of provocative lyrics or revealing costumes, but because the performance is sponsored by Guinness, The Associated Press reported. The official Web site for the show, which is being held on Sept. 25 near Kuala Lumpur to celebrate the 250th anniversary of the Guinness brewery in Dublin, said that “the party is only open to non-Muslims aged 18 years and above.” Of Malaysia’s 25 million people, 60 percent are Muslims; Islamic law forbids the consumption of alcohol. An official at the Ministry of Information, Communication and Culture in Malaysia told The A.P. that government regulations normally prevent alcohol companies from staging concerts, but that an exception had been made in hopes of increasing tourism. “Muslims cannot attend,” the official said. “Non-Muslims can go and have fun.” Recent concerts in Malaysia featuring singers like Gwen Stefani, Avril Lavigne and Beyoncé have drawn the ire of conservative Muslims who have protested the singers’ revealing costumes.

Updated | 2:13 p.m. Just when Kerry Butler thought she was out of the campy jukebox-musical game, it pulls her back in. At least this time she doesn’t have to wear roller skates. On Thursday, publicists for the Broadway musical “Rock of Ages” said in a news release that Ms. Butler would join its cast on Sept. 21 in the role of Sherrie, the female lead. Ms. Butler, who earned a Tony Award nomination for playing Kira in the Broadway musical adaptation of “Xanadu,” will play the “Rock of Ages” role for six performances a week, the news release said, and her understudy will play the role during both performances on Sundays. The role of Sherrie, a Kansas native who arrives in Los Angeles in the 1980s with dreams of movie stardom, was originated on Broadway by Amy Spanger, who withdrew from the show in June for personal reasons. She was replaced by Savannah Wise, who is joining the cast of the “Ragtime” revival.

In an article in Wednesday’s New York Times about the vacation plans of the “God of Carnage” cast, Hope Davis spoke about how it takes a village — not to mention a good makeup artist and costume shop — to turn her into Hillary Rodham Clinton, whom she is playing in a biographical film about the Clintons and Tony Blair.
The show categories in the Fringe Festival are pretty self-explanatory: drama, comedy, solo, clown, vaudeville, magic.

Iraqi security forces on Thursday displayed what they said was a Picasso painting, who they said had stolen the painting during the occupation of Kuwait in 1990, The Associated Press reported. The artwork, said to be called “The Naked Woman,” was taken from the Kuwait National Museum during the Iraqi invasion that preceded the first gulf war. They said the former soldier had been trying to sell the painting and that it was seized in a raid on his house in Hillah, about 60 miles south of Baghdad. The painting was said to have Picasso’s signature and the stamps of the Kuwaiti museum as well as the Louvre. But a Louvre official told The A.P. that it has never had a Picasso in its collection and does not sell its works because they are government property. The Art Loss Register in London told The A.P. it had no record of any paintings missing from the Kuwait National Museum, and no record of this particular painting as missing.
Jeff Bowen and Hunter Bell, the team behind the heavy-meta musical“[title of show],” are writing a new sitcom for ABC — as yet untitled, of course.

U2 would not seem to be the sort of band that takes Jewish holidays into account when preparing its touring schedule, but the coming observance of Yom Kippur has required the group to reschedule a show planned for Giants Stadium next month. In a news release on Thursday, publicists for U2 said that the group’s concert scheduled at the stadium in East Rutherford, N.J. for Sept. 25 has been moved to Sept. 23. The change was made after the New York Jets rescheduled their Sept. 27 football game against the Tennessee Titans to 1 p.m. from 4:15 pm to avoid a conflict with Yom Kippur, which starts at sundown that day. In their release, U2’s publicists said that the staging installation for the band’s tour requires up to two days to disassemble, and the new game time made it “logistically impossible” for the installation to be broken down between a Friday night concert and a Sunday early afternoon game. The release added: “In order to accommodate the New York Jets, the NFL and the state of New Jersey, which owns the stadium, and out of respect for U2 and Jets’ fans of Jewish faith, U2 agreed to move their show rather than pursue other options.”

You can’t tell the story of intertwining American families without an enormous cast: the Broadway revival of “Ragtime” announced its ensemble on Thursday, consisting of some 40 performers who will be sharing stairwells and dressing rooms at the Neil Simon Theater come this fall. The cast features Quentin Earl Darrington as Coalhouse Walker, Jr. and Stephanie Umoh as Sarah, both making their Broadway debuts, as well as Ron Bohmer (“Phantom of the Opera”) as Father, Christiane Noll (“Urinetown”) as Mother and Robert Petkoff (“Spamalot”) as Tateh. Playing some of the musical’s historical figures are Jonathan Hammond (as Harry Houdini), Donna Migliaccio (Emma Goldman), Eric Jordan Young (Booker T. Washington) and, late of “Rock of Ages,” Savannah Wise (Evelyn Nesbit). The musical, which ran at the Kennedy Center in Washington in the spring, is directed and choreographed by Marcia Milgrom Dodge, and is adapted from the E. L. Doctorow novel with a book by Terrence McNally, music by Stephen Flaherty and lyrics by Lynn Ahrens. It is to begin previews on Oct. 23 and open on Nov. 15.

I love "The September Issue," R.J. Cutler's new documentary about Vogue, like Anna Wintour loves Roger Federer. Seriously. Granted, Cutler's film may not be as funny as "The Last Emperor," Matt Tyrnauer's brilliant documentary about Valentino - it's hard to top the image of Valentino's pugs having their teeth brushed by their personal valet - but "The September Issue" offers more laughs than Anna's monthly editor's letter. André Leon Talley playing tennis wearing a Louis Vuitton monogram towel as a scarf is hilarious and rivaled only by his later referring to "the aesthetics of my style." (Que?) And the dressings-down that Wintour gives everyone from the editor-at-large Elissa Santisi to the YSL designer Stefano Pilati serve as reminders that schadenfreude is never out of fashion. The Moment caught up with Cutler, whose previous credits include the political documentary "The War Room," to talk about his foray into fashion.

PUL-E-ALAM, Afghanistan-- Afghan civilians flee as an American helicopter fires on a building where Taliban fighters have taken refuge. The Taliban fighters had earlier stormed a building in Pul-e-Alam, the capital of Logar Province, killing a guard who tried to stop them. The Afghan National Army and American military intervened, and the Taliban used the high vantage point to attack the Afghan National Police headquarters and the provincial governor's office. Witnesses said that two policemen were killed and several shopkeepers injured during the battle, in mid-August.

One of the coolest things about Twitter is how open it is. The company has published the specs for accessing the service, so that outsiders can write their own Twitter programs (Twitterific, Tweetie, Tweetdeck and so on)--and create Web sites that access the stream of Twitter posts and add all kinds of features.

Maybe it's the lingering Woodstock vibes, but lately I've been really into oversize turquoise jewelry. There are great places to find vintage turquoise in Manhattan, but the special pieces either get snatched up or are prohibitively expensive. This summer, however, I discovered what is literally a hidden gem at the Brooklyn Flea. Hideya Sagawa is a former buyer and visual merchandiser for What Goes Around Comes Around. While he was working there, he also amassed an amazing collection of vintage Western and Native American jewelry, clothing and accessories. Sagawa recently teamed up with Kenji Kawasaki, the owner and designer of the Lower East Side boutique Amoskeag XX, and many of his vintage treasures will be on sale there this fall. But you can find a great selection this Saturday at the Brooklyn Flea -- assuming I don't get there first, that is!

It is easy to take anything for granted. Even when you're working in the paddock of the greatest car racing series in the world, if you do it enough times you can occasionally lose a little bit of the sense of how special the world in which you work really is. That is not to say it is easy to get bored in the Formula One paddock; I would not go that far. I'm just saying that it is easy for anyone working in the paddock often enough to forget the first childlike wonder that we experience upon setting foot at an F1 race track or in a paddock for the first time.

The YouTube sensations-turned-TV stars Jeffery Self and Cole Escola are the funniest camp duo since Kiki and Herb. BERLIN | It's happened twice a year, every year since 1997, and has been so successful that it's been copied in cities around the world. Berlin's Long Night of Museums is up again, for the 25th time, this Saturday. The passionate, maddening love between Heathcliff and Catherine in Emily Brontë's "Wuthering Heights" has long been fodder for many artists, from Albert Camus to Death Cab for Cutie. Recently, the photographer Sam Taylor-Wood has expanded the Victorian novel's influence by shooting the very place that inspired Brontë: the area near the village of Haworth in West Yorkshire. For many years, Taylor-Wood - who shared a country house in the region with her then husband, the art dealer Jay Jopling - photographed the wind-swept lands of heather and moors, and ominous gray skies. In the series, "Ghosts," which is on display at the Bronte Parsonage Museum through Nov. 2, Taylor-Wood has created romantic, melancholic reflections offset by simple beauty - gray skies, spidery trees, the odd ram - giving a redemptive quality to a harsh landscape.

A film review on Wednesday about “Taking Woodstock” misstated the setting where a song by the band Love is heard as a shy young stranger is initiated into the mysteries of LSD. It is in a van, not a tent.
The rhythm that pulsates through any number of musical styles from hip-hop to club pop, animates zouk, a dance that originated in the French West Indies and recently found its way to Central Park.

The Entrepreneurial Edge column on Aug. 20, about reduced investments in business ventures by angel investors, misstated the investment activity of the New Vantage Group in Vienna, Va. The group invests in four to six companies a year — not 24, which is the number of companies it typically examines each year to determine its investments.

An article on Monday about an analysis of the emotional slant of Web postings described incorrectly the National Science Foundation’s relationship with Jodange, a company in the field. While the agency awarded a grant to Jodange, it did not invest in the company. The article also misstated the origins of Jodange’s software. It was created by Claire Cardie and her computer science students at Cornell University; Jan Wiebe of the University of Pittsburgh was not involved. And the article misstated Professor Cardie’s job status. She is a current — not former — professor on the Cornell faculty.
Lawyers for three men and a company charged in the fatal fire at the former Deutsche Bank building blamed city, state and federal agencies for the blaze.
Now that Chrysler’s partner is Fiat, which specializes in small cars, Nissan will need to find a way to improve its large-pickup segment.

A listing in the Long Island Calendar in some editions last Sunday about the Gateway Playhouse production of “Dirty Rotten Scoundrels” misidentified the location of the performances. It is being presented through Sept. 12 at the Patchogue Theater for the Performing Arts, not at the Gateway Playhouse in Bellport.
In honor of the 25th anniversary of London Fashion Week next month, several British designers have announced they will return to London for the season.
It is hard to remain disgruntled in a Jonathan Adler environment. Item No. 1 of his manifesto, printed right on the wall, is, “We believe that your home should make you happy.”

An article on Saturday about the strain that the recession is placing on the city’s nonprofit social service agencies referred incorrectly to an annual fund-raising event for the Henry Street Settlement that lost its sponsor, Lehman Brothers. The event is an art show, not an auction.

An article in some editions on Tuesday about the arrest of a Manhattan man on murder charges in the shooting death of an off-duty bouncer at a downtown bar, Forbidden City, misidentified the bar’s neighborhood. It is in the East Village, not the Lower East Side.

An article on Aug. 14 about a poll that showed a narrowing of the presidential election race in Afghanistan misstated the favorable ratings for President Hamid Karzai and for Abdullah Abdullah, the candidate for the largest opposition bloc. At the time of the poll, Mr. Karzai held a favorable rating of 81 percent, not 64 percent, and Mr. Abdullah had a favorable rating of 71 percent, not 48 percent. The 64 and 48 figures reflected the percentage point differences between each man’s favorable and unfavorable ratings. (The outcome of the election is still not known.).

Lance Armstrong’s new cycling team, Radio Shack, will make its debut at the 2010 Tour Down Under in Australia from Jan. 17-24. Armstrong, who finished third in the Tour de France in July while racing for Astana, made the announcement on his Twitter page.

Islanders center Mike Sillinger said he was retiring after 17 years in the N.H.L. because of an injured left hip. Sillinger, 38, played only seven games last season and had surgery in January. In February 2008, a procedure on the hip forced him to miss the final 29 games of that season. He played for a record 12 teams during his 17 seasons, three of which were with the Islanders.

The first World Youth Congress, which ended Sunday in Istanbul, was a great success. At the bridge tables it produced a mixed bag of the good, the bad and the not for children’s eyes. The diagramed deal, spotted by Kees Tammens from the Netherlands, was one of the best.

For the third week in a row country music holds the top spot on the Billboard 200 album chart. Reba McEntire’s new “Keep On Loving You” (Valory) is No. 1 with 96,000 sales, Nielsen SoundScan reported. It is only the second time Ms. McEntire has scored a No. 1 on Billboard’s main chart, though she has sold more than 40 million albums in her career. (She’s had lots of No. 1’s over the years on the country chart, of course.) George Strait’s “Twang” (MCA Nashville), last week’s top seller, fell to No. 2 with 61,000 sales, a 61 percent decline. “Ursa Major” (Mega Collider), Third Eye Blind’s first album in six years, opened at No. 3 with 49,000; Kings of Leon’s “Only by the Night” (RCA) rose one spot to No. 4 with 45,000 sales, and the Black Eyed Peas’ latest, “The E.N.D.” (Interscope), is fifth with 41,000. Michael Jackson’s sales have cooled off a bit lately, but this week they reach an important milestone. “Number Ones” (Epic), the 2003 collection that has dominated sales since Mr. Jackson’s death two months ago, has surpassed Taylor Swift’s “Fearless” (Big Machine) as the best-selling album of 2009. Last week “Number Ones” racked up another 68,000 sales, bringing its total for the year to 1,619,000; “Fearless” has sold 1,608,000 copies in the same period.

Parker Posey, below, may be a one-woman dynamo capable of several projects at once, but even she isn’t powerful enough to overcome Lyme disease. In a statement on Wednesday, Playwrights Horizons said that Ms. Posey, a star of films like “Best in Show” and “Waiting for Guffman,” had withdrawn from the company’s coming production of “This,” a new comedy planned for its 2009-10 season. The statement said Ms. Posey would not be able to take part “due to developing a case of Lyme disease.” Playwrights Horizons said that it was still planning to begin previews of the show at its mainstage theater on Nov. 6 and open the production on Dec. 2, and that it would announce a replacement for Ms. Posey shortly.

Take that, J. K. Rowling, and step off, Stephenie Meyer: Lemony Snicket, the sinister pseudonym of Daniel Handler and the author of the bestselling “Series of Unfortunate Events” sequence, will write a new four-book series, BBC News reported. The Gothic “Unfortunate Events” novels about the Baudelaire orphans, which started in 1999 with “The Bad Beginning” and apparently ended in 2006 with “The End,” have sold more than 60 million copies worldwide. The series’s British publisher, Egmont Press, said that it would begin releasing the new books, whose titles were not given, in 2012. Mr. Handler told the BBC: “I can neither confirm nor deny that I have begun research into a new case, and I can neither confirm nor deny that the results are as dreadful and unnerving as ‘A Series 0f Unfortunate Events.’ However I can confirm that Egmont will be publishing these findings.” A publicist for HarperCollins Children’s Books, which releases the “Unfortunate Events” novels in the United States, said that Mr. Handler was working on the new Lemony Snicket books with his longtime editor Susan Rich, but that North American rights for them had not yet been determined.

A judge sentenced the R&B singer Chris Brown, below, on Tuesday to five years of probation and six months of community labor for assaulting the pop star Rihanna, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Brown will be allowed to serve his sentence in his home state, Virginia, but will have to make return trips to Los Angeles to update a judge on his progress. Mr. Brown pleaded guilty in June to one count of felony assault on Rihanna, a charge that stemmed from an incident on the morning of Feb. 8 when the two fought in Mr. Brown’s car. He had also been charged with making criminal threats, and could have faced up to five years in prison if found guilty on all charges. Judge Patricia Schnegg of Los Angeles County Superior Court ordered Mr. Brown to stay 100 yards away from Rihanna, except at industry events, where he can be within 10 yards. The judge also reminded Mr. Brown that any violation of his probation “comes with the potential for state prison.”.

As a cost-cutting measure, the Minnesota Orchestra has canceled coming concerts that were to have featured the conductors James Conlon and Robert Spano and the violinist Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg as the orchestra weathers the economic downturn, The Star Tribune reported. The orchestra scheduled the concerts late last year. Mr. Conlon, above, the music director of the Los Angeles Opera, was to have conducted a program of Prokofiev and Dvorak on Oct. 29 and 30, and Mr. Spano, the music director of the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra, was to have appeared with Ms. Salerno-Sonnenberg in February. But since the concerts were announced, the Minnesota Orchestra has had to carry out pay cuts for its management and musicians. Gwen Pappas, the orchestra’s director of public relations, told The Star Tribune that the schedule changes were made “for budgetary reasons.” She added, “We have not heard any protests yet.”.

Bob Dylan plans to release a collection of familiar yuletide tunes, to be called “Christmas in the Heart,” with proceeds of the album to benefit hunger-relief charities, he announced on his Web site, bobdylan.com. Among the traditional songs that Mr. Dylan will perform on the album, which Columbia Records is to release on Oct. 13, are “Here Comes Santa Claus,” “Winter Wonderland,” “Little Drummer Boy” and “Must Be Santa.” A statement on the Web site said that all of Mr. Dylan’s royalties in the United States from the album would be donated to the charity Feeding America, and that he planned to donate his international royalties to organizations in Britain and elsewhere that provide meals during the holiday season. “Christmas in the Heart” is the 47th album by Mr. Dylan.

11 P.M. (A&E) CRIME 360 On March 5, three days after Davon Crawford married for the second time, his Cleveland home erupted in gunfire. Mr. Crawford had killed his new wife, Lechea, 30, and her sister, Rose Stevens, 25. Before fleeing, Mr. Crawford, 33, also shot Ms. Stevens's three small children, killing all of them. (Another child was wounded, and a baby was unhurt.) A camera crew from ''Crime 360'' happened to be tagging along that night with two Cleveland police detectives, Tim Entenok and Tom Armelli. At the crime scene a visibly shaken police sergeant briefed the detectives. ''I just want you guys to know, it's one of the worst things I've ever seen,'' he said. This graphic program pairs computer-generated illustrations with documentary footage to show how police solve real crimes. A day after the shooting, Mr. Crawford killed himself as police tried to arrest him. (Above, neighbors outside the house.) 7 A.M. When Irene Mendevil, a high school English teacher, shouts at her students, she said, she gets a sore throat. So she has begun to use an amplifier. ''I had the experience of losing my voice completely,'' she said of her constant shouting. ''No sounds came out of my mouth. I had to write on paper to tell my students what to do.''

UBS will meet with Canadian officials on Sept. 2, a spokeswoman for the country's revenue agency said. Jean-Pierre Blackburn, Canada's national revenue minister, said Canada was seeking to recoup tax losses caused by citizens who hid assets in UBS accounts. UBS said Aug. 19 that it would divulge information on 4,450 accounts to settle a lawsuit in the United States that sought names of clients suspected of evading taxes.
