From the Ground Up is about the writer's construction of a cabin in the Maine woods and offers advice for those thinking of building their own cabin. An excerpt: AT the end of the day Sunday, as yet another thunderstorm passed over the mountains, Paul and I rested on the cabin's porch and enjoyed the sound of the rain striking the roof and cascading from the roof's edge. The porch is not yet enclosed, but it is fully framed and ready to be called a porch. Yes, it looks like a porch and acts like a porch. Sitting on its deck, Paul and I concluded that it was a fine porch indeed.

The Starter Garden is about the progress of the writer's first vegetable garden, in Minneapolis. An excerpt: O NE piece of unfinished business. Earlier this summer I posted the first -- and surely the last -- Starter Garden history quiz. It focused on the gardening habits of some of history's most prominent leaders. I had a mind to mail a packet of scarlet runner beans to the first correct entry. And then I waited for a winner, and then procrastinated, and then waited some more.

KAPLAN--Stanley H. The JCC in Manhattan mourns the loss of Stanley H. Kaplan. We celebrate his extraordinary generosity and a life well lived. Sincere condolences to Rita and the entire family. Marti Meyerson, President Rabbi Joy Levitt, Executive Director

KAPLAN--Stanley. MEF (Musicians Emergency Fund, Inc.) profoundly mourns the death of our patron and benefactor, Stanley H. Kaplan, who with his beloved wife, Rita, gave unstintingly to music and musicians. The President, officers and Board of Directors of Musicians Emergency Fund, Inc., wish to extend heartfelt condolences to the Kaplan family on the death of their husband and father. Stanley Kaplan's personal involvement and support of Musicians Emergency Fund, Inc., was a testimonial to his dedication to classical music that was indicative of the depth and scope of his knowledge and appreciation. Stanley and his beloved wife, Rita, gave generously to young artists and brought careers forward in a way that would never have happened without them. These stand among his good works, and will enrich the lives of audiences and artists for generations to come. The Kentucky Derby winner Mine That Bird is not fully recovered from throat surgery and will not run in the Travers Stakes on Saturday at Saratoga Race Course. His trainer, Chip Woolley, said Mine That Bird would instead be pointed toward the Breeders' Cup Nov. 6-7. Woolley discovered that his star had an entrapped epiglottis on Aug. 17 after a workout and sent him to the Ruffian Equine Medical Center in Elmont, N.Y., for the minor procedure. Mine That Bird has had three endoscopic examinations in the past week, the last one on Wednesday. Woolley and the gelding's owners, Mark Allen and Dr. Leonard Blach, did not like what they saw. Woolley said he also did not want to halt postoperative medication that Mine That Bird was taking so that he could run in the Travers.

When the PGA Tour's FedEx Cup playoffs open with the Barclays this week at Liberty National, the top 124 points-earners from the regular season will begin competing for a spot among 30 finalists in the Tour Championship. That event will determine the winner of a $10 million first prize. The top 100 points-earners after the Barclays will be eligible for the Deutsche Bank Championship, which begins Sept. 4 in Norton, Mass. The top 70 after that event will be eligible for the BMW Championship a week later at Cog Hill outside Chicago. After that event, the points will be reset for the top 30 players.

BENDHEIM--Robert, former president and chairman of M. Lowenstein Corporation, died on Friday, August 21st in Greenwich, CT. He was 93. Mr. Bendheim lived in Greenwich, and had a home in Lyford Cay, Nassau. The Lowenstein Company was a major textile firm, which manufactured apparel and industrial fabrics, and Wamsutta and Pacific home furnishings. Mr. Bendheim started with the company as a trainee in 1946, and served as its chief executive officer from 1972 until 1985, when the company sold to Springs Industries. During this same period, Mr. Bendheim was also an officer and director of the Leon Lowenstein Foundation, Inc., serving as its president since 1976. The Foundation bears the name of Mr. Bendheim's uncle, Leon Lowenstein, who started the Foundation in 1941. The Foundation's principal grants are for medical research and education. Over the years, large grants have been given to Mt. Sinai, Columbia Presbyterian, and Sloan Kettering medical centers, and in education, to Princeton and Fordham universities, the Wharton School of Economics, and programs for improvement of the New York City public schools. Mr. Bendheim graduated from Princeton University in 1937 and attended the Harvard Business School. He served in the United States Navy as a lieutenant from 1942 to 1946, and he received an honorary degree of Doctor of Humane Letters from Fordham University in 1966. He was on the Board of Trustees of Mt. Sinai Hospital, the Boards of Fordham University, and United Way of New York, and served on various committees of Princeton University. His clubs included the Round Hill and Stanwich in Greenwich, Lyford Cay in Nassau, the Princeton Club and the River Club in New York City. He is survived by his beloved wife, Jane, his two daughters by a previous marriage, Lynn Bendheim Thoman and Kim Bendheim, his stepdaughter, Josephine Poole, his brother, John M. Bendheim of Scarsdale, New York, and four grandchildren. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st Street on Thursday, August 27th, at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Bendheim Finance Center at Princeton University, or Princeton University, Princeton, New Jersey 08544.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the youngest of Joseph Kennedy's children and the scion of one of the most prominent families in American politics, died on Tuesday. He was 77. Only one of John F. More than 2,500 people jammed into a high school gymnasium in Reston, Va., on Tuesday night for a forum on health care held by Representative James P. Moran, the Democrat who represents the area. At his side was Howard Dean, the former chairman of the Democratic National Committee and an advocate of a government-run health insurance plan. Mr. Dean seemed to be the lightning rod for the event, fielding an array of questions, sometimes angry ones, about health legislation. Among those more intent on yelling slogans than on asking questions was Randall Terry, the anti-abortion advocate and founder of Operation Rescue, who chanted as Mr. Dean, formerly a practicing physician, tried to speak.

ADVERTISEMENTS for shoes that are meant to help people lose weight and add muscle tone have been ubiquitous this summer. ''Get in shape without ever setting foot in a gym'' is the trademark slogan for Skechers Shape Ups, which say they are designed to ''firm calf and buttock muscles'' and ''reduce cellulite and tone your thighs.'' Other manufacturers make similar claims for their products, which fall into a category called ''functional footwear.'' Generally speaking, these shoes work by creating a slightly uneven platform for the foot, theoretically forcing the leg, buttock and back muscles to exert more energy while walking or at rest. ''You are always toning with EasyTone -- even when you are standing,'' Reebok says of its new line.

A memorial service is scheduled at 1pm on September 3, at Greenwich Reform Synagogue, 257 Stanwich Rd., Greenwich, Ct (203-629-0018).

Sheehan, Associate Dean for International Relations

Shows that involve putting a spin on one of Shakespeare’s plays are fairly common Fringe Festival enterprises, and the results can range from inventive to excruciating. I was feeling guardedly optimistic heading in to watch the BAMA Theater Company production of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” at the Cherry Lane Theater last night. The company is made up of graduates from the Alabama Shakespeare Festival MFA actor training program, so they should know something about the Bard. In fact, I went there myself, though I finished (ahem) quite a few years before the actors in this production.

Though an arbitrator may have cleared Jeremy Piven of any wrongdoing when he left the cast of “Speed-the-Plow,” the National Fisheries Institute isn’t letting the actor off the hook for saying that his mercury poisoning may have been caused by a diet high in fish. The group, which says on its Web site that it is “dedicated to education about seafood safety, sustainability, and nutrition,” wrote in a statement that it cautions the news media “to treat Piven’s statements with skepticism.” The statement continued: “It is important to note that no peer reviewed medical journal has ever published any evidence of a case of methylmercury poisoning caused by the normal consumption of commercial seafood in the U.S. This ruling does not change that simple scientific fact.” Mr. Piven has said that his habit of eating fish twice a day for 20 years contributed to the mercury poisoning he said he suffered during the Broadway run of “Speed-the-Plow,” which left him exhausted, disoriented and fearing for his life.

“Little Gem,” the debut play by the playwright Elaine Murphy about three generations of women in an Irish family, has won the annual Carol Tambor Best of Edinburgh Award at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, the award’s organizers said in a news release. The winning play, presented by Guna Nua Theater in Dublin and the Civic Theater of Ireland, will be produced at the Flea Theater in TriBeCa in January and will be performed in the Under the Radar Festival. To be eligible for the Carol Tambor Award, a show must be an original work not previously performed in New York, and must receive a four- or five-star review from The Scotsman newspaper. Last year’s winner of the award, “Eight” by Ella Hickson, was performed at P.S. 122 in New York and also at Trafalgar Studio in the West End and is scheduled for the Ringling International Arts Festival in Sarasota, Fla., in October.

Like childhood, innocence and baby teeth, a title role in “Billy Elliot the Musical” isn’t forever. On Friday, press representatives for that Broadway production said that the show had named Alex Ko as the fifth actor to play the title character on Broadway. The musical’s publicists also said that Kiril Kulish, one of the three original Billys who won Tony Awards in June for their performances, would depart the show after playing the character a final time on the evening of Oct. 3. Mr. Ko, who was admitted to the University of Iowa Dance Department at age 12 and studied with Eloy Barragán and George de la Peña, will join David Alvarez and Trent Kowalik (both Tony winners) as well as Tommy Batchelor in the Billy rotation the week of Oct. 5.

The makers of a coming film adapted from Naomi Klein‘s book “The Shock Doctrine” probably knew that it would provoke arguments, but not like this: The Independent of London reported that Ms. Klein had withdrawn from participation in the film, and does not appear in its credits as a writer or consultant, or act as its narrator. In the book, Ms. Klein writes about how countries that have suffered wars, terror attacks or natural disasters are taken advantage of by politicians and corporations, finding examples everywhere from post-apartheid South Africa to post-9/11 America. A film adaptation directed by Michael Winterbottom (whose films include “A Mighty Heart”) and Mat Whitecross had its premiere at the Berlin Film Festival and is to be shown on Britain’s Channel 4 on Tuesday. But Ms. Klein told The Independent she had disagreed with Mr. Winterbottom over “the content, tone and structure of the film.” “As often happens, we had different ideas about how to tell this story and build the argument,” she said. “This is Michael’s adaptation of my book, and I didn’t want there to be any confusion about that. I wish the film success.” Plans for distribution in the United States have not been announced.

Showtime sure loves its alphabetically titled shows. Having seen its hit series “The L Word” conclude its sixth and final season in March, the cable channel said in a news release that it had ordered a pilot for a new series starring Laura Linney (whose alliterative initials would have fit right in on that show) to be called “The C Word.” On the new series, Ms. Linney will play a suburban wife and mother who learns that she has cancer; the release said that her character will be “forced to face reality yet also find the light side in a dark situation.” The show, on which Ms. Linney will also serve as an executive producer, is created and written by Darlene Hunt, a producer for “90210” and a writer for comedies like “Will & Grace” and “Good Morning Miami.” In a statement, Robert Greenblatt, Showtime’s president of entertainment, said that cancer is “not usually the subject of half-hour comedy” but added that Ms. Linney “will no doubt make this character both heartbreaking and disarmingly funny, and we’re thrilled that she has chosen this show for her foray into series television.”

The death of a public figure, especially a polarizing one, always makes things a bit dicey in opinionland. Do the detractors speak ill of the dead? Do the defenders pre-empt such criticisms, or does that just inspire the critics? In the case of Ted Kennedy, whose many accomplishments got due recognition everywhere, most chose to duck the fight on anything more problematic. There was comparatively little talk about a Harvard scandal, a very sad end to a first marriage or a controversial rape trial. Even among the pundits and partisans, the name Mary Jo Kopechne was for the most part mentioned only in passing; those on the right who tried to make much of it seemed more petulant than aggrieved -- perhaps even shrill -- while those on the left who tried to make the best of it sounded patently absurd.

The current crop of tennis stars have a stylish legacy to live up to. Pre-World War II players like Suzanne Lenglen and Rene Lacoste revolutionized on-court attire as much as they did the mechanics of the game. And since the advent of regular tennis coverage on TV in the 1970s, when peacocks like Bjorn Borg and Vitas Gerulaitis dazzled audiences not only with their athleticism and guile but also with their logo-laden plumage, attention-grabbing fashion has become as much of a part of the players' weaponry as their ground strokes. So on the eve of the U.S. Open, The Moment serves up some of the sport's winning looks and some dubious line calls.

Strange this, but I imagine if it is a real calendar then the FIA will not wait long before publishing it and sending it out to the people in the media center where I am writing these words.

When West Ham drew Millwall in the second round of the Carling Cup, England's secondary cup competition, there were audible gasps in the Sky Sports studio. Separated by two divisions, West Ham and Millwall rarely come head to head, but their historic rivalry is one of the fiercest in global soccer.

It was more than eight months ago that Norway's Think suspended production of its plastic-bodied, battery-powered urban runabout, the City. Soon after, the company came under the protection of the Norwegian courts, leading some observers to wonder if it was the end of the line for a company with a colorful history that included a brief period of Ford ownership.

Despite some grumbling from the biotech industry, two of the leading biodiesel distributors in Massachusetts are generally pleased with the state's move last week to promote biofuels processed from waste -- as opposed to food crops or emerging feedstocks, like algae.

The disturbance that I mentioned in my previous update on Tuesday has since been upgraded to TS Danny and has tracked northwest toward the southeast US coastline. As of this morning, Danny was located about 350 miles south of Cape Hatteras NC and heading NW at 9kts. The storm has consistently been poorly organized, with an exposed low-level center and the convective activity displaced to the east of the center. Latest intensity is 35kts and 1008mb, and that is not expected to change much as it makes its way toward the coast then gets pushed out northeastward, scraping the US/Canada coast.

It could now be called Boathouse on the Green. The Department of Parks announced that Tavern on the Green, the landmark restaurant in Central Park, will have a new operator: Dean J. Poll, who runs the Central Park Boathouse restaurant.

Fashion insiders have been keeping an eye on Antonio Azzuolo since the inception of his men's line, a.a., three seasons ago. Azzuolo is no stranger to the garment business; both his parents were tailors from Italy. He grew up in Montreal and later moved to Europe after graduating from college with a degree in -- what else? -- fashion. He's designed for Ralph Lauren and worked for Hermès in Paris. His men's line is often described as boarding-school chic, but this fall the line has become a little less academic and a little more luxe. By using materials like cashmere and fur, Azzuolo offers up some special pieces that swing both uptown and downtown.

The Afghan elections commission is posting the results from the Aug. 20 national election here. Results are available by province. Over a week after the vote, plagued by violence and ongoing allegations of fraud, only 17.2 percent of the votes have been counted. According to the Web site, President Hamid Karzai is leading with 44.8 percent of the votes counted. His nearest challenger, Dr. Abdullah Abdullah, has 35.1 percent, the site reports.

Jackson Hole Central Reservations, the city's tourism group, is offering a 4th Flies Free deal: buy three plane ticket to the Wyoming ski resort and get a fourth ticket free. That means you and your friends can take a five-night ski vacation for as little as $142 each person, each night, including airfare and lift tickets.

Their brand of love is even more desperate, and more obsessive, than that of the game's top stars. Although the stakes may seem smaller in terms of money and glory, these players are seeking a qualifying spot in the United States Open draw: win you advance, lose you go home.

Many readers were upset by the broken-toy experiment described in my Findings column about research into guilt. In that experiment, a researcher would tell a toddler to be very careful in handling a special toy. The toy would fall apart as soon as the child handled it, and the child's reactions for the next minute would be systematically recorded. Then the experimenter would leave the room with the toy and return in 30 seconds with an intact replica, assuring the child that the toy had been fixed and that the accident hadn't been the child's fault.

Today's idea: Feminists "underestimate the passion" of new motherhood and instead have emphasized its drudgery, writes Katie Roiphe. Au contraire: she thinks caring for her new baby "is wilder and more narcotic than any kind of work I have ever done."
Commonwealth Bank of Australia plans to raise 900 million Australian dollars ($756 million) selling hybrid securities to bolster the balance sheet, Bloomberg News reported.

LONDON | The vagaries of the English summer can sometimes result in outdoor events being a wash out. London's Serpentine Gallery in Hyde Park has solved this problem by building a temporary pavilion each summer. The pavilion hosts "Park Nights," a themed program of films, music, theater, talks and events, each Friday evening through October 18. Audience members feel as though they are outside but are, in fact, sheltered from the elements. The themes of this year's series are excess, extinction and the spoken word.

R. Allen Stanford's relationship with the chief regulator of his Antigua bank was closer than most. At a meeting in 2003, they became blood brothers, cutting their wrists and mixing their blood in a "brotherhood ceremony" that Mr. Stanford's chief financial officer said promoted an elaborate scheme to hide a multibillion-dollar fraud from American and other regulators, The New York Times's Clifford Krauss writes.

Some bondholders of the Tribune Co. are seeking permission from a federal bankruptcy judge to investigate the company's sale in 2007 to the billionaire investor Samuel Zell, a deal creditors claim led to a bankruptcy filing a year later, The New York Times's Michael J. de la Merced and Brian Stelter write.
A dispute has developed between Goldman Sachs and real estate developer Joe Moinian over office space in Mr. Moinion's 180 Maiden Lane tower in downtown New York, The New York Post says.

Khalid bin Mahfouz, a billionaire Saudi banker who paid $225 million to settle charges of bank fraud in 1993 and later won a string of lawsuits in Britain against writers who had accused him of supporting terrorism, died Sunday at his home in Jidda. He was 60. The cause was a heart attack, according to reports in the Arab news media.

As it did for most of the week, Wall Street spent Thursday searching for direction. The main indexes on Thursday morning were in the red, but climbed into positive territory after an afternoon rebound in oil prices and the energy sector.

A suggestion by the chairman of Britain's markets regulator that financial transactions be taxed to deter excessive risk-taking and future crises has ignited a heated debate in London's financial industry and beyond, The New York Times's Julia Werdigier reported.

Fried pickles, a popular side dish at barbecue joints, are popping up in different guises across the country. At Bobo in Manhattan, the executive chef, Patrick Connolly, dredges cornichons in flour, tempura and panko, and serves them with crab dip (crème fraîche, cocktail sauce and peekytoe crab). He's also inclined to blanket them with shaved bottarga - a far cry from the traditional fried-pickle accompaniment of ranch dip or remoulade sauce.

Here's a novelty on Wall Street that, according to Breakingviews.com, deserves to become commonplace: Some investment bankers are deferring some of their fees until the deals they advise on pay off for investors. This is a little like making bankers eat their own cooking, or serving them dessert only if the main course tastes good, the publication says.
Royal Bank of Canada said on Thursday that its earnings surged 24 percent in the third quarter as a big jump trading revenue more than offset higher loan-loss provisions.
Toronto-Dominion Bank reported a decline in quarterly profit yesterday but easily beat expectations. The bank earned $834 million, or 92 cents per share, for the quarter ended July 31.
National Bank of Canada said on Thursday its profit rose 6 percent in the third quarter as trading revenues surged, surpassing estimates.

Joshua Robinson of The Times writes that the women's event seems poised for an all-Williams semifinal, though neither Serena nor Venus has been particularly impressive since they faced off in the Wimbledon final, which Serena won. The Sports of The Times column on Aug. 11 recounted the pioneering experiences of Wat Misaka, who played briefly for the Knicks in the 1940s and is the subject of a documentary. The column described Misaka as the team’s first draft pick in 1947 based on information from the film’s Web site and the Knicks’ media guide. After publication, however, a reader who has researched basketball history provided The Times with a copy of a record showing Misaka among a select group of players on a so-called negotiation list — not a college draft list. The first player listed for the Knicks as a draft pick that year was Dick Holub. (A Knicks spokesman said he could not independently verify the information.).

An article on Tuesday about Eric Schadt, a scientist who blends mathematics, biology and supercomputers to study diseases, misidentified the company he works for and misstated, in one instance, his title. He works for Pacific Biosciences, not Pacific Biosystems. And he is the chief scientific officer, not the chief technology officer. And the article misspelled the given name of a geneticist who has been a longtime colleague of Dr. Schadt’s. He is Stephen Friend, not Steven.
The federal government should take steps to reduce the risk of foreclosure from unpaid property taxes.
With the appointment of a prosecutor to investigate detainee abuses, tensions between two critical players on the President Obama’s national security team burst into view.
The Department of Defense has identified 791 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:.

An article in some editions on Thursday about the Yankees’ 9-2 victory over Texas misstated the inning during which the Yankees scored five runs. It was the seventh, not the eighth. And an Inside Pitch note with the article misidentified the Hall of Fame pitcher whom Andy Pettitte has tied for third place on the franchise’s career victories list. He was Lefty Gomez — not Lefty Grove, who pitched for the Philadelphia A’s and the Boston Red Sox.

An article in some copies on Wednesday about a visit by the former Yankee Bucky Dent to the Little League World Series in South Williamsport, Pa., referred incorrectly, using information from The Associated Press, to a memorable home run by Dent in a playoff against the Red Sox for the 1978 American League East title. Although it gave the Yankees a lead in the seventh inning, it was not ultimately the decisive blow. (Reggie Jackson’s home run in the next inning proved to be the difference in a 5-4 victory.).

An article last Friday about Caster Semenya, the 18-year-old runner from South Africa whose victory in the 800-meter race at the track and field world championships generated controversy over concerns about her sex, referred incorrectly to people in South Africa whose sex characteristics have been studied because of the prevalence of hermaphroditism among them. They are Bantu-speaking people — not “Bantus,” a term considered offensive because it was used by those in power during apartheid in reference to black people.

A picture caption on Thursday with the continuation of the obituary of Senator Edward M. Kennedy misidentified two of his sisters and omitted a third in some editions. Shown in the picture, of the Kennedy clan in 1934, were front row, from left: Patricia, Rose, Joe (holding 2-year-old Edward), Rosemary, Eunice and Kathleen. (In some editions, Eunice’s name was omitted, and in some editions Rosemary and Kathleen were reversed.).

Jacob Zuma, left, began his first official visit to Zimbabwe as South Africa’s president on Thursday evening. Leaders of the Movement for Democratic Change, which joined a coalition government with President Robert Mugabe and his ZANU-PF party, say they hope that Mr. Zuma will press Mr. Mugabe to halt the arrest of its members of Parliament. Mr. Zuma’s predecessor, Thabo Mbeki, was known for his policy of “quiet diplomacy,” often criticized as appeasement of the authoritarian Mr. Mugabe, 85. Gwede Mantashe, the secretary general of Mr. Zuma’s party, said Wednesday that Mr. Zuma would “become more vocal in what we see as deviant behavior in our neighbor,” mentioning the arrest of M.D.C. lawmakers as an example of such behavior.

You can’t tell the story of intertwining American families without an enormous cast: on Thursday the Broadway revival of “Ragtime” announced its ensemble, consisting of some 40 performers who will be sharing stairwells and dressing rooms at the Neil Simon Theater come this fall. The cast features Quentin Earl Darrington as Coalhouse Walker Jr. and Stephanie Umoh as Sarah, both making their Broadway debuts, as well as Ron Bohmer (“The Phantom of the Opera”) as Father, Christiane Noll (“Urinetown”) as Mother and Robert Petkoff (“Spamalot”) as Tateh. Playing some of the musical’s historical figures are Jonathan Hammond (as Harry Houdini), Donna Migliaccio (Emma Goldman), Eric Jordan Young (Booker T. Washington) and, from “Rock of Ages,” Savannah Wise (Evelyn Nesbit). The musical, which ran at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington in the spring, is directed and choreographed by Marcia Milgrom Dodge and is adapted from the E. L. Doctorow novel with a book by Terrence McNally, music by Stephen Flaherty and lyrics by Lynn Ahrens. It is to begin previews on Oct. 23 and open on Nov. 15. ... Kerry Butler, who earned a Tony Award nomination for the Broadway musical adaptation of “Xanadu,” will join the cast of “Rock of Ages” on Sept. 21 as Sherrie, the female lead. Ms. Butler will play the “Rock of Ages” role for six shows a week, with her understudy playing it during both Sunday performances. The role of Sherrie was originated on Broadway by Amy Spanger, who left the show in June. She was replaced by Savannah Wise, who is joining the cast of the “Ragtime” revival. ... Aaron Tveit, who recently appeared with Ms. Butler in the musical adaptation of “Catch Me if You Can” in Seattle, will return to Broadway in “Next to Normal” on Sept. 7. Mr. Tveit will resume the character of Gabe, which he originated

A change in the way New York City allocates funds to arts organizations has helped level the playing field, according to a report the New York City Independent Budget Office issued on Wednesday. The Department of Cultural Affairs adopted a peer-review system intended to award grants competitively and give larger organizations more fiscal stability by providing them with multiyear awards. The department “generally achieved these goals,” the budget office said. In fiscal year 2007, before the change, 884 groups applied for financing and 780 received awards, according to the budget office survey. Groups that once had individual line items in the city budget got $17.2 million; others got $6.3 million. In fiscal year 2009, 1,084 groups applied, and 882 received awards, with that first set of groups getting $14.7 million and the allocation to the others more than doubling, to $14.3 million.

The government in Malaysia has forbidden Muslims there to attend a concert by the Black Eyed Peas, right, next month — not because of provocative lyrics or revealing costumes, but because the performance is sponsored by Guinness, The Associated Press reported. The official Web site (arthursday.com.my) for the show — which is being held on Sept. 25 near Kuala Lumpur to celebrate the 250th anniversary of the Guinness brewery in Dublin — said that “the party is only open to non-Muslims aged 18 years and above.” Of Malaysia’s 25 million people, 60 percent are Muslim; Islamic law forbids the consumption of alcohol. An official at the Ministry of Information, Communication and Culture in Malaysia told The A.P. that government regulations normally prevent alcohol companies from staging concerts, but that an exception had been made in hopes of increasing tourism. “Muslims cannot attend,” the official said. “Non-Muslims can go and have fun.” Recent concerts in Malaysia featuring the singers Gwen Stefani, Avril Lavigne and Beyoncé have drawn the ire of conservative Muslims, who protested the singers’ revealing costumes.

Jeff Bowen and Hunter Bell, the team behind the heavy-meta musical “[title of show],” are writing a new sitcom for ABC — as yet untitled, of course. Mr. Bowen said he and Mr. Bell were developing the half-hour show with Marc Cherry, the creator of “Desperate Housewives”; the “Housewives” executive producer Sabrina Wind; and Michael Berresse, who directed and choreographed “[title of show]” on and off Broadway. Although the TV show is in the early stages of development, Mr. Bowen said it would not be a musical and would not be based on “[title of show].” He also said there were no plans for him or Mr. Bell to be in the cast. “Not yet, at least,” he said. The series will be Mr. Bowen and Mr. Bell’s first project together since “[title of show]” closed on Broadway in October.

The glass-topped coffin, left, that held the body of Emmett Till, whose 1955 murder in Mississippi helped galvanize the civil rights movement, has been donated to the National Museum of African American History and Culture in Washington, the museum said. The donation will be made public on Friday before a memorial service at the Roberts Temple Church of God in Christ, the site of Till’s funeral. The 14-year-old Till was killed by white men while visiting the house of his great-uncle Moses Wright in Money, Miss., after he was perceived to have offended a white woman. His mother, Mamie Till Mobley, decided to have her son presented in an open casket so the world could see what had been done to him. Till’s body was exhumed from the Burr Oak Cemetery in suburban Chicago in 2005 during another criminal investigation into his murder, and Till was reburied in another coffin. The National Museum of African American History and Culture is scheduled to open on the Mall in 2015. The coffin will be examined and housed in the Smithsonian Institution’s Museum Support Center.

The coming Yom Kippur holiday has required U2, above, to reschedule a show planned for Giants Stadium next month. Publicists for U2 said that the group’s concert scheduled at the stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., for Sept. 25 has been moved to Sept. 23. The change was made after the New York Jets rescheduled their Sept. 27 football game to 1 p.m. from 4:15 p.m. to avoid a conflict with Yom Kippur, which starts at sundown that day. In their release, U2’s publicists said that the staging installation for the band’s tour requires up to two days to disassemble, and that the new time for the game made that process “logistically impossible.”.

NEVAS--Leo. The board and staff of American Jewish World Service mourn the passing of Leo Nevas, a member of our board for more than 20 years and a true global citizen. Leo lived his values, loved and cherished his family, was a leader and changemaker in his community and passionately embraced the possibilities for helping to bring greater justice to the people and the nations of the world. We will miss his thoughtful questions, his wise suggestions, his irrepressible wit and the special twinkle in his eye. Leo's legacy is seen in the commitment to social justice shared by three generations of his family. We extend our sympathies to the entire Nevas family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Ruth W. Messinger, President Barbara Dobkin, Board Chair

EICHBAUM--Ulryk, 96, died on August 26. Born in Przemysl and raised in Katowice, Poland, he attended university in Vienna where he spoke Polish, German, French, English, and competed as a Grand Prix auto racer, driving for Team Citroen before WWII forced him to flee. Ulryk embraced life and savored adventure, competition and conquest. He was passionate about cars, tennis and family. On September 1, 1939 when Germany bombed and invaded Poland, Ulryk instinctively escaped with his wife, Saree, driving to Rumania minutes before advancing German troops closed the Polish border. Only 26 years old, he navigated the chaos of Europe, miraculously obtained a visa to the US, and secured passage from Genoa, Italy on the Saturnia. They arrived in New York Harbor on Columbus Day 1939, homeless and penniless. From Ellis Island they were thrust into the Bronx, where Ulryk found work cleaning toilets. He found distant relatives in Woodbridge, NJ who owned a dairy farm and moved again. In 1940, he succeeded in what he considered his life's biggest accomplishment: Ulryk secured his parents' safe passage out of Poland and entry to Dominican Republic until he obtained their visas to enter the US in 1941. He worked hard and played hard, driving a milk truck to make pre-dawn home deliveries, and playing tennis in the afternoons at the public courts in Perth Amboy. He later turned his passion for cars into a business. In 1954 he became the first Chevrolet dealer in Middlesex County, NJ. After 42 years of owning June Chevrolet, he retired at age 84 and moved from Metuchen, NJ to Boca Raton, FL. Ulryk was predeceased by Saree, his wife of 65 years, and is survived by his daughter, June Eichbaum and son-in-law, Ken Wirfel and grandchildren, Hannah and Mikhaila Wirfel.

'THE BEASTLY BEAUTY' The magic of Coney Island -- well, part of the magic -- is that a hundred crazy things can be going on all at once, and it's hard to tear your attention away from any one of them. But Alison Ward, right, hopes to draw at least some oglers on Saturday with her performance piece ''The Beastly Beauty.'' To be staged on the boardwalk, it's part slapsticky clowning, part baroque theater and part professional wrestling, Ms. Ward, 37, said. It involves dozens of performers done up in costumes that are equal parts revealing and froufrou, divided into teams that represent the beautiful and the grotesque. Naturally they must battle, with cheerleading-style rallying cries, military call-and-response and burlesque dance moves. Also, naturally, it's the men who represent beauty, and the women, mostly, who do grotesque.

KOREY--William. June 16, 1922 to August 26, 2009. Patriarch, scholar, human rights activist, professor, author and champion of the underdog, passed away at the age of 87. Bill had a great zest for life, for music, for laughter and for food. He raged against the dying of the light. He embodied the Talmudic principle that to save one life is to save the world, and thus he saved the world many times. Married for 54 years to Esther, who predeceased him, he leaves behind his loving family: daughters Alix (husband Randy Hansen) and Eileen (husband Robert Kaplan); grandchildren Rachel and Ben; nephews Arthur, Steve and Gil Bardige and their wonderful families; nieces Nikki Director and Susan Korey and their wonderful families; many friends and admirers, and his devoted companion for the last seven years, Diana Marx. A memorial service is planned for October 19th at the Center for Jewish History for those who wish to pay him tribute. He would be deeply touched to be remembered by name in contribution to B'nai B'rith International or the William Korey Fund at the American Jewish Historical Society.

MILLER--Pearl C. After the sudden passing of her revered uncle, Elias A. Cohen on July 2, 1952, Pearl dedicated over 50 years of her life to his Tranquillity Farm and Camp. Leading by example and putting others before herself, Pearl taught thousands of boys and girls how to live, play and work together. She brought out the best in anyone fortunate enough to meet her. Following Pearl's example, and in the spirit of "Noblesse Oblige," her adoring family, the dedicated staff, a grateful alumni and so many loyal friends are all helping to perpetuate Tranquillity Camp as an enduring monument to this great leader. Together, we will do our best to ensure that all generations of Tranquillity's children will mark this day as one to remember our beloved "Pearl," the ultimate teacher. The Tranquillity family is proud to announce the successful completion of our 91st Camp season on August 25th, 2009. Tranquillity Camp, Inc. Earlton, NY Richard Lawrence, President Richard Lerner, Director

Ellie Greenwich, a songwriter who collaborated with Phil Spector, Jeff Barry and others to create a greatest-hits list of 1960s teenage pop songs like ''Da Doo Ron Ron,'' ''Then He Kissed Me,'' ''Hanky Panky'' and ''Leader of the Pack,'' died on Wednesday in Manhattan. She was 68. The cause was a heart attack following a case of pneumonia, her niece, Jessica Weiner, said.

DELANEY--Roberta Esther Bruce, "Nena", was born on April 17, 1943 to Roscoe Conklin Bruce, Jr. and Roberta McLain Bruce in Mexico City, Mexico. Roberta was the great-granddaughter of Blanche Kelso Bruce (R), the first Black Senator of the United States during the Reconstruction after the civil war. Roberta grew up with her older brother, Ronald D. Bruce (Boise, ID) in the Bronx, NY. She graduated in the top 5% of her class from Howard University with a B.S. degree in zoology and received postgraduate credits from the University of Pittsburgh, University of District of Columbia and Morgan State. She was an elementary school teacher of Earth Sciences for many years. Roberta Bruce was married to Page W. DeLaney, DDS from 1964 to 1977. She has three children, Page W. (Amy) DeLaney II, DDS of Central City, PA, Leslie Roberta DeLaney, MD of Oakland, CA and Lisa DeLaney (John) Varner of Pittsburgh, PA. Roberta moved to Pittsburgh, PA from the D.C. - Virginia area to be closer to her children, in June of 2009 and died from a sudden illness on August 14, 2009 at UPMC Passavant Hospital in Pittsburgh, PA. Roberta leaves to mourn: her brother, three sisters: Jackie Bruce, Dorothy Bruce Felter and C. Adrienne Daniels Paris; three children; two grandchildren, Haydan Horton and Hezekiah DeLaney; God-children, John (Jackie) Settles and Shaila Settles (David) Lewis as well as her best friends, Dorothy McTootle Settles and Rita Wood. Roberta is predeceased by her mother, Roberta M. Magill; fathers Roscoe C. Bruce Jr. and Isham B. Jones. May Roberta have the peace and joy in her passing that she gave us all in her life. She was truly an amazing woman and her life and love will be forever remembered by her family and friends. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, 1pm on August 29, 2009 at The Community Church of New York, 40 East 35th Street, New York, NY. with a reception to follow at the Wingate Hotel on 236 West 35th Street.

YORK--Arthur Morgan, of Stamford, CT, died August 14, 2009. He was 94. Mr. York a native of Dover-Foxcroft, Maine, was born on December 13, 1914. He graduated from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1937; and worked as a science reporter for the New York Post and on the publicity staff of Westinghouse Corporation, Pittsburgh. He was married in July, 1942, to Clare Peterson of Naugatuck, CT. During World War II Mr. York was part of the wartime synthetic rubber program in Washington DC. In 1945, he joined the public relations department of United States Rubber Company, later named Uniroyal Corp., becoming in 1961 Director of Corporate Communications. In 1978, Mr. York started his own consulting practice in corporate communications. Mr. York is survived by three daughters, Anita Sawyer of Raleigh, NC, Rita Fogal of Waltham, MA, Carolyn York of Rockville, MD, six grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. He was predeceased by a fourth daughter, Susan Stensberg, and by his wife, Clare, who died in May, 2000.

KOREY--Dr. William. The leadership and staff of B'nai B'rith International mourn the loss of the internationally acclaimed human rights and Soviet expert Dr. William Korey. A longtime United Nations authority, Dr. Korey devoted most of his professional life to improving the world and played a vital role in leading B'nai B'rith's efforts to achieve ratification of the genocide treaty by the United States and other nations. Dr. Korey spent nearly 40 years in the service of B'nai B'rith, much of it directing our United Nations office. A noted author, professor, and communal servant, his impact on the world is immeasurable. The family has asked that contributions in his memory be made to: B'nai B'rith International, 7th floor, 2020 K St. NW, Washington, DC 20006. A memorial service will be held on October 19 at 5pm at the Center for Jewish History in New York City. We extend our condolences to his daughters Eileen and Alexandra and their families. May his memory be for a blessing. Moishe Smith International President Dennis W. Glick Chair of the Executive Daniel S. Mariaschin Executive Vice President

(TCM) SUMMER UNDER THE STARS: FRANK SINATRAOl' Blue Eyes shows off his acting chops in this five-film tribute, starting with ''Some Came Running'' (1958), in which Sinatra (above left, with Shirley MacLaine and Dean Martin) plays an Army veteran who returns home to confront secrets and lies. In ''High Society'' (1956), at 10:30, he joins Bing Crosby, Grace Kelly and Celeste Holm in a musical version of ''The Philadelphia Story,'' about tabloid reporters who invade a society wedding. In ''The Tender Trap'' (1955), at 12:30 a.m., he's a swinging bachelor who finds love when he meets a woman (Debbie Reynolds) immune to his line. And in ''Sergeants 3'' (1962), at 2:30, Sinatra teams up with Dean Martin and Peter Lawford as adventurous cavalry officers who, with their bugler (Sammy Davis Jr.), take on the renegade chief of an American Indian tribe. The evening ends with ''Suddenly'' (1954), at 4:30, starring Sinatra as one of three hired killers posing as F.B.I. agents, who take over a suburban home to plot a presidential assassination. 9 A.M. (CBS) THE DOCTORS Topics include breast-feeding, elective Caesarean sections, pain during intercourse and how watermelon affects the libido.

ALTER--David, of New York, NY and Seaview, Fire Island, passed away on August 27, 2009. Born in Czechoslovakia on October 31, 1923, he was a graduate of Townsend Harris High School, City College of New York and Harvard Law School. A prominent entertainment industry labor attorney, he was Counsel to the Screen Actors Guild for four decades, past president of the Seaview Association, and founding member of the Board of Trustees of The Fire Island Synagogue. His brilliance, wisdom, dignity and strength were an inspiration to all who knew him. He will always be in the hearts of his beloved wife of 54 years, Deborah (King), his adoring daughters Lisa (Joel Confino) and Amy (Ken Ross), and his cherished grandchildren Arielle, Alexandra, Jordana and Clint. Services will be held Sunday, August 30, 11:45am, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, corner of 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in his memory can be made to The Parkinsons Disease Foundation, c/o Lucien J. Cote, MD, 1359 Broadway, Suite 1509, New York, NY 10018.

ALTER--David. The Board of Directors of The Fire Island Synagogue mourns the passing of David Alter whose kindness, gentleness and quiet strength were felt by all who knew him. David will be deeply missed by all of us and the entire community. Our heartfelt condolences go to his beloved wife and synagogue board member Debbie, daughter and synagogue Co-President Lisa, son-in-law and board member Joel Confino, daughter Amy and her husband Ken Ross, and grandchildren Arielle, Alexandra, Jordana and Clint. Shaul Magid, Rabbi Harry Trattner, Cantor

SUSSMAN--Marianne G.,died August 26 in Craftsbury, VT where she summered for more than 20 years. She was born September 10, 1929 in Berlin and with her parents left Germany as the Nazi tyranny intensified. She came to the United States as a child, attended the Dalton School in New York City and graduated from the University of Chicago majoring in literature. She worked at the Saturday Review, Random House, The New York Times Book Review and for 20 years was on the editorial staff of Time magazine. She is survived by Leonard, her husband of 51 years, son Mark Jacob Sussman and his wife Mary-Jo Thompson, stepson David William Sussman, son-in-law Phillip Hyde, grandchildren Samuel and Finn Sussman and step-grandchildren Jane and Rebecca Sussman and Benjamin Sussman-Hyde. A memorial will be announced later.
KAPLAN--Stanley. We honor his memory and the legacy of his extraordinary vision and generosity and send deepest condolences to Rita and the family. The Jewish Museum

BAXT--Stewart. The entire Menowitz and Hamburger families are deeply saddened by the sudden passing of our longtime friend, Stewart Baxt. Stewart was a devoted and loving family man with a large and generous heart who always had a smile on his face and a joke on his tongue, and all who knew him will surely miss his presence. Our heartfelt sympathy goes to his adoring wife Sarah, his son Jeffrey, who recently started College, his daughter Danielle, together with the entire Baxt Family. "Rest in Peace Sweet Man." The entire Menowitz and Hamburger families.

Despite what he called ''the hubbub'' this month about end-of-life health care, Senator Mark Warner devoted a town meeting to the topic on Thursday. It was actually civil. Mr. Warner, Democrat of Virginia, drew a sympathetic audience that included ministers, priests, rabbis, hospice workers, a physician and several constituents who on Tuesday night had attended a local congressman's larger meeting that was disrupted by anti-euthanasia activists.

My Sunday Column argues that our existing health system erodes family values -- by causing the divorce of the woman who was the spine of my column -- and costs far more lives than an army of "death panels" ever could. I'm quite horrified at the thought that we may miss this chance to reform our health care system and assure universal coverage for all Americans. I'd welcome your thoughts on the column, particularly by those working in the medical world or those who have had major encounters with it.

"Exemplar of superfluity" is a wonderful way to start off this weekend's acrostic. It's clear what superfluity means, but the adjective form of that word, superfluous, is much more common. Writing concise and amusing puzzle clues like that is an art form of its own.

Re "The Insult Was Extra Large" (Aug. 23):I suppose it was a bit mean-spirited of Cintra Wilson to suggest that J.C. Penney's stores are dowdy, with clothes for "waddlers." However, for The Times to remain the great paper it is, she should be treasured for her sharp tongue and biting wit. Wasn't H.L. Mencken a fine journalist? Or Tom Wolfe back in the Herald-Tribune days? They were far worse than Cintra. No - the bite is the crushed red pepper in the spaghetti sauce. Please don't dumb her down.JEFF COXKenwood, Calif., Aug. 23, 2009 ●I take issue with your mea culpa on Cintra Wilson's cutting review of the new Penney's Manhattan store. I live in the hinterlands, and I found it accurate and humorous. I used it to illustrate to a friend the workings of fashion snobbery and symbolism. Ms. Wilson has a particular point of view, tongue firmly in her cheek, and she fully aired the inherent conflict between country and city, polyester and silk. Embedded in her satire were tough truths about quality and mass merchandising. I buy The Times for just this level of vivid insight.NAOMI C. DALLOBCincinnati, Aug. 23, 2009 ●I am a Midwestern woman and a size 12. I was quite interested to learn that both of those attributes are laughable.I also am a longtime Times subscriber. I now fear that my public fondness for The Times may prove embarrassing to your staff. Would it diminish their embarrassment if I canceled my subscription?ELIZABETH AUSTINChicago, Aug. 24, 2009●●Re "Baseball's Top-Secret Roster" (Aug. 9):I don't think you address one important aspect of the situation, that being the prosecutors or others who revealed information that was sealed under a court order. To me this is a more serious crime than a ballplayer taking steroids. Illegally and unethically leaking confidential information seems to be getting more and more prevalent. The fact is that The Times and other newspapers are often accessories to this crime. Can you justify this in this case? After all, it isn't the Pentagon Papers. In my humble opinion, journalists need to set the bar quite a bit higher.JACK ACKERMANGarwood, N.J., Aug. 9, 2009 ●While I agree with your assessment concerning the pursuit of sealed orders by The New York Times, and I understand the need of your paper to pursue and publish relevant information regarding any institution, I feel you are publishing salacious and slanderous pieces that are unsubstantiated. Your reporter pursued names at the expense of the larger story and ignored facts that were not only relevant but also imperative to the truthfulness of the report. David Ortiz, Manny Ramirez and Sammy Sosa could have tested positive for legal, over-the-counter supplements, which were not banned under the collective bargaining agreement agreed upon by Major League Baseball and the players' union. You wrote, "But one of a newspaper's fundamental obligations is to examine the integrity of institutions, including baseball," and I cannot help to think about the hypocrisy of such a statement when your own reporters are publishing reports that may be completely and totally incorrect. Slander sells for the Enquirer; truth and facts should be the priority for the Times.COREY HOEHNBoston, Aug. 10, 2009 ●One issue you did not tackle in your thoughtful discussion of the drug test "list" is the use of data collected from a one-shot "survey" to draw conclusions about individuals. Nearly any test for drug usage will have both false negatives and false positives, especially if the test is supposed to detect so many different drugs. False results may not be a big problem if the aim of the tests was to get a rough estimate the proportion of players who were using steroids and other performance enhancing drugs, and if the false positives and false negatives were expected (based on trials) to occur in approximately equal numbers. But it's another matter if you try to use the tests to say something about individuals. Right now, all we know is that some people are falsely accused, and some are falsely given a free pass - and that the public has no idea how big or small these errors are when making judgments about individual players. New York Times reporters talk about error rates in public opinion samples. Why don't they discuss errors and their implications in this context?TOM GAISWilliamstown, Mass., Aug. 11, 2009 ●You forgot to address what some of us think is the most important issue: who is the source of these leaks - which, as I understand it, are 100 percent illegal and unethical - and why are they doing it? Why not prompt The Times to investigate that issue? After all, The times has an inside track - it dealt with them (whoever they are).GERALD GLASSERWestfield, N.J.. Aug. 9, 2009 ●I think people are missing the point about the so-called list: the players were promised confidentiality and anonymity; otherwise, they never would have agreed to the testing. That Alex Rodriguez's rights were violated is no excuse for violating David Ortiz's. I don't have a problem with the press printing news, but whoever is leaking these names is not only violating the law, but is also destroying something of inestimable value: fundamental trust in each other will be destroyed. And for what? The names of players who may have taken something that at the time - six years ago - was not yet prohibited in their sport. Is it really worth undermining the social contract for such out-of-date and unreliable information?TOM BECKEast Windsor, N.J., Aug. 9, 2009●●Re "How Did This Happen?" (Aug. 2):Embarrassing as the error corrections must have been for your editors, I think they are symptomatic of a much greater problem. Frankly, The Times has become fraught with errors, not nearly so much in its print version as on its Web site. More important, you seem to be losing your journalistic soul as the organization slips into being more of an Internet news blog than a serious publication.Back when your Web site was only giving away the newspaper's content for free, it was simply undermining your business model. Now, the Web site increasingly controls the paper's content, and the slapdash nature of 24/7 Web reporting (and blogging) has carried over into print. Worse, any real "news" on the Web site is increasingly overshadowed by the opinionated blogs presented there. So much for being "the newspaper of record." I'm not sure why The Times chose to use its Web site to destroy its newspaper, but that is very much what is happening.GEORGE SCHNEPFManhattan, Aug. 2, 2009 ●I strongly believe writing or editing for a newspaper today no longer has the professional and personal pressure that it did in yesteryear. At 72, I can still vividly recall what it was like to be the equivalent of an apprentice.While in college, I became a stringer for The Trentonian. The city editor, Clyde Lieb, and others taught me to take my first copy off the press and check my work to see if it could have been done better, and then to look at the other guys' work. In addition, the noise of a dozen typewriters and six teletype machines added to the ambiance of urgency and importance. We all believed that what we wrote had to be correct, not only factually but in the proper use of the American idiom of the English language, because we set the example for our readers.Then there was that feeling of pride when your byline appeared, which wasn't very often on The Trentonian in the late '50s. I got two in three years.Walk into a newsroom today and the air is clean and smoke-free, the room is quiet, and there's no aura of urgency, no friendly competitive atmosphere, and I daresay probably no sense of accomplishment by most of the personnel when the bell rings and the press rolls.LEE MALTENFORTSavannah, Ga., Aug. 2, 2009 ●In your analysis of Alessandra Stanley's error-riddled story about Walter Cronkite, why was there no mention of one other factor: the reduction in staff at The Times and the obvious trend seen in the newspaper industry of fewer reporters and copy editors being forced to do more work, thus resulting in a lesser product?As a former newspaper reporter with 25 years in the industry, I know this is a problem nationwide. Newspaper staffs are being slashed to the bone, or the marrow in some instances, and the remaining staff is told to "do more with less." Overworked staffers, declining morale and glaring problems like Ms. Stanley's horrendous errors (compounded by editors' failing in their roles) only chip away at the foundations of journalism.ALAN CLEMONSHampton Cove, Ala., Aug. 2, 2009

The funeral for Senator Edward M. Kennedy begins at the Basilica of Our Lady of Perpetual Help just outside Boston. The rain outside, and the wet streets, offer up a symbolism often remarked upon at dampened funerals as a renewal of life. Or that the heavens are weeping.

Though an arbitrator has cleared Jeremy Piven, below, of any wrongdoing when he left the cast of “Speed-the-Plow,” the National Fisheries Institute isn’t pleased that he said his mercury poisoning might have been caused by a diet of fish. The group, which says it is “dedicated to education about seafood safety, sustainability and nutrition,” cautioned the news media in a statement to “treat Piven’s statements with skepticism.” The statement continued: “It is important to note that no peer-reviewed medical journal has ever published any evidence of a case of methylmercury poisoning caused by the normal consumption of commercial seafood in the U.S. This ruling does not change that simple scientific fact.” Mr. Piven has said eating fish twice a day for 20 years contributed to the poisoning he experienced during the run of “Speed-the-Plow,” which he said left him exhausted and fearing for his life.

He built it, and they came. A recent Frank Lloyd Wright exhibition drew more people to the Guggenheim Museum than any other exhibition since the museum started keeping track of such figures in 1992. In an e-mail message, a publicist for the Guggenheim said “Frank Lloyd Wright: From Within Outward,” a retrospective of Wright’s work timed to the museum’s 50th anniversary that included drawings and his original model for the Guggenheim, drew 372,000 visitors for the 87 days the show was open, from May 15 through Aug. 23. The exhibition is on its way to the Guggenheim Museum Bilbao, where it will be from Oct. 22 through Feb. 14. The museum said that before “From Within Outward” its most well-attended exhibition had been “Frank Gehry, Architect” in 2001, followed by “Cai Guo-Qiang: I Want to Believe” in 2008, “Giorgio Armani” in 2000 and “The Art of the Motorcycle” in 1998. Above, a visitor views a model of one of Wright’s unbuilt projects.

The makers of a film adapted from Naomi Klein’s book “The Shock Doctrine” probably knew it would provoke arguments, but not like this: The Independent of London reported that Ms. Klein, left, had withdrawn from participation in the film and does not appear in its credits as a writer or consultant or serve as its narrator. In the book Ms. Klein wrote about how politicians and corporations have taken advantage of countries that have suffered wars, terror attacks or natural disasters, finding examples from postapartheid South Africa to post-9/11 America. A film adaptation directed by Michael Winterbottom (whose films include “A Mighty Heart”) and Mat Whitecross had its premiere at the Berlin Film Festival and is to be shown on Britain’s Channel 4 on Tuesday. But Ms. Klein told The Independent she had disagreed over “the content, tone and structure of the film” with Mr. Winterbottom. “As often happens, we had different ideas about how to tell this story and build the argument,” she said. “This is Michael’s adaptation of my book, and I didn’t want there to be any confusion about that. I wish the film success.” Plans for distribution in the United States have not been announced.

Under the House health bill now circulating, many Medicare beneficiaries would pay higher premiums for prescription drug coverage, but many would also see their total drug spending decline, the Congressional Budget Office said Friday. And it would not be only Medicare patients who would spend less, according to the budget office, which said the drug-related provisions of the House bill would save the federal government $30 billion from 2010 to 2019.

COSGROVE--Betty Baker, 99, died Friday, August 14, 2009 at home in Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania. Her grandfather was the famed illustrator, Peter Newell. Betty developed her own artistic talents at Smith College, the National Academy of Design, the Sorbonne and the Art Students League from 1928 to 1938. In September 1943 she was appointed by the American Red Cross to serve in Paris. In March of 1945 she was married to her beloved "Cos". Theirs was the first American wedding in occupied Germany. The Cosgrove's lived most of their lives in New York City, Pound Ridge and Maui. She painted until the very last years of her life. Her vibrancy for life and for those dear to her will remain a blessing to her nieces, nephew, cousins, extended family and friends. Donations in her memory may be made to the American Red Cross. Services by Bringhurst Funeral Home At West Laurel Hill Cemetery, 225 Belmont Ave., Bala Cynwyd, PA.

10 P.M. (Cinemax) NIGHTS IN RODANTHE (2008) Pass the hanky, please. Richard Gere and Diane Lane, above, so good together as the tormented husband and wife in ''Unfaithful'' (2002), team up again to play lost souls who find each other at an inn along the stormy and scenic North Carolina coast in this adaptation of the Nicholas Sparks novel. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said that the stars were ''defeated by the scripted clichés and lack of focused direction'' from George C. Wolfe, formerly of the Public Theater in Manhattan. ''Whatever the case,'' she added, ''it's a shame that beautiful movie suffering has gone the way of the durable hack, the kind of studio lifer who knew that action meant, you know, action, and came equipped with a cinematographer who could turn light and shadow and all those glistening tears into a night to remember.'' 10 A.M. As polls show support for a health care overhaul slipping, advocates for change are trying to win back the public. A new television advertisement that began running Friday in 12 states tries to convince middle-class families who already have health insurance that a change would be good for them. ''Eight ways reform matters to you,'' says the narrator over upbeat music and scenes of patients. ''A cap on deductibles and out-of-pocket costs. No annual or lifetime limits on coverage. Preventive care, covered.'' And so it goes, checking off the eight supposed benefits, before directing viewers to a new Web site, FactsAboutReform.org.

President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad lashed out at his chief political rivals on Friday, calling on judiciary officials to ''decisively'' and ''mercilessly'' prosecute them for challenging the legitimacy of his electoral victory and tarnishing the image of the state. The president's remarks, in a speech prior to the nationally broadcast Friday Prayer ceremony in Tehran, underscored the grim reality of a nation whose political factions are deeply divided, hostile and exhibiting no appetite for common ground or compromise.

GREENWICH--Ellie. The readers know who Ellie Greenwich was or they soon will after reading the longer obituaries. She rightfully deserved her election to the Songwriters Hall of Fame. But one area of her life was private. She was a kind, warm, compassionate and caring human being. I met with her many times and each time I came away feeling uplifted. On special occasions, holidays, birthdays, etc. she would send humorous notes and sometimes a small gift wrapped in paper from her unique collection. My wife Robin joins me in extending our condolences to her sister Laura, her brother-in-law Robert Weiner, her niece Jessica Weiner and her nephew Richard Weiner. Ed and Robin Cramer Englewood, New Jersey

The N.F.L. announced new ground rules for the mammoth video boards that hang above the field at the new Cowboys Stadium. After a conference call with the league's competition committee Friday, Commissioner Roger Goodell decided that the screens would not be raised this season, a move that would have cost more than $1 million. Instead, Goodell said that if a ball struck a video board, it would be ruled dead and the down would be replayed. Time would be put back on the clock and all penalties except personal fouls would be disregarded.

A political activist was sentenced to 18 years in prison on Friday for damaging the ''reputation and honor'' of the king and queen of Thailand, the latest in a string of convictions for insulting the country's monarchy. A three-judge panel said the activist, a former journalist named Daranee Charnchoengsilpakul, left, insinuated in a speech last year that King Bhumibol Adulyadej and Queen Sirikit had supported a coup that unseated former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra. She said she would appeal. Thailand has long maintained some of the world's strictest laws against insulting royalty, but only in recent years -- amid political turmoil and concerns about the 81-year-old king's health -- have they been put to use with such regularity.

The WaPo ombudsman hits on a pet peeve of mine from way back: reporting that focuses on how policy proposals are supposedly playing, rather than what's actually in them. You'd think that good reviews and good buzz would be enough to keep a restaurant going strong. But Ken Friedman says that one thing the John Dory didn't have was neighbors. So after dinner on Saturday he closed that cozy seafood restaurant that he and April Bloomfield had opened less than a year ago on a quiet stretch of Tenth Avenue just up from the meatpacking district. An article last Sunday about examples of manipulation of pictures in history referred incorrectly to a photograph whose authenticity has been challenged, Robert Capa’s “Falling Soldier,” taken in 1936, during the Spanish Civil War. It was Capa’s biographer — not Capa himself — who identified the location of the scene as Cerro Muriano. (The location has been central to a debate over whether the picture is a soldier in his fatal moment or is staged. A Spanish researcher contends the picture’s background shows terrain that is 35 miles from Cerro Muriano.).

A review on July 26, about “Israel Is Real: An Obsessive Quest to Understand the Jewish Nation and Its History,” by Rich Cohen, included a quotation from the book that misstated the name of Ehud Barak’s father and his town of origin. He was Israel Brog, not Shmuel Goldfein, and he came from Pusalotas, Lithuania, not from Plotsk, which is in Poland. The quotation also misstates the person responsible for the change of Barak’s original surname. It was Barak himself, not his father.

Four years have passed since Hurricane Katrina made landfall. But the story of what the storm visited upon New Orleans has yet to recede. The Times has kept a watchful presence in the city, and The Times Magazine, for its part, has annually observed Katrina’s mournful anniversary with ambitious journalism about the deep and broad ramifications of the disaster. Three years ago, we published a portfolio of photographs, taken by Brenda Ann Kenneally, of children in and around New Orleans who were still living amid the hurricane’s wreckage. The following year, Michael Lewis wrote about the strange world of hedge-fund guys who place bets on when the Next Big One will hit the Gulf Coast. The DVD column last Sunday, about John Cassavetes’s “Husbands” (1970) and Chantal Akerman’s ”Jeanne Dielman, 23 Quai du Commerce, 1080 Bruxelles” (1975), misidentified the character in “Husbands” who paired off with the woman portrayed by Jenny Runacre. It was Gus (John Cassavetes); it was not Harry (Ben Gazzara), who pairs off with Pearl, played by Jenny Lee-Wright.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about Vivaldi’s compositions that were unpublished during his lifetime misidentified the post held by Susan Orlando, a performer and scholar who was quoted. The error also appeared in an accompanying picture caption. Ms. Orlando is director of the Vivaldi Edition of the Naïve record label, which is releasing the music; she does not oversee the Vivaldi archive at the Biblioteca Nazionale Universitaria di Torino in Italy, which holds the autograph copies of the works.

The DVD column on Aug. 9, about Buddy Giovinazzo’s “Combat Shock” (1986), which was partially shot in the marshlands around Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island, misidentified the location where Stanley Kubrick shot “Fear and Desire” (1953). It was shot primarily in the San Gabriel Mountains in California, not in Prospect Park in Brooklyn.
An article last Sunday about the movie “Taking Woodstock” misspelled the name of a New York town that rejected the festival. It is Wallkill, not Walkill.

''AN important chapter in our history has come to an end,'' Barack Obama said in his first public remarks on the death of Senator Edward M. Kennedy. ''Our country has lost a great leader, who picked up the torch of his fallen brothers and became the greatest United States senator of our time.'' What Mr. Obama didn't say -- and perhaps didn't need to -- was that the closed chapter was the vision of liberalism begun by the New Deal of Franklin D. Roosevelt, extended during the Great Society of Lyndon B. Johnson and now struggling back toward relevance. It holds that the forces of government should be marshaled to improve conditions for the greatest possible number of Americans, with particular emphasis on the excluded and disadvantaged. It is not government's only obligation, in this view, but it is the paramount one.

The suspicions and resentment had built to such a degree that the manager was compelled to call a most unusual team meeting. It was the middle of July 2001 and the Oakland Athletics' clubhouse was about to explode. A series of events on the field led several players to believe that the star shortstop Miguel Tejada had been helping friends on opposing teams by tipping off pitches and by allowing balls they hit to get past him occasionally during games with lopsided scores.

New York secretes its fullest range of smells in the summer; disgusting or enticing, delicate or overpowering, they are liberated by the heat. So one sweltering weekend, I set out to navigate the city by nose. As my nostrils led me from Manhattan's northernmost end to its southern tip, some prosaic scents recurred (cigarette butts; suntan lotion; fried foods); some were singular and sublime (a delicate trail of flowers mingling with Indian curry around 34th Street); while others proved revoltingly unique (the garbage outside a nail salon). Some smells reminded me of other places, and some will forever remind me of New York. FORT GEORGE, THE CLOISTERS

WITH the exception of the occasional role play, most sophisticated grown-ups have left their school accouterments behind. But not Piet Breinholm, a former drummer for the Berlin-based trio 18th Dye, who transformed the once-ubiquitous leather school bag used by Danish children into a chic unisex accessory called The Last Bag (above). It is made entirely in Denmark, and comes in two sizes and a range of school's-out colors: yellow, orange, emerald and color-block combinations. Laptops, cellphones and other trappings of mature homework all fit comfortably in this durable carryall that lives up to its name as the last bag you'll ever need; pietbreinholm.dk. ANA FINEL HONIGMAN

THIS is how fashion works: You have an emotional response to something and you just want it, no matter the cost. And the cost of this motorcycle jacket (right) by Rodarte is a lot. But I know I will wear it for years and even be able to pass it on to my daughter. After all, I still have my Schott black leather jacket from college, and I'm ready for the upgrade! $3,795 at Bergdorf Goodman, New York. ANNE CHRISTENSEN

THE NEWS Law firms have cut their recruitment of new lawyers so sharply that even at top law schools, students say they are having trouble getting interviews and are scrambling to find jobs in government or at public-interest groups, which typically pay much less than positions at private firms. BEHIND THE NEWS With their revenue eroded by the economic downturn, many firms deferred some of their 2008 hiring into 2009, leaving little room for new recruits this year. Universities like Yale, Georgetown and Northwestern say interviews are down by one-third to one-half, and some major firms say they are doing no recruiting at all this year as they rethink how they fill their ranks.

ALTHOUGH customer satisfaction studies have often given Toyota's RAV4 ''cute ute'' high marks for quality, some owners are furious at the automaker because it did not warn them of a serious transmission problem. Benjamin Birkbeck of Yarmouth, Me., who owns a 2002 RAV4, is one of those consumers. His wife, Rhonda, was trying to merge into traffic when a sudden transmission failure meant she was ''almost run over by a semi-truck,'' he wrote in a complaint on the Center for Auto Safety Web site. ''This is a safety issue. My wife was almost killed.''

For years Lorrie McNeill loved teaching ''To Kill a Mockingbird,'' the Harper Lee classic that many Americans regard as a literary rite of passage. But last fall, for the first time in 15 years, Ms. McNeill, 42, did not assign ''Mockingbird'' -- or any novel. Instead she turned over all the decisions about which books to read to the students in her seventh- and eighth-grade English classes at Jonesboro Middle School in this south Atlanta suburb.

ALTER--David, of New York, NY and Seaview, Fire Island, passed away on August 27, 2009. Born in Czechoslovakia on October 31, 1923, he was a graduate of Townsend Harris High School, City College of New York and Harvard Law School. A prominent entertainment industry labor attorney, he was Counsel to the Screen Actors Guild for four decades, past president of the Seaview Association, and founding member of the Board of Trustees of The Fire Island Synagogue. His brilliance, wisdom, dignity and strength were an inspiration to all who knew him. He will always be in the hearts of his beloved wife of 54 years, Deborah (King), his adoring daughters Lisa (Joel Confino) and Amy (Ken Ross), and his cherished grandchildren Arielle, Alexandra, Jordana and Clint. Services will be held Sunday, August 30, 11:45am, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, corner of 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in his memory can be made to The Parkinsons Disease Foundation, c/o Lucien J. Cote, MD, 1359 Broadway, Suite 1509, New York, NY 10018.

ROTHMAN--Esther, Ph.D.,of New York, NY; on August 28th, 2009. Esther put her heart, spirit and endless energy into bettering the lives of the disadvantaged through her life's work in education. She shared a deep love with and was entirely devoted to her lifelong husband and soul mate Arthur - who passed in 2002 - beloved daughter Amy, son-in-law Michael and grandsons Ellis and Jake and numerous other relatives, friends and colleagues.
