WHEN Gideon Rubin draws a blank, he is not befuddled. Rather, he is masking the face of a stranger whose photo he has found in a vintage album. He discovers these albums around the world, then paints sweet-looking portraits that evoke the innocence of a children's storybook, though his subjects have no faces. ''I paint from objects that have life and layers -- things that tell a story,'' said the 36-year-old London-based artist, whose grandfather is the Israeli painter Reuven Rubin and whose fashion-world fans include the designer Narciso Rodriguez. For ''Mexican Summer,'' his solo show Sept. 8 to Oct. 17 at the Hosfelt Gallery in San Francisco, Mr. Rubin painted a faceless European family living in a Mexican village around 1920. He was drawn to them, he said, because they felt out of place. ''I was inspired by what they were wearing, what they were doing, how the two cultures interacted with each other,'' he said. ''But mainly, I was inspired to paint the two kids, a brother and sister.'' KRISTOPHER HOUSER

THINK AGAIN If I have no problem with alternative ways of teaching literature or history, how can I maintain (with the American College of Trustees and Alumni) that there is only one way to teach writing? Easy. It can't be an alternative way of teaching writing to teach something else (like multiculturalism or social justice). It can, however, be an alternative way of teaching history to forgo a broad chronological narrative and confine yourself to a single period or even to a single world-changing event. It is the difference between not doing the job and getting the job done by another route. This difference is blurred in the ACTA report because it is running (and conflating) two arguments. One argument (with which I agree) says teach the subject matter and don't adulterate it with substitutes. The other argument says teach the subject matter so that it points in a particular ideological direction, the direction of traditional values and a stable canon. The first argument is methodological and implies no particular politics; the other is political through and through, and it is the argument the authors are finally committed to because they see themselves as culture warriors. The battle they are fighting in the report is over the core curriculum, the defense of which is for them a moral as well as an educational imperative, as it is for those who oppose it.

NEVAS--Leo. Nevas, Nevas, Capasse & Gerard mourns the loss of its beloved founder. He will be remembered for his brilliant legal mind as well as the impact he made on the lives of others through his many charitable endeavors. He will be greatly missed. We extend our condolences to the entire Nevas family.

KOREY--William. June 16, 1922 to August 26, 2009. Patriarch, scholar, human rights activist, professor, author and champion of the underdog, passed away at the age of 87. Bill had a great zest for life, for music, for laughter and for food. He raged against the dying of the light. He embodied the Talmudic principle that to save one life is to save the world, and thus he saved the world many times. Married for 54 years to Esther, who predeceased him, he leaves behind his loving family: daughters Alix (husband Randy Hansen) and Eileen (husband Robert Kaplan); grandchildren Rachel and Ben; nephews Arthur, Steve and Gil Bardige and their wonderful families; nieces Nikki Director and Susan Korey and their wonderful families; many friends and admirers, and his devoted companion for the last seven years, Diana Marx. A memorial service is planned for October 19th at the Center for Jewish History for those who wish to pay him tribute. He would be deeply touched to be remembered by name in contribution to B'nai B'rith International or the William Korey Fund at the American Jewish Historical Society.

ArtZuid, a quirky open-air exhibition, takes advantage of its location: the grassy arcade on the Minervalaan and the Apollolaan, a section of the Oud-Zuid (Amsterdam South) district with an abundant concentration of playful Art Nouveauarchitecture. The event is part of an effort by neighborhood residents to repurpose the streets of the district, which is also near the Museum Quarter. Anchoring the exhibition of large-scale pieces is a copy of what is possibly Auguste Rodin's most famous work. Framed between rows of trees that line the lanes is a recent cast of the 1902 bronze ''The Thinker.''

Teams from the New York City police and fire departments will play on Sunday at Giants Stadium in the first Mayor's Cup soccer game for charity. The match is scheduled to start at 2 p.m. Eastern as a preliminary to the Major League Soccer match between the Red Bulls (3-16-4, 13 points) and the Columbus Crew (10-3-9, 39). The game will benefit the Patrolman's Benevolent Association Widows and Children's Fund and the Firefighter Sergio Villanueva Soccer Foundation.

Texas Christian Coach Gary Patterson is more of a sideline savant than a ''Top Chef'' candidate. But Patterson, one of the foremost defensive minds in college football, resorted to a food analogy to describe the biggest problem facing defensive coaches in college football -- stopping the multitude of spread offenses. ''It's kind of like people cooking chili,'' Patterson said. ''Everybody's got their own recipe. Everybody loves chili, but some like it hot, some like it meaty, some like it with more tomato sauce. There's a hundred thousand million ways to cook chili. You've just got to figure what their recipe is and what you're going to do to play against it.''

Independents The only one of these teams that has any real B.C.S. aspirations is Notre Dame, and the only thing making those aspirations possible is a schedule featuring two teams that finished in the Top 25 last season. And both those games (Michigan State and Southern California) are in South Bend. The Irish will be dangerous on offense with Jimmy Clausen. He will be throwing to a group of quality receivers, led by Michael Floyd and Golden Tate. Most of the offensive line returns, which could help make the running game more consistent. On defense, the secondary will have to be strong in order to give the front time to gel. Notre Dame may not be beating U.S.C. in October, but if the pieces fall into place, the Irish could make a run at a B.C.S. bowl. At Navy, Coach Ken Niumatalolo helped the Midshipmen win their sixth consecutive Commander-in-Chief's Trophy -- and go to a sixth straight bowl game -- in his first season last year. Quarterback Ricky Dobbs will be leading the triple-option attack, always one of the most prolific offenses in the country. Coach Rich Ellerson takes over at Army, where he has installed the double-eagle flex defense (which he popularized at Arizona) to take advantage of his team's speed and aggressiveness. Still, expect a 13th straight losing season.

FOX--Betty D.,of East Hampton, NY, died suddenly on August 27, 2009 of complications from a fall in April of this year. She is survived by her life partner, Joyce Whitby and their son Duong Fox, who deeply mourn her loss. A former broadcast executive and radio station owner, she was a real estate broker in NYC and East Hampton for the last 25 years. She was a graduate of both Hunter College High School and Hunter College (1954); to both of which she was a devoted alumna recognized for her service. Contributions may be made in her name for breast cancer research. Memorial to be announced at a later date.

EICHBAUM--Ulryk, 96, died on August 26. Born in Przemysl and raised in Katowice, Poland, he attended university in Vienna where he spoke Polish, German, French, English, and competed as a Grand Prix auto racer, driving for Team Citroen before WWII forced him to flee. Ulryk embraced life and savored adventure, competition and conquest. He was passionate about cars, tennis and family. On September 1, 1939 when Germany bombed and invaded Poland, Ulryk instinctively escaped with his wife, Saree, driving to Rumania minutes before advancing German troops closed the Polish border. Only 26 years old, he navigated the chaos of Europe, miraculously obtained a visa to the US, and secured passage from Genoa, Italy on the Saturnia. They arrived in New York Harbor on Columbus Day 1939, homeless and penniless. From Ellis Island they were thrust into the Bronx, where Ulryk found work cleaning toilets. He found distant relatives in Woodbridge, NJ who owned a dairy farm and moved again. In 1940, he succeeded in what he considered his life's biggest accomplishment: Ulryk secured his parents' safe passage out of Poland and entry to Dominican Republic until he obtained their visas to enter the US in 1941. He worked hard and played hard, driving a milk truck to make pre-dawn home deliveries, and playing tennis in the afternoons at the public courts in Perth Amboy. He later turned his passion for cars into a business. In 1954 he became the first Chevrolet dealer in Middlesex County, NJ. After 42 years of owning June Chevrolet, he retired at age 84 and moved from Metuchen, NJ to Boca Raton, FL. Ulryk was predeceased by Saree, his wife of 65 years, and is survived by his daughter, June Eichbaum and son-in-law, Ken Wirfel and grandchildren, Hannah and Mikhaila Wirfel.

While this season's rookie class may not have anyone with 49 home runs like Mark McGwire in 1987, or a player challenging for the Most Valuable Player award like Fred Lynn in 1975 and Ichiro Suzuki in 2001, it does feature an All-Star (Andrew Bailey of the Athletics), a key member of a leading rotation (J. A. Happ of the Phillies) and a July call-up that has put on a power display (Garrett Jones of the Pirates). A look at the race for the Rookie of the Year reveals that a pitcher leads each league.

To Lisbon With Baby in Tow We plan to visit Lisbon in September with our baby, who will then be 1 year old. We'd like to stay for around five days so we can see many of the historical decorative arts sites. We like staying in colorful, old neighborhoods but have not attempted this usual mode with a baby. Do you have any tips for Lisbon with a baby? -- Anna Miles, Auckland, New Zealand

KENNEDY--Edward M. The Modern Language Association mourns the loss of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, whose dedication to higher education and the humanities enriched our nation. The MLA recognized his exemplary work in 2003 with the first Phyllis Franklin Award for Public Advocacy of the Humanities.

The huge swell brought to New York-area beaches by Hurricane Bill last weekend is a happy memory to local surfers. But it claimed the life of Andrew J. Nathanson, 51, a semiretired financier and novice surfer who was in the shore break in East Quogue on Aug. 21 as the storm's first powerful sets arrived. Mr. Nathanson is survived by his wife, Elyse, and three children -- Brian, 19, Alison, 17, and Kevin, 14 -- who have spent the last week wrestling with the pain but finding some solace in that he died doing something he loved.

Four hundred years ago, in his search to discover a Northwest Passage, Henry Hudson explored the river that now bears his name. This summer, Corey Kilgannon of The Times set out to retrace Hudson's trip on his own journey upstream. On the left are excerpts from a journal kept by Robert Jouet, a member of Hudson's crew; on the right, the details of Mr. Kilgannon's adventure. Start from the bottom, as the explorers did. Henry Hudson's River

Last week, budget offices of the White House and Congress increased their projection of federal deficits over the next decade. The White House argued that an overhaul of the health care system is essential because the rising deficit ''is driven primarily by escalating health care costs.'' The Congressional Budget Office estimates that spending on Medicare and Medicaid -- driven by the aging population and the rapid growth of per capita health care costs -- will account for most of the projected growth in primary federal spending for the next 25 years.

Fred Kinne's memorial service earlier this month was like his life -- lots of stories about his exploits as a World War II fighter pilot and as a newspaper editor whose reporters won a Pulitzer Prize for deadline coverage of a 1978 airplane crash. But most speakers wanted to talk about Kinne's remarkable feat in tennis. Between 1952 and 1981, when he retired, he taught an estimated 7,000 youngsters to play tennis -- at no charge.
He was not perfect, but my father believed in redemption. And he never surrendered. EDWARD M. KENNEDY JR., at his father's funeral. [A14]

COHEN--Gerald, New York City, passed away on August 20th in his 76th year. A dedicated New York City public school teacher for over three decades, Gerald spent most of his career at Taft High School in the Bronx. He is the immediate past President of the Mount Sinai Jewish Center, where he was active for over 40 years. He was a loving husband, father and grandfather, and is survived by his wife Eva, his sons and daughters-in-law, Eric, Hugh, David, Judy and Susan, and his grandchildren, Griffin, Sam, Lily, Holden, and Jeremy. Donations in his memory may be made to the Mount Sinai Jewish Center in New York City, or to the Rabbinical School of Hebrew College in Newton, MA.

Atlantic Coast Although play will improve throughout the league, the A.C.C. is still looking for that one dominant team that can contend for a national title. Just when it seemed like Virginia Tech could assume that role, it lost running back Darren Evans (1,265 yards as a freshman) to a torn anterior cruciate ligament. Even with Evans on the sideline, the Hokies are still the team to beat. Quarterback Tyrod Taylor seems poised for a breakout season. The Hokies also have a typically nasty defense led by end Jason Worilds and cornerback Stephan Virgil. Virginia Tech faces Alabama (in Atlanta) and hosts Nebraska in the first three weeks of the season. How the Hokies do in those games will speak to where the conference stands. Georgia Tech running back Jonathan Dwyer is a Heisman candidate in Paul Johnson's dangerous spread-option attack. Miami finished one game back in the division last season and ought to be better this year. North Carolina might be a season away from competing for a title. In the Atlantic Division, quarterback Christian Ponder and a veteran offensive line make Florida State the favorite. North Carolina State quarterback Russell Wilson is one of the most exciting players in the nation.

THREE YIDDISH THEATRES GAVE IN TO DEMANDS of the Hebrew Trades Unions and were able to reopen, to the delight of their audiences. ''The unions demanded that the companies should engage a certain number of actors, whether they were used or not,'' a New York Times article says. ''They demanded that the musicians in the orchestra should be paid $27 instead of $25. They demanded that the bill posters should be paid for posting bills, whether the companies used posters or not.'' The People's reopened with a new play, Leon Kobrin's ''Who Is Guilty?'' while the Lipzen and the Thalia offered Jacob Gordin revivals, respectively ''Mirele Efroth'' and ''The Kreutzer Sonata.'' Jacob Adler, still holding out, was expected to reopen his theater ''in a week or so.'' --The New York Times http://timestraveler.blogs.nytimes.com

DANIELEY--Katie L.,Javits Center Mainstay, 1956-2009. Katie Danieley, Director of Public Safety at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center for the past fifteen years, died on August 26th at her home in New York City. Ms. Danieley, who worked her way up through the ranks from an administrative aid to her director's position, was highly regarded in the convention industry for ensuring that the Javits' many large shows ran safely and smoothly. Following the 9/11 attacks, she converted the Javits into a command center for rescue and recovery operations. Katie was loved and respected for her dedication, compassion, and loyalty. Ms. Danieley, who grew up in California's San Fernando Valley, is survived by her son Kenneth Martin, daughter Megan Danieley, two sisters Barbara and Patsy Jones, and nephew Alexander.

For months, the e-mail messages between Kim Clijsters and Lindsay Davenport consisted of baby pictures. Clijsters fawned over Davenport's son, Jagger, and Davenport oohed and aahed at Clijsters's daughter, Jada. But earlier this year, the messages took on a different tone. Suddenly, Clijsters began asking for advice that few new mothers need: would it be difficult to return to professional tennis? And would the WTA Tour welcome her? Davenport, who had returned to the tour a few month after giving birth in June 2007, assured Clijsters that she had nothing to worry about.

Every season, college football treats its fans to a number of intriguing nonconference games in the first two weeks of the season. These games will not only have an impact on the national title race, but they will give some of the smaller conferences a chance to make an early statement that they belong in the Bowl Championship Series conversation. All rankings are from the Associated Press poll. THURSDAY

Conference USA The league's B.C.S. hopes are centered on Houston and East Carolina, but both are extreme long shots. Houston has the better chance of the two, though its offense will need to outscore both Oklahoma State and Texas Tech in nonconference play, a tall order. Houston's biggest rival in the West division is Tulsa, whose deep receiver corps is the best in the conference. Damaris Johnson, for example, has the potential to lead the Golden Hurricane in both receiving and rushing. Texas-El Paso will welcome back safety Braxton Amy, who missed last season after tearing his anterior cruciate ligament. His presence will boost a questionable defense. Southern Methodist could take a big step forward in June Jones's second season, but the Mustangs still appear a year away from challenging for the West division crown. East Carolina won the league last season coming out of the East division, but will be tested by Southern Mississippi. The Golden Eagles have a rising star in wide receiver DeAndre Brown. Memphis has been nothing if not consistent, winning at least six games in five of the last six seasons, and this season will be no different. Alabama-Birmingham and Central Florida will battle for the third spot in the division. For U.C.F. Coach George O'Leary, it may be a bowl trip or bust.

BERNSTEIN--Peter L. A Memorial Service for Peter L. Bernstein will be held on: September 15, 2009 at 4pm Merkin Hall, 129 West 67th St. Contributions should be made to: Peter L. Bernstein Memorial Fund, Williams College Development Office, Vogt House, 75 Park St., Williamstown, MA 01267.

NEED to be reminded that you are buying a General Motors vehicle? G.M. apparently no longer thinks you do. So it is removing the ''G.M. Mark of Excellence'' logos from all of its Chevrolet, Buick, Cadillac and GMC models. The logo had been a fixture on all G.M. vehicles since 2005.

SIMONS--Barry. Internationally renowned artist, Barry Simons, died on August 18th, 2009 after a brief illness. His surviving family members, sister Stephanie and her husband Seth Alpert, were at his side. Simons' drawings and paintings had a stream of conscious element. They were often informed by the lyrical riffs of a jazz musician, or of an improvisational poet, incorporating Simons multiple creative talents. Like the blues that he loved, his palette was dark and moody, with explosions of color. He displayed a felicitous genius for accidental events: a coffee spill, ink blot, bits of detritus, phone bill, a paper cup or cigarette butt could each be reconfigured and incorporated into his drawings. Barry Simons struggled with accepting his great success. He had said he was on a "quest to release the visionary artist I felt living inside me. So far, the journey has led me through many rented rooms and coffee shops. I'm still looking for that one free refill of coffee with a picture of Rembrandt on the napkin." His work is included in numerous private collections, and in The Oakland Museum of California, The International Folk Art Museum of Santa Fe, The Milwaukee Art Museum, and Intuit: The Center for Intuitive and Outsider Art in Chicago. On August 21st, a graveside service was held for Barry, with family and friends in attendance. The setting was perfect and he would have reveled in knowing how many were gathered to say, "Farewell", and send him on his journey. He will be missed. His friends at The Ames Gallery, Bonnie & Sy Grossman, Karen Frerichs and Sherry Bloom

Michael Mazur, a relentlessly inventive printmaker, painter and sculptor whose work encompassed social documentation, narrative and landscape while moving back and forth between figuration and abstraction, died on Aug. 18 in Cambridge, Mass. He was 73 and lived in Cambridge and Provincetown, Mass. The cause was congestive heart failure, said Mary Ryan, his New York dealer.

GRASS--Alexander. On behalf of the Board of Trustees and the staff of the National Museum of American Jewish History, we express our deepest sympathy on the passing of Alexander Grass, a member of our Board of Trustees. As an active philanthropist and community leader, Alex's contributions to the National Museum of American Jewish History were a wonderful reflection of his commitment to the history and the future of the American Jewish experience. Alex was immensely valued, and his counsel and ardent support will be very much missed by those of us who had the privilege to work with him. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his family. George M. Ross and Ronald Rubin, Co-Chairmen of the Board of Trustees Michael Rosenzweig, President and CEO

One of summer's surprising successes is the long daytime dress. Its before-dark appearance calls to mind a remark made by the California designer Rudi Gernreich on a visit to New York in 1970. Then, the miniskirt was at its height, and Courrèges's space-age dressing was avant-garde, and Mr. Gernreich exclaimed: ''They're wearing their evening dresses in the daytime in New York!'' Mr. Gernreich, known for the topless bathing suit, was all about freeing women for modern life, and ankle-length skirts were not his idea of liberating design. But this summer proved once again that the customer is the ultimate judge of what passes for fashion, and this year, she is in a romantic mood. Many of the dresses are in fluid jersey or cotton. Prints abound, and there is a strong trend for bold bands of color, and of course, black. Belts are rare, but a taxicab-yellow cinch stood out.
CHENG--Jundy. The Board of Trustees and staff of China Institute express their deepest sorrow at the passing of Jundy Cheng, and extend their heartfelt sympathy to the family of Anla Cheng Kingdon.

As part of the cast of Spike TV's reality show this fall, ''The Ultimate Fighter,'' the former professional football players Marcus Jones, Matt Mitrione, Brendan Schaub and Wes Shivers will compete for a chance to fight in the Ultimate Fighting Championship. If you don't remember these guys, you're probably not alone. Mitrione, a backup defensive lineman for the Giants, left the N.F.L. because of injuries. Shivers played a season at offensive tackle for Atlanta, and Schaub, a fullback, never left the Buffalo Bills' practice squad. Jones, 36, a former first-round draft pick, had 13 sacks in 2000 as a defensive end for the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. But he left the N.F.L. in 2003 because of injuries. He had planned to take two years off to heal and then return. But one night, roughly two years ago, while hanging out with friends from college and talking about the U.F.C., Jones and his friends cleared out the living room furniture and began to spar. ''I was a big guy who had never thrown a punch,'' he said.

Most of this city's modern apartment buildings have pools, but sadly, most of its hotels do not. So if you feel the urge to get wet, you can either make friends with a resident or grab your bathing suit and head to Casa de Campo, the city's largest park, where one of the city's most luxurious public pool complexes spreads out over several acres. The ambience at the Centro Municipal Deportivo Casa de Campo (Paseo Puerta del Angel 7; 34-91-463-0050) has more in common with a university aquatics center than one of those urban ''beaches'' of sizzling concrete and chain-link fence. At Campo, towering cypress and cedar trees shade some of the grassy knolls where visitors spread their towels to take a siesta between laps or after lunch.

TRUE art cannot be encompassed in a handbag, no matter how oversize or over-embellished. This is something Louis Vuitton has always understood, ingratiating itself in the lives of artists for the last 155 years. The resulting collaborations are detailed in Rizzoli's forthcoming megatome, ''Louis Vuitton: Art, Fashion and Architecture'' ($85). Beyond high-profile partnerships with the likes of Richard Prince and Takashi Murakami, what ''Art, Fashion and Architecture'' reveals are 80 lesser-known folies à deux. That would include the minimalist Sol LeWitt, who designed silk scarves (left) in the 1980s; the architect Jun Aoki, whose brilliant Tokyo stores (the one in the Ginza is at right) risk eclipsing the contents inside; and the provocateur Vanessa Beecroft, whose naked performance piece was staged for a Vuitton flagship's grand opening on the Champs-Élysées. Ars longa, indeed. AMY THOMAS

THE jeweler du jour Eddie Borgo's obsession with 1970s and '80s rock and the icons who populated it -- Mick, Bowie, Siouxsie et al. -- have made his tough-love cuffs and spiky necklaces a favorite of stylish women. And, it turns out, men. ''We kept getting requests for one-off men's items,'' he said. ''Especially the bear-trap ring -- everyone wanted that one. Then the designer Joseph Altuzarra requested one, and I decided it was time to start a men's collection.'' Beginning this week, select items from Mr. Borgo's new man-jewels line, including the much in-demand ring, will be available on his Web site, eddieborgo.com. WOODS--Richard W.,of Sharon, CT and New York City peacefully passed away on Sunday, August 23rd after a brief battle with cancer, he was age 77. Born and raised in Bridgeport, CT, Richard was a long time resident of Fire Island Pines, and was co-founder of the Woods & Jay company in Long Island City. Known for his wonderfully dry wit and his piercing blue eyes, Richard will be sorely missed. Richard is survived by his life partner of 43 years George, whom he recently married, his brother Bill, sister in law Linda, nephew Brian and many dear friends. Donations in Richard's memory may be made to the Melanoma Research Foundation.

DOMNITCH--Irving, passed away peacefully at the age of 97 on August 26, 2009. He was the cherished husband of Henrietta Domnitch for 62 years; father to Marilyn Metz and Karen Domnitch; brother of Harold Domnitch; grandfather of Justin Metz, Devon Metz, Jonathan Marmon, and Eryn Marmon Dolan; and great-grandfather to Luc Ryder Metz. He lived his life with strength, courage, and humor, surrounded by his family and friends. His determination, generosity, and spirit will be profoundly missed. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be sent to the charity of your choice.

NEVAS--Leo. The Jacob Blaustein Institute for the Advancement of Human Rights of the American Jewish Committee deeply mourns the loss of Leo Nevas, its former Chair and devoted Steering Committee member. As JBI's elder statesman for freedom, Leo championed human rights for all with wisdom, fairness, and pragmatism. He brought remarkable leadership, conviction and strategy to JBI's work. His support for human rights defenders worldwide, including Andrei Sakharov, Helen Suzman, and Aung Sang Suu Kyi, was savvy and selfless. Demanding an end to UN bias against Israel, Leo nonetheless called for universal rights to be a core pillar of the UN's work. Leo Nevas offered a model of what personal responsibility, commitment, and the pursuit of justice for all can achieve, and his memory is a blessing. Sincerest condolences to his family members. E. Robert Goodkind, Chair Barbara Blaustein Hirschhorn Michael Hirschhorn Felice Gaer, Director

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended Saturday, August 15th 2009, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount and department stores; and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Among those categories not actively tracked are: perennial sellers; required classroom reading; text, reference and test preparation guides; journals and workbooks; calorie counters; shopping guides; comics; and crossword puzzles. More than 40 years after the guitarist Brian Jones, a founding member of the Rolling Stones, was found dead at the bottom of his swimming pool, British police have said they will reexamine the case after receiving new information from an investigative journalist, Reuters reported. Jones, a bohemian blues musician who helped create the Rolling Stones in 1962 (and is said to have come up with the group’s name, taken from the Muddy Waters song “Rollin’ Stone Blues”), was found dead on July 3, 1969, at a home in East Sussex that once belonged to A. A. Milne. At that time, Jones had recently left the band, and a coroner’s report gave the official cause for his demise as “death by misadventure,” though subsequent films and books (including “The Murder of Brian Jones” by Anna Wohlin, a girlfriend of Jones who was with him when he died) have suggested that foul play was involved. British officials did not say what new information they had received or who had given it to them. But a spokesman for the Sussex police told Reuters, “These papers will be examined by Sussex Police but it is too early to comment at this time on what the outcome will be.”Read The New York Times’s original report on the death of Brian Jones from July 3, 1969. (pdf)

After you’ve grown tired of intellectual engagement and civil discourse, the motion picture industry is making sure there will be plenty of gun-toting action heroes populating the cineplexes when you want to switch your brain to the off position.Variety reported that a fifth installment in Sylvester Stallone‘s long-running “Rambo” series has been given the green light by the studios Nu Image and Millennium Films. The new film will be directed by and star Mr. Stallone as the one-man killing machine John Rambo, as he fights human traffickers and drug lords while attempting to rescue a kidnapped girl. The previous “Rambo” movie, released in 2008, earned $42 million in domestic ticket sales and $113 million overseas.

A day after Noel Gallagher (sort of) stunned fans with his announcement that he was quitting the popular British rock band Oasis, Mr. Gallagher explained his departure to fans in a statement on the group’s official Web site, oasisinet.com, Agence France-Press reported. In the statement, Mr. Gallagher, the group’s lead guitarist and main songwriter, said that he had been “forced to leave” Oasis, adding that “the level of verbal and violent intimidation towards me, my family, friends and comrades has become intolerable” and “the lack of support and understanding from my management and band mates” left him with no other option. Mr. Gallagher announced his departure from the band in a brief statement that was issued on Friday night, just before Oasis was to perform at the Rock en Seine festival near Paris. Concert organizers said at the time that Mr. Gallagher had fought with his brother, Liam, the group’s lead singer, with whom he has had a notoriously stormy relationship over the band’s 18-year run.
There is life after the Fringe Festival.

Book lovers who were hoping for a decisive showdown between the authors Alice Munro and Margaret Atwood in the Scotiabank Giller Prize, the annual Canadian literary award, were disappointed when Ms. Munro said she did not want to be considered for the prize this year, The Globe and Mail reported. Ms. Munro, whose new short story collection “Too Much Happiness” was seen as a likely nominee for the prize, said she was withdrawing the book from consideration because she has won it twice before, for her collections “The Love of a Good Woman” (in 1998) and “Runaway” (in 2004). Douglas Gibson, whose Douglas Gibson Books imprint releases Ms. Munro’s work in Canada, told The Globe and Mail: “In my role as greedy publisher I pointed out that the Giller Prize produces so much publicity, that even to be nominated for it is tremendous publicity. But her mind is made up on this.” The Giller Prize, of about $45,000, is awarded annually to a Canadian work of fiction; the longlist of nominees for the 2009 prize will be announced on Oct. 6. “Too Much Happiness” is to be released in the United States in November.

It used to be that watermelon was for backyard cookouts and Bubblicious. Then, in 1997, Jean-Georges Vongerichten changed life for the pepo (how botanists refer to the fruit) when he introduced a deceptively simple appetizer at Nougatine: a scaffold built of alternating watermelon and goat-cheese beams, sprinkled with fleur de sel, white pepper and olive oil. Still, the oafish melon remained virtually untouched as a savory option until 2005, when Zak Pelaccio opened Fatty Crab with an unforgettable salad of cubed watermelon and crispy pork belly with Vietnamese mint, Thai basil, shallots and, on the side, a bit of pickled rind.

It's one of the most ubiquitous labels in the world, and perhaps no company understands those implications better than Louis Vuitton. Last Friday, a California district court jury awarded $32.4 million in damages to Vuitton as part of a 2007 suit the Paris luxury maker brought against Akanoc Solutions, an Internet hosting company based in California. Vuitton argued that Akanoc should have known that various sites were selling counterfeit LV merchandise. Last year, in a French court, Vuitton won a $63 million judgment against eBay for its role in selling LV fakes. The online auctioneer has said it tries to police counterfeits and remove them from the site. It sounds as though juries don't think that's enough.

As much as I adore reality TV, even I sometimes have to wonder how much participants are playing to the camera. Last week, I had the chance to sit down with two cast members of "Flipping Out" (Bravo, Tuesdays at 10 p.m.), and I'm happy to say they are exactly as they seem on the show. Which is to say, completely nutty and sympathetic and fascinating all at once. "Flipping Out" chronicles the life and work of Jeff Lewis, who, in Seasons 1 and 2, renovated properties and then sold them at a profit but, in Season 3, thanks to the economic downturn, is now consulting clients on their renovations. Part of the hook of the show is that Lewis is detail-orientated about his business and his life to the point of obsession and of being a total terror to his employees. There's his long-suffering assistant, Jenni Pulos; his long-suffering housekeeper, Zoila Chavez; and his just-joined-the-team design intern, Trace Lehnhoff. The jury is still out on how long he's going to suffer.In person, Lewis is personable and has a great sense of humor, but he is also exacting, the sort of person I would want as a therapist or a personal trainer. He ordered an Arnold Palmer (half iced tea and half lemonade) and even tried it with pink lemonade after the waitress had to adjust his order. Most of the jokes revolved around the newly single Jenni, though he did note how strange it was to go from talking business with CNN to talking Botox with Wendy Williams. Pulos is absolutely charming, sweet and funny, and she made me wish I had someone worthy for her to date. Alas, that first meeting is now lost to a faulty tape recorder, but Lewis and crew were kind enough to answer some questions over email.

The easterly wave I mentioned on Friday has still not been upgraded to a Depression or Storm, but certainly looks like a weak Tropical Storm on satellite imagery. It is now located about 600 miles east of the southern Leeward Islands and heading WNW at 12kts. Nearly every computer model forecasts it to intensify to a hurricane by mid-late week. SSTs in its path are 28-29C, and vertical wind shear is minimal (and expected to remain so for several days). The next name on the list is Erika.

This week, John F. Burns, The Times's chief foreign correspondent, will be taking questions on America's military allies and rising skepticism about the war in Afghanistan. July saw the departure of the last of America's allies in Iraq, down from 38 countries who were in at the start six years ago during the 2003 invasion. Many of those nations signed up for Iraq with barely-disguised reluctance, but have tended to regard the Afghan conflict more favorably because of the Taliban's willingness to host Al Qaeda after 9/11.

Greenpoint, a neighborhood lined with the bones of industry and infused with a rich Polish heritage, has avoided much of the tumult that churns neighboring Williamsburg. Greenpoint's main commercial drag, Manhattan Avenue, is still a village high street, lined with Polish bookstores, cafes and meat markets. Even nearby Franklin Street, a trendy stripe of restaurants and bars, manages to feel sleepy. For now at least, Greenpoint's stunning views of Manhattan are still mostly clear, unobstructed by the kinds of high-rise developments that are starting to sprout -- and wither -- in Williamsburg.

DATAROCK ''Red'' (Nettwerk) A handful of songs into its second album Datarock gets down to brass tacks. ''Dancing is/Everything,'' insists the band's lead singer, Fredrik Saroea, drawing out the phrase against a glittery disco groove. The track's lyrical tone -- ''Dance!'' is its emphatic title -- feels at once deliberate and absurd. And so, for that matter, does the rest of the album.

David was highly regarded and respected for his wisdom, integrity and service to our community. WHITNEY HOUSTON ''I Look to You'' (Arista) Without adversity, a diva is just a singer. It's the back story, the tale of struggle and tenacity, that draws audiences to read more than musicianship into her performances. The singer touches on something personal so the listener can feel like a witness, a confidant, a judge, a voyeur, or perhaps all at once. Seven years after her last album of pop songs, two years after her divorce, Whitney Houston re-emerges with full diva qualifications on ''I Look to You,'' released Monday. Most of its revelations aren't verbal; they're in the husky, vehement sound of her voice.

Just days after France and Switzerland signed a new tax treaty, a French government official said the authorities had achieved a breakthrough in obtaining Swiss bank account data in an effort to catch tax cheats. ''We have obtained the names of 3,000 Swiss bank account holders, of which a part very probably corresponds to tax evasion,'' said Eric Woerth, France's budget minister, in an interview published Sunday by the weekly newspaper Le Journal du Dimanche.

ALBERT--Bernard L. We are deeply saddened by the passing of Bernard L. Albert, he died peacefully in Santa Barbara, CA on August 25, 2009 at the age of 90. He served in the US Army during WWII, graduated from New York University Undergraduate program and New York University Graduate program with a degree in law. He practiced as a attorney in New Jersey for 42 years and also as an arbitrator. He served as a law instructor at Fairleigh Dickinson University, was active as a volunteer in the Heart Association of New Jersey, the NAACP of New Jersey, and a life member of the ACLU. He leaves his wife Jean Albert (nee Berman), a daughter Amy Albert from his first marriage and three stepchildren Alan, David and Susan Levin, as well as five grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. A private service for the family was held on Thursday, August 27.

LASDON--Rand M. With great love and sadness the family of Rand Lasdon mourns his passing. His kindness and wisdom will be missed by many. A service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue on Wednesday September 2nd at 1pm.

Google plans to begin offering online loan quotes as early as September, a lawsuit filed in federal court last week claimed. The suit was filed by LendingTree, which offers consumers mortgage quotes and conditional loan offers online, against Mortech, a company that provides some of the technology that powers the LendingTree service. Google is not a party to the case. But according to the complaint, filed in United States District Court for the Western District of North Carolina, Mortech plans to make its technology available to Google, which, in turn, plans to release a service to compete with LendingTree. The complaint alleges that would be a violation of a contract between LendingTree and Mortech.

SHIMAMOTO--Yoshio, a nuclear physicist who also did work in mathematics and computer science, died August 27, 2009 at Franklin Care Center in Franklin Park, New Jersey. In 1971, Dr. Shimamoto presented a proof of the Four Color Theorem that was subsequently shown to be flawed, but still served as the basis for Ph.D. theses and other works at Harvard, Princeton, Waterloo, and the University of Illinois. Born in Honolulu, Hawaii, in 1924, Dr. Shimamoto served during World War II with the Army Signal Corps in Washington, DC, and the U.S. Strategic Bombing Survey in Japan. Following graduate studies at Harvard and the University of Rochester, he joined the Reactor Department at Brookhaven National Laboratory in 1954 and went on to work in the Nuclear Engineering Department and Applied Mathematics Division there. In 1958, he was responsible for the logical design of Brookhaven's MERLIN digital computer. From 1964 to 1975, Dr. Shimamoto served as chairman of the Applied Mathematics Department at Brookhaven, responsible for management of research in mathematics and computer science. In this capacity, he also managed the laboratory's central scientific computing facility and oversaw the funding, procurement, and development of a laboratory-wide computer network. After resigning as chairman at the end of the first year of a third five-year term, Shimamoto devoted himself to research in combinatorial mathematics, the economics of Outer Continental Shelf oil and gas lease sales (on behalf of the U.S. Geological Survey), the architecture of supercomputers, and the linking of computers for parallel processing. During his tenure at Brookhaven, Dr. Shimamoto held concurrent appointments with the University of Illinois; the U.S. Atomic Energy Commission's Mathematics and Computer Science Research Advisory Committee; the Technische Universitat in Hannover, West Germany; the Universitat Karlsruhe, West Germany; and the University of Tokyo. In 1972, he received the Senior Scientist Award from the Alexander von Humboldt-Stiftung, a non-profit organization that promotes cooperation in international research. Dr. Shimamoto retired in 1987. Dr. Shimamoto is survived by his wife, Kimie, of Skillman, NJ; a daughter, Kiyomi Camp, of Belle Mead, NJ; a son, Ken, of Fort Worth, Texas; six grandchildren, five great-grandchildren, and brother Frank Shimamoto of Naples, FL.

DALE--Frances (nee Bingham). Age 93, died on August 26 at the Village Nursing Home in Manhattan. Daughter of composer and organist Seth Bingham, and his wife Blanche, she was born and raised in Manhattan, where she attended Horace Mann & Lincoln Schools and Barnard College where she majored in Italian, graduating Phi Beta Kappa. She had a distinguished career in Public Relations, working for the French Line, the NY Public Library, the American Scandinavian Foundation, the Girl Scouts of America, the Travelers Aid Association, and the NYC Mission Society, among others. In her later years she reviewed books for Publisher's Weekly. For the last seven years, she resided at the Midway Nursing Ilome, where she was cared for with much compassion while Alzheimer's diminished her life. Her daughter, Patricia Bingham Dale of Manhattan, as well as nieces Diana Bingham Earley of Chicago, Rosalind Bingham Smith of Maryland, and many great-nieces and nephews survive her. There will be a memorial service at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University at a date to be announced. Contributions may be sent to the International Rescue Committee and the Seth Bingham Scholarship Fund c/o American Guild of Organists.

Several years ago, David Nieman set out to study racers at the Western States Endurance Run, a 100-mile test of human stamina held annually in the Sierra Nevada Mountains of California. The race directors had asked Nieman, a well-regarded physiologist and director of the Human Performance Laboratory at the North Carolina Research Campus, to look at the stresses that the race places on the bodies of participants. Nieman and the race authorities had anticipated that the rigorous distance and altitude would affect runners’ immune systems and muscles, and they did. But one of Nieman’s other findings surprised everyone.

Barefoot runners have caught the attention of shoe giants and upstart companies, The New York Times reports, with many offering thin-sole designs that give the feel of barefoot running but with a layer of protection to protect the feet from scrapes, splinters and sharp rocks. Training methods like ChiRunning and the Pose Method as well as the best-selling book “Born to Run” also have fueled interest in the barefoot experience.

The Oscar process is clearly still in process. On Monday, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said its decision last June to double the number of best picture nominees to 10 brings with it a change in voting method.

Good news for Muslims in Malaysia, at least those who are fans of the Black Eyed Peas: concert organizers said that they could attend a coming performance by the band, after previously stating that the show was open only to non-Muslims, Agence France-Presse reported. A Web site for the concert, which is being held on Sept. 25 near Kuala Lumpur to celebrate the 250th anniversary of the Guinness brewery in Dublin, had said that “the party is only open to non-Muslims aged 18 years and above,” and Malaysia’s Ministry of Information, Communication and Culture had said that Muslims could not attend. Of Malaysia’s 25 million people, 60 percent are Muslims; Islamic law forbids the consumption of alcohol. But the concert’s promoters, Artists World Entertainment, said in a statement that the event was now “open to all individuals aged 18 and above,” according to Agence France-Presse. No immediate reason for the change was given, though the original plan to bar Muslims from the show drew widespread attention and criticism.

Though you’ll never see Johnny Cash, Jerry Lee Lewis, Carl Perkins and Elvis Presley reunite on this plane of existence, a Broadway show that brings them together may be the next best thing. On Tuesday, the producers of the musical “Million Dollar Quartet” said that they planned to bring their show, based on a 1956 recording session that brought that famous foursome together at Sun Records in Memphis, to Broadway in the spring.

While the Walt Disney Company was busy snapping up Marvel Entertainment, 20th Century Fox was touching up its own movie franchise based on a long-running Marvel Comics series. Variety reported that Fox has hired Akiva Goldsman to oversee a new movie about the Fantastic Four, the costumed adventure team made up of Mr. Fantastic, the Invisible Woman, the Human Torch and the Thing. Mr. Goldsman (whose screenwriting credits include “Hancock” and “Angels & Demons”) will produce the new film, and Michael Green (a co-executive producer of “Heroes”) will write the screenplay. Fox previously released two “Fantastic Four” films in 2005 and 2007 whose casts include Jessica Alba, Michael Chiklis and Julian McMahon, but it was unclear if any of these actors would be involved in the new film. The Variety report said that, despite the Marvel-Disney deal, Fox continues to control film rights for Marvel properties like the Fantastic Four, X-Men and Daredevil.

The Allentown Art Museum in Pennsylvania has received the art collection of the modernist artist Peter Grippe, including his own works as well as art by Alexander Calder, Willem de Kooning, Franz Kline and others, The Allentown Morning Call reported. Grippe, a Cubist-inspired sculptor and printmaker who died in 2002, had accumulated the collection of more than 500 works in his Long Island home and studio and New York City apartment. It was donated to the museum by his wife, Florence, who had previously worked with its executive director, Greg Perry, at the Zimmerli Art Museum at Rutgers University. Though Grippe’s sculptures, drawings and prints form the bulk of the collection, it also includes rare items like the portfolio “21 Etchings and Poems,” which contains work by Frank O’Hara, Dylan Thomas and de Kooning. The Morning Call also said that a fund would be established for the museum in honor of Peter and Florence Grippe.

As part of its 2010-11 season dedicated to the work of the playwright Tony Kushner, the Signature Theater Company will mount the first New York revival of his “Angels in America” since the Pulitzer Prize- and Tony Award-winning work closed on Broadway in 1994, the troupe’s artistic director said this afternoon.

The 1960s will continue through at least 2010: to the surprise of absolutely no one, “Mad Men,” the hit AMC period drama about a New York advertising agency, has been picked up for a fourth season, the cable channel said Tuesday in a news release. The show, which has been the cornerstone of AMC’s gradually expanding lineup of original programming, won the Emmy Award for dramatic series the year after its premiere in 2007, and it is nominated for 16 more Emmys this month, including outstanding drama. In August the debut episode of its third season was the highest rated “Mad Men” broadcast to date, drawing 2.8 million viewers. A premiere date for the fourth season was not announced.

The wheel in the sky keeps on turning, as does the cast of the 1980s jukebox musical “Rock of Ages.” On Tuesday, the show’s publicists said in a news release that Tom Lenk, a star of the television series “Buffy the Vampire Slayer,” would join the Broadway musical on Sept. 14 in the role of Franz. Mr. Lenk, who previously performed the role in Los Angeles and Las Vegas productions, is replacing Wesley Taylor, who is joining the coming Broadway musical “The Addams Family.” The release also said that the other principal cast members of “Rock of Ages,” including Constantine Maroulis, James Carpinello, Adam Dannheisser, Mitchell Jarvis, Michele Mais and Lauren Molina, had re-signed with the show through summer 2010.

Fresh off directing Vincent Chase in “The Great Gatsby” (for a film adaptation that only existed on “Entourage”), Martin Scorsese has been tapped by HBO to do some real-life work for the cable channel. He’ll be an executive producer of its new series “Boardwalk Empire,” HBO said Tuesday in a news release, which has been ordered for a 2010 debut. Steve Buscemi stars in the series as Nucky Thompson, a man described as “equal parts politician and gangster,” who runs Atlantic City during the Prohibition era. Michael Pitt, Kelly Macdonald, Michael Shannon and Dabney Coleman will also be featured on the series, for which Mr. Scorsese directed the pilot episode.

The musicians of the Seattle Symphony have decided to donate their services for a gala honoring their longtime conductor, Gerard Schwarz, and his 25 years as music director, the orchestra and its players association said Tuesday. The decision comes after a period of turmoil in the orchestra several years ago in which members were bitterly divided into opposing camps over his tenure. The decision came as part of an extension of the players’ contract, which expired on Monday, through the end of the year. “It passed handily,” said Michael Crusoe, the principal timpanist and chairman of the players organization. “We’re all about rallying around a common cause, not emphasizing differences,” he said.

The other day, my daughter, Sasha, was exploring the Great Barrier Reef off the northeast coast of Australia. She'd flown there by seaplane and was scuba diving 30 feet down when - whoosh! - a giant Maori wrasse, a thick, bluish-yellow fish that looks as if it's made of Plasticene and is twice her size, zipped by. Next, after startling a stingray, she swam around with a bottlenose dolphin, before heading back up to the surface and on to the Serengeti for a hot-air-balloon safari.

Since leaving the African coast one week ago, this easterly wave has remained intact, but struggled with shear. Today, an aircraft reconnaissance flight revealed a closed circulation with 45kt sustained winds at the surface and a 1007mb central pressure. So, it was immediately upgraded to TS Erika. School No. 1 in Beslan, Russia, was the locus of mourning on Tuesday, as it has been since the days immediately following the massacre. That was when James Hill, photographing for The Times, chronicled the human aftermath in "Return to Beslan." Even in September 2004, Mr. Hill noted, "In a strange way, the school, which is a place where over 300 people have died, has become a shrine for many people who come to have a look. Some of the parents, in fact, have come every day and walk around. And there's a strange, hushed atmosphere in the school - almost religious." The Ralph Ellison Memorial is a sculpture 15 feet high at Riverside Drive and 150th Street, near the apartment building where Ellison lived for many years. Ellison's novel "Invisible Man" articulates the frustrations of a young black man's treatment as a second-class citizen. The design of the memorial, by Elizabeth Catlett, gives form to the sense of invisibility by presenting a cutout of a forceful male figure in a large bronze rectangle. The sculpture sits in a landscaped island at the end of the street and places the silhouetted form against the backdrop of the forest and river views in Riverside Park, where Ellison loved to sit. Ellison is buried in Trinity Cemetery, to the north.

In our issue of July 26, Tony Horwitz praised Rich Cohen's "Israel Is Real: An Obsessive Quest to Understand the Jewish Nation and Its History" as "provocative and entertaining," citing its "breezy irreverence." He also complained that "Cohen sometimes gets carried away with his own shtick, diluting his humor with material that is overdone or simply inane." Many of our readers in fact found Cohen's "quasi-historical humor," as one put it, too provocative for their taste. Others pointed out errors of fact contained in the book and repeated in one way or another in our review; in a number of instances, upon examination, we concurred, publishing a correction in last Sunday's issue; in some cases, though, we thought it reasonable to allow humor its license. Horwitz himself expected the book - and his review - to be contentious, and he was right. A selection of readers' letters comes after the jump.

If you find yourself being pulled away from shore by a powerful rip current, what should you do? The traditional advice has been to swim parallel to the shore in order to get outside the current. But after an extensive study of these currents -- by using instruments and floating in them himself -- Jamie MacMahan has concluded that your odds are better if you stay still and just tread water.Dr. MacMahan, an oceanography professor at the Naval Postgraduate School in Monterey, Calif., found that the conventional image of a rip current is inaccurate -- that it's actually not a long plume of fast-moving water running out to sea. Instead, rip currents more closely resemble whirlpools, with strong, persistent eddies that circulate throughout the surf zone, Dr. MacMahan reports in an article to be published in Marine Geology. If you swim parallel to the shore, he concludes, there's a 50-percent chance you'll end up be swimming into a stronger current. But if you just tread water, he says, there's a 90 percent chance of being returned to shore within about three minutes.

For a confessed colorphobe like me, Lanvin is, season after season, a neutral dream come true with its monochromatic suits and muted palette. So imagine my surprise when a suit in rusty orange (à la Richard Serra) came down the spring runway along with Kelly green trenches and raspberry track pants, breaking up the procession of navy-on-navy looks. It was enough to make a guy reconsider his wardrobe's spectrum. And while a full two-piece suit in burnt sienna is a few Pantone chips beyond my comfort zone, I'm already thinking about how to wear orange for fall. A bright shade - say, in the form of a sweater - is great to liven up a charcoal double-breasted suit; while a more subdued tone of orange can stand in anywhere camel works. And lest you end up looking like a jack-o'-lantern, one incontestable rule is to never wear orange with black.

Tampa Bay co-owner Len Barrie is accused of misappropriating funds from his British Columbia golf resort to help pay for his purchase of the Lightning. According to a report from the Bear Mountain Resort's former accounting firm, Barrie used at least $2.5 million to help pay for the club as part of a number of transactions the firm says may have been "improper and, in some cases, illegal." The Globe and Mail reports that Allan Neale, a partner at the firm who served as the resort's auditor, expressed his concerns to resort management and resigned from the job. Barrie, who is involved in an ownership and payment dispute with Tampa partner Oren Koules that is being mediated by Commissioner Gary Bettman, denies the accusation and tells the newspaper that the resort's new auditing company "agrees with how I've done it so I don't think there is any issue."• • •Ice Edge Holdings, one of three bidders for the bankrupt Phoenix Coyotes, has booked ice at Saskatoon's Credit Union Centre to stage five Coyotes games if the group's $150 million bid wins the Sept. 10 auction for the team. The dates at the 15,195-seat rink: Nov. 12 (Montreal), Dec. 21 (Columbus), Jan. 21 (Nashville), Feb. 8 (Edmonton) and March 2 (St. Louis).Meanwhile, Senators owner Eugene Melnyk tells The Ottawa Citizen that Jim Balsillie is using "bizarre" tactics in his bid to buy the Coyotes and move them to Hamilton. Melnyk, who was outraged last week when Balsillie's lawyers pointed out that Melnyk had paid fines for securities violations, says he long ago advised Balsillie, "I don't think you knock the door down to try to get a team." Melnyk's comments come on the eve of a key Sept. 2 hearing in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Phoenix in which Judge Redfield T. Baum is expected to rule on whether Balsillie can participate in the Sept. 10 auction for the Coyotes.• • •Former N.H.L. Players Association director of business affairs Vincent Damphousse says that union head Paul Kelly was dismissed Monday morning because of "a kind of paranoia in the group." Damphousse, who left his union job a few months before Kelly came aboard in 2007, characterizes the firing as the latest chapter in a struggle within the N.H.L.P.A. membership between hardliners and accommodationists. Damphousse says there is a push to leave behind Kelly's cooperative stance with league management and return to the confrontational approach of Bob Goodenow, who headed the union for 13 years culminating in the 2004-05 lockout.

Bipartisan health care legislation is still possible and the "gimlet-eyed" President Obama is playing things just about right to get there, according to a Washington Post op-ed column this morning by Norman J. Ornstein, a resident scholar at the conservative American Enterprise Institute. In the House and Senate, Mr. Ornstein writes, every health care issue of consequence has significant Republican opposition:

Happy September! And an end to the fastest summer in recorded history, or so it seemed from here. If this is how you feel doing your shopping for those lists of school supplies, you're not alone. (I'm still trying to find mine!)

While political pundits are giving serious parsing to the meaning of Democratic proposals for a health care overhaul, a literary humor Web site is offering some late-summer comic relief. A recent post on McSweeney's parodies public fears that the proposals would lead to health care rationing and "death panels" denying end-of-life care. In McSweeney's analysis, by Rob Kutner, a writer for "The Tonight Show," a new medical system would have celebrity juries deciding on which patients merit treatment and would enlist branded doctors, be they Dr. Phil or Dr. Pepper, to see millions of new patients clamoring for care.

Pedro Espada Jr., the majority leader of the State Senate who is already at odds with tenant advocacy groups, appointed a new deputy chief of staff last month who in recent years managed dozens of low-income buildings with chronic housing code violations -- even after state regulators revoked his real estate broker's license in 2004, citing "gross untrustworthiness" after he failed to return deposits to would-be renters.
An essay by David J. C. MacKay, a professor of physics at the University of Cambridge and the author of the book "Sustainable Energy -- Without The Hot Air."
Late Monday, it was beginning to look as if the first night session of the United States Open would never end.

A recent study by Robert Scott of Monmouth University found that "every $1,000 increase in credit card debt increases the probability a firm will close by 2.2 percent." It also explained that "reliance on this type of financing may lead many businesses into a long-term liquidity drain that affects their financial stability -- and thus survival."
With schools opening around the country, health officials have begun to ramp up public awareness campaigns and make preparations for combating the anticipated return of the swine flu.

At the Well blog this morning, Tara Parker-Pope tells the tale of a young man in Las Vegas who had a serious heart condition but no insurance, despite working part-time as a D.J. and graphic designer. His case, she writes, "stands out as a striking example of both the best and the worst that the American health care system has to offer - extraordinary medical prowess that is too often out of reach for all but the luckiest and best insured." Read the story.

Airborne Wi-Fi May Soar Despite the DoubtersConventional wisdom says that too few people will pay to use Wi-Fi services when they fly and that the fledgling industry is, therefore, not likely to succeed. Despite those hurdles, domestic airlines have been lining up to wire planes for Wi-Fi service.

Norway's sovereign wealth fund, one of the largest in the world with about $400 billion in assets, plans to commit about $3.5 billion dollars over a period of five years to companies it deems environmentally sound and engaged in sustainable growth in emerging markets, an official at the country's Finance Ministry said Tuesday.

Update | 10:06 a.m. EBay announced on Tuesday that it will sell a majority stake in Skype to an investor group led by the private equity firm Silver Lake in a deal valuing the business at $2.75 billion. Ebay will retain a 35 percent stake and receive $1.9 billion in cash and a $125 million note. The press release is here.

The Oscar process is clearly still in process. On Monday, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said its decision last June to double the number of best picture nominees to 10 brings with it a change in voting method.

Barneys, the luxury retail chain, is considering a debt restructuring or bankruptcy filing that may wrest control of the company from the Dubai-owned firm that bought it in 2007, Bloomberg News reported, citing undisclosed sources.
From our colleagues at DealBook:

The ninth edition of the annual Kustom Kills and Hot Rod Thrills car show took place on Saturday under the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway at Union Avenue in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Sponsored by the Rumblers Car Club, the show is the New York area's most elaborate festival of "kustom culture" and rat-rodding.
Billionaire hedge fund manager Paul Tudor Jones is wagering that Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley spoke too soon in declaring the start of an economic recovery, Bloomberg News reported.
Following the announcement yesterday of Disney's $4 billion acquisition of Marvel, The Wall Street Journal wondered whether the deal was a sort of wellspring in the ongoing M&A drought.

Is there a better story line at the 2009 United States Open than Taylor Dent, who is thankful just to be playing tennis again after being hampered for years by a serious back injury? We don't think so, which is why his matchup against Feliciano Lopez tops our list of must-see matches for Day 2 at the Open.
A bankruptcy judge on Monday approved Tribune Company's request to expedite the sale of the Chicago Cubs, which the Ricketts family has agreed to buy in a $845 million deal.

SkyEurope, a Slovakia-based low-cost airline that sought protection from creditors in June, announced Tuesday that it had ceased operations, effective immediately, The New York Times's Nicola Clark reported.
Although accumulators also bear the nickname "I kill you later," the financial derivatives are making a comeback, The Wall Street Journal reported.

Permira, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, and CVC Capital are among the private equity firms bidding for Citigroup's telemarketing company in Japan, Bellsystem24, three sources told Reuters, in a deal that could fetch more than $1 billion.
Warren E. Buffett intends to raise his stake in BYD, a Chinese maker of electric cars and batteries, the company's chairman said on Monday. The comments sent shares in the company up 8 percent.
Bank of America is looking to pay back some of the billions in federal bailout aid it has received in an effort to get out from underneath the government's thumb, according to a published report.

A bankruptcy judge is recommending Grupo Mexico be allowed to regain control over copper miner Asarco, saying its $2.2 billion bid is more likely to fully repay creditors than that of rival suitor Sterlite Industries.
Taking an enemy-of-my-enemy approach, two challengers to Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania plan to get together Wednesday night for a public forum on health care.

The head of the Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday told U.S. investment firms that they should avoid using bonuses and other inducements to recruit brokers that could encourage them to generate high sales volumes and act against customers' interests.
Carl C. Icahn, one of Yahoo's largest stockholders, has sold 12.7 million shares, reducing his stake in the slumping Internet company by a percentage point to 4.5 percent.

Jerome Kerviel, the French former trader blamed by Société Générale for close to 5 billion euros ($7.2 billion) in losses, was ordered Monday to stand trial, his lawyer, Olivier Metzner, told Reuters.

The Football Scientist, KC Joyner, is a Fifth Down contributor. He breaks down fantasy football matchups twice a week on ESPN.com's NFL Insider section. His 2009 Fantasy Football Draft Guide is now available for immediate download. Lab results for "Scientific Football 2009" are available for those who order the book now.

LONDON | Of all the destinations in the world, London is probably not a place you would normally associate with insects (unless of course you were unlucky with your accommodations). Over the coming weekend (Sept. 4 to 6), however, the Southbank Centre (Belvedere Road; 44-871-663-2501;www.southbankcentre.co.uk), a 21-acre cultural complex on the banks of the Thames, will be experiencing a bug invasion of a different kind. The aptly named "Pestival" will celebrate insects in art and the art of being an insect.
An investigation into possible violations by Porsche regarding the trading of Volkswagen shares has spread outside the sports-car maker's home base of Stuttgart to Frankfurt.
Sparx Group is set to open its first global macro fund to new investors as it departs from a traditional focus on equities in an effort to return to profitability, Bloomberg News reported.

A number of private-equity firms are looking at the asset-management firm TCW as a potential buyout target, The New York Post reported, citing unidentified sources. Kohlberg Kravis Roberts is among those said to be talking to TCW's owner, Société Générale.
A federal judge upheld a jury's verdict that found that a private company run by Maurice R. Greenberg had not breached its duty of trust to the insurer the American International Group.

The oil giant Chevron said Monday that it had obtained video recordings of meetings in Ecuador this year that appear to reveal a bribery scheme connected to a $27 billion lawsuit the company faces over environmental damage at oil fields it operated in remote areas of the Amazon forest in Ecuador, The New York Times's Simon Romero and Clifford Krauss reported.

Indian Energy has raised £9.75 million ($15.8 million) in a placement with existing stakeholders and new investors, The Daily Telegraph reported. On listing, the company will have a market capitalization of £20.3 million.
Barclays Capital may split the assets of its mid-market private equity division, Barclays Private Equity, and the management company which runs it, The Daily Telegraph reported.

KB Financial Group's rights offering was 98.45 percent subscribed when it closed last week, according to a statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, FinanceAsia reported. Although slightly undersubscribed, the group raised the full $914 million it was seeking thanks to the deal being fully underwritten.

Vinod Khosla, the prominent venture capitalist who has been investing hundreds of millions of his own dollars in green technology companies for the last several years, will now invest other people's money, too, The New York Times's Claire Cain Miller reported.
Four years after she took over management of the General Motors pension plans, Nancy Everett finds herself in an unexpected controversy, Geraldine Fabrikant reported in The New York Times.

Brookfield has raised an additional $1 billion of equity for its new investor consortium aimed at buying and restructuring under-performing real estate in Europe and the United States, The Financial Times reported.

As private equity firms try to raise fresh cash via annex funds, opposition from investors is mounting, The Financial Times reported. Driving the demand for the annex funds are companies, acquired during the market boom, that are now struggling to support their high debts.
Calix, a networking equipment company, has completed a $100 million round of funding lead by Foundation Capital, BusinessWeek reported.

Six companies started investor education for initial public offerings in Hong Kong on Monday, putting an end to the quiet days when equity capital markets bankers were trying to justify their existence, FinanceAsia wrote.

Last week, I heard about the opening of a new shop in Reykjavik, Iceland, called the Armoury. It's the brainchild of the designer Sruli Recht and the artist Megan Herbert, and it's in a part of the Icelandic capital they're calling the fishpacking district. Which gives me a chuckle because a) center-city Reykjavik is barely large enough to be subdivided in the first place, and b) if Recht and Herbert are looking to capture a similar frisson of industria as Manhattan's meatpacking district, well, that neighborhood lost its frisson five years ago (if not before, in my worthless opinion).But anyway, who cares? Reykjavik designers and shop owners have proved themselves to be thriving and shrewd, economic woes notwithstanding, and they can be as creative with nomenclature as they like. Not long ago the city christened its main shopping street a "design district," and Icelandic Fashion Week kicks off in the capital for the ninth time on Thursday. For his part, Recht, who was born in Israel, is something of an enfant terrible, with a goth-dandyish ethos that has won him international acclaim but hasn't taken him far from the spirit of his adopted city. Check out his whalets - wallets made of minke whale or Nile perch skin - or his luxuriously shroudlike blankoat sweater knitted from Icelandic wool. And I'm obsessed with his bow tie (below) and its backstory. At the new shop, these and other "nonproducts" - a new one every month - will sit alongside Herbert's illustrated paper-cut works. If you don't plan on being in Iceland anytime soon, some of Recht's pieces are available at BBlessing in New York and at Isetan in Tokyo.

For more than a generation, "two-and-twenty" has been a rule of thumb for management fees in the venture capital industry. It means fund managers get 20 percent of any profits they generate and 2 percent of total assets under management in fees. Private equity is starting to get the hint. Is it time, wonders VentureBeat, for venture capital to do the same?
Taking the rickety paper-based system of health records used in the United States and turning it into a state-of-the-art electronic one is no small task. But someone's got to do it.

Both deals were made for a player to be named.

BALTIMORE - Maybe Yankees pitchers just don't throw no-hitters on the road. Allie Reynolds, Don Larsen, Dave Righetti, Jim Abbott, Dwight Gooden, David Wells and David Cone have all tossed their gems in the Bronx since Reynolds blanked the Indians in Cleveland on July 12, 1951, his first of two no-hitters that season. Andy Hawkins no-hit the White Sox at Comiskey Park in 1990, but he did it in eight innings.

Schedule information on Friday with an art review of “Marcel Duchamp: Étant Donnés,” at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, misstated the museum’s telephone number. It is (215) 763-8100.
Five suspects, all from Eastern Europe, were among 17 accused by the Manhattan district attorney of the online theft of more than 95,000 credit card numbers.

An article in the special tennis section on Monday about the fashion marketing of Roger Federer and Nike misidentified the symbol used on designs by Lacoste, another company with deep ties to tennis. It is a crocodile, not an alligator.

The Sports of The Times column on Sunday, about Brittany Ryan, a kicker for the Lebanon Valley College football team in Annville, Pa., misidentified a university for which another young woman, Katie Hnida, once kicked. It was New Mexico, not New Mexico State. The column also misstated, in some editions, the name of the university where Liz Heaston became the first woman to score in a college football game by kicking two extra points in 1997. It is Willamette, not Williamette University.

An article on Wednesday about a cutback in hiring by law firms misstated several firms’ recruitment decisions involving Yale Law School. Two firms — Baker & McKenzie and Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy — did not register for the program in 2009; another, White & Case, registered but dropped its registration before scheduling any interviews. None of the firms “canceled interviews in New Haven.”.

A picture caption on Saturday with an article about 1,800 teaching jobs in New York City that remain unfilled just days before the school year begins — apparently because principals are resisting orders to fill vacancies from within — referred incorrectly to Timothy Goettelmann, who was at a job fair at Citi Field. He is a teacher on the hiring committee at a high school in the Bronx, the Holcombe L. Rucker School of Community Research — not a principal.

An article on Saturday about a memorial service for Senator Edward M. Kennedy at the John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum erroneously attributed a distinction to the senator’s nephew Joseph P. Kennedy II, who spoke at the event. He is the second eldest child of Robert F. Kennedy, not the eldest. (Kathleen Hartington Kennedy is the eldest.).
An article on Sunday about the funeral of Senator Edward M. Kennedy misstated the year his brother Joseph was killed while on a Navy air mission. It was in 1944, not 1942.

An article on Saturday about Senator Edward M. Kennedy’s widow, Victoria, misidentified a relative of the senator who praised the way she dealt with Mr. Kennedy’s battle with cancer. He is Joseph P. Kennedy II, a nephew — not Joseph P. Kennedy Jr., who was the senator’s oldest brother.
President Obama notified Congress that he is reducing 2010 pay increases for federal workers to 2 percent from 2.4 percent.

Representative F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., the longtime Republican lawmaker from Wisconsin, will undergo radiation treatment for prostate cancer.

A front-page article on Sunday about a re-argument in a Supreme Court campaign finance case described the unsuccessful efforts of Fred Wertheimer, a veteran advocate of tighter campaign regulations, to persuade the Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press to change its position that the government should not have the power under the First Amendment to limit the distribution of “Hillary: The Movie,” a polemical documentary. The article quoted the committee’s executive director, Lucy Dalglish, as saying that Mr. Wertheimer “called a couple of people who were donors, and he cost us some money.”.
