A day after Noel Gallagher (sort of) stunned fans with his announcement that he was quitting the popular British rock band Oasis, Mr. Gallagher (above left with his brother, Liam) explained his departure in a statement on the group’s Web site, oasisinet.com, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Gallagher, the group’s lead guitarist and main songwriter, said that he had been “forced to leave” Oasis, adding that “the level of verbal and violent intimidation towards me, my family, friends and comrades has become intolerable” and that “the lack of support and understanding from my management and band mates” left him with no other option. Mr. Gallagher announced his departure from the band in a brief statement that was issued on Friday night, just before Oasis was to perform at the Rock en Seine festival near Paris. That concert was canceled. Concert organizers said at the time that Mr. Gallagher had fought with Liam, the group’s lead singer, with whom he has had a notoriously stormy relationship over the band’s 18-year run.

The record company of Vera Lynn, below, the British singer of World War II ballads, says she has become the oldest living artist to reach the Top 20 on Britain’s album chart, Agence France-Presse reported. Ms. Lynn, 92, known for her performances of songs like “(There’ll Be Bluebirds Over) The White Cliffs of Dover” and “We’ll Meet Again,” reached the No. 20 position on the chart with her collection “We’ll Meet Again: The Very Best of Vera Lynn,” which was rereleased by Decca Records to coincide with the 70th anniversary of Britain’s declaration of war on Germany at the start of World War II. Among the artists on the chart that Ms. Lynn’s album surpassed are U2, Green Day and Eminem.
“Big Brother” and “60 Minutes” lifted CBS in the ratings on Sunday, a night otherwise dominated by NBC and its preseason football coverage.
A benefit concert for the Actors Fund will include performances by Hugh Jackman and Audra McDonald.

Book lovers who were hoping for a decisive showdown between the authors Alice Munro, below, and Margaret Atwood in the Scotiabank Giller Prize, the annual Canadian literary award, were disappointed when Ms. Munro said she did not want to be considered for the prize this year, The Globe and Mail reported. Ms. Munro, whose new short-story collection, “Too Much Happiness,” was seen as a likely nominee, said that she was withdrawing the book from consideration because she has won the prize twice before — for her collections “The Love of a Good Woman” (in 1998) and “Runaway” (in 2004) — and younger writers should have a chance to win. Douglas Gibson, whose Douglas Gibson Books imprint releases Ms. Munro’s work in Canada, told The Globe and Mail: “In my role as greedy publisher I pointed out that the Giller Prize produces so much publicity, that even to be nominated for it is tremendous publicity. But her mind is made up on this.” The Giller Prize, about $45,000, is awarded annually to a Canadian work of fiction; the long list of nominees for this year’s prize will be announced Oct. 6. “Too Much Happiness” is to be released in the United States in November.
The CBS soap opera “The Bold and the Beautiful” ended its 22-year drought by winning the Daytime Emmy Award for best drama on Sunday.

After you’ve grown tired of intellectual engagement and civil discourse, the motion picture industry is making sure there will be plenty of gun-toting action heroes populating the cineplexes when you want to switch your brain to the off position. Variety reported that a fifth installment in Sylvester Stallone’s long-running “Rambo” series has been given the green light by the studios Nu Image and Millennium Films. The new film will be directed by Mr. Stallone, above, who will again star as the one-man killing machine John Rambo, who will fight human traffickers and drug lords while trying to rescue a kidnapped girl. The previous “Rambo” movie, released last year, earned $42 million in domestic ticket sales and $113 million overseas. In addition, The Hollywood Reporter said Columbia Pictures had hired Peter Craig to write a third installment of “Bad Boys,” the action movie series that has starred Will Smith and Martin Lawrence as a pair of mismatched Miami detectives. The report said that the actors were willing to reunite with the series director Michael Bay (“Transformers”) and producer Jerry Bruckheimer, but that no deal to bring them together had yet been struck.

Forty years after the guitarist Brian Jones, below, a founding member of the Rolling Stones, was found dead at the bottom of his swimming pool, the British police say they will re-examine the case after receiving new information from an investigative journalist, Reuters reported. Jones, who helped create the Rolling Stones in 1962 (and is said to have come up with the group’s name, taken from a Muddy Waters song), was found dead on July 3, 1969, at his East Sussex home, which once belonged to A. A. Milne. At that time Jones had recently left the band. A coroner’s report gave the official cause as “death by misadventure,” though subsequent films and books (including “The Murder of Brian Jones” by Anna Wohlin, a girlfriend of Jones who was with him the night he died) have suggested that foul play was involved. British officials did not describe the new information or identify who had given it to them. A Sussex police spokesman told Reuters, “These papers will be examined by Sussex police, but it is too early to comment at this time on what the outcome will be.”.
Asbury H. Sallenger Jr.'s book tells a true story of coastal fragility, with some romance too.

Restrictions on the sale of incandescent bulbs started taking effect across most of Europe on Tuesday in the Continent's latest effort to get people to save energy and combat global warming. But even advocates concede the change is proving problematic. Under the rules, stores will no longer be allowed to buy or import most incandescent frosted glass bulbs starting on Tuesday. Retailers can continue to sell the bulbs until their existing stock runs out.

It has been months since Carlos Beltran, Jose Reyes and Carlos Delgado have played in a game for the Mets. But one of them will finally be back in action Wednesday -- in Brooklyn, not in Queens. Beltran, out since late June with a bad knee, will play for the Class A Brooklyn Cyclones, a prelude to rejoining the Mets. With David Wright set to rejoin the team Tuesday after sitting out with a concussion, the beleaguered Mets may actually have their Nos. 3 and 4 hitters back in the lineup fairly soon, although at this point, the season is beyond redemption.

Baseball's minor leagues are a proving ground for future big-league players, but they play a similar role for baseball equipment. In the latest experiment, Major League Baseball will mandate that all minor league players wear Rawlings's new extra protective S100 helmet starting in 2010. ''It's a first step,'' said Patrick Courtney, M.L.B.'s vice president for public relations. ''The goal is to get the minor league players used to it and then hopefully when they come up to the major leagues, they will continue to wear it.''

''Senator Enzi's clearly turned over his cards on bipartisanship and decided that it's time to walk away from the table,'' Mr. Gibbs said Monday.

JOHNSON--Barbara. Friends, colleagues, and students mourn the loss of Barbara Johnson, a world-renowned literary critic and professor of English and Comparative Literature at Harvard University, who died August 27. A pioneering practitioner of deconstruction and a distinguished translator, Johnson wrote groundbreaking essays that profoundly influenced the field of literary and cultural studies. She was revered by students for her insight and generosity, admired by colleagues for her brilliance and integrity, and beloved by friends for her wisdom, keen wit, good cheer, and open heart.

Law enforcement officials in the Bay Area community of Antioch said Monday that a bone fragment had been found in the search of a house neighboring the property of Phillip Garrido, the man charged with abducting Ms. Dugard. But a spokesman for the county sheriff said it was not clear if the fragment was human. Searchers have been looking for evidence not only in the Dugard case but also in a string of murders in the area. The authorities suspect that Mr. Garrido had access to the neighbor's property, and may have lived there, in 2006.

KELSON--Max, 84, of Long Branch, NJ, passed away peacefully at home, August 25, 2009. He graduated from Pace University, and in 1955 became a Certified Public Accountant in New York. In 1956 he was admitted to AICPA, and elected a member of the NY State Society of Certified Public Accountants. In 1959, he received his CPA license in New Jersey. In 1961, he founded the firm of Kelson & Merves, Certified Public Accountants, LLC, Howell, NJ. He retired from the firm in 2003. Mr. Kelson is formerly of Monmouth Beach, NJ. He is survived by his wife of 56 years Irma Kelson; and two daughters Laura Kelson of Monmouth Beach, NJ, and Diane Rosen (Louis) of Chevy Chase, MD; and three grandchildren Adam, Justin, and Nina. He was admired and loved by all who knew him, and will live in our hearts forever.

The computer industry has a secret. Yes, the number of transistors on modern microprocessors continues to multiply geometrically, but no one really knows how to get the most out of all these new transistors. That was underscored here last week at Hot Chips, a symposium on the design of fast computers, when John L. Hennessy, the president of Stanford University and the co-author of the leading textbook on computer architecture, challenged a panel of well-known computer designers to describe one significant new idea in the field of parallel computing -- the use of many computers, or many of the processors that are at the heart of computers, at the same time.

Taking an enemy-of-my-enemy approach, two challengers to Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania plan to get together Wednesday night for a public forum on health care. Representative Joe Sestak, above left, a Democrat who is challenging Mr. Specter in the Senate primary next spring, invited former Representative Patrick J. Toomey, above right, the likely Republican nominee for the seat, to a town-hall-style meeting. It will be held on Mr. Toomey's home turf in Allentown, at Muhlenberg College. Mr. Specter was not invited.

GRASS--Alex. UJC/The Jewish Federations of North America, its Board of Trustees and staff mourn the passing of Alex Grass, a dear friend of the Federation system. The national debate on health care tends to focus on providing coverage to people who do not have insurance. But a study released Monday by the Center for Health Policy Research at the University of California, Los Angeles, underscores the limits of the current system in protecting even insured people from the financial risk of being sick. The report, ''The State of Health Insurance in California,'' found that more than 2.2 million of the state's adults -- almost one in seven working-age Californians -- said they had medical debt. And two-thirds of those said they incurred the debt despite having health insurance.

A Mets executive said Monday that moving 75 prospects from the team's program in the Florida instructional league to the Dominican Republic was being done to raise the players' level of competition, not to save money. ''What's been happening on the east coast of Florida is that teams are leaving,'' said Dave Howard, the Mets' executive vice president for business operations. ''The Dodgers left, the Cardinals don't have an instructional league team, the Marlins don't have a full program and the Orioles are leaving. We've been playing mostly intramural games in Florida, and we have a beautiful complex in the Dominican Republic.''

The Brazilian government on Monday presented proposed changes to laws to assign the primary role of developing key deep-sea oil reserves to the state-run energy giant Petrobras, a move that would come at the expense of foreign rivals. The new regulatory framework would be a nationalistic shift for Brazil, which has discovered deep-sea fields in the past two years that Petrobras says could hold tens of billions of barrels of crude oil. That would more than double Brazil's proven reserves of 14.1 billion barrels. President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva said in his weekly radio broadcast that the new arrangement would represent a ''new Independence Day'' for Brazil. The proposal, which needs congressional approval, would confine foreign companies to mostly subservient roles to Petrobras and a new state-owned oil company. The government also said it would establish a special fund to ensure that future oil revenues were regularly funneled to education and poverty reduction.

This documentary by Gemma Cubero and Celeste Carrasco, presented by ''P.O.V.,'' traverses the history of women who bucked tradition and looks at two matadors -- the established Mari Paz Vega, above, and a newcomer, Eva Florencia -- who won't let sexism stand in their way. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY George Foreman and Jenny McCarthy are guests; Rachel Simmons discusses her new book, ''The Curse of the Good Girl.'' Also, the history of red lipstick.

GOODGOLD--Joseph, M.D. The Board of Trustees, faculty, and staff of NYU Langone Medical Center mourn the passing of Joseph Goodgold, M.D., Professor Emeritus at NYU School of Medicine and former director of Rusk Institute of Rehabilitation Medicine. The first in his family to earn a college degree, Joseph attended Brooklyn College, received his medical doctorate at Middlesex University and interned at Brookdale Hospital. Drafted by the army to serve in the Korean War, Joseph was assigned to the Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation Department and received training at the Mayo Clinic under the great pioneers of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation. This experience influenced him to become an electrodiagnostic medicine physician and following the war, Joseph came to NYU to complete a fellowship in Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation. He remained a part of the institution for 40 years. As a professor, Joseph trained doctors from all over the world in his specialty and became the chairman of the department of Rehabilitation. He also served as chairman and director of the Rusk Institute of Rehabilitation Medicine and Director of the Jerry Lewis Neuromuscular Center. An internationally recognized expert, Joseph was a major contributor to his field through numerous scholarly publications and the first textbooks for electromyography. He was also instrumental in establishing the first credentialing examinations for electrodiagnostic medicine. A recipient of the Krusen Award and Distinguished Clinical Award of the American Academy of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation, he also served as the association's president. Joseph also served as the president of the American Association of Academic Physiatry of the American Association of Medical Colleges and the American Association of Neuromuscular and Electrodiagnostics. A colleague and friend, Joseph will be deeply missed. To Mildred and the entire Goodgold family, we extend our deepest condolences. Kenneth G. Langone Chairman, Board of Trustees NYU Langone Medical Center Robert I. Grossman, M.D. Dean & CEO NYU Langone Medical Center

Yankees Set Playoff Prices The Yankees announced ticket prices for potential home playoff games, with prices for most nonsuite seats in the first round remaining the same as the regular season, and some even selling for less -- $5 to $275 apiece. For the American League Championship Series, however, some of the nonsuite seats will double, with tickets selling for $10 to $350 each. And for the World Series, the prices jump to $50 to $425 per ticket -- a 10-fold increase for the cheapest seats, but a 55 percent increase for the highest-price ticket. (NYT)

WATERS-DASHEVSKY--Adam Michael, of Cranford, New Jersey, was released from his life on August 20, 2009. He was 27 years old. He was always on an accelerated trajectory and lived a full life in a short time. A self taught student of everything, his expertise was diverse and included astrology, numerology, and Reiki. His two passions were music and cooking. He had remarkable talent for both creating and performing music and his band Selfless released a CD entitled Conjunction in 2005 and planned to produce a second CD in 2009. Tracks from this album can be found at www.myspace.com/selflessx Adam was also a talented engineer and delighted in mastering other artist's CD's. His second passion was cooking. He graduated from The Natural Gourmet Culinary School in 2003, and combined what he had formally learned with his own distinctive flair to produce culinary alchemy. Adam had a very big heart and helped everyone he met along the way, whether they realized it at the time or not. Adam completed his mission here and now joins his sister, Hallie and Dad, Sid Dashevsky who predeceased him. He leaves behind his mother Virginia Waters, his two half sisters, Anne and Karen Dashevsky, his girlfriend Danielle Smith, his spiritual brother Ian Fford, and many adoring relatives, friends and fans. We miss you Adam and you will be in our hearts forever. A memorial celebration of his life will be held on Saturday, September 12 at 3:00pm at the First Presbyterian Church of Cranford, NJ to be followed by a release party. Private cremation under the direction of the Gray Memorial Funeral Home, Cranford, NJ.

A long, hard summer for Venus Williams nearly turned into a premature autumn for a two-time United States Open champion. She slogged through a sketchy hardcourt season following her loss to her sister Serena in the Wimbledon final in July. And on Monday night, Venus Williams found herself in deep trouble as August came to a close. On a chilly fall-like opening night at Arhtur Ashe Stadium, Williams, seeded third, lost the first set to unseeded Vera Dushevina of Russia, required medical attention for her sore left knee and was three points from losing the match before she summoned the feisty resolve that seems imbedded in the Williams DNA.

Updated | 11:05 a.m. An Australian production of the Tennessee Williams play “A Streetcar Named Desire” turned more physical that expected for its star, Cate Blanchett, who was injured by a stage prop during a performance Wednesday night, Agence France-Presse reported. Ms. Blanchett, who is portraying Blanche DuBois in a production for the the Sydney Theater Company, was performing a fight scene with Joel Edgerton, who is playing Stanley Kowalski. During the scene, Ms. Blanchett was accidentally struck on the head by a prop radio held by Mr. Edgerton. Agence France-Presse quoted audience members as saying that Ms. Blanchett continued to act in the scene, but she had blood on her head and on her neck. The house lights in the theater were then turned on and the audience was asked to leave the building. It was later announced that the performance had been canceled. Tim McKeough, a spokesman for the theater, said that Ms. Blanchett was “absolutely fine” and was expected back for Thursday night’s performance.

For one night only, Jeremy Piven was back on Broadway. On Tuesday, Mr. Piven appeared on CBS’s “Late Show With David Letterman” at the Ed Sullivan Theater, where the subject of his withdrawal from “Speed-the-Plow” (and his recent arbitration victory) quickly came up.

La Scala has closed its uppermost seating gallery to allow the removal of asbestos, The Associated Press reported. A spokesman for La Scala told The A.P. that the asbestos was found in a “very limited” section of the lighting area near the cornice of the vaulted ceiling in the Milan opera house in December. He said the section was sealed until the asbestos could be removed during the opera house’s summer break. La Scala said that about 270 seats were closed as a result, and that ticket holders would be given refunds or upgrades to better seats. The asbestos removal is expected to be finished by the end of October. Rehearsals for planned productions have continued, including the ballet “A Midsummer’s Night Dream,” which begins performances on Saturday.

The Metropolitan Opera will continue its tradition of offering free tickets to final dress rehearsals of its coming productions, giving away a limited number of seats to rehearsals for Puccini’s “Tosca,” Offenbach’s “Contes d’Hoffmann” and Rossini’s “Armida.”

The Librairie de France, the bookstore and New York institution that has operated for 74 years from a storefront in Rockefeller Center, will close at the end of the month, its owner, Emanuel Molho, said Wednesday. Mr. Molho, 73, whose father, Isaac, founded the store in 1928 and moved it to its current location in 1935, said that his lease is set to expire on Sept. 30, and that his rent on the space had become too expensive. “There’s not a chance we can stay here,” Mr. Molho said in a telephone interview. “Even at the current rent, it’s a struggle. Everything that comes here, all the income we get goes to pay the rent here.”

These days, it seems, any book that stands a chance of being read by more than five people must include a reader’s discussion guide: a set of proposed questions at the back of the book for lazy book-group leaders and readers too timid to start conversations on their own.

Fans and scholars of Raymond Carver can now read his entire oeuvre of completed stories in one place: the nonprofit Library of America has published “Carver: Collected Stories.” The volume includes all stories published in his lifetime, four stories that were never collected, and five stories that were discovered after his death.

Colbie Caillat, the 24-year-old singer from Malibu, Calif., whose song “Bubbly” was a ubiquitous hit two years ago, is No. 1 on the Billboard album chart this week with her second release, “Breakthrough” (Universal Republic), which sold 106,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Skillet, a Christian rock band from Memphis, is No. 2 with “Awake” (Atlantic), with 68,000 sales, and Miley Cyrus is No. 3 with 62,000 sales of “The Time of Our Lives” (Hollywood), a seven-song EP released exclusively through Wal-Mart in conjunction with her new clothing line with the designer Max Azria. Kings of Leon’s “Only by the Night” (RCA) holds at No. 4, selling 52,000 copies, and the singer Imogen Heap’s new album, “Ellipse” (RCA), is fifth with 48,000. Reba McEntire’s “Keep On Loving You” (Valory), last week’s top seller, dropped five spots to No. 6 with 42,000 sales.

In a memoir being published posthumously, Senator Edward M. Kennedy talks remorsefully about the car accident that claimed the life of Mary Jo Kopechne – a turn of events many consider a chief reason that he was never able to mount a successful bid for the presidency.

First theater on film, now theater onstage: Spike Lee, who recently directed the film version of “Passing Strange,” will be among the presenters of “County of Kings,” a show written and performed by the poet Lemon Andersen that will be performed at the Public Theater this fall. The show, announced Wednesday in a news release, was featured at the Public’s Under The Radar festival earlier this year, and tells Mr. Andersen’s story about growing up in Brooklyn during the birth of hip-hop music. It is directed by Elise Thoron (“Life? or Theater?”), and is scheduled to begin performances at the Public on Sept. 29, with an official opening of Oct. 12. Its other presenters include Culture Project, Steve Colman and Jayson Jackson.

My Thursday column notes that health reform may well be torpedoed by the visceral American suspicion of government programs. But I note that in fact there are a number of areas where we rely on single-payer systems (albeit at a local level) -- from police to fire. The only area where we're different than other countries is that they also have universal health care, while we don't.

Here on the balmy central coast of California and all across the country, kids are heading back to school. The classes are larger, the No Child Left Behind mandates remain in place and, despite advice from the nation's secretary of health and human services and others, recess and physical education (not to mention art and music instruction) have in many schools been cut back or eliminated. While most of our backpack-laden kids are eager to catch up with friends they haven't seen over the summer, the general feeling is that "playtime is over."
Jill Craybas has been playing tennis for a long time. And she is not about to stop.

Forbes Magazine released its annual valuations of National Football League teams Wednesday, and they showed one thing: even North America's most popular sport is not immune to the recession. Eight teams lost value since last year, and Forbes said it was the first time in 10 years that any team had decreased in value from the previous year.

Samantha Stosur paid the price Wednesday for her difficult first-round victory over Ai Sugiyama on Monday. How many hockey terms would you say have found their way into the general language? Canadians can cite "He'll have to stickhandle the issue," O.K., but what else? Can you think of any right off the bat? -- er, sorry. But really, what has hockey contributed that compares with baseball's "step up to the plate" or "hit a home run"? Or with football's "Hail Mary pass" or "I'd better just punt"? Or basketball's "slam dunk" or "it's a jump ball" or soccer's "playing for time"? Or even cricket's "caught out" or "sticky wicket"? And how often does anyone even refer to hockey metaphorically when they're talking about other things, even in Canada?

Barely three weeks into the life of the "At War" blog, and already we know we've tapped into a powerful and anguished stream in the consciousness of Times readers. We knew, of course, that the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq weigh heavily on the hearts and minds of Americans, and of people farther afield who feel engaged, or troubled, by the "war on terror" that began on that grim September day nearly eight years ago when the aircraft flew into the Twin Towers and the Pentagon. But the sheer volume of readers who have joined in the dialogue that brings a blog of this kind to life has been imposing, even to those of us who have lived these wars, professionally, for much of the last decade. As the designated hitter for the Q and A feature, I'll confess I hadn't anticipated that so many of you -- nearly 400 to date, including 150 who have contributed questions and comments for our second outing, on the question of America's "wobbly allies" - would join us in our new endeavor. I'm grateful that you have, even to those who have taken the more personal approach. "Do you color your hair?", from the anonymous author of the 23rd question to come in on this round, seems a long way from anything that's material to the wars, but, hey, we're not going to discourage anything that's within the bounds of reason and good taste. (And since you ask, sir or madam, the answer is "no," though I've found it common in some of the more ageist parts of the world to find friendly voices suggesting I might want to employ a little boot black - in effect, taking a leaf from the book of Saddam Hussein, who successfully petitioned his American captors in Iraq for the hair dye that disguised his greying head from the world as he underwent the trial that led to his execution).

Venus Williams played her second-round match against Bethanie Mattek-Sands on a tether. Up and down, back and forth, from point to point, Williams evidently struggled with her heavily wrapped left knee. But adrenaline -- and the resultant aggressiveness -- helped her earn a 6-4, 6-2 victory under the midday sun at Arthur Ashe Stadium.

How's this for turning lemons into lemonade: The Sundance Film Festival said that its 2010 installment will have a new section highlighting innovative work in "low- and no-budget filmmaking." Citing the desire to discover and promote more filmmakers of limited resources, John Cooper, the festival's director, said in a statement, "These are not just the films that have been labeled mumble core or dogma or even guerrilla. They are an emerging counterculture within our counterculture." The section, which will be called "Next," will feature six to eight films. This year's festival, which will take place Jan. 21 to 31, had received over 3,689 total submissions as of Sept. 1.

Many of us who think visually have experienced that I-feel-like-I'm-in-a-movie feeling. But the cinéaste Holgar Kraus has taken that idea to another level. His Hamburg-based company, Flexibles Flimmern - Filme in Bewegung (Flexible Flickering - Moving Pictures), hosts regular screenings of classic and obscure films in hand-picked environments that feel like an extension of the movie itself. Some 5,000 fans now follow Kraus's enterprise, which has so far screened 60 films, including the original "Oceans Eleven" at Hamburg's Esplanade Casino and "The Hunchback of Notre Dame" in the bell tower of Saint Catherine's Church.

Dick Berg, the long-time movie and television writer and producer, died Tuesday at his home in Los Angeles at the age of 87, according to members of his family. Mr. Berg, who was born in New York, started his Hollywood career as a dialogue coach for Roy Rogers and other cowboy-actors. Mr. Berg returned to New York in the 1950s, and worked his way into television by writing dramas for the Kraft Theater, Robert Montgomery Presents, Studio One, and Playhouse 90. Back in Hollywood later, he began working on scripts for MGM and Fox, but really made his mark as television writer-producer. He produced the "Checkmate" detective series for Universal, then went on to make dozens of television movies, among them "Wallenberg," "The Martian Chronicles" and "A Rumor of War." Mr. Berg's survivors include Jeff Berg, the chairman of International Creative Management, and Scott Berg, the author of "Max Perkins: Editor of Genius," "Goldywn: A Biography" and "Lindbergh."

Congress returns from its August recess next week, and we've been busy adding new features and information to our Congress API. One of the bigger gaps we've filled is with the cosponsorship of bills: we've added two new responses to detail the bills cosponsored by an individual member, and all of the cosponsors for a particular bill. So now you can see when a lawmaker adds his or her support to a bill - or when that support is withdrawn. For bill responses, we've also added the party breakdown of cosponsors, so you can judge partisan support.

Back when the world was awash with money, fashion became more expensive even as the word "luxury" was cheapened. Bontoni men's shoes are a reassuring reminder that purchasing an investment is still possible. The third-generation Italian company traces its origins to Montegranaro, a medieval hilltop town in the Marche region, where Franco Gazzani's father, uncle and late grandfather made shoes with hand-stitched leather and hand-painted homemade dyes for family, friends and select customers. In 2004, Gazzani and his second cousin Lewis Cutillo decided that their shoes' rising reputation warranted an expansion. But he resisted the temptation to inflate his family name into a mass-market luxury brand. Instead, Bontoni's growth has been measured, and its quality has never been compromised. The shoes are created exactly as they were made a generation ago. Each pair of tapered dress shoes, whose signature attribute is their unique patina, requires 13 weeks to be completed from scratch. The company's team, having grown from three to six, produces 8 to 10 shoes a day in the basement of Gazzani's home. In Italy, where the sanctity of craft has evolved into an ideology like Slow Food, Bontoni sells its elegant bespoke shoes at a starting price of $4,500. Ready-to-wear shoes, priced from $1,000 to $3,500, can be purchased at Bergdorf Goodman Men in New York, Wilkes Bashford in San Francisco and equivalent retailers around the world. Bontoni will hold a trunk show at Bergdorf Goodman Men from Sept. 11 to Sept. 13.

Precisely 100 years ago today, the New York Times newsroom must have been a gloomy place. The newspaper was a sponsor of Robert E. Peary's polar expedition, but Peary still hadn't been heard from as of Sept. 2, 1909. On that day, the New York Herald's entire front page was devoted to the scoop that it had just received by telegram from Peary's rival: "The North Pole Is Discovered by Dr. Frederick A. Cook."

An obituary on Monday about Sheila Lukins, a co-author of “The Silver Palate Cookbook,” which helped introduce many Americans to simple, highly flavored cooking, referred incorrectly to the book’s recipe for ratatouille, which a book editor said had too much garlic in an earlier version. The published recipe calls for two tablespoons of minced garlic, not the 25 cloves that were in the earlier version.

Some members of Opus Dei — not the organization itself — are paying part of the costs.

Milan won the European Champions League final in 2006-7.).

An article on Aug. 4 about campaign proposals by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg that would overhaul mass transit misstated the total number of votes on the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. There are 14, not 17; one vote is shared by four suburban representatives. The same error appeared in an article in some editions on Aug. 6 about commuters’ reaction to one proposal, to eliminate fares on crosstown buses.

An article last Wednesday about Representative Henry A. Waxman’s effort to force drug makers to give back money he says was “a windfall” when drug benefits were added to Medicare coverage misstated the size of the drug discounts the federal-state Medicaid program receives. It receives an average discount of 35 percent — not discounts of “up to 35 percent.” The article also referred imprecisely to Medicaid administrators who have the legal authority to negotiate discounts with drug makers. State Medicaid officials — not all administrators — can seek the discounts. (Their federal counterparts are bound by a set formula.).

An article on Thursday about several Latin American countries’ rejection of punitive policies toward drug users referred incorrectly to the passage of a bill by Mexico’s Congress to decriminalize the possession of relatively small quantities of some drugs. The bill was approved in April, not during the week of Aug. 16. (The law went into effect on Aug. 20, when it was published by the government.) The article also referred incorrectly to former President Vicente Fox’s rejection of a similar bill. That happened in 2006, not “less than two years ago.” (Mr. Fox left office in 2006.) And the article misstated, in some editions, congressional action on that legislation. It had been approved by Congress, not rejected.

An article on Aug. 2 about the difficult conditions faced by reality show contestants referred incompletely to the union status of the performers. While amateur contestants like the ones mentioned in the article do not have union representation, celebrity contestants on shows like “Dancing With the Stars” and performances outside of the competition on shows like “American Idol” are covered by the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists.

President Obama, radical opera, Michael Vick and the studio of Chuck Close are just a few of the subjects to be explored in the 10th annual New Yorker Festival, Oct. 16 through 18. “Shouts & Murmurs Live,” hosted by the magazine’s editor in chief, David Remnick, will include Woody Allen, Noah Baumbach and Paul Rudnick, among others, and a panel on the world of advertising, moderated by Ken Auletta, will feature Matthew Weiner, the creator of “Mad Men.” Interviews with Tyler Perry, Rachel Maddow, James Franco, Tilda Swinton, Wallace Shawn and Ricky Jay are also on the lineup, as well as performances by Neko Case and Steve Earle.

The musicians of the Seattle Symphony have decided to donate their services for a gala honoring their longtime conductor, Gerard Schwarz, and his 25 years as music director, the orchestra and its players association said on Tuesday. In a period of turmoil in the orchestra several years ago, members were bitterly divided into opposing camps over his tenure. The decision was part of an extension of the players’ contract, which expired on Monday, through the end of the year. “It passed handily,” said Michael Crusoe, the principal timpanist and chairman of the players organization. “We’re all about rallying around a common cause, not emphasizing differences,” he said.

Sometimes it pays to procrastinate. From Tuesday through Sept. 20, in this fall’s installment of the 20at20 promotion, some Off Broadway shows will offer $20 tickets starting 20 minutes before curtain. Tickets must be purchased at the box office. Among the shows offering the discount are “The Toxic Avenger,” “The Marvelous Wonderettes” and “Altar Boyz.” If you plan right, you can even see six shows in one Saturday, starting with “The Gazillion Bubble Show” at 11 a.m. and finishing with “Fuerzabruta” at 10 p.m. The 20at20 promotion, which began in 2007, offers the special discount twice a year, in spring and fall. A complete list of participating productions is at 20at20.com.

The Allentown Art Museum in Pennsylvania has received the art collection of the Modernist artist Peter Grippe, including his own works, as well as art by Alexander Calder, Willem de Kooning, Franz Kline and others, The Allentown Morning Call reported. Grippe, a Cubist-inspired sculptor and printmaker who died in 2002, accumulated the collection of more than 500 works in his Long Island home and studio and New York City apartment. His works, including “The Cellist,” above, and “The City,” below, were donated to the museum by his wife, Florence Grippe, who worked with its executive director, Greg Perry, at the Zimmerli Art Museum at Rutgers University. Though Grippe’s sculptures, drawings and prints form the bulk of the collection, it also includes rare items like the portfolio “21 Etchings and Poems,” which contains work by Frank O’Hara, Dylan Thomas and de Kooning.
ABC’s broadcast of the CMA Music Festival, a concert that included performances by Taylor Swift, Brooks & Dunn and other country music stars, delivered Monday’s highest ratings.

The Oscar process is clearly still in process. The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences says its decision in June to double the number of best-picture nominees to 10 brings with it a change in voting method. The best picture will now be chosen by a preferential voting system, rather than the single-choice voting used in other categories. In a statement on Monday, Tom Sherak, the new president of the academy, said preferential voting would help choose the best-picture candidate “with the strongest support of a majority of our electorate.” In the single-choice system, voters pick their film, and the one with the most votes wins. Oscar voters will now be expected to rank their best-picture choices, 1 through 10. Without such ranking, the wider field of nominees raised the possibility that a film would win top honors even it were preferred by only a small plurality of voters. The best picture was last chosen by preferential voting in 1945, the academy said.

Good news for Muslims in Malaysia, at least those who are fans of the Black Eyed Peas: concert organizers said that they could attend a performance by the band, after previously stating that the show was open only to non-Muslims, Agence France-Presse reported. A Web site for the concert, which is being held on Sept. 25 near Kuala Lumpur to celebrate the 250th anniversary of the Guinness brewery in Dublin, had said that “the party is only open to non-Muslims aged 18 years and above,” and Malaysia’s Ministry of Information, Communication and Culture had said that Muslims could not attend. Of Malaysia’s 25 million people, 60 percent are Muslims; Islamic law forbids the consumption of alcohol. But the concert’s promoters, Artists World Entertainment, said in a statement that the event was now “open to all individuals aged 18 and above,” according to Agence France-Presse. No immediate reason for the change was given, though the original plan to bar Muslims from the show drew widespread attention and criticism.
To the surprise of absolutely no one, “Mad Men,” the hit AMC period drama about a New York advertising agency, has been picked up for a fourth season.

Though you’ll never see Johnny Cash, Jerry Lee Lewis, Carl Perkins and Elvis Presley reunite on this plane of existence, a Broadway show that brings them together may be the next best thing. On Tuesday the producers of the musical “Million Dollar Quartet” said they planned to bring their show, based on a 1956 recording session that brought that famous foursome together at Sun Records in Memphis, to Broadway in the spring. Publicists for the musical, which is playing at the Apollo Theater in Chicago, said that the Broadway production would be directed by Eric Schaeffer. Its score comprises songs made famous by those singers, including “Blue Suede Shoes,” “Folsom Prison Blues” and “Whole Lotta’ Shakin’ Goin’ On.” No casting or theater was announced for the Broadway production. ... The wheel in the sky keeps on turning, as does the cast of the 1980s jukebox musical “Rock of Ages.” On Tuesday the show’s publicists said that Tom Lenk, a recurring actor on the television series “Buffy the Vampire Slayer,” would join the Broadway musical on Sept. 14 in the role of Franz. Mr. Lenk, who previously performed the role in Los Angeles and Las Vegas productions, is replacing Wesley Taylor, who is joining the coming Broadway musical “The Addams Family.” They also said that the other principal cast members of “Rock of Ages,” including Constantine Maroulis, James Carpinello, Adam Dannheisser, Mitchell Jarvis, Michele Mais and Lauren Molina, had re-signed with the show through next summer.

Modest construction work is expected to resume on Wednesday morning at the Hilton Theater on Broadway to prepare for the new musical production “Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark,” even though the ultimate fate of the show is still in limbo, three people involved with the production said on Tuesday. Work on “Spider-Man” was suspended in early August because of cash flow problems facing the lead producer, Hello Entertainment. Some of the show’s prospective cast members, meanwhile, were informed that the musical might be canceled altogether, according to agents for those actors. The three people involved with the production said that there was only enough new money to have a handful of workers return to the Hilton on Wednesday; actors have yet to be reassured that the musical is on, and full-scale work on the multimillion-dollar scenery is still being delayed. The people said that the difficulty of raising money to fully capitalize the show, which is expected to cost $35 million or more, has yet to be resolved. They added that the musical’s problems would not be solved by Monday’s announcement that the Walt Disney Company would acquire Marvel Entertainment for $4 billion; the Spider-man character is a Marvel property, but Marvel (and Disney) is not expected to put significant money, if any, into the show. A publicist for “Spider-Man” said previews for the musical, directed by Julie Taymor (“The Lion King”), were still expected to begin in February.

Svetlana Kuznetsova, seeded sixth and ranked sixth in the world, swiftly dispatched Julia Goerges of Germany, 6-3, 6-2, in the first round Tuesday, a result that would have seemed all but ordained. But with Kuznetsova's career, nothing is assured. She and Serena Williams are the only players to win Grand Slam tournaments this year. When Kuznetsova captured the French Open with little resistance from No. 1 Dinara Safina in the final, she secured her first major title since the 2004 United States Open.

The Ralph Ellison Memorial is a sculpture 15 feet high at Riverside Drive and 150th Street, near an apartment building where Ellison lived for many years. Ellison's novel ''Invisible Man'' articulates the frustrations of a young black man's treatment as a second-class citizen. The design of the memorial, by Elizabeth Catlett, gives form to the sense of invisibility by presenting a cutout of a forceful male figure in a large bronze rectangle. The sculpture sits in a landscaped island at the end of the street and places the silhouetted form against the backdrop of the trees and river views in Riverside Park, where Ellison loved to sit.

JAFFE--Viola Albert. Beloved mother of Ellen Jaffe and grandson, Joe Bitz, loving sister of Jacqueline Albert Simon, Viola died peacefully on August 31st, aged 91. Widow of world renowned cardiologist Harry L. Jaffe, Viola worked and corresponded most of her life for the cause of civil and social rights and justice. In the 1970s and 1980s she worked tirelessly as a volunteer at S.A.N.E. and when the couple retired to Carversville, PA she became president of the League of Women Voters in Bucks County, PA. Later, until her mid-80s, Viola worked at A Woman's Place in Doylestown. She became the liaison between the home for abused women and the court, to arrange for legal protection against violence for those who were vulnerable. Her mind and her heart were alert and preoccupied with the social and political issues of our times until her last days. Her family and the wide circle of those whose lives she touched will always remember. The admiration of her nephew, Orville Simon and his sister, Lisette Simon Jacobs were hers always.

The National Football League Players Association is under federal investigation to determine whether some of its leaders tried to collude with league officials by holding secret meetings with them to discuss labor issues without the knowledge of top union leadership. The investigation, being conducted by the Department of Labor, was revealed as part of a lawsuit filed against the union by a union employee, Mary Moran, and was first reported by Sports Business Journal. According to court documents filed in District of Columbia Superior Court on Thursday and obtained by The Associated Press, Moran provided investigators evidence that the former union president Troy Vincent and other union members met with N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell and the Houston Texans' owner, Robert McNair, to provide the league access to confidential union information.

Now that the town-hall-style meetings of the summer recess have more or less run their course, the two sides in the health care debate are moving to the next phase of guerrilla theater: public demonstrations. On Wednesday, supporters of a health care overhaul plan to stage vigils at more than 350 locations across the country, starting at 7 p.m. Under the banner of ''Can't Afford To Wait,'' the vigils are being organized by liberal groups, including Democracy for America, MoveOn, the Service Employees International Union and TrueMajority. Their goal is to put a human face on the need for the overhaul.

(49) TRUMBO With a résumé including the screenplays for ''Kitty Foyle'' and ''Thirty Seconds Over Tokyo'' and the antiwar novel ''Johnny Got His Gun,'' Dalton Trumbo, above, was one of Hollywood's highest-paid writers. And then, in 1947, he refused to testify before the House Un-American Activities Committee, becoming part of the group known as the Hollywood 10. He was convicted of contempt, sentenced to 11 months in a federal prison and barred from practicing his craft. Writing 30 scripts under pseudonyms, and winning an Oscar (as Robert Rich) in 1956 for ''The Brave One,'' he failed to receive public acknowledgment for his contributions until Otto Preminger credited him on ''Exodus'' in 1960, and Kirk Douglas followed suit on ''Spartacus.'' In 1993 Mr. Trumbo's widow was presented with a posthumous Oscar under his real name for the 1953 film ''Roman Holiday.'' This ''American Masters'' presentation is adapted from Christopher Trumbo's 2003 play based on letters his father wrote during the disintegration of his career. They are read here by Joan Allen, Brian Dennehy, Michael Douglas, Paul Giamatti, Nathan Lane, Josh Lucas, Liam Neeson, David Strathairn and Donald Sutherland. 7 A.M. (ABC) GOOD MORNING AMERICAWhitney Houston performs from her new album, ''I Look to You.''

KEAVENY--Deidra Degn, long-time executive with the RFBinder Public Relations Agency in New York, loving wife of Jack, caring daughter of Elaine Fitzgerald and wonderful friend to scores of others, passed away Sunday, August 23 at Calvary Hospital Hospice in The Bronx, NY. In addition to her many responsibilities, for close to 19 years, she ran the agency's intern and associate program, thereby helping launch the careers of dozens of young public relations professionals. It was a role she loved and it began so many relationships with people who came to love her. Deidra's incredibly sweet nature affected everyone she came to know. A memorial service will be held in her honor. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Humane Society in Deidra Degn Keaveny's name.

DeSIPIO--George E.,84, died August 27th at home in Manhattan. Mr. DeSipio, a native of Philadelphia, was a retired partner at the law firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton, which he joined in 1952. Mr. DeSipio was a 1943 graduate of the University of Pennsylvania and a Cum Laude graduate of Harvard Law School. In 1954, Mr. DeSipio married Carol Kohen, and fathered two children, George DeSipio and Sally Hardwicke, currently of Portland, OR. Mr. DeSipio was an avid fisherman and spent many summers at the family cottage on Saltaire, Fire Island. In later years, Mr. and Mrs. DeSipio wintered in Rancho Mirage, CA. Mr. Desipio was a wine aficionado, a music lover and played 5-string banjo. He is survived by his wife Carol, his daughter Sally, his son-in-law Jack Hardwicke, and his grandson, Joe. His son, George, predeceased Mr. DeSipio in 1993. A memorial service is planned for September 18th at 1:30pm at Frank Campbell's Funeral Home in the Upper East Side.

GERSHWIND--Mark. You were a friend, neighbor and advisor. We will miss you and remember you always. We will cherish all the special times we shared. Our hearts go out to Margie, your children and grandchildren. With love, Brenda, Bob and the Feldman family

Unemployment in the 16 countries that use the euro currency rose in July to the highest level in more than 10 years, showing that despite signs of recovery, the European economy continues to struggle. The jobless rate in the euro zone rose to 9.5 percent in July, the highest reading since May 1999, from 9.4 percent in June, Eurostat, the statistical service of the European Union, said Tuesday in Luxembourg.

GERSHWIND--Mark. It is with profound sorrow that the Officers, Board of Governors, members and staff of Fresh Meadow Country Club mourn the loss of our esteemed member, Dr. Mark Gershwind. Dr. Gershwind had been a member for 33 years and served on the Board of Governors for 6 years. We will always fondly recall Mark hitting golf balls on the range, working out in the gym and playing with his grandchildren in the pool. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Marjorie, son Erik (Jackie) Gershwind, daughter Stacey (Michael) Bennett, brother, Dr. Stephen (Arline) Gershwind, brother-in-law Mitchell (Kathy) Jacobson and grandchildren, Betsey, Bradley, Blake, Sophie, Jake and Max. President Obama is planning for ''a new season'' of more hands-on advocacy for an overhaul of the health care system, according to his advisers. Among the likely steps are a nationally televised speech that close allies have recommended and a 10-year price tag below the $1 trillion mark. Mr. Obama met on Tuesday with advisers including Rahm Emanuel, the White House chief of staff, and David Axelrod, a senior strategist, to prepare for Congress's return to work next week, after a month in which many lawmakers have been spooked by contentious town-hall-style meetings and polls showing slipping support for Mr. Obama and his health plans.

With anger still boiling on both sides of the Atlantic over the freeing of the only man convicted in the 1988 Lockerbie bombing, the British and Scottish governments, eager to blunt allegations that they rode roughshod over the life sentence passed by a Scottish court and the rights of the Lockerbie victims, released a thick file of previously confidential documents on the case on Tuesday. In themselves, the documents seemed unlikely to still the controversy over the Scottish government's decision on Aug. 20 to release Abdel Basset Ali al-Megrahi, a former Libyan intelligence agent, who had served eight years of a minimum 27-year sentence. He was convicted in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, which killed 270 people, including 189 Americans.

If Fredrik Colting needs any blurbs for his book “60 Years Later: Coming Through the Rye,” he probably should not seek one from Judge Guido Calabresi. Judge Calabresi was one of three judges on a panel at the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in Manhattan that on Thursday heard arguments on whether Mr. Colting should be allowed to publish the book in the United States. In July, a federal district judge indefinitely enjoined the publication of “60 Years Later,” which Mr. Colting wrote under the pen name J. D. California, and has promoted as a sequel to the J. D. Salinger novel “The Catcher in the Rye.” On Thursday, The Associated Press reported, Judge Calabresi called Mr. Colting’s book a “rather dismal piece of work.” But two judges on the panel questioned if the federal district court had heard enough evidence before issuing its injunction. The court did not immediately rule on Thursday.

The theater department at the University of Wyoming at Laramie has decided to hold a staged reading of “The Laramie Project — 10 Years Later” on Oct. 12, joining more than 120 theaters across the nation and overseas that will also have readings on the same day.

What we’re reading on Thursday morning.Jackson’s Final Farewell: Agence France-Presse previews the long-delayed burial services for Michael Jackson, which are scheduled to take place this evening at the Forest Lawn Memorial Park in the Glendale suburb of Los Angeles, more than two months after the singer’s death.

Only weeks ago, it seemed that the New Zealand soprano Kiri Te Kanawa was preparing for her exit from the operatic stage: in August, she was quoted by The Daily Telegraph as saying that a production of Strauss’s “Rosenkavalier” at the Cologne Opera in April 2010 would “be my last. It’s not as if I want to do it on a regular basis now, because it’s exhausting.” This was interpreted to mean that she was winding down her opera career, though she would continue to perform concerts. But on Thursday, Ms. Te Kanawa told ABC News in Australia that she had no plans to retire following a set of concerts this week at the Sydney Opera House. “I haven’t got any plans to die either,” she said, according to the ABC report. “I mean, that could be on the cards too before I retire.” She is scheduled to sing the role of the Duchess of Krakenthorpa in Donizetti’s “Fille du Regiment” at the Metropolitan Opera in February, and said it was possible she would sing more opera roles after her appearance at Cologne.

When you’ve got a name like Cassavetes, it’s apparently impossible to have an uncontentious relationship with Hollywood. The filmmaker Nick Cassavetes has filed suit against the studio New Line Cinema, saying that he was removed as the director of a planned film about the conservationist Daphne Sheldrick after rewriting its script for free, The Hollywood Reporter said. In his lawsuit, Mr. Cassavetes (whose films include “The Notebook” and “My Sister’s Keeper”) said that he delivered a complete rewrite of a script for “Peaceable Kingdom,” a biographical film about Ms. Sheldrick and her efforts to protect elephants in Kenya, a project he undertook for no pay because he believed he was promised the job as the film’s director. After delivering a script that he was told the studio liked, Mr. Cassavetes said he was taken off the film. He is seeking damages for his writing and directing fees, as well as jobs he missed while working on “Peaceable Kingdom.” New Line Cinema did not comment on the lawsuit.

A video game controversy that began with an uproar in 2005 ended quietly this week as the parent company of the makers of the Grand Theft Auto series said it paid $20.1 million to settle a class-action lawsuit involving claims that a version of the game included hidden sex scenes, Bloomberg News reported. In a statement, Take-Two Interactive, whose Rockstar Games division produces the best-selling Grand Theft Auto games, said that the settlement was paid to plaintiffs who said they were defrauded when they purchased Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas without knowing it contained explicit content. That game was released in 2004, and the sex scenes, which were not readily accessible in it, were later found by players using a homemade computer program called Hot Coffee. The revelation prompted an outcry from lawmakers, and major retailers like Wal-Mart and Target said they would not stock the game until the sex scenes were completely removed. The class action suit was filed in 2005 in Federal District Court in Manhattan. Take-Two said the settlement also resolves claims by investors that the company improperly backdated stock options, according to Bloomberg.

“Prime Suspect,” the long-running British police drama that let Helen Mirren wear a detective’s badge before she got to don the British crown, is being reinvented for American television. The Hollywood Reporter said that NBC has ordered a pilot episode of a new “Prime Suspect” series intended for audiences in the United States, to be written by Hank Steinberg, the creator of the CBS crime series “Without a Trace.” The original “Prime Suspect,” which was created by Lynda La Plante and first shown in Britain on the ITV network in 1991, starred Ms. Mirren (“The Queen”) as Jane Tennison, a detective chief inspector contending with her first substantial murder investigation as well as the sexist attitudes of her mostly male coworkers. Seven “Prime Suspect” series were produced through 2006, and broadcasts on PBS help introduce American viewers to Tom Wilkinson and Ralph Fiennes. No casting has yet been announced for the American version of the show.
Broadening its definition of business news, the Fox Business Network said Thursday that it would simulcast the “Imus in the Morning” radio show starting on Oct. 5.

The cautionary tale of Joel Tenenbaum continues. Weeks after he was ordered to pay $675,000 to record labels for illegally downloading and sharing music, those labels are saying that Mr. Tenenbaum, 25, a graduate student at Boston University, is continuing to encourage music piracy by linking to a file-sharing service on a Web site created for his defense, The Boston Globe reported. A Twitter feed for joelfightsback.com, a Web site run by Mr. Tenenbaum’s legal team, posted a link to the Swedish file-sharing service The Pirate Bay. That site, whose founders were convicted in April by a Swedish court of aiding in copyright violations, posted a playlist called “The $675,000 Mixtape,” which linked to the songs that Mr. Tenenbaum admitted to downloading illegally, and featured a photograph of Mr. Tenenbaum with his arms crossed. The Recording Industry Association of America has filed for an injunction that would order Mr. Tenenbaum to destroy his illegal files and stop promoting piracy. Mr. Tenenbaum said he had nothing to do with the song list on The Pirate Bay, and plans to appeal his verdict and fine.

"Every old sock needs an old shoe," sang Kate Bush, and the guys who make footwear for men can't agree more. I recently posted about Mark McNairy's cool collection of retooled - rebooted? - Bass Weejuns. And Red Wing, in collaboration with J. Crew, is having a heck of a resurgence, driven by a couple of restyled classics. Now there's news that Derek Galkin, the talented shoe designer behind the lost brand Medium, has reintroduced Seavees, a casual 1960s shoe line from the West Coast. Working with Sperry Topsider, Galkin gradually tweaked the label's iconic shoes with interesting color combinations and materials. Its classic deck shoe will make its debut next spring in rip stop nylon, or colored suede with a brick red sole. Meanwhile, the leather heads at Billy Kirk have teamed up with Sebago to reinterpret a work shoe and boot taken from their Docksides collection. Finally, Cole Haan is reproducing, line for line, its vintage saddle shoes and camp mocs, circa 1985. Which brings to mind the Simple Minds anthem from that stylishly fertile era: "Don't You Forget About Me."

For the second time in a week, one of the bylines in Pictures of the Day belongs to Farzana Wahidy of The Associated Press, whose identity - as an Afghan woman who works professionally as a photographer - and whose pictures both stand out. She actually has two pictures in today's show: Slide 1 and Slide 4. Her earlier picture, on Aug. 31, struck a much darker tone. It showed a 40-year-old man whose nose and ears were said to have been cut off by the Taliban on election day. In an interview on the Web site WarShooter, she was asked about the importance of photojournalism in Afghanistan. "Over 90 percent of Afghans are illiterate," she was quoted as saying, "so they can't read to get information about their country and the world. I find photojournalism more useful because such a large percentage of my country's population gets their news from looking at photos." In that same interview, she acknowledged the peril of her calling. "Some people say to me that if I die doing this work that it will be a shame for my family. If I die doing this, it's not a shame for me because I have big responsibility with this job. If I die doing this work, I will be proud."

First there was Elmgreen and Dragset's double domestic fantasy, "The Collectors," which occupies the Danish and Nordic pavilions of the Venice Biennale through Nov. 22. Now the Swiss multimedia artist Pipilotti Rist presents her "dream living room" at Hauser & Wirth in Zurich through Oct. 17. While creature comforts like furniture do not seem to be high on Rist's list of priorities (there's a sofa here, a pair of chairs there), the space is a riot of color and light, its walls decked with images taken during the making of her soon-to-be released feature film "Pepperminta," layered over a wallpaper of steroidal tulips in one room and her digital photomontage, "I Never Taught in Buffalo" in another. At the center of the installation, behind a brightly patchworked curtain, a private circular dance floor beckons. Indeed visitors to the gallery are invited to shake their booties as the spirit moves them, a concept that Rist encourages them absolutely to try at home.

On these sites, you can pose a question--any question at all--and crowdsource the answer. You watch and wait as the vast masses chime in with their opinions on your questions.

I have an article today that discusses how a retirement system based on private savings is affecting the job market. In short, when the economy is contracting, and employers are trying to shrink their payrolls, older workers cling to their jobs because their nest eggs have shrunk. In other words, as Prof. Teresa Ghilarducci at New School put it, 401(k)'s act as a sort of "reverse automatic stabilizer" for the economy.

I recently visited San Francisco on assignment for a design story, but let's face it, what I mostly thought about was food. I arrived on Saturday, just in time for a hearty but subtle pork shoulder in tomatillo sauce at Zuni Café, followed by espresso granita, which is possibly my favorite dessert in the world. Sunday morning, I wolfed down cornmeal pancakes for brunch at Bar Jules in Hayes Valley, which is shaping into a great food neighborhood, before nipping around the corner to Miette to drool over a ginger cupcake with cream-cheese icing. I did not buy it, however, because I planned to sample the ice cream at Humphry Slocombe. Its list of flavors is dizzying: ice creams like black walnut or salted licorice, and sorbets like Hibiscus beet or Thai chili lime. I ordered a kiddie scoop of Blue Bottle Vietnamese coffee with hot fudge sauce (because I could).

In a time in which Photoshop and iPhone applications allow us to easily alter photographs in just about every way imaginable, it's refreshing to see the work of John Wood, who was mastering the art of photo manipulation way back in the 1960s. The 2009-10 hockey season officially begins on Thursday with the opening match of Germany's Deutsche Hockey Liga season. It'll be Adler Mannheim entertaining the Nuremberg Ice Tigers at the 13,600-seat SAP Arena, with the opening faceoff set for 7:30 p.m. local time. It's tonight's only game (the score is in: Mannheim 4-1 Ice Tigers, with 2009 M.V.P. Fred Brathwaite stopping 31 of 32), and the rest of the D.E.L. gets under way on Friday. But all opening games will feature a moment of silence for Robert Müller, the national team goalie who played for two years with an incurable brain tumor before finally succumbing to it last season.

An obituary on Friday about the songwriter Ellie Greenwich, who collaborated on “Leader of the Pack” and other hits of the 1960s, misstated the name of the college from which she graduated in 1962. At the time, it was Hofstra College, not Hofstra University. (It changed its name in 1963.).

An obituary on Aug. 7 about Donald Marshall Jr., whose wrongful conviction for the 1971 murder of a friend and exoneration 11 years later led to a re-examination of Nova Scotia’s legal system and changes in Canadian rules of evidence, misstated the circumstances that led to the friend’s killing, which had actually been committed by an elderly man they had encountered in a park. While Mr. Marshall admitted he was with his friend during that encounter, he withdrew an earlier admission that they were trying to rob the elderly man; Mr. Marshall was never charged with robbery. The obituary also misstated a change in rules of evidence resulting from the case. The prosecution must now fully disclose to the defense any evidence it has; the defense must ensure that full disclosure from the prosecution takes place, and must fully disclose its own evidence only in establishing alibis. The rule change does not mean that both “the prosecution and the defense must now share evidence fully.”.
In an article for Vanity Fair, Levi Johnston shares his view on the Palin home life. It’s too bad he is untrustworthy about every subject not covered by Field & Stream.

The Scientist at Work article on Tuesday, about the coastal geologist Asbury H. Sallenger Jr., author of “Island in a Storm,” a new book about a hurricane that struck Louisiana in 1856, rendered the name of the publisher incorrectly. It is PublicAffairs, not Public Affairs.

An article on Tuesday about efforts to develop ever smaller successors to the transistor misstated part of the name of the device that is the current industry standard. Known as Mosfet, the device is the metal-oxide semiconductor field-effect transistor— not metal-oxide “silicon.”.

An article on July 29 about the author William T. Vollmann and his new book, “Imperial,” about Imperial County in California, and a picture caption with the article referred incompletely to the high level of salinity in the Salton Sea, a lake in Imperial and Riverside counties. Irrigation runoff is one of several factors contributing to the salinity level, not the only one.

An article on the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about distress in the commercial real estate sector incorrectly paraphrased a comment by Richard Parkus, a research analyst for Deutsche Bank, about recent market trends. He said that office vacancies are increasing and rents are decreasing, not the other way around. The article also misstated the dollar total of commercial mortgages that are due to expire by the end of next year and the total that had been due to expire this year but were extended. The amounts are $393 billion (not million) and $39 billion (not million), respectively. And the article referred incorrectly to Murray Hill Properties’ mortgage payments on the building it owns at One Park Avenue. The mortgage is current; the company has not missed a payment.

An article on Tuesday about evidence of a bribery scheme connected to a lawsuit against Chevron that could reach into the family of Rafael Correa, Ecuador’s president, misstated the first name of Mr. Correa’s brother, a prominent businessman involved in other accusations of corruption. He is Fabricio Correa, not Patricio Correa.

An article on Aug. 14 about drugs to attack cancer stem cells referred imprecisely to the founding of OncoMed Pharmaceuticals, a pioneer of such drugs. While Dr. Michael F. Clarke started the firm, he did not do so alone; Dr. Max Wicha was a co-founder.

Fans and scholars of Raymond Carver can now read his entire oeuvre of completed stories in one place, as the nonprofit Library of America has published “Carver: Collected Stories.” The volume includes all stories published in his lifetime, four stories that were never collected and five that were discovered after his death. Perhaps most notably the volume includes earlier versions of all 17 stories published in “What We Talk About When We Talk About Love,” the 1981 collection that cemented Carver’s reputation as a master of the minimalist short story. The stories had been radically edited and cut by Gordon Lish, then Carver’s editor at Alfred A. Knopf. At the time Carver tried to halt publication of the book, but Knopf went ahead. William L. Stull, an English professor at the University of Hartford, and Maureen P. Carroll, an adjunct professor of humanities at the university, reconstructed the Carver stories from Mr. Lish’s papers. Mr. Stull and Ms. Carroll also edited the Library of America collection.

La Scala, above, the Milan opera house, has closed its uppermost seating gallery to allow the removal of asbestos, The Associated Press reported. A spokesman for La Scala told The A.P. that the asbestos had been found in a “very limited” section of the lighting area near the cornice of the vaulted ceiling in December. He said the section had been sealed until the asbestos could be removed during the opera house’s summer break. La Scala said that about 270 seats had beene closed as a result, that ticket holders would be given refunds or upgrades to better seats, and that the asbestos removal is expected to be finished by the end of October. Rehearsals have continued for planned productions, including the ballet “A Midsummer’s Night Dream,” which begins performances Saturday.

An Australian production of the Tennessee Williams play “A Streetcar Named Desire” turned more physical that expected for its star, Cate Blanchett, above, who was injured by a stage prop during a performance on Wednesday night, Agence France-Presse reported. Ms. Blanchett, who is portraying Blanche DuBois in a production for the Sydney Theater Company, was performing a fight scene with Joel Edgerton, who is playing Stanley Kowalski. During the scene Ms. Blanchett was accidentally struck on the head by a prop radio held by Mr. Edgerton. Agence France-Presse quoted audience members as saying that Ms. Blanchett continued to act in the scene but had blood on her head and neck. The house lights in the theater were then turned on, and the audience was asked to leave the building. It was later announced that the performance had been canceled. Tim McKeough, a spokesman for the theater, said Ms. Blanchett was “absolutely fine” and was expected back for Thursday night’s performance. The production is scheduled to go to the Kennedy Center in Washington and the Brooklyn Academy of Music in the fall.

Colbie Caillat, the 24-year-old singer from Malibu, Calif., whose song “Bubbly” was a ubiquitous hit two years ago, is No. 1 on the Billboard album chart this week with her second release, “Breakthrough” (Universal Republic), which sold 106,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Skillet, a Christian rock band from Memphis, is No. 2 with “Awake” (Atlantic), with 68,000 sales, and Miley Cyrus is No. 3 with 62,000 sales of “The Time of Our Lives” (Hollywood), a seven-song EP released exclusively through Wal-Mart in conjunction with her new clothing line with the designer Max Azria. Kings of Leon’s “Only by the Night” (RCA) holds at No. 4, selling 52,000 copies, and the singer Imogen Heap’s new album, “Ellipse” (RCA), is fifth with 48,000. Reba McEntire’s “Keep On Loving You” (Valory), last week’s top seller, dropped five spots to No. 6 with 42,000 sales.

How’s this for turning lemons into lemonade? The Sundance Film Festival says its 2010 installment will have a new section highlighting innovative work in “low- and no-budget filmmaking.” Citing the desire to discover and promote more filmmakers of limited resources, John Cooper, the festival’s director, said in a statement: “These are not just the films that have been labeled Mumblecore or dogma or even guerrilla. They are an emerging counterculture within our counterculture.” The section, which will be called Next, will feature six to eight films. Next year’s festival, which will take place Jan. 21 to 31, had received more than 3,689 total submissions by Sept. 1.

The Metropolitan Opera will continue its tradition of offering free tickets to final dress rehearsals of its coming productions, giving away a limited number of seats to rehearsals for Puccini’s “Tosca,” Offenbach’s “Contes d’Hoffmann” and Rossini’s “Armida.” At noon on Sept. 13 the Met box office will offer 3,000 free tickets to the Sept. 17 final dress rehearsal for “Tosca,” conducted by James Levine, directed by Luc Bondy and starring Karita Mattila, above. The Met said it would hold similar open houses for the Nov. 30 rehearsal of “Les Contes d’Hoffmann,” directed by Bartlett Sher and starring Joseph Calleja, Anna Netrebko and Alan Held; and the April 9 rehearsal of “Armida,” directed by Mary Zimmerman and starring Renée Fleming. Ticket information for those rehearsals will be announced later.

First theater on film, now theater onstage: Spike Lee, who recently directed the film version of “Passing Strange,” will be among the presenters of “County of Kings,” a show written and performed by the poet Lemon Andersen that will be performed at the Public Theater this fall. The show, announced on Wednesday in a news release, was featured at the Public’s Under the Radar festival earlier this year and tells Mr. Andersen’s story about growing up in Brooklyn during the birth of hip-hop music. It is directed by Elise Thoron (“Life? or Theater?”) and is scheduled to begin performances at the Public on Sept. 29, with an official opening on Oct. 12. Its other presenters include Culture Project, Steve Colman and Jayson Jackson.

The Librairie de France, the bookstore and New York institution that has operated for 74 years from a storefront in Rockefeller Center, will close at the end of the month, its owner, Emanuel Molho, below, said on Wednesday. Mr. Molho, 73, whose father, Isaac, founded the store in 1928 and moved it to its current location in 1935, said that his lease will expire on Sept. 30, and that the rent had become too expensive. “There’s not a chance we can stay here,” Mr. Molho said in a telephone interview. “Even at the current rent it’s a struggle. Everything that comes here, all the income we get goes to pay the rent here.” The store, which specializes in French books, also had a publishing arm that during World War II printed the works of writers including Antoine de Saint-Exupéry (“The Little Prince”) who had emigrated. Mr. Molho estimated that the shop now carried about 10,000 titles and said that he had already packed up about 800 cartons of books that he would be taking home when the store closed. “I’m attached to these books,” he said. “I find it very hard to let go.”.

JAFFE--Bernard, 93, passed away peacefully on September 1, 2009. Brother of the late Henry and Saul Jaffe, he is survived by his beloved wife Fern, to whom he was married for 67 years, his son and daughter-in-law, Dan and Naomi, and his grandson Michael. He received an undergraduate degree and then an advanced degree in industrial engineering from Columbia University. He was a world traveler, an art collector, and had multiple business interests in the US and overseas, including for over 50 years, serving as the President of Montefiore Cemeteries. He was deeply loved and respected and will be sorely missed by his family, many friends and colleagues. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th Street, New York City, at 11:15am on Thursday, September 3rd. Interment will follow at Old Montefiore Cemetery. Donations may be made to: Visiting Nurse Service of New York, 1675 Broadway, 18th Floor, New York, NY 10019, or to: Central Park Conservancy, 14 E. 60th Street, New York, NY 10022.

As stalled global trade talks resume Thursday, the world will look to the two countries most responsible for their acrimonious collapse last year -- the United States and India -- to lead negotiators in striking a deal that is palatable to both developed and developing countries. While there are signs that the host of this week's session, India, has become more willing to bargain, negotiators are still trying to determine whether the administration of President Obama is even paying attention yet.

Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, plans to shine a light Thursday on the particular problems that women face with health insurance. Ms. Sebelius will join a round-table discussion in Portland, Me., with Representative Chellie Pingree, a Maine Democrat, and officials of AARP and the Maine Women's Lobby. Women who are insured through their employers tend to be protected by federal laws that bar sex discrimination. But those who buy insurance in the individual market face a variety of problems.

Many people around the country say they fear government involvement in health care. But a new analysis of Gallup Poll data has found little difference in the way Americans on private health insurance plans rate their care, compared with people insured through the government Medicaid or Medicare programs. In either case, at least 7 in 10 Americans rated their insurance plan's coverage positively. And more than 8 in 10 usually give positive ratings to their plan's quality. Those figures remained consistent over the six years from 2003 through 2008.

Marat Safin was on the attack Wednesday, his shots infused with a passion that was gone from his game. It was after his first-round loss at the United States Open -- 1-6, 6-4, 6-3, 6-4 to Jürgen Melzer -- which closed out his storied Grand Slam career, and he was speaking about his younger sister, Dinara Safina. Safina, the top-ranked women's player, survived a scare in a first-round match, in which her serve and her confidence seemed to desert her. She and her brother are the first brother-sister act to reach No. 1. Safin became the top-ranked men's player in November 2000, at age 20, shortly after upsetting Pete Sampras to win the Open title.
