BUCHANAN--Harry Winters III, of Milford, PA, died from cancer on Friday August 28. Born in Brooklyn November 9, 1923 to Harry W. and Eugenie Buchanan, he served with the U.S. Army in Europe during World War II, and was a graduate of both Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and MIT. Mr. Buchanan worked in the chemicals industry, holding senior executive positions in the Metal & Thermit, Virginia Chemicals, and Celanese Corporations. He served as a Director of the Virginia Manufacturers Association, the Chemical Manufacturers Association, United Virginia Bank Corporation, and Crompton & Knowles, and on the board of advisors to the Darden School at UVA. Mr. Buchanan was married for 58 years to the former Barbara Combes of Larchmont, New York. He is survived by his devoted wife, six children, and sixteen grandchildren. The viewing will be on September 4 at Cliff Park in Milford, PA, from 6:00-8:00pm. The funeral will be at 12:00 noon in Saint Patrick's Catholic Church, Milford, on Saturday, September 5.

TAKING a Bikram, or hot yoga, class can be daunting: the room is heated to more than 100 degrees (and may rise to 115) and modesty is on standby, with yogis wearing the workout equivalent of bikinis. The practice is named for Bikram Choudhury, the 63-year-old yogi who created a set of 26 postures and 2 breathing exercises repeated identically in every class. The humidity in the room is meant to make people sweat out toxins and stay limber. ''Bikram helps with the A.D.D. that we all have,'' said Dara G. Cole, 35, co-owner and manager of Bikram Yoga South Slope in Brooklyn. ''The heat and the intensity of the postures demand a quality of attention and focus that expand your ability to concentrate.''

These days, the industries have changed, but something similar is happening again, helping Poland to escape the searing global recession.

DeSIPIO--George E.,84, died August 27th at home in Manhattan. Mr. DeSipio, a native of Philadelphia, was a retired partner at the law firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton, which he joined in 1952. Mr. DeSipio was a 1943 graduate of the University of Pennsylvania and a Cum Laude graduate of Harvard Law School. In 1954, Mr. DeSipio married Carol Kohen, and fathered two children, George DeSipio and Sally Hardwicke, currently of Portland, OR. Mr. DeSipio was an avid fisherman and spent many summers at the family cottage on Saltaire, Fire Island. In later years, Mr. and Mrs. DeSipio wintered in Rancho Mirage, CA. Mr. Desipio was a wine aficionado, a music lover and played 5-string banjo. He is survived by his wife Carol, his daughter Sally, his son-in-law Jack Hardwicke, and his grandson, Joe. His son, George, predeceased Mr. DeSipio in 1993. A memorial service is planned for September 18th at 1:30pm at Frank Campbell's Funeral Home in the Upper East Side.

TAKING QUESTIONS

After a series of doping scandals involving horses, an ethics panel has asked the International Equestrian Federation to create an independent investigative unit to help clean up the sport, according to a report. The panel also recommended that the federation, known as the F.E.I., pay its judges and other officials, increase security in stables at events, and make better distinctions between drugs intended to medically treat horses and those intended to enhance performance. More coverage at nytimes.com/sports.

From the Ground Up is about the progress of the writer's construction of a cabin in the Maine woods and offers advice for those thinking of building their own cabin. An excerpt: THIS last weekend, among the projects we tackled, my brother Paul and I installed more of the pine ceiling. The cabin has a vaulted ceiling, and we worked off of scaffolding. Paul had to head back to Portland, Me., on Saturday. So on Sunday I worked alone and made good progress on the pine-board walls in the ell. The freshly sawed boards show a sunny buttermilk surface with swirls of cinnamon knots here and there, marking the vestiges of the limbs of the trees whence these boards came. I like knowing that they grew not far from the cabin in this native soil.

LIPMAN--Belle Ackerman. The Northeastern University community is greatly saddened by the passing of Belle Ackerman Lipman, beloved grandmother of alumnus and university corporator M Benjamin Lipman. On behalf of the university, we extend our heartfelt condolences to Benjamin and the entire Lipman family. May the memories of her admirable and adventurous life provide comfort and inspiration always. Sy Sternberg, Chairman of the Board of Trustees Joseph E. Aoun, President

FRADRICH--James, award-winning concert pianist, composer, orchestrator and musical director, passed away August 27 at UMDNJ in Newark, NJ due to complications from liver illness while waiting for a second transplant. He resided in Union City, NJ. Jim was a child prodigy and state-level award-winning pianist who performed both as soloist and with several symphony orchestras. He gained prominence as a composer, orchestrator and musical director off-Broadway and regionally. He was archivist for the Rodgers and Hammerstein Library from 1979-1981 and was a frequent assistant to the Broadway composer, William D. Brohn. Born January 22, 1951 and raised in Menasha, Wisconsin, he graduated from Lawrence University (B.M.) in Appleton, Wisconsin in 1971. There is a void in our hearts and he is very deeply missed by many people. He will be remembered for his gentle elegance and dapper style, his sharp wit and his uncompromising love for the arts. Jim is survived by his life partner of 27 years, Kevin McMullan, and several cousins. Memorials will be held at Leber Funeral Home, 2000 Kennedy Blvd., Union City, NJ on Thursday, September 3, 6-8pm. A memorial in celebration of his music, date and time to be announced, is being planned for late October. Donations may be made to The James Fradrich Memorial Scholarship (for classical pianists and composers) at Lawrence University or to the Actors' Fund of America. Jim, thanks for the music. Kevin McMullan William D. Brohn Valerie Gebert

GERSHWIND--Mark. Dearest Mark, we are heartbroken you succumbed to that devastating illness after such a courageous fight. You will be in our hearts forever. We shall always love you. Ellen and Bob Jaffe

Some small-business owners have a new health care hero in Des Moines: Representative Leonard L. Boswell, right, a Blue Dog Democrat who represents a district in central Iowa. Des Moines members of a national group called the Main Street Alliance are celebrating Mr. Boswell's recent decision to come out in unambiguous support of a government-run ''public option'' for health insurance. The alliance is a network of small-business groups that back a health care overhaul along the lines supported by many Democrats.

Roger Federer, seeking his sixth Open title, defeated Simon Greul of Germany, 6-3, 7-5, 7-5, on Wednesday night to advance to the third round. Federer will face the 31st-seeded Lleyton Hewitt, who cruised past Juan Ignacio Chela, 6-3, 6-3, 6-4. Greul, ranked 65th in the world entering the tournament and as low as 208th a year ago, played aggressively in the second and third sets, attacking Federer's serve, but could not overcome Federer's changes of pace.

The Starter Garden is about the progress of the writer's first vegetable garden, in Minneapolis. An excerpt: WHEN I began sowing seeds in the snow-white nights of March, I had a mind to test whether kitchen gardening is a thrifty pursuit.

GERSHWIND--Mark. A Champion with style as a husband, father, grandfather and friend. During your last battle you showed us how a real champ gives up his title. Much love to Margie, Eric, Stacey, and families. Midge and Morty

GERSHWIND--Mark Everett. Poppy there is only one you. You made special time for each of us. We were so lucky to have you, but it was too short. Love, All of your Grandchildren

Forbes magazine released its annual valuations of N.F.L. teams Wednesday and they proved one thing: Even North America's most popular sport is not immune to the recession. Eight teams lost value since last year, and Forbes said it was the first time in 10 years that any team had decreased in value from the previous year. Still, times are not that tough. The average team value is $1.04 billion. That was unchanged from last year -- meaning it did not rise, as usual -- and the magazine said buyers were discouraged because of the financial climate and the difficulty in securing credit.
GERSHWIND--Dr. Mark. You are our hero, and inspiration. All our love, Carol and Mark Christina and Robert

Samantha Stosur paid the price for her difficult first-round victory against Ai Sugiyama. The 15th-seeded Stosur required 2 hours 4 minutes to beat Sugiyama in three sets Monday, and it seemed to have a lasting effect Wednesday when she was upset by Vania King, 7-5, 6-4. King, 20, had to play only three games in her first-round match because her opponent, Anastasiya Yakimova, retired with a foot injury.

Sergei V. Mikhalkov, a poet and writer who rose at the height of the Stalinist era to the apex of the Soviet literary hierarchy, eventually writing the lyrics to the Soviet and Russian national anthems, died in Moscow last Thursday at the age of 96. Denis Baglai, a spokesman for one of Mr. Mikhalkov's sons, the Russian director Nikita Mikhalkov, confirmed the death, saying that Mr. Mikhalkov had long been ill with heart problems.

When No. 14 Boise State plays No. 16 Oregon on Thursday night, it will be the biggest regular-season game in Boise State history, which means more exposure for its signature blue turf. The field was an ingenious marketing gimmick that others are starting to adopt.

The last cut is the deepest. It will come Saturday, when the Giants trim their roster from 75 players to 53, not including Michael Boley, the linebacker who will serve a suspension for the first game of the season. So that means Thursday night's preseason finale -- at New England -- will be the last game, at least for a while, for 21 players currently on the roster.

GERSHWIND--Mark. We mourn with you the passing of a wonderful man who made a meaningful difference in the world. Our thoughts are with you today and always. Bob Small and everyone at JFI.

KANDEL--Lottie, passed peacefully at home among loved ones on September 2. Beloved wife, mother, nana, and great grandma, born "early 1900s", whose best times were in Brooklyn, Rockville Centre, and Palm Beach. "Everybody's beautiful." Instead of flowers or fuss, just sip some scotch with someone and smile. A brief graveside service for immediate family is planned.

Today’s Marathon Tech Review at the Gadgetwise blog includes an interesting discussion of electronic muscle stimulators. The gadgets are commonly used in physical therapy, but new portable units have become popular with athletes trying to fend off muscle fatigue.
Spotting a marathon runner’s car in the parking lot can be easy — vanity plates aside: Sub3Hr, Brn2Run.
Everybody complains about the high cost of college. In his latest Your Money column, my colleague, Ron Lieber, decided to find out why it is so expensive.

Updated | 10:29 a.m. On the hardcover list this week is “Filthy Rich,” about a washed up ex-football player and the dangerous party girl he finds himself serving as a bodyguard. The graphic novel is billed as being full of “sex, violence and back stabbing ego maniacs with criminal intentions.” Written by Brian Azzarello and illustrated by Victor Santos, “Filthy Rich” is one of the first two books (including “Dark Entires,” written by the crime novelist Ian Rankin and illustrated by Werther Dell’Edera) in the Vertigo Crime line of comics published by Vertigo, which itself is an imprint of DC Comics.

A simmering controversy over the new City-to-City program at the Toronto International Film Festival heated up a few degrees, as Jane Fonda, Wallace Shawn, and David Byrne signed onto a letter protesting the selection of Tel Aviv as the year’s spotlight city. Indiewire has been on top of the protest, which was triggered when the Canadian filmmaker John Greyson pulled his short film “Covered” from the festival, which begins next Thursday.

What we’re reading on Friday morning.Services for Michael Jackson, DJ AM: In Friday’s New York Times, Randal C. Archibold reports on Thursday night’s burial of Michael Jackson, a tightly guarded event at the Forest Lawn cemetery in Glendale, Calif., whose attendees included Elizabeth Taylor, Lisa Marie Presley, Macaulay Culkin and Quincy Jones. The Associated Press has a report on a memorial for DJ AM that was held at the Hollywood Palladium on Thursday night, modeled after a 12-step meeting used in addiction recovery programs, that was attended by Lindsay Lohan, Robert Downey Jr. and John Mayer.

Because it is the Friday before Labor Day, and because most everybody loves photographs of cuddly baby animals, here is a picture of a dwarf mongoose pup and its mother at the Bronx Zoo. The Wildlife Conservation Society informs us that the dwarf mongoose, a social creature native to sub-Saharan Africa that lives in small groups led by a dominant male and females, is the smallest carnivore in Africa. The zoo’s recently born pups and their proud parents can be seen at the Carter Giraffe Building. (And yes, we checked, the plural of mongoose is mongooses.)

When a pseudonymous graffiti artist who calls himself Cartrain stole some pencils from a Damien Hirst installation at the Tate Britain museum, he thought he was escalating a friendly feud between himself and Mr. Hirst, the Turner Prize-winning artist. Instead, The Independent of London reported, Cartrain, 17, and his father were arrested, and Cartrain may be charged with damaging an artwork worth more than $16 million. Cartrain, who has previously appropriated images of Mr. Hirst’s famous diamond-encrusted skull, called “For the Love of God,” for his own collages, admitted that on July 4 he took the pencils from the installation, called “Pharmacy,” which closed in August. After his arrest, Cartrain said he was told by officers that the pencils alone were worth more than $800,000. In a statement, the Tate Britain confirmed to The Independent that a box of pencils had been taken from the installation and the theft was being investigated by the police.

Though “Saturday Night Live,” the long running NBC sketch show, has been quieter than the program’s Studio 8H on a Sunday afternoon about details for its coming 35th (!!) season, the Upright Citizens Brigade Theater has revealed that some graduates of its training program will be joining “SNL” as performers and staff writers.

Though the writer and director Tyler Perry is best known for working with his own material — the titles of his seven feature films to date have all started with his name — he has agreed to make his first movie adaptation: Mr. Perry will write, direct and produce a film version of “For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/When the Rainbow Is Enuf,” the Ntozake Shange play, The Hollywood Reporter said. The play is presented as a series of poems about subjects like love, sex, abortion and rape, delivered by a seven-woman ensemble. It was first performed in California in 1975, then brought to New York’s New Federal Theater and later to the Public Theater and Broadway’s Booth Theater in a version produced by Joseph Papp. A 1982 television version produced for “American Playhouse” featured Alfre Woodard, Lynn Whitfield and Patti LaBelle, as well as Trazana Beverley, a Tony Award winner from the Broadway production. No casting for Mr. Perry’s film, which Lionsgate plans for a 2010 release, has yet been announced.

Updated | 2:39 p.m. Say what you will about the Beatles, but we think this up-and-coming British pop outfit is going to hit it very, very big. Variety reported that the coming boxed set which compiles the monaural mixes of the Fab Four’s original albums, part of an octopus’s garden’s worth of new Beatles products that will be released on Wednesday, has proved so popular that EMI will produce more copies of the collection. The 13-CD, $299 box set, called “The Beatles in Mono,” was supposed to be limited to 10,000 copies, but quickly sold out at many online stores. (Unlike the coming stereo remasters of the Beatles albums, which will be sold individually, the mono versions will be available only in the box set.) A spokeswoman for EMI told Variety that retailers that sold out of their initial allotment of “The Beatles in Mono” would be sent more, but did not say how many additional copies of the boxed set would be made.An article by Allan Kozinn about the newly remastered Beatles catalog can be found here.

Updated | 6:05 p.m. Earlier Friday, we reported that “Saturday Night Live” had hired two new female cast members for its coming season. And at least one female player will not be returning to the show: Michaela Watkins, who was hired last year as a featured performer, did not have her contract renewed for the coming season. (Update: A report in Variety said that Casey Wilson, who joined “SNL” in 2008, also did not have her contract at the show renewed.)

The Minneapolis Institute of Arts has a new piece of merchandise to offer at its gift shop — not to mention an endearing anecdote that inspired it — following a young art fan’s recent visit to the museum, The Star Tribune reported. On a recent survey of the museum’s Gallery 308, Tim Piowtrowski, a guard there, noticed a little girl who was admiring a 17th-century portrait of the French aristocrat Catherine Coustard, the Marquise of Castelnau, with her son, Léonor, by the French painter Nicolas de Largillière. The young aficionado, whose age was not given, was so taken by the deep blue velvet dress worn by the Marquise in the painting that Mr. Piowtrowski had to admonish her: “Please don’t lick the art,” he said. That phrase now adorns a T-shirt on sale at the museum for $22.50. The painting was unharmed, according to The Star Tribune.

It’s been hard to flick a magazine this year without happening upon an article about street art or seeing that yet another established gallery (the Fondation Cartier, the Grand Palais) has mounted some kind of mammoth graffiti homage in a tardy bid for hipness. So mentioning one more show on street art could be forgiven for eliciting yawns. But wait: the small Ernest Pignon-Ernest exhibition, which opened Friday at the Galerie Lelong in Paris and runs through Oct. 10, is not your average street art.

A high-wattage celebrity contingent is arriving on Broadway this fall, from Jude Law in “Hamlet” to Sienna Miller in “After Miss Julie” to Hugh Jackman and Daniel Craig in “A Steady Rain.”

After the stock market crashes of September 2008, the usual summer-recess changes in the Manhattan gallery scene feel more fraught than usual. Roberta Smith’s article today samples the mood and surveys the departures, arrivals and relocations of several galleries and finds that views of the market can differ sharply. The article is only a small sampling of the scene in New York, but views of the art market vary sharply. What changes in the gallery scenes — in New York and elsewhere — have you noticed? Please let us know with a comment here.

John Burns, The Times's chief foreign correspondent, has been taking questions regularly from readers of At War. Here, he answers a question from a reader about Friday's airstrike near the northern city of Kunduz in the context of the newly revised rules of engagement issued by Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, the top commander of American forces in Afghanistan.

Derek Jeter received a scheduled day off Friday night against the Toronto Blue Jays, nearly guaranteeing that he will break Lou Gehrig's franchise mark for hits when the Yankees begin a 10-game homestand Monday.

This month marked my tenth consecutive summer spent in New York City, and if there's one thing I've learned, it's that it's easy to get depressed in August. I used to imagine that everyone I knew just disappeared and was off having a great time with their shrimp cocktails in the Hamptons or their madcap tours of Europe or South America. They were whale watching or swimming with dolphins by day and watching the stars by night from a beach that was not Coney Island, not Far Rockaway and definitely not the Red Hook municipal pool. Now, thanks to Facebook, I don't have to imagine. I know it's all really true.

Gael Monfils, he of the teased hair and of the Nadalian biceps, has many nicknames. "La Monf" makes sense only in French, since it's a meaningless diminutive. "Sliderman," meanwhile, really shouldn't make any sense in French at all since it's built from English words.

If Skype becomes the biggest thing since Facebook -- and it just might -- it will be because of people like, well, me. People who resisted it for years, thinking that the cost of phone calling had gotten so low anyway that free was unnecessary. People who might have had a bad experience with Skype years ago, before its sound was as crystal clear as it has since become. People who had kids traveling abroad -- as both my sons did this summer -- and suddenly found Skype a godsend. And now I'm hooked on it.

The rules of tennis have remained fairly consistent since the late 1800s. However, this month (after the U.S. Open), the Association of Tennis Professionals will change some rules in the doubles game, including reducing sets to five games each. According to the association, the point is to attract more singles players to doubles and to make matches faster and more exciting.

Tomas Berdych is starting to settle in at the Open. After what he admitted was a nervous first round match, the No. 17 seed from the Czech Republic overcame a spirited challenge from Horacio Zeballos of Argentina today, 6-3, 6-7 (3), 7-6 (2), 6-2.
Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City. Subjects include the last days of summer, an Iraq veteran denied custody of her daughter, and a little league baseball team.

The frustration that Agenda readers have shared over the Small Business Administration's A.R.C. loan program (see here and here and here) has finally percolated up to some of those responsible for fashioning it in the first place. On Tuesday, Senator Bill Nelson, Democrat of Florida, held a press conference in North Fort Myers, where, according to the North Fort Myers Neighbor, a weekly paper, he decried the dearth of A.R.C. loans in Florida as "appalling."
Scenes from an alfresco home movie theater on the roof of a Brooklyn apartment.
Phillip Swanson is a junior offensive lineman at Western Michigan. He will be writing for The Quad throughout the season.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is urging riders to "step aside, speed your ride." It has reminded subway riders that offering one's seat to the disabled is not only polite, but a legal requirement. Now it is trying to draw attention to an age-old subway-riding annoyance -- even if it is one many of us do, on occasion.
Detroit sports fans woke up Friday with a collective gasp: Ernie Harwell, the beloved broadcaster, has been found to have inoperable cancer.

Jane Lubchenco, the administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, led the United States delegation this week to the World Climate Conference, a meeting in Geneva aimed at providing the world with the information needed to navigate a changing climate. I spoke with Dr. Lubchenco briefly as the meeting adjourned. Here are her impressions of the most important outcomes.From Weather Services to Climate Services: She hailed the decision by the 1,500 participants, convened by the World Meteorological Organization, to establish a Global Framework for Climate Services "to strengthen production, availability, delivery and application of science-based climate prediction and services." Dr. Lubchenco has made the expansion of a National Climate Service in the United States a high priority. The goal is to help farmers, city planners and other people adjust investments and activities to account for shifting climate patterns in the way they rely on the National Weather Service for day-to-day advice.

It is a scene from which many of us would naturally recoil, or at least avert our eyes: a grievously injured young man, fallen on a rough patch of earth; his open-mouthed and unseeing stare registering - who can know what? - horror or fear or shock; being tended desperately by two companions in what are the first moments of the final hours of his life.

Following the shooting on Wednesday of Christian Poveda, a filmmaker and photojournalist who had chronicled the Mara 18 street gang in El Salvador in the documentary, "La Vida Loca," the police arrested a man suspected of being a gang member. News of Mr. Poveda's killing cast a pall over Visa pour l'Image, the most important international photojournalism festival, in Perpignan, France, where Mr. Poveda had exhibited his photographs last year. An appreciation of Mr. Poveda's work, and other details from this year's show at Perpignan, will appear on Lens next week.

Our colleagues at the Lens blog have published an interesting post on the debate over the publication of a photograph of a U.S. Marine who was mortally wounded in Afghanistan. The photograph, taken by Julie Jacobson, depicts Lance Cpl. Joshua M. Bernard, 21, of New Portland, Me., shortly after he was struck by a rocket-propelled grenade during a Taliban ambush of his squad last month in Dahaneh, Afghanistan. He lost one of his legs in the attack and died later at a Marine compound during surgery.

Oregon has suspended running back LeGarrette Blount for the rest of the season for punching a Boise State player after the Ducks' loss Thursday night. The suspension will include any possible bowl game, the university said.

Robert Gibbs, the White House press secretary, talks about health care reform, government transparency, the unemployment rate and how his exposure on television has affected his daily life.

A tiny spit of land in southeastern Maine, with little more than a few private homes, a single hotel and a small rocky beach, may not seem the most alluring of vacation spots. But as Geraldine Fabrikant, a business reporter for The New York Times, discovers, Prouts Neck is a place of near-religious pilgrimage for devotees of the painter Winslow Homer, who painted some of his most iconic works on this rugged coastal community.

Earlier today, NHC wrote their final advisory on Erika, which was downgraded to a Tropical Depression on Thursday. In the face of strong mid-level wind shear, the low-level circulation was completely removed from the mid- and upper- level circulation and convection. The remnant circulation is now south of Puerto Rico and will we monitored for any signs of redevelopment.
Mark Bittman cooks a dish that can be found in the villages south of Naples, pasta with beans and mussels.

In the struggle to figure out how to get more girls in poor countries in school, there are a zillion strategies. Building more schools. Offering free school lunches, or sacks of grain to families of girls with perfect attendance for a month. Iodine supplements so that fetal girls don't suffer iodine deficiency (which seems to retard their mental development more than it does boys'). Deworming, so that kids are stronger and healthier and miss less school.
The eighth seed on the women's singles draw was upset as Francesca Schiavone, the 26th seed, defeated Victoria Azarenka, 4-6, 6-2, 6-2 at the Grandstand Court.
If the results go its way, the United States men's national team could fashion World Cup qualifying in the Concacaf region into a four-team race by late Wednesday night.

In "New York Sleeps," a new book of black-and-white photographs, familiar sites in New York City appear ghostly and spectral, devoid of the people who give the metropolis its movement and life. The book is not a fantastic depiction of how the city would look without humans, but rather the product of a photographer's patient, unusual technique.

Holidays have long been risky times to share the roads, and statistics show that drinking and driving is a major reason. Last year during Labor Day weekend, 40 percent of all fatal crashes involved a drunken driver, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

Credit cards have gotten a lot of attention lately. My blogmate, Scott Shane, wrote a very interesting post the other day questioning whether credit cards cause business failure or are a symptom of it. Good question. Mr. Shane cites a study by an entrepreneurial research group that says that every $1,000 of credit card debt a business takes on increases the chances of failure by 2.2 percent. Seems rather obvious.

We're getting deeper into marathon training season, when the long runs are approaching their peak and our bodies are feeling the strain. I don't know about you, fellow runners, but I am always on the lookout for resources that offer guidance on preventing injuries and can help me recover faster from the aches and pains.

The House's top Republican has urged Representative Charles B. Rangel, the New York Democrat whose finances have again come under intense scrutiny, to step down as chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee until a House panel has completed its investigation of him.

BOISE, Idaho - Part of the lore of the blue field at Boise State is that it treats visiting birds worse than it treats opponents. That's saying something, because regular-season visitors have been dealt 50 consecutive defeats at Bronco Stadium.

(Editor's note: Many fantasy drafts will be held this weekend, and the Fifth Down is here to help. Translation: I'm as hopelessly behind in my draft prep as you all are. Brandon Funston of Yahoo Sports offers his top three tips.)1. Understand where the depth exists: This year seems to be a fantastic year for quarterback and tight end depth. While a Tom Brady or Tony Gonzalez is a nice luxury to have, you'll pay a name-brand price for them on draft day. You can wait on these two positions until the late middle rounds and still have a solid chance at ending up with players (QB Matt Schaub, TE Chris Cooley, for example) who have legit shots at finishing among the top half-dozen producers at their respective positions. Spend the early rounds mining the top shelves of the running back and wide receiver classes.

More than halfway through a rare trans-Arctic commercial voyage, two German heavy-lift ships carrying power-plant components from South Korea to a Siberian port were scheduled today to pass the northernmost point on their route, the Vilkitsky Strait. The ships have been encountering small icebergs and rafts of sea ice since they passed through the Bering Strait last weekend, company officials say. But they are being escorted by the Russian nuclear-powered icebreaker 50 Years Since Victory to limit risk and also have Russian pilots aboard. Excerpts from the Sept. 3 log entries of the two German vessels, the Beluga Fraternity and Beluga Foresight, are appended below. Just a brief reminder. Industrial production is now rising; so, probably, is real GDP. Given the way the official business cycle dating committee dates recessions, this probably means that the recession -- again, as officially defined -- is over.

The Writers Guild of America, West, said its members saw earnings reported to the guild drop 17.9 percent to $801.4 million in 2008, while the number of writers reporting income fell 9.7 percent to 4,163. The year was affected by a three-month writers strike that began late in 2007. According to the guild's annual report, television earnings fell 3.1 percent to $437.5 million, while feature film earnings dropped $30.7 percent to $361 million. The television drop was similar to a decline in the previous year, but feature income had risen sharply in 2007, as studios hurried film projects and stockpiled scripts in anticipation of the strike. The guild reported just $2.9 million in writers' income from radio news, informational writing and interactive work, down 17.1 percent from 2007.

With Labor Day upon us, and the chill of autumn in the mornings, it's time to put away the sand pails and sharpen our pencils to get back to work. And what better way to do that than with a cool new desk, a couple of which have caught our eye here at The Moment. Pottery Barn offers the Architect's Drafting Table, a desk that doubles as a counter or dining table when you lift or lower the top. If you're after something a little sleeker, check out Konstantin Grcic's Steel Pipe desk, designed for the Muji Manufactured by Thonet collection, a recent collaboration between the German design company Thonet and the Japanese minimalist retailer Muji that is a match made in austerity heaven. The desk can easily double as a buffet in a pinch, and it keeps your design cred spotless with its Modernist lines, an homage to Thonet's pioneering tubular steel furniture of the 1920s. Either way, you get a versatile piece of furniture and a whole new place to not keep knickknacks.

"Produced water," as it is known in the oil industry, is briny fluid trapped in the rock of oil reservoirs. It is by far the largest toxic byproduct produced by the oil industry, and in addition to salt, it is often loaded with chemicals, residual oil and heavy metals.

Fulcrum BioEnergy claims it can derive commercial-scale ethanol from municipal waste - and it just ran the first demo that proves it, the Pleasanton, Calif. company says. An article on Tuesday about China’s tightening control over the production of rare earth minerals misidentified the country in which Avalon Rare Metals, a non-Chinese producer, was trying to open a new mine. It is Canada, in the northwest area, not Australia.
As the plane was touching down in Nassau, flames were spotted near the lefthand engine. All 93 on board escaped safely.

An article on Thursday about the first major survey of contemporary art from Pakistan at an American museum, at the Asia Society in Manhattan, misstated the number of years since Pakistan’s creation. It is 62 years, not 52.

A picture caption on Thursday with the Abroad column, about the owner of a secondhand bookstore in Britain who said he had to close because of competition from the Oxfam charity, which runs 130 secondhand bookstores around the country, misidentified the site of the Oxfam bookstore in London shown in the picture. It is on Bloomsbury Street, near the British Museum, not in Cecil Court. (Cecil Court, where there are many secondhand bookstores, was shown in another picture.).

Because of an editing error, an article on Aug. 25 about the announcement that the filly Rachel Alexandra would face older male horses in the Woodward Stakes this Saturday at Saratoga misstated the size of the purse for the race before it was raised to $750,000. It was $500,000, not $250,000.

A video-game dispute that began with an uproar in 2005 ended quietly this week as the parent company of the makers of the Grand Theft Auto series said it paid $20.1 million to settle a lawsuit, including claims that a version of the best-selling game had hidden sex scenes, Bloomberg News reported. In a statement, Take-Two Interactive, whose Rockstar Games division produces the game, said that among the plaintiffs to be paid were those who said they were defrauded when they bought Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas without knowing that it contained explicit content. That game was released in 2004, and the sex scenes, which were not readily accessible in it, were later found by players using Hot Coffee, a homemade computer program. The revelation prompted an outcry from lawmakers, and major retailers said they would not stock the game until the sex scenes were removed. The class-action suit was filed in 2005 in Federal District Court in Manhattan. Take-Two said the settlement also resolved claims by investors that the company improperly backdated stock options, according to Bloomberg.

The cautionary tale of Joel Tenenbaum continues. Weeks after he was ordered to pay $675,000 to record labels for illegally downloading and sharing music, those labels are saying that Mr. Tenenbaum, 25, a graduate student at Boston University, is continuing to encourage music piracy by linking to a file-sharing service on a Web site created by his legal team, The Boston Globe reported. A Twitter feed for the site, joelfightsback.com, posted a link to the Swedish file-sharing service the Pirate Bay. That site, whose founders were convicted in April by a Swedish court of aiding in copyright violations, posted “The $675,000 Mixtape,” a playlist that linked to the songs that Mr. Tenenbaum admitted to downloading illegally and featured a photograph of him with his arms crossed. The Recording Industry Association of America has filed for an injunction that would order Mr. Tenenbaum to destroy his illegal files and stop promoting piracy. Mr. Tenenbaum said that he had nothing to do with the song list on the Pirate Bay and that he planned to appeal his verdict and fine.

Only weeks ago, it seemed that the New Zealand soprano Kiri Te Kanawa was preparing for her exit from the operatic stage: in August, she was quoted by The Daily Telegraph as saying that a production of Strauss’s “Rosenkavalier” at the Cologne Opera in April 2010 would be her last. “It’s not as if I want to do it on a regular basis now, because it’s exhausting,” she said. This was interpreted to mean that she was winding down her opera career though she would continue to perform concerts. But on Thursday, Ms. Te Kanawa, above right, told ABC News in Australia that she had no plans to retire after a set of concerts this week at the Sydney Opera House. “I haven’t got any plans to die either,” she said, according to the ABC report. “I mean, that could be on the cards too before I retire.”.

If Fredrik Colting needs any blurbs for his book “60 Years Later: Coming Through the Rye,” he probably should not seek one from Judge Guido Calabresi. Judge Calabresi was one of three judges on a panel at the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in Manhattan that heard arguments on Thursday about whether Mr. Colting, above, should be allowed to publish the book in the United States. In July, a federal district judge indefinitely enjoined publication of “60 Years Later,” which Mr. Colting wrote under the pen name J. D. California and has promoted as a sequel to the J. D. Salinger novel “The Catcher in the Rye.” On Thursday, The Associated Press reported, Judge Calabresi called Mr. Colting’s book a “rather dismal piece of work.” But two judges on the panel questioned if the federal district court had heard enough evidence before issuing its injunction. The court did not immediately rule.

If you are of a certain age and find yourself engaged in a brawl over the health care overhaul that results in the loss of one of your digits, it is a very good idea to have Medicare. While passing by a demonstration in Ventura County, Calif., northwest of Los Angeles, on Wednesday evening that was in support of the overhaul, William Rice, 65, became involved in a confrontation with the demonstrators and a fistfight ensued, ending with a demonstrator biting off half of Mr. Rice's left pinky finger, said Detective Eric Buschow of the Ventura County Sheriff's Department.

DIAZ--John A.,78, of Rancho Mirage, CA, and Westhampton Beach, NY, and formerly of Matinecock, NY, passed away on September 2, 2009. A coal-miner's son, John labored from the age of four and rose to become chairman of Morgan & Finnegan LLP (Ret. 1999) and a Fellow of the American College of Trial Lawyers. Beloved husband of Michelle, John is survived by his children Drew, Patrick, and Kathryn (of Peggy, d. 1998), and Michael and Nicole (of Michelle). He is also survived by grandchildren Patrick Conor, Sarah, Julia, John III, Clare, and Dylan. Man of science; lover of life, letters, tennis, opera, and his family. "The weight of this sad time we must obey." - Shakespeare, King Lear.

8 P.M. (TCM) PRIME TIME FEATURE: GEORGE PAL PRODUCTIONS George Pal was working on ''When Worlds Collide'' (1951) at Paramount Pictures when, in the studio's story library, he came across several unproduced scripts based on the H. G. Wells novel ''The War of the Worlds.'' But even Cecil B. DeMille hadn't been able to get the film made. In 1952 Mr. Pal hired Barré Lyndon to update Wells's Victorian tale. This three-film tribute to Mr. Pal begins with his 1953 version of ''The War of the Worlds,'' set in a California town not far from Los Angeles and featuring Martian war machines with cobralike control arms designed by Albert Nozaki and created by Gordon Jennings. (Gene Barry, above left, and Ned Glass are among the cast members.) Next, at 9:30, is ''The Time Machine'' (1960), based on another Wells novel and starring Rod Taylor as an Edwardian scientist who creates a machine that carries him to the year 802701. The tribute closes at 11:30 with ''Houdini'' (1953), starring Tony Curtis as the magician and escape artist and his new real-life bride, Janet Leigh, as his future bride. 7 A.M. (ABC) GOOD MORNING AMERICA The primatologist Jane Goodall talks about her new book, ''Hope for Animals and Their World.''

COUNTY FAIR AND MORE A scrappy patch of grass on the western shore of the Gowanus Canal -- the disturbingly tepid, heavily polluted waterway oozing through South Brooklyn -- the BKLYN Yard is an unlikely club space, though its grim industrial aesthetic surely passes for chic in certain circles. (Pull up a cinder block and gather 'round the tarp-topped stage!) On Saturday the Yard will close its season with the Brooklyn County Fair, a free daylong celebration of local music, crafts, ales and more, including Steve's Authentic Key Lime Pie (a Red Hook staple), Van Leeuwen Artisan Ice Cream, Margarita Hernandez's Famous Tacos & Huaraches, a ringtoss competition and a blight-be-darned Biggest Tomato contest.

One hundred youths from 4-H programs were sent home Thursday from the Minnesota State Fair in St. Paul after several young people in a dormitory there tested positive for swine flu, state health authorities said. The early departures began even as Minnesota's commissioners of health and education took part in a hand-washing contest at the fair's ''Germ City booth,'' one of many efforts to promote awareness about ways to avoid the flu.

Mark was an exceptional person who lived life to the fullest and was an example to all who were lucky enough to know him. His legacy will endure. Joan, Mark, Lee, Jon & Julie

TELEVISION Maybe it's because Alan Ball has cut back on the wooden solemnity (see: ''Six Feet Under'') and allowed ''True Blood'' to be what it wants to be: a dirty children's adventure story. Or maybe it's because Anna Paquin has been getting naked more often.
I joined the force to battle blazes, not to be an emergency room doctor. J. R. MUYLEART, a Washington firefighter, on the number of medical emergencies he deals with. [A1]

Broadening its definition of business news, the Fox Business Network said Thursday that it would simulcast the ''Imus in the Morning'' radio show starting on Oct. 5. As expected, Fox said it had signed a multiyear deal with Don Imus, right, the host who was fired by CBS Radio and MSNBC two years ago after making racial remarks about the Rutgers University women's basketball team. His program was revived by the radio company Citadel and the rural television network RFD-TV, but Mr. Imus ended the television deal last month. The simulcast, to be shown from 6 to 9 a.m. Eastern time, is expected to buoy the low-rated Fox Business Network, which began in October 2007. Mr. Imus doesn't make financial news a regular part of his talk show, but Fox said the program ''will incorporate additional business news into its format.'' Notably, three of the anchors partially displaced by Mr. Imus's hiring will host a three-hour morning-news program on the network's Web site, FoxBusiness.com, from 6 to 9. The anchors of the Web show, Jenna Lee, Connell McShane and Ashley Webster, will also appear regularly on ''Imus in the Morning,'' Fox said. Alexis Glick, a vice president at Fox Business who now leads the network's 7 to 10 a.m. hours, will remain the host of the 9 a.m. hour. In a statement, Mr. Imus said: ''I love Fox. Roger Ailes is the pre-eminent genius of American broadcasting. Who wouldn't want to do this?''

ELECTRONICA AND MORE New York's oft-slighted electronica fans get a festival all their own this weekend. The Electric Zoo, held on 24 acres of soon-to-be-trampled grass on Randalls Island, offers four stages with more than 50 artists. The vast range of techno, from disco to minimalism, will be represented, with megaclub mainstays like Armin van Buuren, who headlines on Saturday, and Detroit-sound makers like Richie Hawtin on Sunday. New York's indie favorites, like James Murphy & Pat Mahoney of the influential label DFA Records and Andy Butler of the group Hercules and Love Affair, will also spin, alongside scenesters like the Los Angeles D.J. Steve Aoki. (Grass killing aside, the festival is environmentally conscious: the organizers say 80 percent of its power will be fueled by biodiesel, made in Brooklyn from soybeans, and taking public transportation, including water taxis, is encouraged. After-parties will be held at Pacha in Manhattan both nights.)

IF not for the abolitionist Frederick Douglass and his son, Ray Langston would most likely not be sitting on his screened front porch here gazing out at the Chesapeake, the landmark 4.3-mile-long Bay Bridge, the classic Thomas Point Shoal Lighthouse, the anchored freighters and across the way at the Eastern Shore of Maryland.

SHAKESPEARE There remain small pockets of civilization, not so far from Manhattan, where Elizabethan English is still spoken fluently, at least in the summer months. At Shakespeare & Company, in Lenox, Mass., and the Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival, in Garrison, N.Y., the language of the canon is delivered with such confidence, clarity and accessibility that you may start to believe it is the region's mother tongue. Fast-acting theatergoers and bardolaters can still catch a choice offering from each of these repertory troupes.

DANCE The interesting surprise of ''Diaghilev's Theater of Marvels: The Ballets Russes and Its Aftermath,'' at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts, is how much of the exhibition isn't about Diaghilev or his ballets.

EVEN we have to admit: It hasn't been a very entertaining summer. There have been successful movies, but none -- whether Hollywood blockbuster or art-house upstart -- have managed to remain in the national conversation beyond their opening weekends. Nothing onstage has equaled the drama of the health care debate or the Henry Louis Gates Jr. arrest. The biggest news in music was the death of Michael Jackson; the biggest events on television -- with apologies to ''Mad Men'' -- were the funerals of Mr. Jackson and Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

SHANLEY--Paul Joseph, died peacefully at home surrounded by loved ones on September 2 after a brief illness. Beloved father of Mimi Shanley Taft, Catherine Shanley, Eliza Shanley, and Jane Shanley Brown. Father-in-law and friend to Lloyd Taft, James Carone and Bradford Brown. Grandfather of Daniel, Virginia and Bennett Taft; Lilian and Emma Carone, and Isobel, Samantha and Abigail Brown. The former publisher of Art in America and Arts Magazine was predeceased by Isobel, his wife of 52 years. A memorial service will be held at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, 85 Greenway So. Forest Hills, NY at 2pm on Sunday, September 13. In lieu of flowers contributions in Paul's name may be made to the St. Luke's Music Fund.

There was a time when a second-round match against the 77th-ranked player would offer little trouble for Tommy Haas. That time was in 2002, when he was ranked second in the world. Haas, 31, continued his recent run of living in the past by defeating Robert Kendrick, 6-4, 6-4, 7-6 (3), on the Grandstand Court.

The competition among Giants wide receivers grew more intriguing Thursday night, when Sinorice Moss and Hakeem Nicks played well enough to complicate the equation. Their performances were among the highlights before the Giants squandered a three-touchdown lead and lost to New England, 38-27, on two fourth-quarter touchdown runs by BenJarvus Green-Ellis of the Patriots.

BROADWAY Puppets cannot shed tears, so spare a few for the furry stars of the beloved musical ''Avenue Q,'' which says a final farewell to Broadway on Sept. 13. When this witty, inventive comedy featuring foulmouthed hand puppets made the leap from the Vineyard Theater to the big time in 2003, few suspected it would become one of the longest-running Broadway musicals of the new century so far, logging more than 2,500 performances. At the Tony Awards, the little show that could occasioned the biggest upset in recent memory when it snatched the big prize -- the award for best musical -- as well as the book and score awards from the grasp of the witches in the monster hit ''Wicked.''

PETERSEN--Harry E.,died on August 26 from complications of a stroke in New York City. He is survived by his wife Lois; daughters, Andrea, Erica and Christina and four grandchildren. He was a graduate of The Berkshire School and a partner of Salomon Brothers. Visitation at Nagel Funeral Home, 352 E. 87th St., NYC on September 8 from 3-6pm. Funeral Mass at St. Stephens of Hungary Church, 414 E. 82nd St., NYC on September 9th at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to The Association of Retarded Children, 223 Moore St., Hackensack, NJ 07601

SALSA Salsa fans don't have a prayer of escaping the Hilton New York this weekend. The ninth annual New York Salsa Congress has been going on since Wednesday, and it continues through Sunday evening with performances, competitions and dance workshops around the clock, all of it designed to give professionals ample networking time and curious amateurs a chance to jump-start their dance education.

DAVIS--Edward Shippen, of New York City died on August 28, at his home in The Springs, East Hampton. Born at New York Hospital January 23, 1932 of Wendell Davis and Lavinia Riker Davis, he was a graduate of Pomfret School, Harvard College, and the Harvard Law School. His professional life centered around his partnership as a corporate lawyer with Hughes Hubbard & Reed. He served for a number of years as a Director of Hillenbrand Industries and Cognitronics Corporation. Ned had a lifelong commitment to educational issues, serving as a member and later president of the Board of Trustees of Collegiate School, a life Trustee of Pomfret School, and most recently a Director of the Bronx Charter School for Children in Mott Haven. To the end of his life he was actively involved as a member of the Executive Committee of Doctors of the World-USA as it achieved its transition to the independent entity HealthRight International. Ned is survived by his wife of 29 years, Barbara Thompson Davis, and his daughter Martha Knapp Davis. He was predeceased by his son Edward Shippen Davis, Jr. He was the attentive stepfather of Tamur and Daniyal Mueenuddin, their wives Lauren Ingram and Cecilie Brenden. He also left three young grandsons. With the support of East End Hospice, his family was able to be with him to the end. The funeral service will be held at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at 90th Street on Thursday, September 10 at 4pm. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be sent to East End Hospice, Westhampton Beach, NY.

One week before the start of the season, the N.F.L. said that 20 percent of its games could be blacked out locally. Commissioner Roger Goodell, in a meeting with reporters Thursday, called the figure a worst-case situation. Some cities are worse off than others. Jacksonville may not have any of its eight regular-season games broadcast locally. Detroit, devastated by the economic downturn, also faces blackouts.

RIBACK--Hilda. The Yeshiva University family and the Yeshiva University Women's Organization is deeply grieved by the passing of Hilda Riback, wife of the late beloved Rabbi Sidney B. Riback, obm, mother of Gabrielle (and Seymour, obm) Propp and Deborah (and Moshe) Zwang, sister of Adrian (and Ruth, obm) Skydell, Irving (and Cecile) Skydell and Anita (and Chaim, obm) Chanowitz, grandmother to Amery Propp, and his brothers Douglas, Rodney and James, grandmother to Ariel (and Gordon) Mehler and Oren Zwang and great-grandmother to Grace and Rachel Mehler. Hilda Riback was a scholarly woman in Jewish and general studies, she was also a highly respected former Rebbitzen and communal leader. Hilda was honored at the YUWO Spring Luncheon in 2002 and received the ''Generation to Generation'' award and is a founding member of the Presidents Society. Gabrielle Propp served with distinction as National President of YUWO, she is presently on the Executive Council and a founding member of the Presidents Society. Gabrielle and her late husband Seymour Propp, obm, are YU Guardians. Heartfelt condolences are extended to all of the above and the entire Riback, Skydell and Propp families. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Dinah Pinczower, National Chair, YUWO Honie Berko, National President,YUWO Yosefa Knoll, National President, YUWO Harriet Muss, National President, YUWO

With the Obama administration about to begin its final push on a health care bill, it is trying in every way possible to reduce public distrust of government. Toward that end, administration officials have begun a campaign to show that the federal stimulus is an example of a program that works, hoping to reduce criticism before Congress votes on a health care overhaul. On Thursday, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. unleashed a fervent defense of the stimulus, saying that it helped avert what some had feared would be a second Depression and was not a ''grab bag'' of too many programs.

CONTE--Robert H.,D.D.S., of Bedford on September 2, 2009, at the age of 82, beloved by his wife, Dorothy, and his children, Robert, Jeanne, Douglas, Pamela and the late Arthur. Dr. Conte attended Fordham University and received his D.D.S. from the University of Pennsylvania. He served with distinction in the Navy during World War II and the Korean War. An avid golfer, Bob was a lifelong member of Winged Foot Golf Club. A Memorial mass will be held at St. Patrick's Church in Bedford on Wednesday, September 9, at 10am. In lieu of flowers, gifts to Memorial Sloan-Kettering's pediatric cancers research would be appreciated by the family.

THE Hanford Reach National Monument in the arid steppe of south-central Washington is a nature lover's dream with the Columbia River flowing wide and free below chalk-white cliffs, an abundance of birds, and populations of deer, elk and coyotes. But there's a twist: It surrounds the Hanford nuclear reservation, one of the world's largest environmental clean-up projects.

YOUNG--Dr. Elizabeth, Professor of Psychiatry, Senior Research Professor at the Molecular and Behavioral Neuroscience Institute and member of the Depression Center at the University of Michigan passed away on September 1, 2009 after a yearlong battle with leukemia. She was 59 years old. Dr. Young was an internationally renowned biological psychiatrist and neuroendocrinologist who conducted seminal work on stress biology and its role in depression and other mood disorders. She was raised in the Detroit and Chicago areas and completed her medical degree from The Ohio State University in 1976. She completed her residency in Psychiatry at the same institution in 1979. She received postdoctoral training at the University of Michigan Medical School in the Department of Psychiatry and the Molecular and Behavioral Neuroscience Institute. She was then recruited to the faculty of the Institute and the Department where she remained until her death. Dr. Young was the quintessential "translational" physician-scientist, who understood the biology of stress and used that knowledge to enhance our understanding of the causes of mood disorders. A particular focus of her research was to uncover the biological and psychosocial reasons for the increased vulnerability of women to depression and anxiety. Dr. Young was also a loving wife and stepmother, a caring physician, a wonderful collaborator and mentor, an ardent gardener and appreciator of the best that life has to offer, and a devoted friend. She is survived by her husband Dr. Peter Hinman, her stepdaughter Dr. Mira Hinman and two step-granddaughters Annika and Celia McDermott-Hinman. A ceremony to honor her memory is planned for early October. A Memorial Fund has been created to establish The Elizabeth A. Young Lectureship on Stress and Mood Disorders at the University of Michigan. Donations to the Fund can be sent to MBNI, 205 Zina Pitcher Place, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-5720. Attn: R. Freedman.

The English Premier League club Chelsea, one of the richest clubs in world soccer, was barred Thursday from signing any new players for a year because it encouraged a teenager to break his contract with a French team and sign with Chelsea. FIFA, the sport's world governing body, said that Chelsea could not take part in the next two transfer periods, January 2010 and during next summer's off-season. The next time the Chelsea team would be able to sign a new player -- nationally or internationally -- would be January 2011.

Witness the modest popularity of ''The Hurt Locker,'' Kathryn Bigelow's viscerally charged but thoughtful Iraq war movie about a United States Army bomb squad whose mission is to defuse improvised explosive devices.

A young mother living at a sought-after Midtown Manhattan address during the Great Depression would have stood out from her building's other matrons if she did anything all day except dress elegantly and attend charity functions. But throughout the 1930s, Hildreth Meière, who was divorced and had a blue-blood Mayflower pedigree, left her young daughter with a governess at the family's Park Avenue apartment each weekday and headed off to a messy rented workplace on West 57th Street. There Miss Meière (pronounced mee-air) would put on a smock, give orders to a few assistants and paint designs for murals, mosaics, stained-glass windows, tapestries and metal and terra-cotta sculptures. Specializing in sweeping landscapes and realistic portraiture on gilded backgrounds, she installed works at a hundred public and religious buildings, like Radio City Music Hall and Temple Emanu-El in Manhattan, the National Academy of Sciences in Washington and the Nebraska State Capitol.

With President Obama due to welcome the Stanley Cup champion Penguins to the White House on Thursday, an unexpected decision by the Department of Transportation has banned Air Canada charter planes from flying between United States cities -- suddenly throwing the travel plans of the N.H.L.'s Canadian teams into chaos. The decision in August, overturning eight years of practice by Air Canada's Jetz charter service, stipulates that charters originating in Canada may stop in only one United States city. It was made in response to instances in which injured players have left the charter and not returned to Canada on the same plane.

Lleyton Hewitt came very close to toppling Andy Roddick at Wimbledon this year. After leading the Washington Huskies to a Rose Bowl victory in 1978, Warren Moon quarterbacked the Canadian Football League's Edmonton Eskimos to five straight championships before going on to a 17-year career in the N.F.L. In "Never Give Up on Your Dream: My Journey," Moon collaborates with the journalist and author Don Yaeger to tell his story. Moon recalls the racism and death threats he faced early in his N.F.L. career, and discusses the lingering challenges faced by African-American quarterbacks today. Moon writes with equal candor about his professional successes and his personal mistakes. The result is a wrenching account of his journey from childhood to football immortality (in 2006, Moon became the first black quarterback inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame).

Because of an editing error, an article on Page 36 this weekend about the failure of economists to anticipate the latest recession misquotes the economist John Maynard Keynes, who compared the financial markets of the 1930s to newspaper beauty contests in which readers tried to correctly pick all six eventual winners. Mr. Keynes noted that a competitor did not have to pick “those faces which he himself finds prettiest, but those that he thinks likeliest to catch the fancy of the other competitors.” He did not say, “nor even those that he thinks likeliest to catch the fancy of other competitors.”.

An art review on Aug. 21 about “Cinnabar: The Chinese Art of Carved Lacquer,” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, misidentified the chemical compound known as cinnabar. It is mercury sulfide, not mercury oxide.

A picture caption in the Escapes pages on Friday with an article about Highland Beach, Md., a town founded by the son of the abolitionist Frederick Douglass that became an enclave for the black middle class, misstated the given name of a woman shown with her sons in front of a tent. She is Belinda Elvan Nixon, not Sabrina Nixon.

An article on Thursday about the playwright Zayd Dohrn, son of the former Weather Underground leaders Bill Ayers and Bernardine Dohrn, misstated the period in which the Weather Underground conducted a campaign of bombing public buildings. It was only in the 1970s, not the ’60s and ’70s. The article also referred incorrectly to the site of an accidental bomb explosion in Greenwich Village in 1970 that killed three members of the Weather Underground, and it misidentified two people who survived the blast and fled. The explosion occurred in a town house, not an apartment, and the survivors were Cathy Wilkerson and Kathy Boudin — not Mr. Dohrn’s parents, who were not there.

A simmering controversy over the new City-to-City program at the Toronto International Film Festival heated up a few degrees when Jane Fonda, right, Wallace Shawn and David Byrne signed a letter protesting the selection of Tel Aviv as the year’s spotlight city. The protest was set off when the Canadian filmmaker John Greyson pulled his short film “Covered” from the festival, which begins on Thursday. Mr. Greyson and others have complained that the Tel Aviv selection amounts to complicity with an Israeli “propaganda” machine and ignores the sufferings and achievements of Palestinians. Cameron Bailey, who programmed City-to-City, said in an open letter last week that the selection was an independent curatorial decision and had nothing to do with Israeli propaganda. One thing is certain: What might have been one of the festival’s less noticed film series is going to get some attention when it opens on Sept. 11 with an 8:45 a.m. screening of “A History of Israeli Cinema, Part 1,” directed by Raphael Nadjari.

When a pseudonymous graffiti artist who calls himself Cartrain stole some pencils from a Damien Hirst installation at the Tate Britain museum, he thought he was escalating a friendly feud with Mr. Hirst, the Turner Prize-winning artist. Instead, The Independent of London reported, Cartrain, 17, and his father were arrested, and Cartrain may be charged with damaging an artwork worth more than $16 million. Cartrain, who has previously appropriated images of Mr. Hirst’s famous diamond-encrusted skull, “For the Love of God,” for his own collages, admitted that on July 4 he took the pencils from the installation, called “Pharmacy,” which closed in August. After his arrest, Cartrain said he was told by officers that the pencils alone were worth more than $800,000. In a statement, the Tate Britain confirmed to The Independent that a box of pencils had been taken from the installation and that the theft was being investigated by the police.

Though the writer and director Tyler Perry is best known for working with his own material — the titles of his seven feature films to date have all started with his name — he has agreed to make his first movie adaptation: Mr. Perry, right, will write, direct and produce a film version of Ntozake Shange’s play “For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/When the Rainbow Is Enuf,” The Hollywood Reporter said. The play is presented as a series of poems about subjects like love, sex, abortion and rape, delivered by a seven-woman ensemble. It was first performed in California in 1975, then brought to the New Federal Theater in New York and later to the Public Theater and the Booth Theater on Broadway, in a version produced by Joseph Papp. A 1982 television version produced for “American Playhouse” featured Alfre Woodard, Lynn Whitfield and Patti LaBelle. No casting for Mr. Perry’s film, which Lionsgate plans for a 2010 release, has been announced.

Say what you will about the Beatles, but we think this up-and-coming British pop outfit is going to hit it very, very big. Variety reported that the coming boxed set compiling the monaural mixes of the Fab Four’s original albums, part of an octopus’s garden’s worth of new Beatles products to be released on Wednesday, had already proved so popular that EMI will produce more copies of the collection. The 13-CD, $299 set, “The Beatles in Mono,” was supposed to be limited to 10,000 copies, but quickly sold out at many online stores. (Unlike the coming stereo remasters of the Beatles albums, which will be sold individually, the mono versions will be available only in the boxed set.) A spokeswoman for EMI told Variety that retailers that sold out of their initial allotment of “The Beatles in Mono” would be sent more, but did not say how many additional copies would be made.

CONTE--Robert H.,D.D.S., of Bedford on September 2, 2009, at the age of 82, beloved by his wife, Dorothy, and his children, Robert, Jeanne, Douglas, Pamela and the late Arthur. Dr. Conte attended Fordham University and received his D.D.S. from the University of Pennsylvania. He served with distinction in the Navy during World War II and the Korean War. An avid golfer, Bob was a lifelong member of Winged Foot Golf Club. A Memorial mass will be held at St. Patrick's Church in Bedford on Wednesday, September 9, at 10am. In lieu of flowers, gifts to Memorial Sloan-Kettering's pediatric cancers research would be appreciated by the family.

JAFFE--Bernard. We mourn the passing of Bernard Jaffe, a man whose generosity of spirit afforded millions the opportunity to visit "the Rebbe's Ohel" - the resting place of the Lubavitcher Rebbe, of righteous memory. Mr. Jaffe's kindness and caring will never be forgotten. We extend our condolences and the traditional blessings of "may you be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem", to his beloved wife, Fern, and to his entire family. Rabbis Sholom Duchman, Abba Refson and the Board of Directors of Ohel Chabad Lubavitch

Detroit sports fans woke up Friday with a collective gasp: Ernie Harwell, the beloved broadcaster, has been found to have inoperable cancer. Harwell, 91, disclosed his illness in an interview with Bill McGraw, a veteran writer with The Detroit Free Press.

SEID--Florence, 97, "Flo" died peacefully on September 3rd at her home in Florida. She lived a long and very happy life as the devoted wife of 71 years to her late husband Clarence "W2KW." Mother of Jane Chaves and the late Carol Seid. Sister of Evelyn Gerstenblith. Grandmother of the late Mark Chaves. She is survived by her grandchildren Susan and Scott Zucker, and Mark's wife Kim, also by her great-grandchildren Jeri, Brian, Evan and Allison. Her family will miss this gentle, loving and kind lady of extraordinary strength, whose wisdom and keen intelligence we will never forget. Services will be privately held.

SCHUR--Sylvia Zipser, born Brooklyn, NY, June 27, 1917, long-time resident of New Rochelle, NY, died Chicago, IL, September 2, 2009. Widow of Saul Schur (d. 1988) and Kaneji Domoto (d. 2002), loving mother, doting grandmother, endlessly creative writer and developer of new products for the food industry, and mentor to many young women starting in business and journalism. Sylvia graduated Hunter College, served as a food editor at PM, Seventeen, Look, Flair, Woman's Home Companion, and Parade, founder and president of Creative Food Services, author of over a dozen cookbooks, consultant to General Foods, Duffy-Mott, Campbell's, Seagram's, and to restaurants including The Four Seasons. She was the second president of Les Dames d'Escoffier New York. She is mourned and missed by sons Stephen Schur of San Francisco, Jonathan (Annie) Schur of Paris, France, and daughter Jane (Carl) Smith of Chicago, grandchildren Aaron, Ethan, Jeremy, Lucia, Solon, Matthew, and Julia, and brother, Philip Zipser. Services at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel (Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street), Sunday, September 6, 9:30am. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The Self Help Home in Chicago, IL, or Les Dames d'Escoffier New York.

Beloved father of Mimi Shanley Taft, Catherine Shanley, Eliza Shanley, and Jane Shanley Brown. Father-in-law and friend to Lloyd Taft, James Carone and Bradford Brown. The unemployment rate surged to 9.7 percent in August, signaling that joblessness and financial anxiety were likely to endure in millions of American homes for many months. The Labor Department's latest employment report, released Friday, added weight to a growing belief that, at least technically, the economy had already escaped the grip of recession. Though 216,000 net jobs vanished in August, the losses continued to moderate from their worst numbers of the year.

LUKINS--Sheila. The NYU Steinhardt School of Culture, Education, and Human Development mourns the loss of alumna Sheila Lukins. A gifted gourmand and successful businesswoman, Ms. Lukins pleased our palates with her culinary innovations and inspired us with her entrepreneurial spirit. After two days of meetings, trade ministers said on Friday that they were ready to resume negotiations on a long-stalled free-trade agreement. But they appeared to have made little progress on bridging the differences between developing countries and the United States that had scuttled the deal. Trade ministers from 36 countries said Friday that they were committed to completing the nearly eight-year-old trade talks known as the Doha round by the end of 2010. But the tenor and substance of the comments suggested that few were willing to make the concessions needed to achieve that goal.

LINN--Louis, M.D. We at The Mount Sinai Medical Center are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend and long-time colleague, Louis Linn, MD, Clinical Professor of Psychiatry Emeritus at Mount Sinai School of Medicine. For more than a half century, Dr. Linn was a leading psychiatrist, neurologist, and psychoanalyst at Mount Sinai. A veteran of World War II, he pioneered the field of partial hospitalization for psychiatric patients and directed the Day-Night Hospital at Mount Sinai, which serves as a model program throughout the country. The Mount Sinai family extends our heart-felt condolences to Dr. Linn's loved ones. Peter W. May, Chairman, The Mount Sinai Boards of Trustees Kenneth L. Davis, MD, President and Chief Executive Officer, The Mount Sinai Medical Center Dennis S. Charney, MD, Dean of the School of Medicine and Executive Vice President for Academic Affairs, The Mount Sinai Medical Center Wayne K. Goodman, MD, the Esther and Joseph Klingenstein Professor and Chair of the Department of Psychiatry, Mount Sinai School of Medicine.

RIBACK--Hilda. The family of J. Peter and Shoshana Lunzer mourns the loss of their aunt Hilda. Her high heels, high ideals and high society grace and charm will be sorely missed. Piha Potcha D'Chochma.

COHEN--Edward Baron, 91, on September 4, 2009. Devoted son of the late Elias and Rachel (nee Baron) Cohen. Loving brother of Sherman and the late Mortimer. Beloved husband of Suzanne (nee Mendelson). Loving father of Andrew and Richard. Affectionate grandfather and uncle. Together with his brothers, Edward helped shape the skyline of Manhattan to what it is today. To paraphrase Christopher Wren, "If you want to see his monument, look around you." Funeral Service Sunday, September 6, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st St., NYC.

LINN--Louis, M.D. It is with deep sadness that we mourn the passing of Dr. Louis Linn, internationally-renowned psychiatrist and beloved husband of Miriam, father of Judy and Robert, grandfather of David, Laura, Josh and Rebecca and great-grandfather of nine. He was a superb clinician and mentored generations of doctors. He was a professor of psychiatry at Mt. Sinai Medical Center from the late 1940s until his death and saw his last patient this past Monday. He contributed greatly to his field through extensive writing on psychosomatic medicine, disaster psychiatry, child development, psychoanalysis, psychiatric diagnosis, schizophrenia and community psychiatry. He was born May 14, 1914 in Newark, NJ and was sent to college and medical school by his five older siblings. He served in the U.S. Army during World War II as a psychiatrist participating in the North African campaign, continuing through Italy and then into France, arriving in Paris soon after its liberation. His love of life and his passion for science, music and literature will be missed by everyone whose life he touched. The funeral will be Sunday, September 6th at 11:45am at the Riverside Memorial Chapel at 180 West 76th Street.

Victoria Azarenka, the eighth seed in the women's draw, was upset by 26th-seeded Francesca Schiavone, 4-6, 6-2, 6-2, at the Grandstand Court. Schiavone, from Italy, came out of an injury timeout for treatment to her right thigh and went up, 3-0, in the third set. That prompted Azarenka to smash her racket. Azarenka had a chance to break at 4-2 and 15-40, but Schiavone managed to hold serve. Schiavone received a massage from a trainer during the next changeover.

Minutes after a disheartening loss to Boise State in the highly anticipated kickoff to the college football season on Thursday night, Oregon running back LeGarrette Blount threw a punch that sent an opponent to his knees and placed an exclamation point on what has been a tawdry past few weeks for big-time college athletics. Blount, who was suspended Friday for the rest of the season, apologized. ''I just kind of lost my head,'' he said after the game. ''A couple of players started pushing, and that's when I lost my head. I lost my temper. I apologize.''

8 P.M. (HBO) THE SECRET LIFE OF BEES (2008) A teenager with a violent past (Dakota Fanning, right, with Tristan Wilds) runs away with her abusive father's employee (Jennifer Hudson) to an Upcountry town in 1964 South Carolina, where she tries to unlock the secret of her mother's past. Queen Latifah, Alicia Keys and Sophie Okonedo play the beekeeping sisters who take them in. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said that the film, adapted by Gina Prince-Bythewood from the novel by Sue Monk Kidd, ''insists so strenuously on its themes of redemption, tolerance, love and healing that it winds up defeating itself and robbing Ms. Kidd's already maudlin tale of its melodramatic heat.'' He added, ''You can almost feel how badly it wants to be about the lives, not of bees, but of black women at a pivotal moment in the recent past.'' 10:30 A.M.
